You expend one of your Secret dice and choose a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier within 30 ft. of you. These creatures gain temporary hit points equal to the number rolled and gain resistance to a type of damage until the end of the next minute. The damage type can be psychic, force, or necrotic.

Secrets Unleashed.name: Secrets Unleashed
Secrets Unleashed.description:
With a mere whisper, you awaken the deepest terrors within a soul.

When you hit a creature with an attack, you can expend one of your Secret dice to force the target to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you can use your bonus action to whisper one word. The creature is considered frightened of that word. For example, you can say sword, hat, wall, ground, even your own name. The creature is frightened by a number of rounds equal to the result of your expended Secret dice. If the creature succeeds the saving throw, you deal psychic damage equal to half the total rolled.

Secrets’ Power.name: Secrets’ Power
Secrets’ Power.description: With a chilling murmur, you unveil a sliver of the dread secret you harbor. When you make an attack and don’t have advantage on it, you can expend one of your dice to give yourself a bonus on the attack roll equal to the roll of your Secret die. If you don’t qualify for Sneak Attack, you can use Sneak Attack nonetheless.

The Eldritch Retribution.name: The Eldritch Retribution
The Eldritch Retribution.description:
Bound within your very essence, the concealed truth not only fortifies your thoughts but manifests as a dark arcane force against foes.

By the time you reach 9th level, you have learned to cast these spells without expending a spell slot or a material component. You can cast each of them once a day: bane, detect thoughts, and fear.

In addition, you gain resistance to psychic damage, and your mind can’t be read by magical means.

Bound Fate.name: Bound Fate
Bound Fate.description:
Bound to the timeless weavers, your soul resonates with the very threads of fate and the inexorable march of time, making you a living conduit of the universe's most enigmatic designs.

Starting at 1st level, you can twist the threads of fate around you, and you can do that a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Bound Fate

As a bonus action, you bind your fate with a willing creature within 30 ft. of you for 1 minute. During that minute, you can magically swap places or share damage. To swap places you must use your action, and the creature must be able to hear you. After you swap places, the bond between you and the creature ends.

If either of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to split the damage in half (rounded up) and divide them amongst two of you, if the creature is willing. When you do so, the one that originally did not take the damage reduces the damage by half and your bond ends.

At 6th level, your range for this feature becomes 40 ft. At 11th level, it becomes 60 ft.

Bound Time.name: Bound Time
Bound Time.description:
Bound to the timeless weavers, your soul resonates with the very threads of fate and the inexorable march of time, making you a living conduit of the universe's most enigmatic designs.

Starting at 1st level, you can twist the threads of fate around you, and you can do that a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Bound Time

As an action you can rewind time for a brief moment whenever you or an ally that you can see within 30 ft. of you is endangered. If you or a creature you can see fails an ability check or takes a hit, you can use your reaction to reroll the dice. If the target is hostile to you, it can avoid the reroll by succeeding on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC.

At 6th level, you can also rewind saving throws.

Foretold Life.name: Foretold Life
Foretold Life.description:
Bound to the very sinews of time, your communion with fate elevates you to an omnipotent apex, where you deftly pull and twist the strings of destiny, reshaping the world's narrative in your dark design.

A 14th level, you learn the foresight spell and it doesn’t count against the warlock spells you know or Mystic Arcanum that is available to you. Until you reach 17th level, it works differently for you. You can cast it using an action, without expending a spell slot and its duration is 1 minute. When you reach 17th level, if you choose the foresight spell for your Mystic Arcanum, you can use this feature to cast it without expending a use of Mystic Arcanum, but the spell’s duration is 1 hour for you.

Threads Intertwined.name: Threads Intertwined
Threads Intertwined.description:
The cryptic tapestries of destiny unfurl before your gaze, as your grasp over the intricate weaves of fate tightens, plunging you deeper into the world's shadowed secrets.

When you reach 6th level, you can magically control another humanoid’s fate within 15 ft. of you. As an action, you can force the humanoid to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, you decide on its fate:

  • Bound. It is stunned until the end of your next turn.

  • Speechless. It can’t talk for 1 minute. It can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns to end the effect.

  • Ill-Fated. It has disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the end of your next turn.

You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest or you can expend a spell slot to refresh it. If you expend a spell slot in this way, it can’t be restored until you finish a long rest.

Threads Past and Future.name: Threads Past and Future
Threads Past and Future.description:
With the arcane rites whispered in forbidden tongues, you summon the audacity to beckon fate to your circle, demanding answers from the very cosmos that dares to weave destinies in its silent loom.

At 10th level, you can spend 10 minutes and 150 gd worth of special herbs that are collected under the blood moon to make a sacred ritual known to the weavers. You name a specific event, person, war, or place that existed in the past and ask up to five questions about it. Your patron or another entity related to that name answers the questions with one sentence. The answer’s accuracy depends on the nature of the creature.

Essence of the Long Road.name: Essence of the Long Road
Essence of the Long Road.description:
Tempered by endless horizons and the silent wisdom of the road, the journey bestows upon you an enlightened mind.

Starting at 3rd level, you gain these benefits:

  • You gain proficiency in the Survival skill and Navigator’s Tools.

  • You can’t be lost except by magical means.

  • While traveling, you have advantage on saving throws that force you to take exhaustion.

  • By spending 1 Ki Point, you can cast the misty step spell.

  • You can spend 3 Ki Points and 10 minutes meditating to decrease your exhaustion level by 1.

Hard Roads Stridden.name: Hard Roads Stridden
Hard Roads Stridden.description:
The roads, once mere pathways, now bend to your profound mastery. Such is the depth of your expertise that you can now invoke the arcane arts to bridge vast distances with but a thought.

You can spend 3 Ki Points and 1 minute meditating to decrease your exhaustion level by 1.

Share the Bread.name: Share the Bread
Share the Bread.description:
The shared hardships and camaraderie of the road have etched deeper lessons into your soul. Your presence alone steels the composure of your allies.

By the time you reach 6th level, you learned to share the roads and its perils with your companions. Whenever you spend a Ki Point near an ally that is within 5 ft. of you, you choose one of the benefits below:

  • Both of you gain +2 bonus to your Armor Classes for a number of turns equal to your Martial Arts die while you are within 30 ft. of each other. If another Ki Point is spent while this bonus is active, this AC bonus does not stack.

  • You and your ally gain temporary hit points equal to your Martial Arts die + your Wisdom modifier.

  • If you cast the misty step spell until the end of your next turn, you can include a willing ally that is within 5 feet of you. When you cast the spell, the target appears within 5 ft. of you in an unoccupied space. If no such place is available for the character, it fails to come with you.

  • You and your ally gain resistance to one type of damage for a number of turns equal to your Martial Arts die while you are within 15 ft. of each other. The damage type can be: bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing.

Circle of the Sun.name: Circle of the Sun
Circle of the Sun.description:
From dawn's first light, mankind revered the sun's boundless blaze; it was their deity, compass, and ensign. Those who truly understood would dare to meet its gaze, finding solace in its brilliance. Recognizing its hand in the flourishing of both tender sprouts and towering titans, they hungered for such might, forging sacred circles.

Within these radiant conclaves, a chosen few began to commune more deeply, their souls intertwining with the very essence of the sun. They became the keepers of its secrets, the whisperers of its ancient tales, and the bearers of its untamed energy, sometimes leading whole civilizations with banners beholding the sun’s golden visage, sometimes with whispers within temple complexes and catacombs. The land responded to their call, the beasts heeded their song, and from their hands, golden, blazing magic flowed. It was whispered among the shadows and sung atop the mountains that these chosen were not mere druids but the very embodiment of the sun's benevolence: The Circle of the Sun Druids, guardians of nature's most hallowed luminescence.

Oath of Crusade.name: Oath of Crusade
Oath of Crusade.description:
They are more than just holy warriors; they are the harbingers of resurgence. Their armor, marred with the scars of countless battles, is adorned with emblems of a holy war. With blades that seem to shimmer with the promise of dawn and shields etched with tales of divine retribution, they stand as a beacon in the darkest of wars.

In the midst of clashing steel and fading faith, their presence is a chilling reminder: even in the throes of death, the Crusader fights on.

Path of the Otherworldly Might.name: Path of the Otherworldly Might
Path of the Otherworldly Might.description: Exposure to torn reality can change people, almost always in dreadful ways, but there are warriors who use these changes to pull strength from the void, the Al-Ghaib. Path of the Otherworldly Might is a warrior’s discipline passed down through lines of warriors who were marked by an arcane disaster, or a scarring spell rebound. This discipline allows the wielders to be aware of the reality rifts around them and use these rifts to draw upon martial aspects to enhance their combat abilities.

Otherworldly Aspect Improvement.title: Otherworldly Aspect Improvement
Otherworldly Aspect Improvement.hint:
Your body is a gateway through which the essence of arcane flows into this world. Being present in both ends of the bridge you see through the veil and sense the otherworld better than most.
                                
                                Starting at 6th level, you have advantage on Intelligence checks to remember lore about arcane aspects, other worlds, and such matters.
                                                
                                In addition, you can choose one of the aspects below. You can take your early choice again or choose another, as your understanding and mastery over the aspects have improved.

Otherworldly Communication.title: Otherworldly Communication
Otherworldly Communication.hint: Starting at 10th level, you start to hear and understand beyond the veil, as if you have ears there. You learn the contact other plane spell. You can only cast it as a ritual and you roll a Constitution saving throw instead of Intelligence saving throw as stated in the spell. You choose one of your aspects directly, and an appropriate creature answers you.

Ultimate Aspect.title: Ultimate Aspect
Ultimate Aspect.hint: you can cast the detect evil and good spell without needing any material and as an innate spell once a day.

sQYVtJc4uKFOtseF.title: Ultimate Aspect
sQYVtJc4uKFOtseF.hint: Starting at 14th level, the veil has shrouded you and you reach your ultimate understanding. You choose one of the aspects below and reach the epitome of your understanding of aspects. In addition, you can cast the detect evil and good spell without needing any material and as an innate spell once a day.

Soul of Maat.name: Soul of Maat
Soul of Maat.description:
These sorcerers are not mere conjurers of spells: they are living vessels of Maat, guardians of equilibrium in a chaotic universe. Their presence oscillates between shadow and light, their very souls a testament to the age-old dance of truth and balance. Every incantation they invoke is touched by the divine essence of harmony, and their gaze, penetrating and wise, reflects the eternal quest for order.

Clad in robes woven from threads of destiny and bearing staffs carved from ancient trees, these sorcerers carry a subtle yet powerful symbol – the ostrich feather, the emblem of Maat. It serves as a reminder of the universe's enduring search for balance: just as the hearts of the departed are weighed against this feather in age-old rites, so too do these sorcerers weigh their every action against the eternal scales of truth. In a world teetering on the precipice of imbalance, the Sorcerers of the Soul of Maat stand as unwavering sentinels of cosmic harmony.

The College of the Doomsayer.name: The College of the Doomsayer
The College of the Doomsayer.description: Doomsayers are an infamous cadre of bards that despoils the hearts of their enemies within and beyond combat. Just as their proficiency with foretelling cataclysmic events through prophetic verses is legendary, so too are the instruments of their choice: brutalistic grand horns, quarterstaffs with brutish religious iconography, and overbearing prayer beads with gothic trinkets.

The Flagellant Domain.name: The Flagellant Domain
The Flagellant Domain.description: A sharp sound slices through the ungodly stagnation of the night. A follower, a believer, strikes herself repeatedly while quoting the Holy Scripture. Her blood is spilt all over the place. Her face is reminded of the ultimate serenity, and pain only flashes in the moments of the strike. Her faith prevails, and her sins are taken away with each stroke. She knows that her back is full of scars and with the memories of pain. She knows, however, that her Lord suffered more, and she finds power and might with each strike.

Channel Divinity: Redemption from the Lo.title: Channel Divinity: Redemption from the Lord

The Sentry.name: The Sentry
The Sentry.description: A Sentry, unlike the common ranger, is drawn to the heartbeats of settlements. Whether guarding the city's denizens from lurking dangers or lured by its manifold secrets, they tread the cobbled pathways more than the untamed trails, bound by a sense of higher purpose or captivated by the urban tapestry's intricate dance

The Veil Warden.name: The Veil Warden
The Veil Warden.description: In the oppressive shadows of the city's underbelly, silence is the currency of the powerful. Those who harbor the world's darkest truths wield a power far beyond mere knowledge, bearing burdens that could shatter weaker souls. Behind grimy facades and in the echoing chambers of forgotten crypts, initiates of time-forgotten orders, whispered cults, and clandestine sorcerers either stand as the last bulwark against these eldritch truths or scheme to thrust their malevolence upon the unsuspecting world

The Weaver Patron.name: The Weaver Patron
The Weaver Patron.description:
Her hands moved with purpose, weaving a silent spell that bound a king's speech. Her smile, a subtle blend of triumph and secret delight, seemed to twist fate itself. Around her, the threads of destiny responded, bending gracefully to her silent command, making her the unseen weaver of a kingdom's fate in the heart of shadow.

Under the same dark stars, an elderly elf saw the threads of the future in mirrors, gently separating each one, delving into the mysteries of time behind the misty mirrors of fate. His raven black hair fell over his black robe covered in magical runes, perfectly complementing the hands that wove fate in the darkness.

In the heart of the void between cosmic horror and stars, the masters of predestination work the stretched strings. Legends like the Fates sisters, Norns, Shai, and Kala swirl around in this space. Some follow these legends, while others encounter a weaver in their search for power and answers. Through their pact, they aim to take the threads of their fate into their own hands. The real question, however, is whether they are merely serving a fate already written, or can they truly rebel against a fate written with their own free will?

results.1-1: In Jerusalem lies your chance to settle a crippling trade debt. Protecting the caravan and succeeding in the city's cutthroat markets is your only hope to avoid financial ruin and a life of servitude.
results.2-2: You are sent as envoys to negotiate with King Baldwin IV, but the real task is to repay a massive debt to the crown, incurred by your homeland. If you fail, your local government faces severe diplomatic and economic repercussions…
results.3-3: You are an ambitious merchant seeking to establish new trade routes in Jerusalem. Your goal is to secure lucrative contracts with local suppliers, navigate complex market dynamics, and outmaneuver rival traders to build a profitable trade empire.
results.4-4: As a skilled architect, you travel to Jerusalem to study its famed architectural marvels. Your objective is to gain inspiration and knowledge to apply to a significant construction project back home, requiring you to engage with local architects, scholars, and builders to exchange ideas and techniques.
results.5-5: You are a savvy banker tasked with establishing a branch in Jerusalem. This requires negotiating with local authorities for permits, understanding the economic landscape, and building a network of clients. Your success could bridge financial gaps between diverse communities and create new opportunities for trade and investment.
results.6-6: You are a collector and trader of rare manuscripts, and Jerusalem's libraries and monasteries hold the promise of undiscovered literary treasures.
results.7-7: It is rumored that there are many good blacksmiths forging incredibly good quality metal armor and weapons. You may need it for your own business and your recent unsuccessful attempts at rebuilding your business endeavors puts you in a dire position.
results.8-8: You recently failed at a job and you hear that the city needs many hands from many occupations that could be put to good use. Especially for a person like yourself: an adventurer.

results.1-1: You must journey to Jerusalem on a sacred pilgrimage, not just for devotion, but to settle a debt owed to a powerful religious order. Failing to fulfill this holy mission could bring divine wrath upon you and your loved ones.
results.2-2: Your quest for ancient knowledge leads you to Jerusalem, driven not just by curiosity, but to repay a debt of honor to a legendary scholar. Failure to uncover the sought-after secrets could tarnish your mentor's legacy forever.
results.3-3: Seeking a healer in Jerusalem serves as your cover to spy on a secretive medicinal guild for a rival faction. As you search for the cure, you must also discreetly gather information on the guild's practices and alliances.
results.4-4: A dear mentor who once dreamt of a pilgrimage to Jerusalem has passed away in Baghdad. Honoring their last wish, you are here to complete their journey, facing both emotional and physical trials along the sacred path.
results.5-5: You flee to Jerusalem not for sanctuary, but to seek retribution against someone who betrayed you in the past. As you navigate the city's labyrinthine streets, you know this vendetta will end in death – yours or theirs.
results.6-6: A dear friend, now passed, always dreamed of visiting Jerusalem but could never make the journey. Carrying their diary filled with notes and sketches of the city, you embark on this journey to fulfill their dream, experiencing the city through their eyes.
results.7-7: A loved one of yours or someone dear to you in a way you choose, came to Jerusalem some time ago, possibly to join the Holy War. You are in search of them.
results.8-8: You have a calling in your heart. It lies in Jerusalem and you know it’s a holy duty. You must join this holy war as a Crusader or as a Saracen.

results.1-1: A mysterious seer has prophesied that your destiny lies within the ancient walls of Jerusalem.
results.2-2: In your family's old heirlooms, you discover a cryptic scroll hinting at a long-lost family treasure hidden somewhere in Jerusalem.
results.3-3: You're a renowned artist who experienced a vivid dream of a unique, undiscovered artifact in Jerusalem. Believing it to be the inspiration for your masterpiece, you travel to the city, intent on finding this artifact and unveiling its hidden beauty through your art.
results.4-4: Once a noble of Jerusalem, you were unjustly exiled. Hearing rumors of political shifts, you return, determined to reclaim your honor and position.
results.5-5: As a musician, you're haunted by a fragment of a melody you once overheard, said to originate from an ancient instrument in Jerusalem. Believing that completing this melody is key to your greatest composition, you embark on a quest to uncover the musical secret.
results.6-6: An ancient astrological event predicted only once in a millennium is set to occur, visible perfectly from Jerusalem. As an astronomer, you cannot miss this celestial event, believing it holds the key to understanding the cosmos.

results.1-1: Saracen envoy victory. All of the Crusaders are killed, with minimal loss for the Saracens ([[1d4]]).
results.2-2: Saracen envoy victory. Most of the Crusaders are killed ([[2d6+2]]), and the rest retreat to the city. Moderate loss for the Saracens ([[2d4]]).
results.3-3: Saracen envoy victory. Crusaders retreat with moderate loss ([[2d4]]), with moderate loss for the Saracens ([[2d4]]).
results.4-4: A tie, with the Crusader group at fault – with minimal losses for both sides ([[1d4]]). The scouts and guards of the caravanserai banish the Crusaders.
results.5-5: A tie, with the Saracen envoy at fault –with minimal losses for both sides ([[1d4]]). The scouts and guards of the caravanserai banish the Saracens.
results.6-6: Crusader group victory. Saracens retreat with moderate loss ([[2d4]]), with moderate loss for the Crusaders ([[2d4]]).
results.7-7: Crusader group victory. Most of the Saracens are killed ([[2d6+2]]), and the rest retreat to the north.
results.8-8: Crusader group victory. All of the Saracens are killed, with minimal loss for the Crusaders ([[1d4]]).

results.1-1: Whispering Walls: At night, the city walls echo with whispers in a long forgotten tongue, Old Persian, ancient dialects of Aramaic languages or even some that can’t be comprehended. Anyone listening closely might catch their own name being called with a soft manner.
results.2-2: Ghostly Processions: Some swear that spectral figures in ancient garb appear at the darkest hours of the night, walking solemnly towards the Temple Mount before vanishing and wail in front of the walls. However the tears fall in silence, without screams and loud cries, weeping in serenity against the breeze of night.
results.3-3: Unearthly Fog: Sometimes the streets are covered in thick, eerie fog that rolls in, enveloping the city. Within the fog, the faint sounds of ancient harp and distant cryings can be heard.
results.4-4: Reversed Shadows: During the day, people’s shadows point towards the sun instead of away from it, causing alarm and confusion among the populace.
results.5-5: Crying Statues: Statues around the city are occasionally found weeping tears of blood, with no explanation as to how or why this occurs. Sometimes it’s seen as actual tears. Most people believe it to be a miracle.
results.6-6: Weird Echoes: Sometimes words that were uttered hours or days ago can resurface from the exact same place. People are having a hard time explaining this weirdness.
results.7-7: Blinding People: Some people lose their ability to see at random times and regain it after a few minutes or few hours.
results.8-8: Mirage of the Past: Especially at dawn, people tend to bump into some weird people, with clothes that look ancient at times, wildly looking for something but once out of sight, never to be seen again. Some swear that they saw a Roman legionary or a Greek warrior from distant lands.
results.9-9: Benevolent Shadows: People claim that their shadows sometimes act independent. More and more people claim their shadows do what seems impossible.
results.10-10: Mysterious Inscriptions: New, hard to decipher inscriptions appear overnight on the city’s oldest buildings, especially at churches. Scholars and mystics are baffled by their meaning and origin. Some recognize ancient tongues and the writings are usually similar: “Beware the mother!” and ‘’Romanes Eunt Domus’’. One of these seem grammatically wrong though.
results.11-11: Chanting Winds: The winds winding through the city streets carry faint, discordant chants that unsettle the minds of listeners. Those who listen too long find their dreams haunted by cryptic visions.
results.12-12: Subtle Shifts in Light: At random intervals, the natural light in Jerusalem subtly shifts, casting unnaturally long or distorted shadows even when the sun is high. This subtle anomaly causes unease among the citizens, as the normal suddenly seems unfamiliar and foreboding.
results.13-13: The Watchful Eyes: Citizens report seeing eyes staring at them from within the stone blocks of buildings and the city walls, especially during the twilight hours. These eyes sometimes blink before disappearing.
results.14-14: Wild Life Weirdness: Animals around the city sometimes act as if they know something and are almost human-like: listening to conversations, producing sounds appropriate for a situation (a cat meowing as if it says uh-huh), defecating in public bathrooms (in correct places) and more.
results.15-15: Unexpected Visitors: Some doors are loudly banged at nights crying for help, like their life is in immediate danger. However, when the door opens, there is no one there.
results.16-16: The Marks on the Body: People that have dreams about having a relationship with a demon or djinni wake up with “qinah” (henna) on their bodies.
results.17-17: The Crying Child: Residents often hear the cries of a child late at night coming from the abandoned quarter. Those who go looking for the source find only a small, ancient doll lying on the ground, wet with fresh tears.
results.18-18: Where Did I Sleep?: People claim that they wake up in very many different places that they slept but no one saw them sleep walking in the city.
results.19-19: Last Breath: Some people found dead with a mirror in their hands. All that they have in common is their trace of last breath on the mirror’s glass.
results.20-20: Eerie Words: Sometimes children speak so adult-like and so deep adults are shocked and this event usually creeps the people out.

results.1-1: The ones that perform an ablution can’t restore hit points for 1 hour.
results.2-2: The ones that perform an ablution suffer a 1d4 penalty in their ability checks for 10 minutes.
results.3-3: The ones that perform an ablution gain the effects of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.n4JDcFKe5ikzYmAc]{gentle repose} spell if they die.
results.4-4: The ones that perform an ablution gain resistance to the next 5 damage they took until the next day.
results.5-5: The ones that perform an ablution gain 2d4 temporary hit points.
results.6-6: The ones that perform an ablution gain the effects of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.Opwh2PdX4runSBlm]{aid} spell.

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

Our adventure, The Sigil of Jerusalem, starts on the outskirts of the Holy City of Jerusalem, in a caravanserai called “Ana Eli,” which translates to “Mother’s Hand” and is a welcoming place to stay for adventurers. It is in the northern part of Jerusalem, on the great road that leads to Syria.

Potential players need to consider this for their characters, as the main story will be initiated within the walls of the city: Each character needs a strong reason to go into Jerusalem.

Leveling Up and Character Progress

The adventure is intended to start at Level 1 and to conclude at Level 8. The leveling up is handled with milestones stated in information boxes at the end of certain sections:

Level 2 | Either after Optional Quests in Mother’s Hand or just before Jerusalem: Silver Towers section in Act I: Rebehold the Stars

Level 3 | At the end of Omar Mosque Dungeon in Act I: Rebehold the Stars

Level 4 | At the end of Legacy of the Basileus Dungeon in Act II: We Become What We Behold

Level 5 | At the end of Kerak Castle: A Wolfsbane section in Act II: We Become What We Behold

Level 6 | After completing the Five Keys of Cairo quest in Act II: We Become What We Behold

Level 7 | At the end of Act II: We Become What We Behold

Level 8 | At the end of the Library Pageless Dungeon in Act III: Little Death by the Paradise

Character Ideas

This section offers basic ideas and guides to your character to help you fit them in the world of the Crusades. For a more detailed character builder, see the Character Builder section in Era of the Crusades.

Choose your race

As in the core rulebooks, you should decide which race you’d like to play first. It has an impact on some of the decisions you have to make ahead.

Human

If you choose to play as a human, you don’t need extra effort to adapt your appearance, as you have nothing to hide. However, if you have some arcane features regarding your body due to your class, background that is magical or arcane in nature, you must take some precautions to hide them as it may arouse many questions.

Non-Human

If you choose to play as a non-human race, think about the sections on how to keep your arcane features a secret from the superstitious, hateful, and ignorant eyes of the locals. See Running a Story in the Crusades in the Era of the Crusades to see how you might hide amongst the humans. Naturally, some races will need to go to greater lengths than others to hide their true nature.

Where did you come from?

Take some time to consider this question. Jerusalem is a place where people from different civilizations all across the world meet. Though it doesn’t have to define you, the place you come from is still important in understanding how you fit into this rich tapestry and decide your place in the world through roleplaying and character development.

1) I am from Kingdom of Jerusalem

You can be a local of the Kingdom of Jerusalem or be born in the city itself. You can be a knight, squire, farmer, trader, priest, acolyte, sage or a person with a whole other profession or interest. You are on your journey to return to the city. It is where you live after all – it can be the reason for the beginning of the adventure. You know the customs, laws, culture, habits, and other aspects about the city. You probably know who’s in charge, which lord does what, and which knightly order helps out the poor and similar core information regarding the city. The GM may feed you needed information in the right places without an ability check.

2) I am from Europe

You are from Europe, including but not limited to the urban centers of Berlin, Vienna, Toledo, Paris, Warsaw, Belgrade, Copenhagen, Brussels, Stockholm, London, Venice, Rome, and Florence. You came here for a cause. It can be for pilgrimage, joining the crusade or a whole other reason. You still share a bond with the locals and nobles in Jerusalem. There is a good chance you have the same faith and speak the same languages or at least you are familiar with the languages spoken in the Holy Lands and probably know the general customs and traditions of the kingdom.

3) I am from Ayyubid Dynasty

You can be from Cairo, Alexandria, Damascus, Aleppo or a similar city or countryside controlled by the Ayyubid Dynasty, thus from the areas called Egypt or Syria. You can be a local Muslim or an Eastern Christian, or even one of the descendents of the Ptolemaic Dynasty or local Egyptians of old. You are familiar with the area, as Jerusalem is surrounded by the Ayyubid forces and Saladin’s army is closing in. You are aware of the general customs, laws, and people in the city and know some important figures by name.

4) I am from other Muslim countries

You can be from Isfahan, Baghdad, Tashkent, Ghazne, Anatolia or other Muslim-controlled places. You may have originated from the remnants of the Great Seljuk Empire as they face their last years or come from Anatolia, the very heart of the Sultanate of Rum, another country controlled by the Seljuk Dynasty. You are familiar with Muslim laws and customs but probably don’t know the specifics about the Holy Lands and especially about Jerusalem. You may bring special trade goods, interesting items, weapons, and other things after consulting with your GM.

5) I am from Byzantine Empire or other Christian realms

You are from Constantinaple, Macedonia, Silistre, Thessaloniki, Kiev, Moscow, Thracia or a similar Christian-ruled realm. You can be considered as an ally of the Crusaders depending on your worldviews or you could be an Eastern Orthodox believer who has an enmity towards the Roman Catholics. You probably know Greek, Russian, Armenian or other proper language and do not share the tongue with the locals. You can bring special items from your realms with the discretion of the GM. You can be greeted as a friend or an interesting traveler, but the locals most likely heard about your realm and will be interested in what you brought. In general, you are a stranger to these lands and you do not know local laws, customs, and traditions and only heard them in legends.

6) I am from distant lands

You can be from Nanjing, Xi’an, Lhasa, Delhi, Ferghana, Ordu Baliq, Otugen, Mali, Kyoto, or Kilwa. You are most likely considered a stranger among these lands, and you probably only know of myths, legends and childhood tales of the holy cities of the Levant. Though people from all over the world are commonplace in the markets and caravanserai of the region, people are more likely to be curious of you and want to raise a glass of ale with you and hear your story. Alternatively, some may be suspicious of you and act hostile towards you.

If the GM allows it, you may bring interesting weapons, items, armor, tools or exotic goods with you.

Jerusalem Hooks

This section offers ideas about your characters’ motive for entering Jerusalem. There can be just one motive or many at once depending on the character’s backstory. Work with your GM to establish the details.

Business Reason

You are trying to reach Jerusalem in a matter related to your occupation, profession or interest.

@UUID[Macro.3AfBkFOmTDk0jczP]{Roll Business Reasons Table}

D8

Business Reasons

1

In Jerusalem lies your chance to settle a crippling trade debt. Protecting the caravan and succeeding in the city's cutthroat markets is your only hope to avoid financial ruin and a life of servitude.

2

You are sent as envoys to negotiate with King Baldwin IV, but the real task is to repay a massive debt to the crown, incurred by your homeland. If you fail, your local government faces severe diplomatic and economic repercussions…

3

You are an ambitious merchant seeking to establish new trade routes in Jerusalem. Your goal is to secure lucrative contracts with local suppliers, navigate complex market dynamics, and outmaneuver rival traders to build a profitable trade empire.

4

As a skilled architect, you travel to Jerusalem to study its famed architectural marvels. Your objective is to gain inspiration and knowledge to apply to a significant construction project back home, requiring you to engage with local architects, scholars, and builders to exchange ideas and techniques.

5

You are a savvy banker tasked with establishing a branch in Jerusalem. This requires negotiating with local authorities for permits, understanding the economic landscape, and building a network of clients. Your success could bridge financial gaps between diverse communities and create new opportunities for trade and investment.

6

You are a collector and trader of rare manuscripts, and Jerusalem's libraries and monasteries hold the promise of undiscovered literary treasures.

7

It is rumored that there are many good blacksmiths forging incredibly good quality metal armor and weapons. You may need it for your own business and your recent unsuccessful attempts at rebuilding your business endeavors puts you in a dire position.

8

You recently failed at a job and you hear that the city needs many hands from many occupations that could be put to good use. Especially for a person like yourself: an adventurer.

Personal Reasons

Your reason to reach Jerusalem is based on personal reasons. It holds a significance for you on a personal level.

@UUID[Macro.iNvebms86qlmNcL4]{Roll Personal Reasons Table}

D8

Personal Reasons

1

You must journey to Jerusalem on a sacred pilgrimage, not just for devotion, but to settle a debt owed to a powerful religious order. Failing to fulfill this holy mission could bring divine wrath upon you and your loved ones.

2

Your quest for ancient knowledge leads you to Jerusalem, driven not just by curiosity, but to repay a debt of honor to a legendary scholar. Failure to uncover the sought-after secrets could tarnish your mentor's legacy forever.

3

Seeking a healer in Jerusalem serves as your cover to spy on a secretive medicinal guild for a rival faction. As you search for the cure, you must also discreetly gather information on the guild's practices and alliances.

4

A dear mentor who once dreamt of a pilgrimage to Jerusalem has passed away in Baghdad. Honoring their last wish, you are here to complete their journey, facing both emotional and physical trials along the sacred path.

5

You flee to Jerusalem not for sanctuary, but to seek retribution against someone who betrayed you in the past. As you navigate the city's labyrinthine streets, you know this vendetta will end in death – yours or theirs.

6

A dear friend, now passed, always dreamed of visiting Jerusalem but could never make the journey. Carrying their diary filled with notes and sketches of the city, you embark on this journey to fulfill their dream, experiencing the city through their eyes.

7

A loved one of yours or someone dear to you in a way you choose, came to Jerusalem some time ago, possibly to join the Holy War. You are in search of them.

8

You have a calling in your heart. It lies in Jerusalem and you know it’s a holy duty. You must join this holy war as a Crusader or as a Saracen.

@UUID[Macro.Rpfx0dBuXb2hizEM]{Roll Other Ideas Table}

D6

Other Ideas

1

A mysterious seer has prophesied that your destiny lies within the ancient walls of Jerusalem.

2

In your family's old heirlooms, you discover a cryptic scroll hinting at a long-lost family treasure hidden somewhere in Jerusalem.

3

You're a renowned artist who experienced a vivid dream of a unique, undiscovered artifact in Jerusalem. Believing it to be the inspiration for your masterpiece, you travel to the city, intent on finding this artifact and unveiling its hidden beauty through your art.

4

Once a noble of Jerusalem, you were unjustly exiled. Hearing rumors of political shifts, you return, determined to reclaim your honor and position.

5

As a musician, you're haunted by a fragment of a melody you once overheard, said to originate from an ancient instrument in Jerusalem. Believing that completing this melody is key to your greatest composition, you embark on a quest to uncover the musical secret.

6

An ancient astrological event predicted only once in a millennium is set to occur, visible perfectly from Jerusalem. As an astronomer, you cannot miss this celestial event, believing it holds the key to understanding the cosmos.

Class

Backstory/Class Ideas

Barbarian

Seeking to prove your strength and earn the respect of your tribe, you've heard of a legendary warrior in Jerusalem known for their unparalleled combat skills. You journey there to challenge them and gain glory through a test of might.

Bard

A famous bard has composed an epic poem said to reveal a hidden truth about Jerusalem's history. Intrigued and inspired, you travel to the city to uncover the story behind the poem and compose your own masterpiece.

Cleric

A divine vision has called you to Jerusalem, where an ancient relic of your deity is said to be hidden. Your mission is to find and protect this sacred object, facing both spiritual and physical trials on your holy quest.

Druid

Your very connection to the wilds calls you to a city for the first time. When you commune with nature, you feel the corrupted branches and roots of a dark tree trying to embrace Jerusalem and drown it dark lands that resemble a dreadful swamp.

Fighter

You are looking for seasonal warriors that can train you or you are looking for formidable warriors that can test your might and prowess. You are sure to find one in Jerusalem, the victorious army that defeated Saladin years ago.

Monk

Your spiritual connection to the cosmos has recently been crippled. You now seek a way to reforge it and your inner Ki guides you to the city of Jerusalem. Your masters and mentors all agree that something dark and dangerous lurks under it and it is worthy of investigating.

Paladin

You are a holy warrior and Jerusalem, the holiest city, is where you belong. Deus vult!

Ranger

As a ranger, you journey to Jerusalem to track a rare, mythical eagle rumored to nest atop the city's ancient walls, seeking to understand its mysterious connection to the city's history and the natural world.

Rogue

You are looking for a mysterious person last seen in Jerusalem. Someone offered an entrance to an important black market in exchange.

Sorcerer

Your arcane research has led you to Jerusalem, where a convergence of magical ley lines is rumored to occur. Seeking to tap into this immense power, you journey to the city to unlock new magical abilities and secrets.

Warlock

Through your patron, you feel a sense of dread and a calling from the cosmos itself that stimulates the ancient fear that resides inside you. The very heart of Jerusalem is infested with the horror that strangles your soul and you must discover what lies there.

Wizard

An ancient library in Jerusalem holds a spellbook containing unique and powerful spells. As a wizard, you seek this book to expand your magical repertoire and delve deeper into the arcane arts.

Conflicting Characters

The Holy Lands are in the middle of turmoil and there are two main sides: the Kingdom of Jerusalem (The Crusaders) and the Ayyubid Dynasty of Syria and Egypt (The Saracens). The players are free to choose who they are; there are no restrictions (unless you, as a GM, force some restrictions on them, this is going to be your story after all). All that is expected from the players is for them to have a strong reason to travel to Jerusalem.

As the player characters are free to choose, there can be many different characters with different and even opposing backgrounds. For example, one character could be a Mamluk-trained-fighter and a loyal soldier to Sultan Saladin, leader of the Saracens, while the other could be a proud and strong Crusader (a Paladin) who is extremely loyal to King Baldwin. From a distance, these characters seem to clash from the beginning and could turn enemies very quickly. In Sigil of Jerusalem, this is not the case.

There are several reasons that can be explored before the beginning of the campaign:

  • There is truce between Baldwin and Saladin. It is a fragile peace but some Muslim entries to the Crusader cities are allowed.
  • The story’s main plot is about an eldritch horror that lies beneath the city of Jerusalem rather than the enmity between the two clashing countries.
  • The characters’ backgrounds can be tied to stopping the enmities between them.
  • The story’s first important moment will tie the characters nonetheless to a tied cause. So, at the beginning of the story, some tension between them can be explored and that could turn out to be a great companionship.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Introduction

Player Options

Here in this chapter, you will find subclass options created for the Era of the Crusades setting and the World of Historica Arcanum, a series of profession choices for our mechanical addition to 5th edition, new spells, magic items, feats, and other options.

Story Hooks

Only for players' eyes, the Story Hooks section is designed to set personal agendas for the Player Characters for the adventure module. GMs can use this section’s rollable tables or narrative suggestions to create unique starting points for their players so that the adventurers can be eased into the main questline!

Cast of Characters

In this chapter of the book, we provide detailed information, backstory, and roleplaying ideas for the main NPCs of the Sigil of Jerusalem. These characters play an important role in shaping the story and providing challenges for the players, so it's important to bring them to life with compelling personalities and motivations. We've included detailed descriptions of each NPC's appearance, abilities, and motivations, as well as suggestions for how to roleplay them and incorporate them into the story.

The Sigil of Jerusalem

The main adventure module of Historica Arcanum’s Crusader saga is the Sigil of Jerusalem, with the main campaign taking players on a quest to uncover and destroy an eldritch conspiracy within the Holy Lands. In this section you will find everything you may need to run the Sigil of Jerusalem campaign, from meticulously crafted Questlines to maps of locations and dungeons, side adventures to potential downtime activities, consequences for branching narratives to combat encounters to test your players with.

Descriptive Boxes

Foreword.name: Foreword
Foreword.text:
Foreword

Dear Friends,

As we sit down to share our thoughts on the journey to “Era of the Crusades,” it’s hard not to feel a rush of emotions. We’re Sarp and Doğa from Metis Creative, and if there’s one thing we’ve learned from our adventures in creating worlds to explore, it’s that stories have the power to bridge worlds.

When we first dreamed up this project, the idea of Historica Arcanum, the idea of running a Tabletop RPG Studio, we couldn’t help but worry about being left out of the global community. We were culturally, and geographically far away - and the dread of not being able to get our voices heard was overbearing. Yet, this was one of the instances that we couldn’t be happier to be proven definitively wrong.

The love, passion, and unwavering support you’ve shown us have not just filled us with an insatiable hunger to create; they have truly made us feel that we were a part of the global Tabletop community. And for that, we are grateful. Honestly, we’re still pinching ourselves to make sure it’s real.

“Era of the Crusades” is a project that’s close to all of our hearts at the office. It was a setting that we really wanted to make since we released the first Historica Arcanum - City of Crescent. Everyone in the team, from writers to artists, poured their hearts and souls into this book, making sure every page, every illustration, and every line of text captured the essence of the story and world we wanted to bring to life. It’s with this setting, where we’ve started to really nail the dark, mysterious, and slightly eerie tone we’ve always wanted the World of Historica Arcanum to have. This book marks a significant step in developing our universe, laying down even more pieces of the lore that will grow and evolve with time and new entries to the setting.

Sharing this creation with you feels like sharing a piece from our souls. The late nights, the brainstorming sessions, the occasional frustrations, and the breakthrough moments—it’s all been a labor of love, a testament to what we can achieve together, as a team and as a community. Your enthusiasm and support light the way for us, encouraging us to keep dreaming, creating, exploring, and sharing new worlds that resonate with the depth and diversity of the human experience.

Thank you for joing this incredible journey with us. As you turn the pages of Era of the Crusades, know that you’re stepping into a world crafted with love, dedication, and a little bit of magic from everyone at Metis Creative.

With all our gratitude and love,

Sarp and Doğa

Metis Creative

Act I: Rebehold the Stars.name: Act I: Rebehold the Stars
Act I: Rebehold the Stars.text:
“How can the heart travel to God, when it is chained by its desires?”

-Ibn Arabi

The world was waiting, having taken a deep breath. It was enslaved amongst the clouds, and the despair brought forth by the darkening sky was attempting to suffocate the most sacred city in the world. Despite all the darkness, enemies at the gate, and traitors within, a silver flag was hoisted towards the heavens, rising from every tower on the walls, striving to reach the stars. Brave warriors on the high battlements, fixing their eyes on the roads and all the struggles that lay ahead, were waging a sincere and relentless battle against the fear that would take their hearts to the depths of the abyss.

The walls, to which almost everyone feeling a sacred call in their heart turned their gazes, were facing one of the greatest challenges in history. In these lands that have breathed as the heart of faith for thousands of years, secrets lay hidden, difficult to see for those whose inner eyes were closed. The custodians of this city, accustomed to altering the fate of the world, were struggling to perceive the threats lurking behind the veil.

A victorious king sat upon the throne of the city. Despite his young age, he had proven his strength to everyone and had overcome seemingly impassable obstacles. Yet, the whims of fate, the very curse of Mother Nature herself, were subjecting him to an impossible test. His greatest rival, a sultan determined to become the city’s conqueror, knew that the mysteries within the walls walked arm in arm with what horror lies beyond the veil and carried - and bravely fought - the marks of the rising darkness in his soul with each passing day.

Two adversaries, each holding deep respect for the other, were acutely aware that they were destined to engage in a desperate struggle. They knew that they would not have the chance to sit and debate the most skillful commanders in the world as two former rivals and new friends after the war was over, like Hannibal and Scipio did. They both knew that this war would cost one of them their lives.

The people living within the walls entered their beds at night, knowing all too well that they could not easily escape the ruthless claws of war. They could do no more than place their trust in their young king and their bravest of knights.

Very few heard the calm and enticing lullaby rising from behind the curtain. Not far from a caravanserai that gazed distantly at the city’s battlements, there gathered a group eager and willing to reach the silver towers, looking towards the visage of the most sacred city with hope. Neither the owners of the stifling silence among the shadows nor those who followed the faith in their hearts were aware of this.

Mother’s Hand: A Caravanserai at the Edg.name: Mother’s Hand: A Caravanserai at the Edge
Mother’s Hand: A Caravanserai at the Edg.text:
Mother’s Hand: A Caravanserai at the Edge

Section Summary

In this section, the adventurers will form a party, explore the caravanserai called Mother’s Hand, and meet with an important NPC named Yakup al-Qudsi. They can possibly take on small quests as a form of introduction to the campaign. The caravanserai will be attacked by Raynald of Chatillon, and Yakup’s escape attempt with magic will result in a strong spell rebound effect. As a result, the adventurers will inherit Yakup’s Sigil and find themselves near the city of Jerusalem – at the Tomb of Lazarus, a holy site.

Estimated Level: 1-2

A few miles outside the city of Jerusalem, a caravanserai is situated on the road for travelers, pilgrims, and others to spend a night or two while they rest and prepare for the rest of their journey. It is also an outpost for merchants to meet with others and establish a connection with many possible contacts.

The winds carry the ill news of war and bloodshed. As the sorrowful clouds fight away the radiant sunlight, the faces around the caravanserai seem to be sunless and joyless. The very fragile peace of the world hangs in a delicate balance, and the ones who take a side in this endless war are perilously close to the edge. You notice two different sides in this small caravanserai, just as the world you know also shattered between the cross and the crescent. The chasm bleeds, and you only see blades in the dark to widen the bloodshed; almost nothing makes an attempt to stop it.

You notice warriors with stern faces, armed from head to toe –proudly carrying the cross on their chests, close to their hearts. Their gaze is upon the newly arrived –the followers of the crescent. Neither party is here to disturb the peace or be the reason the balance is off the scale and cause all hopes to fall from the edge right into the abyss. However, you feel the ice in the air, filling the gap between them.

Hirelings

Note on Economy: Instead of gold pieces (gp) gold dinar (gd), instead of silver pieces (sp) silver dirham (sd) and instead of copper pieces copper fals (pl. fulus) (cf) is used. The conversion is the same: 1 gold dinar is equal to 10 silver dirhams and 1 silver dirham is equal to 10 copper fulus. Please note that these changes do not affect the official pricing of items and other shoppings and are not designed to be historically accurate.

There are 20 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.E9CvDPDg5dFEpVjS]{guards}j in the caravanserai. Their captain is a Frankish man called Christopher who uses the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.D5UqYD1EnTrJaMTO]{knight}j stat block. Other than that, the caravanserai has 7 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa]{scouts}j, who usually hunt for meat in the surrounding area. All of the above can act as guides and guards; The usual fee is 2 sp/mile.

Christopher is an elderly crusader who was banished from the city due to letting some Muslim pilgrims in the Dome of the Rock. He believes that all religions should be treated equally, and the war is pointless. He was born in Jerusalem and protected the Dome for many years. However, the things he witnessed changed his worldview slowly, and he no longer wished to fight for a greater cause. Once he left the city, he was taken prisoner by a bandit group and was sold as a slave. His slavery ended when the owner bought his freedom. He now seeks peaceful times and tries to collect enough coins to travel around the world, but he feels obligated to pay Alexios for his freedom.

Stables

There are many mounts that the adventurers or other guests can purchase or trade their own mounts. Usual horses that have 60 ft. of movement speed (like riding @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rz8UTUnFT87BsAFR]{horse}j) cost 20 gd, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.FQMFuzzSh73d0Nrd]{camels}j cost about 15 gd, and slower mounts like @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.Vk7uHVkJ5b26gaTh]{mules}j or donkeysj cost 5 gd. There are also special mounts that can be purchased.

Designer’s Note: These mounts are intended to be cheaper than the 5th edition’s original prices. It is made this way so the adventurers can purchase them early in the game.

@UUID[Actor.7z2gdIUKclr6nVrv]{Turkoman Horse} | 100 gd
Turkoman Horse uses the warhorsej stat block but has a speed of 70 feet.

@UUID[Actor.QKFQ6VsVQBW44C13]{Ferghana Horse} | 55 gd
Ferghana Horse uses the riding horsej stat block but has 14 AC.

@UUID[Actor.7nVzLzJxJYJ9QNoO]{Cerigyn Nojan} | 125 gd
Cerigyn Nojan uses the warhorsej stat block but has multiattack.

@UUID[Actor.XPd7lXT7MnzHMcEz]{Karabakh Horse} | 30 gd
Karabakh Horse uses the riding horsej stat block but is immune to fear.

@UUID[Actor.h0kidJYNtfF8agdK]{Yakutian Horse} | 110 gd
Yakutian Horse uses the warhorsej stat block but has 30 HP.

@UUID[Actor.r0fehoYjXp0gRCpY]{Nisean Horse} | 25 gd
Nisean Horse uses the draft horsej stat block but has a passive Perception score of 14.

@UUID[Actor.YMXO4THVg3d1EVkM]{Steppe Pony} | 18 gd
Steppe Pony uses the ponyj stat block but has a speed of 50 feet.

Main Building

The main building has numerous tables scattered around and many waiters and attendants roaming. The owner of the caravanserai is a man called Alexios of Greek origin and is an elderly man who uses the artisanh stat block. He raises orphans of the war and teaches them a craft. As an artisan, he is experienced in many fields. Check out the Professions section in Era of the Crusades and other Historica Arcanum books for more possible Professions.

Alexios mourns the death of his two children, early in the 1180s. Each morning, he wakes up early before dawn, and travels to a nearby pond. He spends some time there watering two beautiful flowers, interestingly colorful and healthy in this desolate area. The flowers are a tribute to his two children that died during the war. If the matter is brought up, he will state that both Crusaders and Saracens were responsible. Alexios bought Christopher from slave owners and set him free immediately. Christopher, however, wanted to stay by his side and settle his debt. Alexios does not see Christopher as indebted to him, and he enjoys his company as the captain of his guards.

In the main building, there are about thirty attendants that work for the caravanserai and attend to many needs, from kitchen duties to tending to horses. Most of them can be considered to use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{commoner}j stat block and share the upper two floors among themselves for accommodation.

Courtyard

The courtyard usually is full of travelers and merchants that are coming from or out of Jerusalem. Due to times of relative peace, the traders are free to continue their affairs as they wish. In the courtyards, their caravans and goods are at the ready if the adventurers wish to trade.

There are also two interesting groups: a Crusader group and a Saracen envoy from Damascus who are traveling to Cairo. They clearly don’t enjoy the other’s presence, and the adventurers can catch cold looks or long and intimidating glares towards one another if they spend time in the courtyard.

Characters with Passive Perception of 13 or higher notice a man in his late thirties, possibly of Arabic descent and trying to keep a low profile and warding off unwanted attention. He seems to be working at the caravanserai, near the well. He serves water to those who ask and tries to act as a shy and quiet person. A further [[/skill Insight 10]] or [[/skill Perception 10]] check reveals that he pays attention to every face and rarely loses focus. If the roll is above 15, the character also notices that he hides a scar. The scar is actually from a spell rebound effect (check out the Magic in Historica Arcanum section in Era of the Crusades).

This character is Yakup al-Qudsi, a sigil knight of Jerusalem, and he is directly connected to the main story. He carries the Sigil of the Serpent on him. He is currently on the run from Jerusalem; since the plot of Guy of Lusignan and Raynald of Chatillon is in play, he fled for his life. He has a serious injury and was forced to rest here for a day. He plans to leave as soon as possible.

His plan to get away as soon as possible, however, will be prevented by one of the main Characters Raynald of Chatillon. He will raid the caravanserai and trigger the main event for the caravanserai.

Yakup lost an item of immense personal importance: a locket from his ancestors. He will be very grateful if the adventurers find the locket and bring it back. He does not want to do it himself because he avoids any possible unwanted attention.

Yakup has no idea what happened to the locket, but he discovered a wizard’s tomb on his way here; he believes there may be useful spell scrolls there. Yakup will inform the adventurers that it is probably guarded. They can identify the specific tomb with the Mark of Banu Musa, which is a symbol of a wave with the letter ب on it. [[/skill History 15]] check reveals that Banu Musa is a group of engineers that originates from Baghdad. Banu Musa means the Sons of Musa and was founded by three brothers: Abu al-Qasim, Ahmad ibn Musa ibn Shakir, and Al-Hasan ibn Musa ibn Shakir, known as Abu al-Qasim, Ahmad, and Al-Hasan for short, respectively. Check out the “The Locket of Yakup” quest below.

Yakup also warns the adventurers that they should perform a small ritual before touching and carrying the locket: one should put their hands on the soil, move their fingers until they are all covered, then pour some water on them while chanting a children’s song. This will let them carry the locket unharmed.

If the adventurers look around for a quick investigation, they will encounter an abundant number of snake scales and a possible snake net near the well.

Traders

Pierre (traveling merchanta, NG): Pierre is a local Christian from Jerusalem and a rare book merchant who knows many languages (in addition to his stat block) and is a very educated man. He was an acolyte at the Church of St. Anne, and was raised there as an orphan who was taken into service by Father Godfrey. Godfrey is a priest who takes care of orphan children. Godfrey’s kindness and dedication very much inspired Pierre, and he started to find books, tomes, and many sources of information for Godfrey’s teachings for other orphans. As the years advanced, he became very proficient in book trading and tracking them. He left the godly ways a long time ago and focused mostly on book trading, languages, and similar topics.

Sophia (Traveling Merchanta, CG): Sophia is an adventurous young merchant who came to the Holy Lands in search of true love. She believes that she will meet someone very important in her journeys based on the words of a seer back in Rome. She usually slips this sentence in Greek while meeting new customers: “The moon is down.” It sounds like a general phrase or a proverb, but it is a line from Ancient Greek Sappho’s poems. She waits for someone to complete the sentence with, “but I lie alone.” She is very enthusiastic about her work and enjoys cracking jokes here and there. She is interested in people’s life stories and their adventures. She sells many goods suitable for traveling and hunting, as well as very mundane and useful items.

Crusader Group

There are sixteen armed men (crusader infantrya) resting before they complete their journey to Jerusalem. They come from Poitou and are led by a capable warrior named Conrad of Niort (crusader knighta). Conrad is looking for his older brother in Jerusalem, who joined the crusade years ago. They arrived after the Saracen Envoy did. Conrad is suspicious of them but keeps his men in check and doesn’t want any problems between the two groups. Some of his men want to attack them, claiming it is their part in the crusade, while others do not want to disturb the already fragile peace.

Saracen Envoy

There are thirteen armed men (Mamluk Sentinela) in the envoy who are traveling from Damascus to Cairo. They strayed from their original path in order to pick up the dead body of their commander, who was close to Jerusalem on a private matter and was found dead by local pilgrims; they immediately informed the nearest Ayyubid force. Their new commander Hamza (Mamluk Veterana) was his apprentice, and he took his men to complete their last mission for their deceased commander. The deceased commander’s name was Albars, and he had a secret affair with a priestess near Jerusalem.

Each group has a warmonger among them, and a [[/skill Insight 12]] check reveals them. If the party does not intervene, the troublemakers will ignite a problem between the two groups that will possibly initiate a fight – such as blaming the others for theft, disrespect, heresy, or a similar problem. Optional Quests

It is intended for adventurers to spend some time in this caravanserai. They can meet and form an adventuring party, or if they start getting to know each other, they can spend some time gathering information about Jerusalem or their personal endeavors. If you want them to spend more time here before the attack of Raynald, they may be given these quests in exchange for some coins. These quests are designed to be short for early levels and focus on monster fighting.

However, it is advised that the adventurers complete the Locket of Yakup quest, as it connects heavily with the main story.

The Locket of Yakup

The tomb is located within one hour walk’s reach. It appears to be a normal grave under the shadow of a tree, with the name Nurullah ibn Musa carved on it. The Mark of Banu Musa is small on the gravestone, but it can be easily spotted by anyone looking for it. A [[/skill Survival 10]] check reveals that there is a solid object beneath it, far above for a grave. It is not customary for Muslim burials to involve solid objects. Rather, they are buried well deep with only a white shroud. The object is actually the beginning of a ladder that leads downwards.

With each step you take, a subtle aroma begins to pervade your senses, intensifying as you descend. It's an unsettling scent, primarily because it's so wholly unexpected. You had braced yourself for the stench of decay, perhaps even death, yet what greets you is neither. Instead, an acrid smell assaults your nostrils, almost as if it's singing the hairs within. Upon reaching the bottom and venturing into its heart, your eyes start to water. This is a scent you recognize, one that's ingrained in your memory. It's the odor of rusty chains abandoned in a damp chamber for centuries, reminiscent of an old, retired blacksmith whose hands are eternally marred with the soot and scent of metal. It's the threatening presence of a darkened, burnt orange nail that could fatally pierce your skin with a single swipe. The longer you linger here, the more you sense this pervasive, rusty essence beginning to claim your belongings, as if it seeks to engulf them—and not just them, but your very bones as well.

Main Grave Room

The room has a sarcophagus, with one set of full plate armor (actually an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.eORmAXuV5v3nWsQL]{animated armor}j) in front of it, and a carved steel plate on the left. On the ground, there is a carpet made from silk, obviously torn by the cruel touch of time. The carpet’s weave tells the story of Moses and the Parting of the Red Sea. Players who speak Arabic or Turkic languages realize that Musa is the name for Moses in Arabic and Turkic dialects. The carpet has magical grease under it which can be noticed with a Passive Perception score of 13 or higher or with an active [[/skill Perception 10]] or [[/skill Investigation 10]] check. If the creatures succeed in the active check, they also notice a loose plate under the carpet, which triggers a mechanism.

The steel plate on the left has a dragon’s carving on it, and if the carpet is removed, the trap is triggered; the mechanism belches fire in a 15 ft. cone. The ones inside the area must succeed on a [[/save 10 dex format=long]] or take [[/damage 1d6 fire average]] damage. The grease also catches fire and forces the ones on the greased area to make another [[/save 10 dex format=long]]. On a failed save, they catch fire. Unless one spends an action to put the fire out, they take [[/damage 1d4 fire average]] damage at the start of each of their turns.

This also triggers the plate armor’s mechanism. Its magic comes alive, and the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.eORmAXuV5v3nWsQL]{animated armor}j attacks the adventurers. When defeated, a sapphire and a small parchment drop from its helmet. The sapphire is a magic item - the deep sea sapphire.

After the adventurers bring the locket, Yakup will reward them with [[/award 25gp]] each, but he will further explain what the sigil is and what the locket does. The locket is actually a magic item that lets the user cast the mage armor spell at will (it is included in his stat block).

The adventurers advance to Level 2.

Missing Book

Pierre informs that a book titled Diwan Lughat al-Turk (Compendium of the Languages of the Turks) is missing. It is a dictionary and an important work compiled by Mahmud Kashgari. The clues around his cart – with a successful [[/skill Survival 10]] or [[/skill Perception 10]] or [[/skill Investigation 10]] check– show that only two kinds of beasts have been around: a dog and a squirrel.

The tracks can be traced to a small cave half an hour away. There is a medium-sized, intelligent monster and a shapechanger called Aji Asil – a type of dragon – and his companion, a squirrel named Titanus, who became an awakened beast when his druid friend died years ago. If they return the book, Pierre will award them with two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.9GSfMg0VOA2b4uFN]{1st-level spell scrolls} of their choice, at your discretion.

Grave Danger

Two travelers lose three of their companions to sickness and head to a nearby hill to bury them. One of them (an Artisana named Francis) returns with scars and a worried face. He says that he and his companion were ambushed by wild beasts, which led to the other's death. It can be understood that he is hiding something with a [[/skill Insight 12 passive format=long]] or an active [[/skill insight 10]] check. He can be persuaded ([[/check Cha 10]] check, proper skills may apply depending on the approach) to tell what happens, but he seems reluctant, and believes that no one would believe what happened.

The mud at your feet seems almost sentient, grasping and pulling you deeper into the dark earth with every step. Labeling this place a graveyard would be the fantasy of a madman. Gone are the orderly graves adorned with flowers by grieving loved ones. Instead, the remains of the dead lie scattered, some stacked haphazardly like butcher's meat awaiting cleaning, others dismembered and unrecognizable, stripped of dignity and identity. A few are arranged in spirals, hinting at the grotesque beginnings of a macabre ritual. And then, there's the odor—the stench of decay you had been mentally bracing yourself for assaults your senses with a potency beyond imagination. As it fills your lungs, you can almost feel the rot taking root within you. You're left to wonder if the abyss of hell itself could rival the foulness of this air.

The hill they went to hosts a mourning @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{specter}j and two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.nU8GN8La8DCt8SDb]{skeletons}j under its command, recently rose from their graves.
