If the adventurers help clear out the area and defeat the specter, Francis will award them with four cups of Blessed Ayran - Yogurt Drink.

The Raid

Harbingers from the sky bring a terrible cry from the heavens. With the first light, you hear horses neigh, furious and deadly. Their gallops shutter your sleep and, with it, your deep dreams. Dozens of suits of silver armor shine like a blazing and vengeful moon under the dawn’s crimson clouds. This intense red is usually believed to be a sign of a night drowned in blood. The blood of the innocent, the warrior, the victim, the martyr, no matter. You do not know if the night was painted crimson, but you are now sure the dawn and bright morning will be.

Unbeknownst to the players, Raynald of Chatillon, the lord of Kerak, and his men are striking the caravanserai at dawn. Their goal is to capture Yakup al-Qudsi. Thirty-two men (@UUID[Actor.b6kWTMwy1GnF21NG]{brute knights} and @UUID[Actor.iQN4H2wZ6EnJptbk]{brute warriors} of the wolf sigila) attack and catch the whole caravanserai off guard after the departure of the Crusader group and the Saracen envoy.

It is important to time the attack after the two groups’ departure. If the adventurers immediately leave the area or are convinced to side with a group for the remainder of their journey, Yakup may accompany them. In this case, they can be immediately attacked by Raynald of Chatillon’s forces.

The adventurers witness the attack but are counted as surprised unless they have a feature that prevents it, such as a feat or a class feature. Yakup immediately tries to escape but is quickly cornered by the enemy. The enemy appears to be ruthless, slaying everyone in their path, and is not interested in showing mercy to the injured or surrendered.

The leader, Raynald himself, can be seen in the heart of battle with incredible might and horrible methods:

A large man with a greatsword dismounts his horse, voluntarily giving up his advantageous position. The air fills with dread as he approaches Yakup viciously. Even though you can’t see his face, you feel his determination and intent to kill Yakup is far greater than any killer you have witnessed. While the gap is narrowing, a sudden surge of blood pours from the leader. To your shock, he cuts his own arm with one swift strike. He seems to ignore the pain and hastily charges towards Yakup.

Before he is ready to strike, you hear those words: “Finally, the restless nights are over!”

The adventurers are cornered by one @UUID[Actor.iQN4H2wZ6EnJptbk]{brute warrior of the wolf sigil}a and can fight him. While you describe the events, they can engage in combat with it.

If dangerous situations occur or the threat is defeated, Yakup casts a dimension door spell. It is important that he is close to the adventurers, at least 60 ft. Due to the spell rebound effect, the adventurers will be affected by the spell as well and will be teleported away against their will.

You notice Yakup imitating the ancient signs to cast a powerful spell. Those of you who are aware of the arcane matters of the world know this one: a conjuration spell that will lead Yakup out of here, to a place of relative safety: dimension door!

However, when Yakup vanishes, the light goes out for you. Suddenly, the stars in the sky betray your desire for light, and you find yourself engulfed in darkness. A starless, cosmic cold surrounds your very soul and attempts to strangle you at the edge of darkness. You feel some strong iron chains pull you to a dark hole, and a sudden, soft lullaby is heard from a distance. You hear a calling that resembles your mother’s voice, even if you didn’t know her.

You suddenly feel you’ve been struck by a volcano’s eruption. The feeling of burning is felt in your body. Something is branding you. You feel your skin yielding to the pain and heat, and you hear Yakup’s agony in the distance. You feel his scars are yours now, and somehow, his destiny marches your way, and there is nothing you can do to stop it.

The lullaby stops when the chains are gone and the branding is done. The skies show mercy, and suddenly, the stars rush to your aid. The strangling darkness vanishes in front of you, and you feel a chilling cold down your spine. You are in a place far from the bloodshed. You emerge from the darkness, witness of your own miracle, where once Lazarus rose by taking the hand of Jesus of Nazareth, now you rise at the Tomb of Lazarus, in a hill close to the City of God.

The adventurers all gain four levels of exhaustion and are down to 1 HP. The first sight they see is a man near them: Yakup al-Qudsi, who has lost all his breath and is lying side by side with death.

When you arrived, there were once many relics and sacred grounds, all broken to many pieces with strange shapes and horrible fates: Bodies clashed with each other and fused together in a hellish manner. Stones are carved unnaturally, and relics are rusted away by a dire explosion. Bodies are carved into the stones; some body parts are reaching out of the stone, as if screaming for help. But none are alive. No one can scream anymore. Body parts are all over the place. All shattered to pieces and fused into the stones or each other. You don’t know how many people died here. How many bodies fused into the holy grounds like this? You notice Yakup’s face in a stone wall. His face twitches with pain and agony. His last moments are forever embraced by the stones; his pain will always be visible here.

You notice you are at the center of all this. Your arrival caused this. The spell rebound broke this holy place and shattered its belongings.

At the corner of your eye, you notice knights, high and mighty in their shining armor and strong horses. Their eyes are fixed upon you. Their leader, a charismatic warrior, looks shocked at the events of this and acts rapidly. His expression is firm. His eyes focus on a spot on your bodies, as if something caught his attention. When he does that, you realize you have scars, the brands. They look very similar to Yakup’s.

When he is close enough, you only hear these words:
“You are under arrest.”

The knights’ leader is Balian of Ibelin (Check out the Characters section for further information). He is escorted by five crusader infantrya. He takes the adventurers into his custody and asks for them to stand down without resisting. If he needs to, he will knock them out without powerful blows and carry them to the city unconscious. Given the outnumbered situation, Balian will not hesitate to attack if the players are aggressive and try to resist. All of their items and belongings will be taken away. He will not be prone to conversation at the moment and will not question them on the events, as he believes it must be done in the safe walls within the city.

Their next destination is their original one: the city of Jerusalem.

If they didn’t before, the adventurers reach Level 2.

Jerusalem: The Silver Towers.name: Jerusalem: The Silver Towers
Jerusalem: The Silver Towers.text:
Jerusalem: The Silver Towers

“How can the heart travel to God, when it is chained by its desires?”

-Ibn Arabi

Section Summary

The adventurers will be punished with execution due to harmful acts against the holy grounds. In the cell, King Baldwin IV himself will greet them, who recognized the sigil from his book and will execute other people in place of the adventurers, thus saving them and freeing them from any unwanted attention. They will now serve him. Balian will test their strength in a quest to find the ones that escaped from prison. After the first quest, adventurers will be present at the reconstruction project of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, which will lead to their first encounter with the “Seals of the Lullaby Palace.” After they complete this quest, the king will explain that he seeks a cure for his leprosy and asks the adventurers for their aid.

The adventurers will enter the dungeon in the Mosque of Omar, which leads them to the Cisterns under the Dome of the Rock. They will get their hands on the first key and open the second floor of the Lullaby Palace.

They will reach Level 3.

When the adventurers are about the enter city, read:

Time stops. The city stands proud and strong, seemingly there since the beginning of time. You feel the eyes of the first men settled in the city. Although the walls have been rebuilt many times, you see the first stones that arise from the ground. You see kings’ images, caliphs’ shadows, and crusaders’ radiance. You see faithful men and women, all praising their gods or divine spirits. You feel the eyes of David, Cyrus, Heraklios, Omar, Godfrey…

The winds are restless. The light in the heart of the city is prone to fading away, and you feel the ones that shelter it losing their power. The city is about to fall to darkness, and your hands are bound. Your eyes are about to go blind.

The city of Jerusalem is detailed extensively in our setting book: Era of the Crusades, where numerous locations, knightly orders, and many significant points of interest are described. To bring the city to life, explore quests, and access a wealth of information about the city, you can check out the section titled Jerusalem - City of God in the Era of the Crusades.

The adventurers will be thrown in a cell in the city prison, giving them a chance to rest. They will have enough time for two long rests, which will lower their exhaustion levels by two. Balian will place two special warriors as their guards: two Crusader Knightsa named William of Venice and Phillip of Toulouse. They are both silent and don’t communicate with the prisoners.

After three days have passed, they will learn that they have been sentenced to death due to their destruction of a holy site. Balian of Ibelin will personally bring this news. Right after Balian delivers the verdict, a figure emerges from the dark corners of the jail, seemingly with a crimson cloak and a marble mask that covers all of his face:

The king himself.

You are surrounded by one thing: authority. One that stirs your heart and arrests your gaze. An image that inflicts nothing but might. His slow pace ends right in front of you. Unexpectedly from a king, he only takes a stool to sit on and takes his time to shift his gaze across your cell slowly. He pays attention to every single one of you. Not a single soul dares to break the silence as if the whole of Jerusalem waits for his command for it to be over.

“A number of spies who happen to look like you are being taken away for execution. In your stead. From now on, you are dead.”

The king has been informed of the weird brands on each character by Balian of Ibelin, who was afraid of killing them due to unknown danger. He was afraid that killing them would have serious consequences. The king, however, recognizes the brands and thus deems the adventurers important in his search for the cure for his disease. He will withhold this plan for the moment, and he will talk about these topics:

  • They will be taken to a new room close to the guards’ office, and their original equipment will be given to them. It will be their living quarters for the time being.
  • They will be in service of the king for the time being, and Balian of Ibelin himself will be in charge of their actions. They should prove their worth.
  • He will question them about the brands they carry. If the adventurers are completely honest about the events that happen and share what they know about Yakup al-Qudsi, the king will be satisfied and reveal that he has seen the brand before in a book, and it is another mystery that they can solve together.
  • He will learn about their talents and knowledge in arcane business. He will reveal that he is also interested in those matters himself.
  • The king warns them they are not allowed to leave the city and ensures that he can find them if they do.

After the conversation is over, the adventurers will be moved to their living quarters, which are simple but comfortable. Balian will personally escort them there and will be immediately informed of a certain escape that has happened in the prison. Balian will turn to the adventurers and announce that this will be their first task done in the name of the king.

Prison Break

When Balian and the adventurers arrive at the area, they will notice there are four cells, of which only one is empty. The other three cells hold one prisoner each. Two guards of the cell are recently coming to their senses and can be questioned about the events.

The Escapees

Two people escaped from the prison: an Arab named Mamduh and a warrior within the ranks of Raynald of Chatillon named Alec. Mamduh is a traveling artista with the powers of a third-level bard, and Alec is a @UUID[Actor.iQN4H2wZ6EnJptbk]{brute warrior of the wolf sigil}a.

Mamduh tricked the guards into being put in the same cell as Alec, who is a childhood friend of his, and then tricked them into bringing a piece of iron and flame for a seemingly paganistic ritual. He used the iron and flame to cast the heat metal spell and melted the bars; then Alec hastily used his strength to knock out the guards.

They will travel to the Church of St. Anne together and hide in one of the rooms while plotting an escape from the city.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.E9CvDPDg5dFEpVjS]{Guards}j: Each of them was knocked out with brute force from crushing blows to the backs of their heads, near their spines. A DC 10 Medicine (can be applied with Intelligence or Wisdom, depending on the type of examination: [[/skill Medicine 10 int]] or [[/skill Medicine 10 wis]]) check reveals that it was either a hard object that hit them or a large fist, which seems unlikely. One guard will tell the adventurers that one of the escapees wanted a piece of iron and flame, which was part of a pagan ritual he wanted to conduct before his death. His name was Mamduh, and he was arrested for heresy, seemingly following the ways of the old Arabic pagan religion. He received the death penalty. The guard took pity on him and decided to honor his last wish. After several moments, he was hit on the head. The other guard saw nothing.

There was another escapee with him in the cell, a warrior from the ranks of Raynald of Chatillon who was accused of infidelity and was caught lying in bed with a prostitute in the poorer quarters of the city. The event was discovered by a devoted priest and he immediately informed the officials. Raynald had no choice but to let his man be taken into prison and face judgment.

Below, it is described which prisoners are in which cells, and under what conditions they will share the information they hold. Thus, the adventurers have the opportunity to move around and interact with the city as much as they like. They can complete their quests one by one or altogether if needed. If the prisoners' requests are met, the necessary information is provided in the "Information Gained" section.

For more quests, locations, and points of interest about the city, check out Era of the Crusades - The City of God section.

Cell A: A man of Arabic descent named Na’il (scholar of Cairoa) is imprisoned in the cell. He is accused of spying on behalf of the Sultan of Egypt, Salah ad-Din. He denies being an enemy of Jerusalem. A [[/skill Insight 15]] check confirms that he is indeed serving the crown in Cairo. He came here to find a cure for his beloved companion: An awakened chameleon named Luigi, named for a dear friend of Na’il’s from the city of Napoli. Na’il wants the adventurers to find a cure for Luigi, who is ill with a curse called Old Man’s Poison. The cure is a potion called remedy of the church, made only by certain priests in the city of Jerusalem. The priests can be found near the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, and the cure can be bought for 50 gd or with a [[/skill Persuasion 15]] check for free.

The information gained: One of the men is a spellcaster and used the heat metal spell on the bars. They used hand signs to communicate with each other.

If the adventurers are successful in saving Luigi, Na’il will ask them to take Luigi with them, as he does not see a way out of this and can’t ask them to save him. Luigi can befriend the party and act as an ally. If there are spellcasters who can cast find familiar, he can be used as a familiar spirit.

Cell C: A scholar and a surgeon named Jaques is being held in this cell. In recent days, he was accused of killing an important merchant of the city (named Hassan) while he was sick, and Jaques was performing surgery on him. Jaques used a special medicine to put Hassan to sleep and told the relatives he should wake up after 1 hour, which he didn’t. Relatives accused Jaques of poisoning the merchant, and he received a death penalty. Jaques is only willing to share information if the adventurers prove his innocence, which he is certain of.

In truth, the merchant had a secret affair with another merchant’s (Djemil, artisana) wife (Elif, traveling artista). When the rival merchant Djemil found out about the affair, he interfered with his food and poisoned him further, and then blamed it on the surgeon. Djemil has the poisoning kit stored in his cart, which can be used as proof of Jaques’s innocence.

The information gained: Alec is inhumanely powerful, and before he attacked the guards, his eyes had a purple shimmer. This information will give the adventurers an advantage on the saving throw against Alec’s Corrupting Presence and other abilities that enforce a condition called Corruption.

Church of St. Anne

When you see the building, you notice a certain joy pouring into your soul, and you are blessed with the most innocent voice in the world: the laughter of children. Amongst the fog that suffocates the city, the only radiant spark seems to be here.

The church is located in the north-western part of the city and is an important place of worship for the people. The leading priest of the church is a man called Father Godfrey. He is a priest with high intelligence and a very compassionate man. He is different from most priests and avoids religious dogma and mostly uses teachings about peace, compassion, love, and learning.

Father Godfrey is about fifty years old, with a shaved and clean face and short gray hair. He has scars starting from his neck down to his chest and has callused hands. He was taken prisoner from a village near Edna during the early campaigns of the Zengid Dynasty when he was only a child. While in a prisoner camp, he was freed by a local imam named Zaid. He was raised as a scholar and taught astronomy and mathematics as well as many languages. However, Zaid’s main teaching was that all human life is sacred, and learning and teaching are very important for those who have sharp minds. Zaid believed that Godfrey was very bright and that his turn to teach would eventually come.

Godfrey always felt the calling of Jerusalem and has always been a strong believer. Zaid never enforced Islam on him and at all the times said that: “We are under different pillars of light that look like they are coming from different sources. However, both beams are from the same sun.” Eventually, Godfrey left for Jerusalem and always helped those in need.

Other than Father Godfrey, two sisters (local priesta) named Aliceq and Maryq work in the church and take care of the perimeter.

The Magic of the Church: The Church of St. Anne was blessed due to its holy aura and the efforts of a priest during its conquest by Muslim forces in the seventh century. The priest invited Caliph Omar to the garden and personally asked for his blessings and the continuation of the church and its studies. Omar observed the orphans in the area and saw the innocence within them. He replied that he would not touch any of those who remain loyal to the city and added: “Your presence is enough to bless this place; you need none from me.”

Each creature resting in the church receives a blessing as if the greater restoration spell was cast on it when they finish a long rest. If they are of good alignment, they are under the effects of the bless spell for the next two hours.

Fountain of the Blessed: The water in this fountain is believed to be holy water and carries a faint magical essence. Believers that use some of the water according to their beliefs (such as crossing oneself) gain temporary hit points equal to their Wisdom modifier.

Godfrey’s Chamber: It is a modest room with only necessary furniture and objects. On his desk, a letter from his teacher, Zaidq, can be found. Apparently, he will visit the city, and he’s very ill, possibly coming to spend his final weeks. He’s afraid that the roads will be dangerous, and due to the upcoming war, he may not be allowed into the city.

Library: It contains many books and tomes on religious and academic topics. One shelf contains a hidden door, especially untouched by Father Godfrey if asked, as he did not want to disturb whatever was in it. It leads to a small vault with a lock (DC 15) and contains 4 spell scrolls that are 2nd level or lower. There is also a note signed from a man called Sheref ad-Din: “Find me near the mosque. I’ll be playing backgammon.” Only active mosque in the city is the Mosque of Omar.

During the day, the children’s number almost reaches thirty due to more from the neighborhood coming for lessons and lectures from Godfrey. The lectures usually happen in the library or the courtyard.

Sisters’ Rooms: Sisters stay in the same room with two beds and modest furniture. Sister Maryq is in her mid-thirties and keeps her private belongings under her bed, in a small chest, with a mirror and a drawing in it. The drawing is a small and cozy house on a sunny hill and signed by a child, which can be understood by the handwriting. It is titled: “My mama’s dream house -Anthony.”

Sister Aliceq is a young woman in her twenties who aspires to be a powerful magic user. She believes that her faith will prevail no matter what. She keeps some books on arcane matters and legends near her bed and has a personal journal full of notes, suggestions, training routines, and such about spellcasting.

Sister Alice and Sister Mary will be ambushed by a group of madmen (4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.Cy3A0rsNMPLZozam]{Thugs}) that went crazy due to Little Death effects. If the adventurers did not coincide with it, their belongings can be found beneath the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. Check out the Little Death section below.

Abandoned Warehouse

The warehouse is a large room with 20 ft. wide and 30 ft. long walls. It appears to have not been in use for a very long time due to strange noises in the night. It was abandoned by Father Godfrey to prevent children from coming here and to protect them from whatever problem was there. He used a Faithful Seal to bar the door, which was ripped apart by Alec at night.

Father Godfrey sensed the seal was being broken and confronted Alec and Mamduh. Alec threatened to hurt the kids if Godfrey didn’t help them.

Inside, Alec and Mamduh can be found. It seems that Alec is using leeches to transfer his blood to Mamduh and turn him into a branded sigil warrior like him. Combat is almost unavoidable. If the adventurers do not interfere with the process (which takes almost an hour), Mamduh will receive five levels of Corruption and become corrupted and will attack people around him, including Alec, once the process is done.

If Alec notices the adventurers observing the warehouse or sees them before they enter, he will attempt to take a child as hostage and force the adventurers to retreat. His eventual goal is to escape the city and gain his freedom.

If any creature sleeps in the Abandoned Warehouse, their dreams will be plagued with nightmares of being buried alive while a woman sings a lullaby. Due to this, any creature attempting a long rest in the room must succeed on a [[/save 10 wis format=long]] or can’t benefit from the long rest.

Corruption

This new condition works like exhaustion by means of mechanics; each long rest reduces it by one level, and the greater restoration spell can affect it as it affects exhaustion in the spell’s description.

Corrupted. The creature has disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks but has advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks.

Other than the condition, Corruption has 5 levels:

Level 1: The target sees under normal light as if it is in dim light. It bypasses every kind of vision except Truesight, Tremor Sense, and Blindsight. In total darkness, if it has darkvision or a similar means to perceive, it sees as the normal rules deem appropriate.

Level 2: The target sees under dim light as if it is in total darkness. It bypasses every kind of vision except Truesight, Tremor Sense, and Blindsight.

Level 3: While perceiving its surroundings as if it is in dim light, it must succeed in a [[/save 10 wis format=long]] when making an attack roll, or it confuses the target as a friendly creature; thus, it must attack another creature or lose the attack.

Level 4: While perceiving its surroundings as if it is in normal light, it must succeed on a [[/save 10 wis format=long]] when making an attack roll, or it confuses the target as a friendly creature; thus, it must attack another creature or lose the attack.

Level 5: The target is blinded and sees everyone in shades and colors. It can’t discern friend from foe and perceives everyone as hostile creatures of the GM’s choice, related to its characteristics, knowledge, traits, fears, and other circumstances.

While the adventurers fight with the brute warrior of the wolf sigil, their abilities due to the Serpent Sigil will be revealed and can be added to their character sheets:

The Serpent Sigil. You are always under the effects of the protection from evil and good spell and the speak with animals spell. However, the speak with animals spell only works with snakes and similar beasts.

The Sigil Breaker. You deal an extra 1d6 radiant damage to any creature bearing one of the sigils or its marks. Additionally, if you kill a creature bearing the sigil itself, it will be shattered and lose its power.

The Sigil’s Bane. The sigil’s power can be unleashed upon those who wear the other sigils. For 1 minute, you have advantage on attack rolls against the wearers of the sigil, or the ones who bear its marks. This works as if you’re concentrating on a spell, and once used, it can’t be used again until you finish a long rest.

The Ancient Tongues. The bearer can speak, read, and write Akkadian and Babylonian.

If the adventurers successfully save the children and defeat the enemies, Father Godfrey will reward them with the spell scrolls behind the hidden door if the adventurers ever notice that place. If the adventurers don’t notice such a place, Father Godfrey will offer them two flasks of holy water and offer them support on general matters, such as tending wounds, broken bones, spending the night, or similar matters.

After the quest is over, they will be informed by city guards or other officials that Balian can be found at the construction site of the Church of Holy Sepulchre.

Little Death

Due to the approaching birth of the dragon that is the mount of Whore of Babylon beneath the city of Jerusalem, some strange events may happen to various NPCs, random people on the street or even on the adventurers themselves. These effects mostly to enrich and foreshadow the main conflict and can be implemented in city Quests in Jerusalem - City of God section in Era of the Crusades, or directly can be used in the flow of this adventure.

The most prominent sign is the missing people and their dead bodies. While they delve deep in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre (see below) or while traveling in the city they may encounter many dead bodies, missing people who are dead and their belongings that suggest their deaths. Such NPCs are marked with q symbol throughout the adventure.

From time to time you can use the descriptive texts below to detail the strange happenings and check out the table below:

You have heard that sleep is often called the little death, a time when you lie in repose so akin to the stillness of the grave. Each night, as you slumber deeply, your breaths slow and your thoughts fade, mirroring the final peace that awaits us all. It’s a nightly rehearsal, a gentle reminder of the inevitable: You are mortal. You are close to your grave and your spirit knows it. What is the meaning of a single life against the tides of eternity?

Some nights, a faint, almost unseen movement catches your eye, dancing at the edges of your vision. It’s as if a kind figure, caring and tender, hovers just out of sight, brushing your cheek with the softness of a mother’s kiss. It’s comforting, reminding you of the sunny days. The subtle, loving presence that watches over you is gone once you open your eyes or actively search it. Where it might have gone?

At times, you could swear a distant lullaby drifts through the air—a melody so sweet and faint, it vanishes the moment you try to listen. Yet, this elusive song is not yours alone to hear; many catch its fleeting notes, a shared whisper of comfort that dances just beyond the silence. When you try to hum or play the melody, you just can’t. It feels like trying to remember a drifting dream.

You’ve sensed the unease that creeps through the streets of Jerusalem. People are vanishing, going missing and the whispers of their absence ripple slowly, steadily. Fear mounts, and the rumors that once hushed and shunned are welcomed with open arms, because most people know it in their bones: Dark stars are upon the realm and the end might be near.

In your wanderings, you must have observed at least five souls, their actions unmoored from reason. They roam, they shout, they gesture wildly to unseen visions. Madness, it seems, has laid its hand upon them, drawing them into its unpredictable dance through the city’s shadowed lanes.

Blinding People: Some people lose their ability to see at random times and regain it after a few minutes or few hours.

8

Mirage of the Past: Especially at dawn, people tend to bump into some weird people, with clothes that look ancient at times, wildly looking for something but once out of sight, never to be seen again. Some swear that they saw a Roman legionary or a Greek warrior from distant lands.

9

Benevolent Shadows: People claim that their shadows sometimes act independent. More and more people claim their shadows do what seems impossible.

10

Mysterious Inscriptions: New, hard to decipher inscriptions appear overnight on the city’s oldest buildings, especially at churches. Scholars and mystics are baffled by their meaning and origin. Some recognize ancient tongues and the writings are usually similar: “Beware the mother!” and ‘’Romanes Eunt Domus’’. One of these seem grammatically wrong though.

11

Chanting Winds: The winds winding through the city streets carry faint, discordant chants that unsettle the minds of listeners. Those who listen too long find their dreams haunted by cryptic visions.

12

Subtle Shifts in Light: At random intervals, the natural light in Jerusalem subtly shifts, casting unnaturally long or distorted shadows even when the sun is high. This subtle anomaly causes unease among the citizens, as the normal suddenly seems unfamiliar and foreboding.

13

The Watchful Eyes: Citizens report seeing eyes staring at them from within the stone blocks of buildings and the city walls, especially during the twilight hours. These eyes sometimes blink before disappearing.

14

Wild Life Weirdness: Animals around the city sometimes act as if they know something and are almost human-like: listening to conversations, producing sounds appropriate for a situation (a cat meowing as if it says uh-huh), defecating in public bathrooms (in correct places) and more.

15

Unexpected Visitors: Some doors are loudly banged at nights crying for help, like their life is in immediate danger. However, when the door opens, there is no one there.

16

The Marks on the Body: People that have dreams about having a relationship with a demon or djinni wake up with “qinah” (henna) on their bodies.

17

The Crying Child: Residents often hear the cries of a child late at night coming from the abandoned quarter. Those who go looking for the source find only a small, ancient doll lying on the ground, wet with fresh tears.

18

Where Did I Sleep?: People claim that they wake up in very many different places that they slept but no one saw them sleep walking in the city.

19

Last Breath: Some people found dead with a mirror in their hands. All that they have in common is their trace of last breath on the mirror’s glass.

20

Eerie Words: Sometimes children speak so adult-like and so deep adults are shocked and this event usually creeps the people out.

Church of the Holy Sepulchre: Reconstruction Site

As you approach the construction site, you notice that the Church of Holy Sepulchre has lost nothing of its sacred spirit. You almost hear a faint prayer in your ears that prays to the skies. The walls wish to tell you their stories, especially about a man with thirty silver pieces, a man who prayed at the stairs rather than inside, a woman who carried woodwork to the depths, and more.

You can’t help but wonder how many steps were taken before you. How many dreams faded, or how much blood was spilt? How many stories ended here?

Or how many of them started?

You feel like yours has already started, and you are entering a new chapter.

When you see the king’s tent and his colors on fabrics near the construction, the thoughts leave you, and reality welcomes you. The sound of metal, the hammer on the stone, the shovel on the dirt, and soft paintings of working men are in your ear. The king’s voice calls to you: “Welcome to the Church of Resurrection!”

The adventurers see King Baldwin and his personal guards (especially one muscular and tall one takes the attention) and meet with Sybilla, the Princess of the Kingdom and sister to Baldwin, right next to him.

The tall and muscular guard is called Sir Claude of Paris. He is actually a Sigil Knight resurrected by Guy of Lusignan and is loyal to him. He will be encountered by the adventurers in the future, so it is advised that he be emphasized by description to ensure he is remembered later.

For the princess, read:

A smile covered the woman’s face. A regal beauty shone on her with a touch of subtle innocence and youth’s excitement. Her noble face is the center of attention, only rivaled by the marble mask of her brother, the king. You feel her gaze upon you, judging subtly and analyzing openly. There is not a clue on her face that reveals her thoughts, only traces of curiosity.

For Sir Claude of Paris:

The tall guard has an unnatural stance, appearing calm and confident. Although his helmet obscures his face and expressions, he is clearly a formidable threat to any trained warrior. His dedication to his duty is so profound that it is not far-fetched to think of him as a holy warrior. The strength in his wrist, the determination in his steps, and his lethal skill are plainly evident to trained eyes. You feel like prey alongside a hunter, as if one wrong move could prompt him to deliver punishment.

The king introduces his sister to the adventurers. She carefully looks at each of them and appropriately makes their acquaintances, but she remains silent otherwise.

If the adventurers explain and summarize the events at the Church of St. Anne, the king will be pleased and congratulate them. He and Balian will briefly show the main construction site and the process. An engineer leads the primary workforce inside the walls to a damaged pillar and a large door which goes downstairs.

When the adventurers get close, read:

You hear a certain “Click!” sound as you approach the damaged pillar. Your trained and experienced eyes notice the magical sensation and walls suddenly close in front of you, stopping you from entering the place where the workforce is. You hear the men shout for help and hit the closed wall. Even as one of the stronger ones swings his hammer against the wall, you hear only a faint crashing sound and feel a little vibration.

The king does not let panic take over and immediately seizes control: “Do not fear! You will be out of there shortly!”

As the voice of the king stirs the hearts, the men slowly calm down, only for mere seconds. The men’s voices in panic reach you, and one of them shouts as strongly as he can: “Something’s here, Your Grace! We are not alone!”

The king immediately casts the knock spell and opens the door back rapidly.

After the adventurers go inside, three Karabasans, the Chthonic Horrors, will engage them. Sir Claude of Paris may intervene and help the adventurers to make him more memorable.

@UUID[Actor.sN2Zy0G0riT6cpwd]{Karabasan,}
the Chthonic Horror

Small aberration, chaotic evil

Armor Class 13 (natural armor)

Hit Points 13 (3d6 + 3)

Speed 20 ft., fly 40 ft.

7 (-2)

16 (+3)

12 (+1)

12 (+1)

9 (-1)

Skills Stealth +7

Senses darkvision 120 ft., blindsense 10 ft.

Languages understands two common languages

Challenge 2 (450 XP)

Unity With Shadows. The karabasan can move through solid objects but takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn in a solid object. Additionally, it can turn invisible as a bonus action if it is within dim light or darkness. The invisibility stays until the end of its next turn, until it makes an attack or casts a spell.

The Burden on Your Chest. As a bonus action, the Karabasan can strike a foe within 15 ft. of it and run towards it without provoking opportunity attacks. The creature must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone. The Karabasan sits on the creature. While sitting on it, the creature is paralyzed, and Karabasan weighs 5 times heavier. When any attempt is made to move Karabasan off the creature, it has +10 bonus to related ability checks or saving throws due to its weight.

The Suffocating Mark. When the Karabasan sits on a creature, it leaves a mark of horror. At the end of each long rest, the creature must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or be paralyzed for 1 minute. During the paralysis, the creature can’t breathe. Each day, the duration increases by 1 minute. The mark of horror can be identified by a DC 10 Intelligence (Arcana) or Wisdom (Nature) check or an identify spell cast on the creature.

Actions

Suffocation: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, one target, reach 5 ft. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) bludgeoning damage plus 2 (1d4). The creature is forced to make a DC 11 Charisma saving throw, or their Constitution score decreases by 1.

The Hidden Breath

After the Karabasans are defeated, a newly opened and hidden section of the Church is revealed to you: a wide room with a strong black flame in the middle and a large door made of pitch-black. You feel like you are staring at the heart of the void. The room has no edge corners and no walls. Instead of the walls, you are greeted with flesh, veins, and, with it, an unexpected vibration: a pulse. Like the veins and the whole walls moving like a heart’s pulse and the black veins reaching onto the door.

The door has a giant parchment on it: a seal. It is written in reverse Arabic letters: “Locked. Banished. Awakened. Hold your breath to unmake. Forget the sun to unveil.”

A [[/skill Nature 10]] or [[/tool mason int 10]] check reveals that the door is made of a material known as “marsik.” It clearly has Arabic architectural signs. However, the rest of the room, except the altar, seems to have been here for a really long time.

Marsik is actually a term used for coal that has not been burned properly, a word in Turkish. However, the guild of blacksmiths in Damascus discovered an arcane way to make the Marsik more powerful and solid, “Layet-Efel-Ahen (Stainless Iron),”. For further information on Stainless Iron, check out Act II: We Become What We Behold.

Marsik is a special material that absorbs magic and damage to an extent. When the metal of armor is covered with marsik, it will grant a damage threshold to the wearer (5 damage) and grant +1 bonus to saving throws against spells and other magical effects. If it is used to cover a blade, the weapon gains the siege ability, dealing double damage to constructs. If it is applied to doors, walls, and similar surfaces in large quantities, the door will gain a damage threshold equal to 30 damage and get resistance to all nonmagical attacks.

A quick investigation or casting detect magic inside the room reveals that there is a handle inside the flame. The flames must be extinguished, and the handle must be pulled to open the door. Marsik will not yield to damage and magic.

The Seals of Kings - Entrance to the Lullaby Palace

This is the first obstacle that the adventurers face before they are thrown into the adventure. When the Whore of Babylon was sealed in ancient times by Cyrus the Great, he used a seal and bound her to the city to avoid further destruction by her. This seal, however, was not strong enough. This was discovered by Heraklios, the Basileus of the Eastern Roman Empire who ruled from Constantinople. He further improved the seal.

In later years, when Caliph Omar conquered the city, he sensed the seals’ weakness. He foresaw their eventual downfall, and prepared another seal, which is what the adventurers discover.

Each seal opens a new floor until the Womb of Dragon is reached, where Cyrus bound the Whore of Babylon. With each passing day, the Dragon is getting stronger and preparing to bring the Whore of Babylon from her bound place, an extra-dimensional prison, which will be introduced in the Lullaby Palace section in Act III: Little Death by the Paradise.

The first seal can be unmade by the Breath of the Caliph that carries the last breath of the Caliph Omar, which was put in a device called Extinguisher – hidden inside the cisterns under the city, still protected by his unyielding guardian. This is the first dungeon –which the adventurers are about to enter.

The second seal can be unmade by the Blood of Basileus, which can be found intact on the True Cross hidden under the Byzantine Cardo.

The third seal can be unmade by the Voice of Shahenshah, which can be found in the Cylinder of Cyrus, where Cyrus put his memories and vision of the world. It is located in the Library Pageless, the headquarters of Peter the Hermit, one of the holders of the Sigils of Jerusalem, granted by Whore of Babylon and distributed among the Crusaders.

King Baldwin is not adequately knowledgeable in this whole manner. His main goal to pursue this excavation to the deeps, he believes there is a cure for his leprosy at the end.

The king will tell this from memory: “Where the pulse lies bloodless with the vein, hold your breath – or all will be in vain.”

If the adventurers wait for an explanation, the king will stay silent for a moment and then will explain these:

  • This was the reason he was personally overseeing the reconstruction of the church.
  • There is a strong mystery concerning the room and whatever lies below Jerusalem. The king has seen the sigil before, in a book: an important magical item called The White Book. The book is heavily encrypted, and the part he told from memory was one of the first parts to be solved.
  • The king will reveal that he probably doesn’t have much time due to his leprosy, and his well-being isn’t getting any better with each passing day. With the incident at the Church of St. Anne and now saving the workers from horrible monsters, the adventurers have proven themselves and may have proved that they may be the only hope to help cure the king. This is why the king needs their help. He believes The White Book hints there is a cure for most diseases.
  • His leprosy can’t be cured by even the most powerful clerics; it has been tried before.

If the king deems the adventurers trustworthy, he will mention that if anything happens to him he will give the book for safekeeping to his mother, the Mother Queen Agnes. Mother Queen has the statblock of Scholar of Jerusalem. She usually doesn’t leave the Temple Mount.

The king dies in Act II. So before departing for Kerak Castle, this exchange of the book will be completed. Even Sibylla does not know about this.

When the adventurers and the king focus on the room, a [[/skill Religion 10]] check reveals this: usually, reverse Arabic letters mean “spellcasting” or “communication with the djinni” in Islamic tradition. Many ancient spells and rituals involve writing Arabic letters from left to right (although they are normally written from right to left.) and reading them aloud.

If read aloud, the flames come to life:

A whisper from the depths fills your very soul, as if you hear it inside your skull. The whisper drowns every other sound; you can’t even hear the flickering of flames, only a distant echo in your memories.

“Find where the breath is enchained. Where the conqueror companion’s last wish is restrained. Venture deep until your eyes can’t see, until you feel the breeze of the blue sea.”

[[/skill History 10]] check reveals that the conqueror companion is Caliph Omar, the one who conquered Jerusalem. Companion is the short version of “Companions of the Prophet” and the translation of the word “Al-Sahaba,” which defines the ones who followed, saw, and accompanied the Prophet Muhammad during his lifetime. Conqueror is obvious, as Omar was the most successful Rashidun Caliph, conquered many territories and expanded the Rashidun Caliphate to its mightiest state.

The king immediately realizes that the adventurers should venture to the Mosque of Omar, as it was built where he first prayed after the conquest of the city. He is not sure what the remaining bits mean, but the Mosque of Omar is a really good place to start.

The String of Life

If the adventurers investigate the room further, they will realize the material resembling flesh and meat and black veins is still alive, as if the source of the pulse. A [[/skill Medicine 15]] or an Intelligence (Medicine) (possible herbalists or physicians among the adventurers have advantage on the roll), this resembles a birth cordon that ties the baby and the mother together.

This cordon actually feeds the dragon beneath and it mostly devours on actual blood and essence of the city. Through its physical form, most of the dead in the city’s blood and essence is sucked into it and reaches directly to the dragon at the womb.

It is deep within the room, but when the adventurers reach the area behind the Blood of Basileus, they can attempt to actually wound or poison the dragon. If you deem appropriate, they can damage Whore of Babylon and the Womb this way (check out Act III: Little Death by the Paradise for Womb and the Whore of Babylon).

Dungeon: Mosque of Omar.name: Dungeon: Mosque of Omar
Dungeon: Mosque of Omar.text:
A simple yet strong building catches your eye. At first, among the dense view of the city, you see no usual mosque where the minarets reach through the sky. The building is surrounded by other parts of the city, only showing itself with a shade of slightly darker color and interesting geographical shapes hidden in the edge of pillars and some dusted doors. A few Muslims can be seen inside, paying their respects to the place and praying inside its walls.

The mosque is guarded by three crusader knightsa, and they are there to prevent any problem caused by the Muslims. Very few Muslims or pilgrims in the city visit the place for namaz (prayer). No adhan is recited; it is forbidden by the city law. Only during the prayer can the lead imam recite the prayers. The imam is usually chosen by the cemaat (the current members of the community during the prayer) to lead the namaz.

Many Muslims perform their prayers in silence and without drawing any attention, as some eyes may be hostile towards them given the current situation of the Crusades. However, King Baldwin IV lets Muslims pilgrims enter the city and pray in peace.

If the adventurers have found the note, there are two men right at the small courtyard of the mosque, quietly sitting near the flowers and playing a game of backgammon. Sheref ad-Din may be accompanied by Father Godfrey or another Chritsian priest of the city. He usually spends time here to get to know the people of the city and connect with them. He is actually a Satrap.

In the world of Historica Arcanum, a satrap is a dedicated protector of the world who is dealing with otherworldly dangers and eldritch horrors with the ability to banish them from this world. Satraps are heavily detailed and examined in Empires of the Silk Road and Herald of Rain; for further information, the Characters section in HoR may be checked, as many satraps are introduced, and the main antagonist of the story actively hunts down satraps: prominent satraps from that from that book are Al-Istakhri, Yaqut al-Hamawi, Caliph Al-Zahir, Hayat-Jawhar Khatun and one of the mightiest satraps, Rumi.

If Sheref deems worthy, he may share some bits of information with the party. Father Godfrey may speak on their behalf. Sheref would explain his dreams as best as he can: A darkness gathers in Jerusalem. Beneath the earth, there’s a womb and a beating pulse. The pulse was weak but it is getting stronger by the day and there is a mother in the dream. A mother with a terrible purpose, but he is not sure what it is. Once belonged to the world for sure but became so distant over time, it is now otherworldly.

If the adventurers are focused on getting rid of that threat and would promise to work together, he could explain what a Satrap is.

Usually a man with a serene face, the imam of the mosque is a man named Jaffar (local priest, NG), born to a Crusader father and a Muslim mother. He was left in the streets and raised by the local thieves. He found his way to the mosque and found a Quran among the dirt and dust. He devoted himself to the reading and cleaning of the mosque. Locals respect his kindness and good manners. He also provides food and shelter to Christian pilgrims as well. Due to this, city guards and Crusaders don’t touch him.

He has a special @UUID[Item.wMMPVnYzuMiYLvqd]{hallowed prayer sheet} (common variant) that is believed to bring good luck. Jaffar can be persuaded ([[/check Cha 12]] check, proper proficiencies may apply) to give the prayer sheet to Azize, the mad woman mentioned in the Prison Break section above. It is usually kept in a small room above the mosque, inside a chest with a lock (DC 10) with the only wealth Jaffar has, which is four gold dinars and seven silver dirhams.

The Hallowed Prayer Sheet

Wondrous item, common

It is a @UUID[Item.wMMPVnYzuMiYLvqd]{trinket} touched by magic and, when read by a believer, it shortens the length of a long rest by 1 hour, as it soothes the heart and soul.

Variants:

  • The @UUID[Item.DME6Bx69Sn3KwTUh]{uncommon} version of this prayer sheet reduces the duration of a long rest by 2 hours, and the reader wakes up with temporary hit points equal to their Wisdom modifier.
  • The @UUID[Item.M1WrkOfgGYoxuFMV]{rare} version of this prayer sheet reduces the duration of a long rest by 3 hours, and the reader gains this ability: “Whenever you finish a short rest, you restore extra hit points equal to 1d8 + your Wisdom modifier.”
  • The @UUID[Item.EIRV28gZGGeY8vy4]{very rare} version of this prayer sheet gives the reader the ability to take the benefits of a long rest when it finishes a short rest. However, it must spend at least 48 hours in a place counted sacred by the believers to be used again after 3 short rests.

A prayer sheet’s rarity can be upgraded through the constant usage by a believer in a sacred place touched with the hallow spell for a year. A regular sheet that contains a prayer from a holy text and is written by believers may gain magical properties after the sheet spends at least one year in a holy place and if used by believers every day. A church may contain this item with a chance of 10% (A GM may roll a d100 when the adventurers walk into a church).

If the adventurers arrive here after the Hidden Breath section, they will immediately realize a small part of the wall is covered in marsik. There are two torches next to it. If the torches are blown, the marsik plate will move and open a narrow pathway. It can be detected by a [[/skill Investigation 10]] or [[/skill Perception 10]] check.

The pathway leads to stairs that go below.

The recommended level for this dungeon is Level 2. King Baldwin may spare them four potions of healing before they venture in.

The Hall.name: The Hall
The Hall.text:
The Hall

You see a well, bone dry for at least fifty years as you can breathe all the dirt in the hall. The stones form steps as they get away from the well. The well’s stone walls almost reach a human’s height. Time has done its deed in the underground, and stones have fought back. They look like the war was hard, and there are years ahead before they start to lose.

The hall has seven doors that lead to other rooms of the dungeon. Except for Room E, all rooms have torches with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.MK6gpQMeDFo0cP9f]{continual flame} on them.

At the center, stone steps of a circular shape lead to the well. Adventurers with a passive Perception score of 11 or higher will notice the first six stone circles are not above the ground level. After the sixth circle, the steps start to rise.

The well seems empty, without any water in it. Climbing to the last step will trigger the well’s magical effects.

All stones that have circular shapes are enchanted: a detect magic spell will reveal their magical nature. The outermost stone circle (marked with the letter alpha (α) will create a force field that can only be nullified with a 6th-level dispel magic. The force field will not let any material pass through it from the inside. Anything from the outside can pass through but is trapped until it is dispelled. It is intended for adventurers to be trapped within the circle.

When the well’s magic is triggered, a monster made of stone will emerge from the depths of the well: a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.0m8QyDN52qw9zzOM]{gargoyle}j that looks like a stone dragon. When the combat starts, the well has its own initiative turn, which is 20.

At the initiative count 20, roll from the table below to determine which circle will be activated and roll again for which effect will occur:
