The stone gargoyle will drop a key and two @UUID[Item.W7n6uxt41YIFIWJL]{crystals} that are consumable magic items. When one of the crystals is broken by a creature, it restores 2d6 hit points. The key can be used to open the door of Room E.

Room A.name: Room A
Room A.text:
Room A

You encounter very old ablution faucets and stone tools in front of them. The dryness can be felt in your throat.

In this room, there are marble taps placed on the walls. It is a room where Muslims perform ablution, a cleansing process overseen by Muslims. All Muslims must go through this cleaning process to be able to perform a namaz.

The faucets are enchanted with magic. It enchants the water in an unexpected way until the next dawn:

@UUID[Macro.OmDJg6EHhtcl3CuE]{Roll Effect on Water Table}

d6

Effect on Water

1

The ones that perform an ablution can’t restore hit points for 1 hour.

2

The ones that perform an ablution suffer a 1d4 penalty in their ability checks for 10 minutes.

3

The ones that perform an ablution gain the effects of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.n4JDcFKe5ikzYmAc]{gentle repose} spell if they die.

4

The ones that perform an ablution gain resistance to the next 5 damage they took until the next day.

5

The ones that perform an ablution gain 2d4 temporary hit points.

6

The ones that perform an ablution gain the effects of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.Opwh2PdX4runSBlm]{aid} spell.

Some of the faucets are broken, and the dirt and soil behind them are visible. A [[/tool mason wis 10]] or a similar skill or tool check related to this area of business will notice the water is stuck with a broken marble piece at the leftmost faucet, thus preventing water for all others. If the adventurers spend 10 minutes fixing it, the water flows again, and the faucets’ magic enchants the waters.

Room B - Library.name: Room B - Library
Room B - Library.text:
Room B - Library

Even with the passing of time, the books and parchments gathered here are still holding on to life. Many sheets are scattered around; it looks like someone left in a hurry a long time ago.

The small room is a library and a workspace. Shelves are made of wood and barely stand against the danger of rot. Mostly religious texts can be found, teachings about Prophet Muhammad and his companions. A careful examination ([[/skill Investigation 12]] check) reveals these about the compound:

  • This is a secret Sunni school, founded at the heart of Jerusalem during Shia rule.
  • One of the teachers wrote about the Crusaders' march through Anatolian soil in 1097 CE.
  • They wrote about an important figure in the First Crusades, Peter the Hermit (check out the Characters section for further information). It is stated that he took a personal interest in collecting books and parchments along the way of the People’s Crusade.
  • Most of the religious texts have notes on them in ancient languages, notably Aramaic and Sumerian. If the adventurers manage to read the passages, they realize the teachers are giving lectures about the ancient religions of Mesopotamia, which should be unknown at that point.

Room C - Classroom.name: Room C - Classroom
Room C - Classroom.text:
Room C - Classroom

Floor tables and cushions that have lost the fight against time fill the room. In the corner, a big table stands proudly, without any signs of rot, like it was built there yesterday. You see some glass bottles, herbs, and similar materials on the table, all appearing fresh and stable.

This was a classroom once where students listened to lectures while sitting on the cushions and taking notes at their floor tables, a common practice in most maktabs and madrasas (elementary schools and higher education, respectively). Most of the wooden desks look fragile and on the brink of collapse due to rot and rust. Only the teacher’s table is standing strong because it is magical. A detect magic spell or a [[/skill Arcana 10]] check reveals that it is magical. It is enchanted against rot and rust and protects whatever is on it from going rotten or decomposing over time.

On the table, there are three @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.tables.RollTable.JzLOE4IxcmxjLLuz]{potions of resistance}, two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.ytlsBjYsZ7OBSEBs]{potions of healing}, and one @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.CAZMwFBWp9VC0ZCg]{potion of water breathing}.

Room D - Dormroom.name: Room D - Dormroom
Room D - Dormroom.text:
Room D - Dormroom

Forgotten memories greet you. Rotten sheets, pillows, clothes; broken toys made of wood; hardly visible paintings on the wall… There must be a graveyard nearby for the children that spent their time here.

There are many bunk beds and personal items that have succumbed to the passage of time. Most toys and similar objects dissolved or went bad because of the rot that surrounds them. The walls have many paintings on them. Among them, one stands out as it has endured through the ages and resembles the classic Virgin Mary paintings; however, this time she has dragon-like wings, which the symbolism can be understood with a [[/tool painter int 10]] check.

Room E.name: Room E
Room E.text:
Room E

The room is protected by the arcane lock spell (DC 20). If the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.0m8QyDN52qw9zzOM]{gargoyle}j is defeated in @UUID[.2vpcJpqVXuDq3sPS]{the Hall}, its key can be found on it.

A dreaded carving of a dragon greets you when you enter the room. It appears to gather its might and to blow the deadliest fire seen in the world since the first days of the stars.

A carving of a dragon and four torches spiked to the ground await in the room. All four are extinguished. If all four are simultaneously lit, the carving of the door will lead to a pathway that leads downstairs.

Warehouse.name: Warehouse
Warehouse.text:
Warehouse

This is a storage room filled with crates and barrels. Most of the items went bad and the smell is unbearable. There’s a cursed item that affects this room: A straw doll made by one of the deceased students.

Straw Doll: The straw doll affects a certain type of food. When eaten, it forces a creature to make a [[/save 13 con format=long]] or curse them. The curse forces the creature to have nightmares at night. The nightmares force the creature to make a [[/save 10 wis format=long]] or they can’t complete a long rest. If the doll is washed by a believer in holy water that is worth at least 50 gd for at least one minute in the company of a heartfelt prayer, its curse is gone and affected creatures’ curses are broken.

Room F.name: Room F
Room F.text:
Room F

It resembles an office belonging to a person in charge. The bookcase has many books but almost all of them are in ruins and in a rotten condition. Only a version of the Bible has survived. It is filled with doodlings and scratches, almost all of the book has been deformed by a mad person. A quick [[/skill Investigation 10]] reveals that only one part remains untouched: Revelation 17:1-18. If the adventurers can read Latin, they can easily understand the texts untouched. If a character has memorized the Bible, they can also understand which parts are mentioned.

1F And there came one of the seven angels which had the seven vials, and talked with me, saying unto me, Come hither; I will shew unto thee the judgment of the great whore that sitteth upon many waters:

2F With whom the kings of the earth have committed fornication, and the inhabitants of the earth have been made drunk with the wine of her fornication.

3F So he carried me away in the spirit into the wilderness: and I saw a woman sit upon a scarlet coloured beast, full of names of blasphemy, having seven heads and ten horns.

4F And the woman was arrayed in purple and scarlet color, and decked with gold and precious stones and pearls, having a golden cup in her hand full of abominations and filthiness of her fornication:

5F And upon her forehead was a name written, MYSTERY, BABYLON THE GREAT, THE MOTHER OF HARLOTS AND ABOMINATIONS OF THE EARTH.

6F And I saw the woman drunken with the blood of the saints, and with the blood of the martyrs of Jesus: and when I saw her, I wondered with great admiration.

9F And here is the mind which hath wisdom. The seven heads are seven mountains, on which the woman sitteth.

10F And there are seven kings: five are fallen, and one is, and the other has not yet come; and when he comes, he must continue a short space.

11F And the beast that was, and is not, even he is the eighth, and is of the seven, and goes into perdition.

12F And the ten horns which thou saw are ten kings, which have received no kingdom as yet; but receive power as kings one hour with the beast.

15F And he said unto me, The waters which thou sawest, where the whore sitteth, are peoples, and multitudes, and nations, and tongues.

18F And the woman which thou sawest is that great city, which reigns over the kings of the earth.

*Historical Note: For clarity, this version is taken from the King James version.

This book is considered a magic item. While on a person, it gives +1 bonus to Religion checks and the book is immune to fire damage.

Staircase.name: Staircase
Staircase.text:
Staircase

The steps made of stone lead downstairs to @UUID[.S2hHFflEsbEqDxFB]{Room G}.

Room G.name: Room G
Room G.text:
Room G

The room only contains one black 3-foot-square cube made from marsik. If a creature has the @UUID[Actor.sN2Zy0G0riT6cpwd]{mark of horror from the Karabasan}a creature, they must succeed on a [[/save 12 wis format=long]] or take one level of corruption. The marsik cube stands on a plate that triggers a trap. The trap, when activated, releases a gas. The gas fills the room swiftly. The creatures in the room must succeed on a [[/save 10 con format=long]] or have disadvantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws for 1 hour.

There’s an oil portrait of a man in a sarik, a form of turban among Muslim men, of Arabic descent. A [[/skill History 15]] check reveals that it is a portrait of the Prophet Muhammad, which is a huge form of heresy according to Islamic tradition. The portrait is magical; if burned, it will form itself again after 1 hour. It was enchanted by its creator, one of the first companions of Muhammad, and he was punished by Omar in later years for painting Muhammad’s image.

If the portrait is burned, a door to the @UUID[.T37c98mUUOAXRt0U]{Secret Room} is revealed. The door only shows itself with the burning of the portrait.

Secret Room (S).name: Secret Room (S)
Secret Room (S).text:
Secret Room (S)

The secret room was built to conceal an office room, a table, and a chair. The table has a tiny jar on it, full of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.cGUPm15mLfhGDz2b]{dust of disappearance}, and a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.a26LjC4QxP1oorXC]{headband of intellect}. Other than the items, the room is empty. It has one other door that opens a hallway that leads to the @UUID[.XiRNncpQuZItUVjl]{Room of Hafiz}.

Room H.name: Room H
Room H.text:
Room H

A room filled with crates, barrels, and chests. One chest draws attention with its size in the back of the room. It is a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.hx240PG5r5qpRet3]{mimic}j in disguise. If defeated, the mimic will yield two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.ytlsBjYsZ7OBSEBs]{potions of healing} and a scroll of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.Opwh2PdX4runSBlm]{aid}. Other chests contain clothes, cosmetics, fabrics, and similar objects, but they are not so well aligned with the religious school upstairs, as cosmetics are usually frowned upon. Clothes are mostly suitable for children and they resemble stage clothes.

Room I - The Room of Ice.name: Room I - The Room of Ice
Room I - The Room of Ice.text:
Room I - The Room of Ice

A sudden chill rushes to your face. An unexpected view, a floor made of ice, greets you and nothing else. A chill literally runs down your spine and coldness grips your throat, in an attempt to embrace you.

The room is full of ice, and beneath it are traps. The ice is very thin, and any step on it will cause the ice to begin breaking; anyone stepping on it must succeed a [[/save 10 dex format=long]] or fall into acid beneath it. The acid floor is 2 feet high. Any creature that falls into the acid and starts its turn in the acid takes [[/damage 2d6 acid]] damage.

Room K.name: Room K
Room K.text:
Room K

The room has a suit of plate armor placed on the ground at the center of the room. A close inspection with a [[/skill investigation 10]] or [[/skill history 10]] or [[/skill perception 10]] check reveals that the suit of plate armor is made up of different parts. The helmets and the gauntlets do not fit the breast, arms, and legs.

The plate armor seemingly belongs to a Crusader and more specifically, a Knight Templar. The red stripes and crimson cross are visible on the breast plate.

Developments:

When the parts of the armor are moved from the room, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{specter}j attacks the adventurers, and if more than one part leaves the room at the same time, the specter gains temporary hit points equal to [[/r 2d4]] for each number above one. Until the set of armor is complete, the specter can’t be killed. As long as the set of armor is incomplete, whenever it reaches 0 hit points, it is dropped to 1 hit point instead and gains a -2 penalty to its attack rolls (the attack roll penalty can be a maximum of -6, so the specters can have a total of attack roll bonus of -2).

Room L.name: Room L
Room L.text:
Room L

This room has a suit of plate armor as well, placed in the middle of the room. If the adventurers entered this room first, they can roll for the inspection checks stated in Room K.

This suit of plate armor belongs to a Knight Hospitaller. The same parts as the Templar’s armor do not fit. However, the parts found in Room K fit this armor. The parts that do not fit this armor must be taken to Room K.

Developments:

When the parts of the armor are moved from the room, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{specter}j attacks the creatures in this room as well, and if more than one part leaves the room at the same time, the specter gains temporary hit points equal to 2d4 for each number above one. Until the set of armor is complete, the specter can’t be killed. As long as the set of armor is incomplete, whenever it reaches 0 hit points, it is dropped to 1 hit point instead and gains a -2 penalty to its attack roll (the attack roll penalty can be a maximum of -6, so the specters can have a total of attack roll bonus of -2).

When the suits of armor are complete, the specters vanish, and they appear as peaceful spirits. They are two brothers, Michel (a Knight Templar) and Marcus (a Knight Hospitaller). They thank the adventurers for helping them find peace. They were killed by a Muslim man with rotten flesh when they found these underground chambers. They were bound to kill any intruders.

Room M.name: Room M
Room M.text:
Room M

A sense of celestial serenity fills your heart as you notice the small fountain in the room. It is slightly hot and at the perfect temperature for a moment of relaxation and peace. The steam coming from the water soothes your muscles and takes all the dirt away from your mind.

The middle of the room is occupied by a small fountain made of stone. It is full of enchanted water. Any creature that gets in receives an effect depending on the levers behind the fountain.

There are four levels that draw attention. Each of them changes the quality of the water inside the fountain. Currently, only the fourth level is drawn. Each has an Arabic word inscribed on them.

First Lever: It says “wayanqi” on it. It means “and purifies” in Arabic. When activated, it will turn the water into a cursed pool. Any creature who enters the fountain must make a [[/save 10 con format=long]] or take [[/damage 1d6 necrotic]] damage and receive one level of exhaustion.

Second Lever: It says “sudura” on it. It means “chests, breasts, or hearts” in Arabic. When activated, it will turn the water into a blessed pool. Any creature who enters the fountain gains the effects of the bless spell for 1d4 hours.

Third Lever: It says “qawmin” on it. It means “people” in Arabic. When activated, it will turn the water into a favored pool. Any creature who enters the fountain gains the effects of the divine favor spell for 1d4 hours.

Fourth Lever: It says “muminin” on it. It means “the believers” in Arabic. When activated, it will turn the water into a soothing pool. Any creature who enters the fountain regains [[/healing 2d6+2]] hit points.

When read in the correct order, it reads as “wayanqi sudura qawmin muminin,” which translates to: “and purifies the hearts of the believing people.”

A [[/skill Religion 10]] check (made with advantage for Muslim characters or well-versed in reading the Quran) reveals that it is an altered version of a verse from the Quran: “وَيَشْفِ صُدُورَ قَوْمٍ مُؤْمِنِين” is transcribed as "wayashfi şudūra qawmin mu’minīn" and translates to “and heals the hearts of a believing people" in English. This phrase is from the Quran, implying that faith or the message of the Quran brings peace or healing to the hearts of the believers. The word “heal” is changed to “purify”

Room M directs to the Room of Hafiz.

Room of Hafiz.name: Room of Hafiz
Room of Hafiz.text:
Room of Hafiz

The smell of rotten flesh and corruption of the air take you by surprise. You are facing one of the most horrible things you have ever seen. A man engraved into the wall in the most nightmarish way possible. His flesh reaches out of his body to the ceiling. His veins cover the wall with the manner and the aggression of a parasite. His bones almost leave the body and come alive in this cursed room.

A man, or what’s left of it, remains in the middle of this terror and desolation. The wrinkled body is etched in his screams to be freed of this abyss, and his eyes are sparkling with madness and pure horror. A ruined voice, wrapped in the sins of decades and depths of a fallen heaven, reaches out to you in a strong, pitched, almost feeling like a djinn’s dreaded command from Al-Ghaib: “ibtaidu! khudam al-um maluna, ibtaidu!”

In Arabic, it means: “Stay back! The servants of the wretched mother! Stay back!”

The man in the room is called Hafiz Mustafa, a man who was the imam of the Mosque of Omar in 1099 CE. He was a devoted Muslim and a respected Hafiz (the ones who memorize and recite the Quran from memory) in the community. He met with Peter the Hermit before the First Crusade and deemed him as a dangerous man due to his obsession with “perfecting” humans. The phrase was already against Mustafa’s religious views, as the hadith states, “Allah created Adam from his image.”

He and Peter the Hermit became adversaries, and Peter claimed the city would fall and that he’d find Hafiz and seal the enmity between them with his victory.

During the First Crusaders’ final launch on the city, Hafiz knew Peter the Hermit was coming for him, and he took all the children and the sheltered Muslims to the depths of the mosque, mesmerized by what he found down there. He successfully made his way here and protected the people.

This room and connected other rooms, which are now in ruin and already crumbled to pieces, contained precious books and tomes about Al-Ghaib and many other arcane aspects of the world. He deemed knowledge to be of utmost importance and memorized all of them, kept reading until all of it was engraved in his brain. Its cost was madness. He used some rituals and melted the back of his body with the door as he did not want to be taken away by force to protect what he knew.

As he is a madman with incredible knowledge and many secrets of the world, he is very reluctant to share them, and the only door forward is behind his back. Hafiz may warn them about Peter the Hermit and his pursuit of the “perfect man” but is willing to share no more information.

There are some scrolls that can be salvaged from the ruins. If the mending spell is cast on them or a similar way to restore an item is applied on the ruins, scrolls reappear and can be read. They tell the story of a Shah-banu (a queen in Persian culture) through them.

It is about a sorrowful day in ancient Persia, kingdom of Cyrus. It is ordered by Cyrus to “mourn for a year” because he lost his beloved one. The legends say that no child was ever born that whole year. And rains almost consumed the land. Shah’s sorrow was great and the land missed his Shah-banu. The legends record her name as Cassandane.

As time passed, many of the sheltered Muslims died here, and he buried them all in this room. All of their spirits are trapped here, inside their bodies. If the adventurers attack Hafiz or forcefully try to get past the door, four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.nU8GN8La8DCt8SDb]{skeletons}j will rise from their graves and protect Hafiz. Hafiz is hard to persuade or intimidate; it is only possible with a strong argument including why the adventurers should reach the end of this dungeon ([[/skill Persuasion 20]] check).

Hafiz has 20 hit points and 13 Armor Class. With his death, a small chest can be found under him, and in it, a hammer and a chisel. The hammer has Arabic engraving on it, which can be translated as: “They built the idols; I used it to destroy them.” A [[/skill History 10]] or [[/skill Religion 10]] check reveals that the text is about the day Prophet Muhammad entered the Kaaba and destroyed the idols of the pagan religion of Arabia, ensuring the victory of the Muslims in Makkah.

The hammer is magical, and when it hits an object, it deals 20 force damage. It can be treated as a light hammer for other mechanical purposes.

The door leads to a staircase that goes up.

Platform 0.name: Platform 0
Platform 0.text:
Platform 0

The platform is made of stone and is 60 ft. high from the ground. Other platforms, the central platform, and the only other door on the west side, can be observed here. Two pools filled with water at the far sides of the room can also be observed.

Moist in the Lungs: The place is full of a thick moist. Even breathing proves to be difficult. Each dash action taken in this area and in the Cistern requires a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature loses 10 ft. of movement speed; this reduction may stack. If a creature loses half of its movement speed, it also gains one level of exhaustion.

Other platforms have stone idols belonging to old ages and are covered in moss and similar materials, hinting that this whole chamber was once filled with water. In order to proceed, the adventurers must destroy all idols with the hammer.

Central Platform.name: Central Platform
Central Platform.text:
Central Platform

When the door to Platform 0 is opened, four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.UthHOT7QfZfEIUue]{steam mephits}j form in the central platform and attack the adventurers.

Platforms 1-2-3-4-5 have two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SMfgOsfPgf6rb01k]{flying snakes}j that protect the idols once a creature touches the platform.

Platform 1.name: Platform 1
Platform 1.text:
Platform 1

The platform has the idol of @UUID[Actor.BtdeiM0bdwbui8qk]{Attar}, the thunder god in pre-Islamic Arabian religion. Its eyes are depicted as furious thunderclouds. The statue has 60 hit points and 12 Armor Class. After each hit, all the creatures on the platform or within 5 ft. of it must make a [[/save 10 con format=long]]. On a failed save, the creature takes 1d4 thunder damage and is pushed 10 ft. away from the platform. On a success, the creature takes only half the damage.

Platform 2.name: Platform 2
Platform 2.text:
Platform 2

The platform has the idol of @UUID[Actor.6mo2BbkjO5ZtM3Fs]{Basamum}, the god of healing. It carries two plants in his hands and has a mischievous look in his eyes. The statue has 45 hit points and 11 Armor Class. After each hit, all the creatures on the platform or within 5 ft. of it must make a [[/save 10 con format=long]]. On a failed save, the creature takes 1d6 necrotic damage or half as much on a successful save.

Platform 3.name: Platform 3
Platform 3.text:
Platform 3

The platform has the idol of @UUID[Actor.ddkSp1nMbu13rRZD]{Al-Uzza} on it. Al-Uzza is a goddess of beauty, charm, and fertility. The statue has 50 hit points and 10 Armor Class. After each hit, all the creatures on the platform or within 5 ft. of it must make a [[/save 10 wis format=long]]. On a failed save, the creatures are charmed and must spend their next action to move 10 feet to the edge of the platform. If one reaches the edge and has still not completed 10 ft. of movement, the creature falls from the edge.

Platform 4.name: Platform 4
Platform 4.text:
Platform 4

The platform has the idol of @UUID[Actor.Xz9CjvxrM9DsfcLg]{Shamsum}, the goddess of the sun. The statue has 35 hit points and 10 Armor Class. After each hit, all the creatures on the platform or within 5 ft. of it must make a [[/save 10 con format=long]]. On a failed save, the creatures are blinded for the next 1d6 rounds.

Platform 5.name: Platform 5
Platform 5.text:
Platform 5

The platform has a united idol of two figures: @UUID[Actor.fPoLbPutFd2XduOm]{Isaf and Naila}. According to legend, Isaf and Naila had sexual intercourse in the Kaaba and were petrified by Allah for their sin. The statue has 45 hit points and 11 Armor Class. After each hit, all the creatures on the platform or within 5 ft. of it must make a [[/save 10 con format=long]]. On a failed save, the creatures are restrained and begin to petrify. At the start of their next turn, they repeat the saving throw; on a failed save, they are petrified for 24 hours. On a success, the petrification ends.

Pool A.name: Pool A
Pool A.text:
Pool A

The pool has natural hot water in it, coming from natural underground sources.

At each dawn, the pool recharges its magical ability. When a creature gets inside and spends a minute in the pool, it gains [[/healing 4d6 temp]] hit points. If a creature falls down to the pool, it does not take any bludgeoning damage if the fall is shorter than 90 ft.

Pool B.name: Pool B
Pool B.text:
Pool B

This pool also has natural hot water.

At each dawn, the pool recharges its magical ability. When a creature gets inside and spends a minute in the pool, it gains resistance to all damage for 10 minutes. A creature can benefit from this only once per day.

Behind Platform 5, a door opens to a corridor and reaches the cistern.

Cistern.name: Cistern
Cistern.text:
Cistern

The cistern has 10 pools filled with water, and it only reaches half the height of a medium creature. The water is sensitive to lightning damage. Any creature in the pools that takes lightning damage gets an extra 1d6 lightning damage.

The door of the cistern leads to the final room: Room of the Guardian. The door is unlocked but is protected by a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.8KSVpQZyzius93ko]{will-o’-wisp}j .

At initiative count 20, the water pools have magical auras that pull people in. The creatures must succeed on a [[/save 10 str format=long]] or fall into the nearest pool.

At initiative count 15, a lightning bolt strikes five random pools. The creatures inside the pools, or the ones within 5 ft. of it, must succeed on a [[/save 10 dex format=long]] or take [[/damage 2d6 lightning]] damage or half as much on a successful one.

Room N - The Last Corridor.name: Room N - The Last Corridor
Room N - The Last Corridor.text:
Room N - The Last Corridor

This small corridor leads to the last room, which is empty except for two small paintings on the left and right walls. The painting on the right has a woman in a desert running from one hill to the other, and there’s an infant child crying sitting on the ground. The painting on the left has the portrait of a well in the middle of a desert as well.

A [[/skill Religion 10]] check reveals this is the story of Hajar, the second wife of Ibrahim (Abraham) and mother of Ismail (Ishmael). In Islamic tradition, Hajar went from Safa to Marwa seven times to find water and from where Ishmael cried and pound his feet while crying, a well sprang open: the well of Zamzam – the blessed water. Both paintings are magical and connected to each other. If the adventurers do one of the following or another action you deem appropriate, a secret compartment on the floor reveals itself: It has four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.L887NdWEP5NqHCrQ]{greater potions of healing} and two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.8MPnSrvEeZhPhtTi]{potions of lightning resistance}.

  • Putting the painting on the left under the painting on the right.
  • Pour water into the painting on the right/casting a spell that produces water on the painting on the right.
  • Binding two paintings together with a rope.

The main goal is to symbolize water reaching the painting on the right.

The door to the last room is unlocked.

Room of the Guardian.name: Room of the Guardian
Room of the Guardian.text:
Room of the Guardian

In a room full of water, every hair on your body feels the electricity in the air. You feel as if you are standing at the highest mountain possible, wrestling with the thunderous clouds. Every inch of your body is on alert. Every breath you take is induced by the very lightning in the room.

A fierce creature, an undead with rotten flesh, a red bandana, and thunderous eyes shimmering with flashing lightning, stands in the way between the Breath of the Caliph and you. Lightning surges in the air are coming from him, and with each step from the door to him, the electricity thickens. The lightning surges envelope him, and the thunderbolts shout from his muscles and fists.

The scariest part is his eyes. His lifeless eyes shimmer with fury and dedication. He stands there proudly, like a god of thunder, lightning, and storms. He has the name of Zeus, Odin and Erlik all over his eyes. You feel the wrath of Olympus, Asgard, and Otuken all at once. His voice echoes in the room with a decisive, unyielding tone: “Go away now, while you can.”

A small altar at the center of the room has the magic item called Breath of the Caliph. Except for the central and four platforms nearby, the area is covered with water and considered difficult terrain.

The water is sensitive to electricity and if the creatures take lightning damage, they take additional lightning damage equal to [[/damage 1d6]].

The Breath of the Caliph is protected by his one-time guardian, @UUID[Actor.tjbGf0J0jPGRcn18]{Abu-Dujana} –one of the famous swordsmen of the Prophet Muhammad, made a name for himself during the battles that expanded Islam and wore a famous red bandana while fighting. After the death of Caliph Umar, he inherited his last breath and swore an oath to protect it.

@UUID[Actor.tjbGf0J0jPGRcn18]{Abu-Dujana}

Medium undead, lawful evil

Armor Class 17 (red bandana)

Hit Points 52 (8d8 + 16)

Speed 30 ft.

STR

16 (+3)

DEX

11 (+0)

CON

14 (+2)

INT

11 (+0)

WIS

11 (+0)

CHA

15 (+2)

Saving Throws Con +4, Wis +2

Skills Athletics +7, Perception +4

Condition Immunities charmed, frightened

Damage Resistances poison, necrotic; bludgeoning, piercing and slashing from nonmagical attacks

Damage Immunities thunder, lightning

Senses darkvision 60 ft. passive Perception 14

Languages Arabic

Challenge 3 (700 XP)

The Red Bandana. While Abu-Dujana wears the red bandana, its Armor Class is 17, and he has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Actions

Multiattack. Abu-Dujana makes two melee attacks.

Yatagan. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) slashing damage plus 3 (1d6) lightning damage.

Thunderous Roar (1/day). Each creature within 15 ft. of Abu-Dujana must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, creatures take 7 (2d6) lightning damage plus 7 (2d6) thunder damage.

After the defeat of the guardian, adventurers can find a letter from Caliph Uthman (the succeeding caliph after Omar) to Abu-Dujana, relieving him of duty and attending him as the “Guardian of the Breath” at Jerusalem.

The Breath of Caliph.name: The Breath of Caliph
The Breath of Caliph.text:
The Breath of Caliph

The lamp-shaped object resembles the finest stories from the Arabian Nights or long-forgotten tales from the lands without spring under the scorching sun. It feels almost alive, in the middle of two breaths and two heartbeats. You expect steam to pour out of it and take the shape of a creature, or you expect a magical aura to fill your lungs with might and arcane powers.

The lamp is silent. It has Akkadian runes on it, wrapped in Arabic prayers from the Quran, and the maker’s fingerprints can be seen on its metallic, silvery surface. It has no lid, and its handle is made of marsik, creating a contrasting color with the shining silver. When you inspect it closely, you notice soft spots and very tight parts made from silk and hair. Its craft has faded into obscurity, and its magic feels so archaic that its raw potential could trigger the deadliest spell round right away.

Anyone holding it is welcomed with a fresh feeling of air as if its existence clears the air. Each breath you take is clean, refreshing, and mesmerizing. A clarity of mind surrounds you, and you can feel its breathing. Slowly, very silently… It’s breathing, indeed.

Only an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3OZnNhunvRtPOQmH]{identify} spell reveals its magical abilities.

@UUID[Item.jwTmAL3xtfFNB3LC]{The Breath of Caliph}

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

It has two charges left. Only a willing humanoid who is accepted as the caliph can sacrifice their living years to recharge the item. Each year represents a charge. The item can hold a maximum of ten charges.

By spending a charge, a puff of wind is released into a space within 5 ft. of the creature that holds it, and one of these can be achieved:

  • It can duplicate the gust of wind, greater restoration, wind walk, dispel magic (5th level), remove curse, or wind wall spells.
  • It extinguishes any fire source without exception.
  • If you choose to specifically target a creature in the space of effect, you grant the creature a +10 bonus on Constitution saving throws for the next hour or heal it equal to 8d8 + 10.
  • If a dead creature is chosen as a target, it can’t be turned into an undead.

A secret door reveals itself after the guardian is defeated, thus the adventurers can leave the dungeon.

The adventurers advance to Level 3.

Room J.name: Room J
Room J.text:
Room J

Four pillars draw one’s attention in the room. The door that leads down the corridor has a pillar on each side and one in the opposite direction. Once a creature enters the room, the pillars shoot fire into the area they form (Area A). Each creature enters the area for the first time or starts its turn there must make a [[/save 10 dex format=long]] or take [[/damage 2d4 fire]] damage.

At the far side of the room, a chest awaits the adventurers. It has a lock on it (DC 11) and contains four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.ytlsBjYsZ7OBSEBs]{potions of healing}.

The corridor that leads down the path to @UUID[.qPHrxX3Ug8J9BviS]{Room M} has two doors that open to @UUID[.NkR5i8uSc0zSNd02]{Room K} and @UUID[.LyzFpx2iKXlh5ApI]{Room L}.

Room M’s door has no handle and is made of marsık. In order for the door to be opened, Room K’s and Room L’s development sections must be completed.

ACT II: We Become What We Behold.name: ACT II: We Become What We Behold

Act II: We Become What We Behold.name: Act II: We Become What We Behold
Act II: We Become What We Behold.text:
“I am my beloved and my lover; I am my knight and my maiden.”

-Ibn Arabi

First, light hits you when you leave the darkness. The light of the city and the sky welcomes you bitterly. You notice the dull expression on the clouds and their arrested breath. They are gathering with ill omens and darker shades that are brought from the colorless nights and deepest blacks. Sleepless hours seem to await you as the restless night grows stronger and stronger. Only the abyss awaits because you realize that’s the only option: the light eventually fades and only darkness remains.

Jerusalem: The Dire Winds.name: Jerusalem: The Dire Winds
Jerusalem: The Dire Winds.text:
Jerusalem: The Dire Winds

Section Summary: After opening the first floor of the dungeon under the Church of Holy Sepulchre, the adventurers visit the Lullaby Palace for the first time. After the event, they learn that the second seal is hidden beneath the Byzantine Cardo in a dreaded dungeon they should enter with Princess Sibylla: the Legacy of the Basileus, hidden deep by Emperor Heraclius, to find the True Cross: the Blood of Basileus.

Estimated Level: 3-4

The adventurers venture out from the dungeon and find themselves in the city with the Breath of Caliph in their possession. The city of Jerusalem is a safe place for now, but they may encounter many obstacles as their achievements will now be heard of by their enemies: Princess Sibylla of Jerusalem and Sir Guy of Lusignan. In addition, adventurers may have time to travel the city and visit many sites for numerous reasons, and you may want to create time for their personal adventures, quests, and events related to their backstories after their first encounter in the Lullaby Palace.

Church of the Holy Sepulchre: The Biting Phoenix

With the intervention of the adventurers, Guy of Lusignan and Princess Sibylla decide to take action to protect the womb. Guy of Lusignan will deploy one of the deadliest knights in his service: @UUID[Actor.snsCmaxiyewnj75o]{Sir Claude of Paris} (@UUID[Actor.nBodSqcOWZovDsGr]{Risen Knight of the Phoenix Sigil}a). He is a Frankish warrior who was adopted by a worker that worked in the construction of the Notre Dame de Paris. Sir Claude joined the Crusades as a young man a few years ago and was brutally murdered by the Saracens during a frontier skirmish, after killing fifteen armed men in a dire situation. With the help of Guy of Lusignan’s Sigil of the Phoenix, he was resurrected and given new powers, emboldened by a new chance at life. He became devoted to Sir Guy due to his incredible powers and his resurrection, believing that he was the messiah who was promised to cleanse the world of heretics. Under Guy’s rule, he became very cruel and brutal in his methods, and turned into a monster without mercy.

In addition to the Risen Knight statblock, Sir Claude has the following features as well:

Loyalty to the Phoenix. Unlike other Sigil Knights, Sir Claude can be resurrected by Sigil of the Phoenix even if he takes necrotic damage.

We Do Not Talk About the Sigils (1/day). Sir Claude of Paris can use his reaction to deal himself a deadly blow to intervene in his potential capture. When he does, he takes necrotic damage equal to half of his maximum hit points (51 necrotic damage). This reaction can be triggered by a spell that would incapacitate him, or by some other restraining condition, or when the potential superiority of his foes is ensured with a fallen comrade or similar circumstances.

Frighten the Prey (3/day). Sir Claude’s smile and vitality remind one creature within 60 ft. of him of their mortality and fragility. A construct or an undead is immune to this effect. The target must succeed on a [[/save 13 wis format=long]] or become frightened of Sir Claude for 1 minute. The frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

He usually closely guards the King as a show of Guy’s loyalty to the King. After the intervention of the adventurers, though, Guy will put him in charge of attacks on the construction workers at the Church and engage with the adventurers.

Also, after the adventurers inform King Baldwin that they were ambushed, the King’s suspicions will start to emerge about his personal guard’s betrayal.

From time to time, during their days in Jerusalem, you as the GM can prepare several ambushes and engagements throughout the city led by Sir Claude. He will openly challenge the party for “failing to kill him” and try to annoy them by being resurrected again and again. Each resurrection costs him some deformities in his armor, face, and body.

If Guy of Lusignan dies or Sir Cluade’s head is cut off, resurrection won’t be possible for Sir Claude.

Church of the Holy Sepulchre: Under the Surface

When the adventurers arrive at the door below, they can use the Breath of the Caliph to extinguish black flames and open the door to the lower floors. When the door opens, read:

One of the most ancient fears is assaulting all of your senses: the fear of falling. You feel as though you are walking on the edge of a cliff, with the painful winds gnawing at your skin and every survival instinct you possess. An old saying comes to mind: “Don't look down, so that you won't be afraid;” however, even if you don't look down, you can feel the depths gazing back at you. Your knees feel weak, as if they could give out at any moment. It's as if you're about to fall into an endless abyss, plummeting into your darkest nightmares. All these feelings are chasing you right now and are staring right at you from afar. A terrifying and utterly unnatural void stretches out in front of you, calling you towards the deepest depths of the nine hells.

The way to the second door is interrupted by a giant hole, a rift that leads to darkness. It leads to the Lullaby Palace and the adventurers’ first glimpse of the greater picture that surrounds Jerusalem. If desired, the adventurers can go around it.

The rift has a 20-foot radius, and even to the untrained eyes, it reeks of magic and seems to carry the essence of Al-Ghaib. A dark smoke rises from its edges, taking the shapes of humanoids and similar creatures. The creatures appear to be falling into the rift or slowly lying down near it as if falling asleep.

Apart from the rift, the room’s interior reminds one of an ancient religious site filled with archaic stones and intriguing shiny stones within solid natural walls. The second door seemingly doesn’t belong to this ancient sight, as it has a giant cross on it and a grand seal: the seal of Byzantine Emperor Heraclius. A [[/skill History 12]] check reveals this information for the players. If a player is proficient in Greek or Ancient Greek, the check is automatically successful, as the Emperor’s name can be read directly.

The Rift

With a [[/skill Arcana 10]] check, the adventurers may realize the rift reeks of conjuration magic and will likely travel to otherworldly places rather than below the earth. Its bottomless appearance is caused by magic. Better rolls may reveal further information:

Roll Total

Information Revealed

13

The essence of the rift is not from Al-Ghaib; its nature reminds you of the pocket dimensions of powerful magicians and similar figures.

15

This is raw magic. Raw magic means it’s not a spell or a consciously cast ritual; rather, it happened by accident, due to a creature’s immense power, or a random effect on the material fabric of the world.

17

Despite reeking of conjuration magic, the smoke carries hints of enchantment magic.

20+

The smoke almost carries the same essence as the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.KhwiSi9fwVfUPtku]{sleep} spell.

If the adventurers willingly leap into the rift, they will reach the @UUID[JournalEntry.0jCG6b00WlmXqVjq.JournalEntryPage.IVrV9ndwfZABWBNR]{First Balcony} part of the @UUID[JournalEntry.0jCG6b00WlmXqVjq.JournalEntryPage.jSD97c35ibNK8Heq]{Lullaby Palace} (check out @UUID[JournalEntry.0jCG6b00WlmXqVjq]{Act III: Little Death by Paradise}).

Note to the GM: The players may choose to ignore the Rift and may not want to jump into a seemingly dangerous place willingly. This only results in missing out on lore-wise materials designed in the “Balconies” section in the Lullaby Palace.

Ancient Findings

The carvings on the wall seem to resemble screams and victory shouts drowned in silence, an army as a whole celebrating a victory. They were like beauties trapped in that precise moment. The symbols, icons, and figures etched into the wall with tremendous passion symbolized an ancient victory, depicting the fall of a colossal titan. However, like the emperors whose names were cursed in Roman inscriptions, the fallen titan also resembles a pitch-black void. This time, the name was not cursed by those who came after; whoever carved those marks on the wall had depicted the fallen titan as a consuming darkness.

With a [[/skill History 10]] check, it is revealed that the ancient remains in the room are from the Achamanaeid period of Jerusalem, made in the name of the great emperor Cyrus the Great. It depicts a victory of Cyrus, seemingly against a dark foe. This fallen enemy’s face and identity is unclear, intentionally drawn without a face and form, only made of darkness that devours.

Note to the GM: These carvings tell of the day that Cyrus the Great bound to Whore of Babylon beneath the city of Jerusalem.

Among some cracks in the wall there is a spell that was put there by Cyrus the Great to aid anyone with the correct motivations and power. Anyone touching a crack in the wall activates the spell, and its effect is determined randomly.

First, the creature that touches it must succeed on a [[/save 20 cha format=long]]. On a failed save, it can’t lie for the next 10 minutes. Then, a male’s voice, strong and deep, is heard in the Akkadian tongue: “What happens to the dragon?” Due to their sigil, the adventurers can understand it.

A [[/skill Insight 10]] or an Intelligence check reveals that the voice emphasized the word “dragon” as if it despised it. If the adventurers answer with the sentences below or with a close meaning, they will be granted a boon until they finish a long rest or the next dawn (whichever comes later). They can’t receive a boon again until two days have passed. All creatures in the room may gain different boons, depending on your discretion.

  • The dragon belongs in hell.
  • The dragon must be dead.
  • The dragon must be killed.
  • The dragon is defeated.

If they stay silent for more than 2 minutes or answer in a wrong or irrelevant manner (such as a statement “the dragon flies” or the like), nothing happens.
