The Door

A sacred feeling draws your attention amid all these ruins and rifts to other worlds. The massive cross above the door is engaged in a battle with all the deeply embedded evils gathered around it. Unfortunately, it is losing the battle. The seal is weak and getting weaker by the second. Three holes on the cross catch your eye, as if someone had been crucified there, and the marks of the nails remain.

The door has a magical seal on it, very much like the one Omar built on the first door, except it resembles a hole designed to bear a cross in it. The only thing that can disrupt it is the Blood of Basileus. It is located in an underground catacomb in the Byzantine Cardo neighborhood of the city (Check out the @UUID[.7LfdO7vF2j1nKOq7]{Dungeon: Legacy of the Basileus} section below for the dungeon that it is located in).

If the adventurers take advice from the King, he will easily make the connections between the Basileus and the possible Byzantine remains in the city, advising the adventurers to visit Byzantine Cardo.

A Search in Byzantine Cardo

For shops, stores, inns, and other points of interest in the street, check out Jerusalem - The City of God section in the Era of the Crusades.

With the resources of the King, the adventurers find a small obelisk left from the Byzantine era that carries a number of Greek letters. However, even for Greek speakers, the letters don’t mean anything and seem to be random. A [[/skill Arcana 10]] check also reveals that these letters, their meanings, and the way that they are read aloud are gibberish.

The meaning of the words when the puzzle is solved is: “Only the blood of the heir can reveal the blood of the emperor.” The emperor can be used as a synonym for a Basileus, as the Byzantine Emperors used the title Basileus. The heir of King Baldwin is Princess Sibylla, and her blood can open the door. (Check out the Dungeon: Legacy of the Basileus section below.)

Order of Saint Lazarus

Supremus Ordo Sancti Lazari Hierosolymitani Sacri Romani Imperii

Eyes shimmering with a spark of joie de vivre are visible only between tightly wrapped white bandages, complemented by armor adorned in green. This is how you recognize the knights of the Order of Saint Lazarus. Known for their never-removed bandages, their deadly silence, and equally lethal swords, they embody the unique pride of knighthood with their resilience, devotion, and strength. As silent oath-takers, they stand close to the royal family, protecting them from all dangers. They are always ready, both in their awareness and with their swords.

The Order of Saint Lazarus, also known as the Leper Brothers of Jerusalem, was founded in a leper hospital a few decades ago. The order’s main goal is to care for the people diagnosed with leprosy and research a cure for it. Their order became militaristic over time as their economy relied on donations, and war was the best income source.

The signature of this order is their green cross, and, most of the time, members wear bandages all over their bodies or at least the visible parts. Most of the newcomers and low-ranking members are allowed to show their skin, but those who reached knighthood or entered the order as knights must swear an oath to wear the bandages all the time, both to protect others from catching leprosy and as a symbol of unity, silence, precaution, and dedication.

The leader of the order is a middle-aged man called Lambertus of Martigues (Crusader Veterana, LG, 19 Constitution, 17 Intelligence). He is a leper and his condition has greatly worsened (his Constitution score is normally 6), but he has a special item called Bandages of Lazarus, made from fabrics imbued with a strong ritual. He offered the fabrics to King Baldwin when he learned about his leprosy, but the King refused, stating that Lambertus deserved the items because he served the realm.

@UUID[Item.awLcB8SfaGEuRDE1]{Bandages of Lazarus}

Wondrous item, rare, requires attunement

While attuned to these bandages, your Constitution score becomes 19 if it isn’t higher already. In addition, whenever you receive healing, you also regain hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

Lambertus is a devoted Christian and a man who is curious about all manner of medicine and illnesses, especially leprosy. He constantly visits the city folk to diagnose early sightings of leprosy among them, intervening to take them into treatment quickly. He constantly works on herbs, plants, fungal life, arcane methods, and more in his studies. He is secretly in love with a beekeeper in the city, a woman named Giselda (Artisana), but due to his leprosy, he never approaches her and only secretly helps her. Giselda’s small backyard in the city is on a desecrated site, which possibly lost its grace during the First Crusade. Due to the desecration, some spirits from nearby graveyards may linger and hurt civilians. Unbeknownst to most people, Lambertus spends one night each Sunday soothing the spirits around.

Sir Lambertus is a good man and can be a possible ally for the adventurers if they act early against Princess Sibylla or Guy of Lusignan. If presented with solid proof, he can be persuaded to side with the adventurers.

Richard Lighthand (Crusader Priesta) is the priest of the order and alongside performing his priesthood duties, he is also responsible for tending to the wounds of the knights. After losing his brother to leprosy as a young priest, he decided to be actively involved in helping people who suffer from the same affliction. Once he noticed he could do more than just pray, he felt enlightenment and joined the order to help more people.

Although he is in his thirties, most of the order look up to him for being wise, calm, and helpful. While many in the order cover their faces, whether it is due to their rank or deteriorating condition, Richard refuses to do so even if it means not rising in ranks. As he is looking over the sick, he claims this way is more peaceful and relatable for the patient because showing a face also shows what remains of humanity within them.

The young fighter Cain Ironladq (Crusader Championa), has a reputation for being the symbol of wrath inside the order. With his red dyed bandages inside his bulky armor, he is easily noticeable among others. While no brother-in-arms has yet beaten him in a fair fight, they like to challenge themselves from time to time, inviting Cain to a training duel. He covers every part of his skin, leaving only his eyes and mouth open, devoting himself completely to the order and the Leper King.

Cain carries a greatsword and states that it will be passed on to the knight who defeats him in a fair duel. Cain’s Greatsword is a two-handed weapon but can be held one-handed if the wielder meets or surpasses these prerequisites: 20 Strength and 16 Dexterity.

Cain is often used as the executioner inside the order and as the axeman regarding situations outside. Though knights in the order know they can trust Cain with their lives, they sometimes find his violent ways unnecessarily excessive. He frequently talks with the priest of the order Richard, and confesses his sins, asking guidance from him and forgiveness from the lord. He believes every man he kills makes him more of a sinner but thinks he is too far beyond to turn back and redeem his salvation.

Features

Bandage of Saint: While wearing these bandages, a member of the order's Constitution score becomes 15 if it isn't higher already.

Face of Leprosy: People are afraid of those who are cursed with leprosy. Members of the order gain +2 to their Charisma (Intimidation) checks.

Nerve Loss: Leprosy causes numbing and loss of sensation. Members of the order are resistant to fire damage.

Unyielding Spirit: The suffering and isolation faced by lepers strengthen their resolve. Members of the order gain advantage on saving throws against being frightened or charmed.

Familiarity with Fatigue: Tiredness doesn’t affect those who are used to it. Members of the order can remove 1 level of exhaustion on a short rest. This effect can only be used once per day.

Cloaked: Those who are cursed with leprosy cover themselves in sheets of cloth. Members have +2 bonus of Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

Dungeon: Legacy of the Basileus.name: Dungeon: Legacy of the Basileus
Dungeon: Legacy of the Basileus.text:
In order to head to the dungeon, the adventurers must take blood from the princess. If they first consult with King Baldwin, he will personally escort them if the princess needs any further persuasion.

The princess waits in the courtyard, among the silver towers, under the shadow of the Dome of the Rock. Seemingly peaceful, she watches over the city in an arbor amongst beautiful flowers. While you approach, she notices your footsteps, and without turning, she starts speaking: “Queen Melisende made this garden, you know.” You are not sure who she talks to. “And my mother brought new colors, believing that this city needed the joy and brightness of them.”

While conversing, possible topics include:

  • Tidings of war: Rumors and intelligence reports suggest that levies are on the move to Cairo or Damascus, contributing to war efforts. No one is sure about their destination; intelligence has evidence that Saladin will besiege Masyaf, the Hashashin stronghold in Syria.
  • Possible new heir: The son of Sibylla, Baldwin V, is to be named heir soon, but his newly diagnosed leprosy worries the princess deeply.
  • The eldritch dangers in the city and the mysteries that surround the Church of Holy Sepulchre.

When the adventurers voice their intentions, the princess smiles and stands up:

A sudden smile appears on her face, full of joy and brightness, as if a new spring has come to her side. She slowly unsheathes her dagger, hidden amongst her clothes, takes a few steps back, and declares:

“If you want my blood, you should come and take it.”

If any of the adventurers manage to score a hit against the princess, she will stop fighting and will proceed as if nothing had happened by taking the lead. If the adventurers momentarily hesitate due to shock, she will say: “Come on, we have a calling from the basileus himself.”

She intends to get to know the adventurers better and would like to learn their weaknesses and anything that she can exploit later. Sibylla has to play along with the adventurers for a while because her brother was in the thick of things, and his insight is clear and strong. Thus, it is in her best interest to continue deceiving him and the adventurers until the time is right.

Princess in the Dungeon: If Sibylla of Jerusalem escorts the adventurers, she will not demonstrate her full power. For example, she will not use spells of 3rd level or higher at her disposal except in the face of certain death. In terms of puzzles or other aspects, she may help with the solutions if you deem her knowledgeable or intelligent enough for such an occasion. Especially in the Room of Roma, her high Charisma could be very beneficial if adventurers ask for her aid.

She will defend herself but mostly stay back in battles, encounters, and other dangerous situations. She can be persuaded to leave the dungeon early if the adventurers take too much damage.

While at the Byzantine Cardo, the princess will want to escort the adventurers in the dungeon, an offer the adventurers are free to refuse, but the princess will assure them that she is capable of defending herself.

After she puts her blood on the door, it is opened in a subtle manner, slowly revealing a staircase down to the first part of the dungeon.

The damp air hits your face as if the strongest waves of the Mediterranean are crashing against you. Each step you descend seems dedicated to taking you further away from this world, and finally, at the door, you are greeted by a quite legible Greek inscription:

“...while cleverness is appropriate to rhetoric, and inventiveness to poetry, truth alone is appropriate to history.” - Procopius of Caesarea

Procopius is a late antique Greek scholar and historian who lived a hundred years before the time of Heraclius (c. 500-560 CE.). A [[/skill History 10]] check reveals this information.

Dungeon Summary: The dungeon was designed by Basileus Heraclius to hide the True Cross that bears his blood, which was used in a ritual to seal the Womb of the Dragon. Each room represents an important place for the Roman Empire in general, taking into account the history from 753 BCE to c. 600 CE, as the Byzantine Empire (as Eastern Roman Empire, and after the fall of the Western Roman Empire, the sole Roman Empire) is directly a continuation of the Roman Empire.

Each room has a test of its own, but they are not mandatory, though completing them helps the party gain power through the dungeon and makes the final boss fight relatively easier. However, they must gather at least five magical items from each room and offer them in the Room of Mare Nostrum to advance into the final room, where Theodore, the brother of the emperor, awaits as the guardian of the Blood of Basileus.

Rot in the Dungeon: Weapons and magic items found in the dungeon slowly rot away. There is no specific timeline, and it rots when the item or weapon leaves a room with an adventurer. If it is taken out from the dungeon, it will rot away. If the adventurers defeat Theodore, the rotting effect will be gone, and the items will be able to go beyond the dungeon, taken as rewards by the adventurers at your discretion, except for the Sword in the Stone. A [[/skill Arcana 10]] check made in each room reveals the item’s remaining time before rotting away.

It is up to you to decide the lifespan of the items. The recommended method is once every two rooms, roll for a percentile dice. On a result of 0-30, the item rots away.

The Room of Britannia.name: The Room of Britannia
The Room of Britannia.text:
The feeling that rises from legends envelops you. You feel proud and honored. Before entering this room, who you were doesn't matter anymore: now you are a knight whose heart lacks nothing, who feels nothing but loyalty to one true person, and whose love is boundless. The entire kingdom embraces you, forgives you, and exalts you. All the growing trees, the distant sounds of laughter, and the cheerful voices of children...They all shine here because of you.

But...where exactly is this place?

The colors green and brown surround the adventurers, as there are many trees in the first room. Stone ruins are also mixed in the scenery. At the center of the room, a large rock stands proud and ancient. What draws the adventurers’ attention is a scene from legend: A legendary sword lodged in the stone.

The room wants to test the adventurers in an Arthurian manner by putting their Honor, Honesty, Valor, and Loyalty to trial.

A sudden wave of magic seems to strike you as legends materialize before your eyes. If there is anyone among you familiar with the islands that lie in the north of Europe, they would already hear in their ear an archaic voice recounting tales of a sword embedded in stone, a noble king, a round table, and brave knights.

When any of the characters enter the space within 15 ft. of the sword, a ghostly hand will appear on the hilt and trigger the trials. It looks like a gentle and feminine hand, perhaps even noble. A [[/skill History 12]] check reveals that this must be a vision of the Lady of the Lake. The hand firmly grasps the sword. Any attempt to pull it is an automatic failure and will warn the attempted adventurer mentally not to try again. If not, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qoFEjfrANBdrCP6m]{ghost}j will appear and engage with the adventurers; if defeated, it will drop an amulet of broken tree.

@UUID[Item.1lXliCMXWi1aU56p]{Amulet of Broken Tree}

Wondrous item, uncommon, requires attunement

A wooden amulet made from the branches of a tree that is broken and scorched from lightning. It usually contains a carving symbolizing the broken tree. While attuned to the item, you can cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.8zT7njvqbpXs4Cel]{spare the dying} at will and can cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.n4JDcFKe5ikzYmAc]{gentle repose} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.I2LUSF5ogc7Bj62e]{speak with dead} spells without expending a spell slot. Once you do so, you can’t use them again until you finish a long rest.

Trial of Honesty

If the princess is with them, she will not say anything about the trials or give a clue on how to solve them. She sincerely believes these tests are for adventurers and would like to see their quality.

While the adventurers are getting close, they see a faint figure walking in the distance. A knightly figure with old armor, possibly belonging to centuries ago, walking away from the adventurers, only his back is to be seen. They accidentally drop a Cold Iron Dagger and walk away. The adventurers are expected to resist taking the Cold Iron Dagger for themselves and give the item back to the knight.

This is the first test of the room: Honesty.

If they follow the knight, they will encounter him in a state of meditation, sitting on the ground, concentrating inwards. He seems to be unaware of his surroundings. He does not respond to any questions. If he is harmed, the adventurers are considered to have failed and must battle the knight (you can use the Fallen Crusadera or Crusader Veterana statblock). If they drop the item nearby for him to get it later, the knight will vanish into thin air with a smile on his face.

If the adventurers keep the Cold Iron Dagger for themselves, they will be considered to have failed, and the forest around them will be caught in blazing and scorching flames suddenly appearing. At the start of each of their turns, the adventurers must succeed on a [[/save dex 13 format=long]] or take [[/damage 2d6 average=true]] damage. However, they can keep the Cold Iron Dagger and offer it in the Room of Mare Nostrum or take it out of the dungeon if they are successful.

@UUID[Item.Hxe7rBtgNY052kp9]{Cold Iron Dagger}

Weapon (dagger), rare, requires attunement

You have a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. It deals an extra 10 (3d6) piercing damage to fey, fiends and undead. This damage can’t be reduced by any means.

Trial of Honor

Right after the successful Trial of Honesty, the adventurers find themselves in an interesting sight:

It seems as if spirits are appearing around you and coming to life: knights, ladies, servants, silent oath-takers, cautious watchers, and loyal warriors. Their colorful garments make you feel as if you're glimpsing a style from a very long time ago, more than just old clothes—especially the armor and swords, which suggest these newly appearing spirits are not from your time. Yet you feel you belong there.

Among the eyes that turn towards you, one is so noble that you have no doubt he is a king. Directly in front of him, you see a man bowed low to the ground, missing an arm. His words are the first you hear: “If need be, I will face trial by combat; I do not accept the accusations.”

Then, those noble eyes turn to you, and it's as if your clothes are perfectly appropriate for the setting, and you look as though you have been a part of this place for a long time, and his voice echoes in your heart:

“Then, who among you will be my champion?”

As the man is missing an arm and is only one person; thus, the adventurers are expected to choose one of them amongst themselves as the champion and fight him in an equal way. The way to equalize the combat can include one of the choices below or something entirely you deem appropriate:

  • The champion uses their bad hand/only one hand, tying their other hand to their body.
  • Choosing a champion with a poor Strength score (less than 12) or with other disadvantages.
  • Giving the man a chance to strike first or give an obvious advantage.
  • The champion uses no weapons but lets the man equip a weapon for himself.
  • Anything that willingly puts the champion to attack with disadvantage or other penalties.
  • Giving the man a strong magic item and a mechanical help (like casting a beneficial spell, giving a class feature like bardic inspiration or the like) also works.

If you want the fight to be serious, the man may use a CR 3 or similar humanoid’s statblock, such as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.D5UqYD1EnTrJaMTO]{Knight}j or a Crusader Noblea, but the test is not designed to put a trial on their abilities.

If adventurers prove their honor, the spirits will vanish immediately with an approving nod from the nobleman at the last second, leaving behind four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.L887NdWEP5NqHCrQ]{potions of greater healing}. If needed, one of the spirits around them may give clues to the adventurers that fighting with full force against a man with one arm missing has no honor by directly stating it or implying it.

Trial of Valor

In this trial, the courage of the adventurers is tested. There can be several ways:

  • Putting them against an almost undefeatable monster in a hard situation, such as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.UFW8M3JHzHkxUEGM]{Mummy Lord}j that is about to kill a helpless commoner. The adventurers are expected to try to save the commoner; they do not have to succeed. Cautious ways to distract the monster, such as using spells and similar solutions, can also be accepted as long as they try to save the helpless commoner.
  • Depending on the adventurers’ backgrounds, personal stories, classes, faiths, and other aspects, a source of fear could be introduced for each of them. For example, if there is a cleric in the party terrified of demons due to a massacre in their village, a demon could be put in front of them to test their valor.
  • They could be put in a position that would certainly end in death.
  • Causing them to make a [[/save wis 20 forma=long]] or a similarly hard position that would end in them being frightened, and they can be expected to fight nonetheless.

If at least one of the adventurers proves they have valor, they pass the test and are immediately counted as if they had finished a long rest.

Trial of Loyalty

Mists appear among the trees, and this time, it is not spirits but a dark figure that materializes before you, standing in front of a flowing waterfall. You are sure it is not alone there; indeed, its reflection in the water before it and from the waterfall moves differently from the dark figure, as if it has its own will and presence. The reflection in the puddle speaks, and you can see its face: a witch from your mothers’ tales and your deepest nightmares. The ones that make the dreams come true and seal the fates of time.

“Rí Deircc stands as our witness; our words bind the fates. Speak, reveal the yearnings of your heart. What you voice, so shall be wrought.”

The three witches appear as if they are actually there, and not like the way spiritual knights and nobles appeared.

Ri Diercc means Red King in Middle Irish. Characters that are proficient with similar tongues or with a background close to Irish lands may learn the phrases’ meaning with a DC 15 Intelligence (History) check. Red King is a Scottish king named Macbethad mac Findláech, an eventual inspiration for the famous main character of William Shakespeare’s Tragedy of Macbeth centuries later.

The adventurers must be tested with their greatest temptations. The witches will offer them their wildest dreams and will act like their arrival is not about the dungeon’s magic or whatever is going on here. They are truly here to grant them whatever the characters desire.

However, a [[/skill arcana 20]] or [[/skill Insight 20]] check will reveal that the three witches are part of this dungeon as well and are only trying to fool them. The party can be tempted to stray from their path, abandon their loyalty to a person, a country, an ideal, or something similar:

  • Wealth & Treasure: Witches offer a substantial amount of gold, magical items, or rare artifacts.
  • Power & Authority: Witches promise a position of power, such as becoming a lord, a high-ranking officer, or a recognized hero.
  • Immunity: Assuring any crime or act that is considered illegal will have no consequence for them anymore.
  • Revenge or Justice: Witches offer instant revenge by giving them the chance to punish an ally who has wronged them or someone else in the past.
  • Knowledge & Secrets: Offer forbidden or hidden knowledge that a character deeply desires.
  • Love or Affection: Witches can use an adventurer’s romantic desires by offering the affection or attention of a person they have feelings for.
  • Restoration or Healing: Witches promise to provide a rare opportunity for healing a grievous wound, curing a disease, or even bringing a loved one back from the dead as a reward for disloyalty.
  • Fame and Glory: Witches offer the chance to be celebrated as a hero in songs and stories, and become mythical heroes.
  • Salvation or Redemption: Witches offer a chance at redemption for past misdeeds or a guarantee of salvation in the face of eternal damnation, which hinges on betraying someone’s trust.

If the adventurers refuse the witch, they are counted as successful. If needed, witches may perform illusions or similar magical ways to trick the adventurers. The DC for realizing the fraud is 15. If they accept an offer, the witches will laugh and disappear, leaving behind a magical item proper to their promise but dripping with satire and irony. For example, if they need it for healing, they could simply give a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.ytlsBjYsZ7OBSEBs]{potion of healing}; for revenge, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.tEWhsb2lYF4uvF0z]{+1 arrow}; for love or affection, a friends cantrip scroll; for fame and glory, a silvered dagger; for knowledge and secrets, a letter written in Latin that appears to be from Judas, telling the hiding place of Jesus of Nazareth (a magical paper that has immunity against fire and rot) or something similar.

Conclusion

If the adventurers are successful on all trials, the spectral hand will be removed from the sword, and they will be able to pull it from the stone and the exit reveals itself. For the exit to reveal itself, the adventurers can simply wish to exit the room and the door still opens.

@UUID[Item.BfaQYoKAIIfldkG9]{Sword in the Stone}

Weapon (longsword), legendary, requires attunement

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

When you hit a creature with this sword, you can force it to make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it gains vulnerability to a damage type of your choice for 1 minute. This ability can’t be used again until you finish a long rest.

When they leave the room, they will be greeted with a small body of water filling the corridor they must cross. Each step in the corridor is counted as moving in difficult terrain, and when they reach the door to the Room of Paris, they will restore [[/r 2d6]] hit points.

Room of Gaul.name: Room of Gaul
Room of Gaul.text:
As you are enveloped by the beauty of a fountain and the refreshing air, at the very entrance of the door, you encounter two wounded Roman legionaries. Although you are surprised to see them, they show no sign of surprise at your presence. While their injuries are not fatal, it seems unlikely they will be able to move for some time.

The two legionaries are called Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus. They seek the aid of the adventurers and point out the fountain: A proud and seemingly native member of the Nervii (a Belgic tribe that dominated northern Gaul during the conquest of Rome) stands in front of the fountain with a long staff that has a golden eagle standard on top of it. The legionaries must retrieve the eagle standard, Aquila.

If the princess is with the adventurers, she may give general information on the Roman Empire and Caesar’s conquest and how Aquila is a very important and even religious item in Roman society. She will note that after the defeat at Teutoburg, the Romans spent decades reclaiming the lost eagle standards.

The tribesman speaks a Celtic language, is a very joyful man and a devoted soldier to his duty. He does not need a statblock because he is not technically there. He can’t be touched, harmed, or targeted by spells or other effects. Pilus and Vopiscus accidentally injured themselves while trying to retrieve the Aquila.

He can be persuaded to yield the golden eagle in these ways (or if the adventurers come up with a different approach, it is up to your discretion):

  • In exchange for 500 gold dinars or a very valuable item that is worth ~500 gd.
  • By a dice game: The dice game is for two people. They put dice in two cups. A cup has three six-sided dice. They roll and put the cup to the ground. Each of them guesses what they have rolled. This game can be actually played in your game by using d6 dice. As the GM, roll a Wisdom (Insight) check with a +5 for the tribesman against a DC 10. If it passes, it knows what dice he rolled. And for the adventurers, they can add or subtract their Dexterity or Wisdom modifier from their roll. If the adventurers win three times out of five, they gain the golden eagle.

If the adventurers do not possess a way to communicate with the tribesman, he will offer them a rod of the seeker and point at the door for them to leave.

@UUID[Item.ZMHnw7Jl7RLHvCDM]{Rod of the Seeker}

Wondrous item, rare, requires attunement

This rod is made from a dead oak tree, under the full moon by a shaman. While attuned to it, you can cast the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.SleYkHovQ8NagmeV]{locate object} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.gXtzz9t1DTzJeLr4]{locate creature} spells once a day (each) without expending a spell slot or you can reroll a spell attack roll instead of casting these spells. This feature recharges at dawn.

Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus will give the adventurers a helmet and a gladius. The helmet and the gladius are both magical items. In addition, they will speak on behalf of the adventurers in the @UUID[.6r5YOcIPhu3ZO4qe]{Room of Roma}.

@UUID[Item.r8gBELb1s6IrHNqn]{Helmet of the Legionary}

Wondrous item, uncommon

While wearing the helmet, your armor class increases by 1, and whenever you are hit, you reduce 1d4 damage dealt (you still receive 1 point of damage no matter what) if the damage type is bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing.

Instead of Helmet of the Legionary, an item called Commander’s Helmet from the Era of the Crusades.

@UUID[Item.ZYh5lwKnAjyMBJf4]{Commander’s Helmet}

Wondrous item, uncommon, requires attunement

While wearing this helmet you can issue orders to your allies. It has 5 charges. You can expend a charge to give out one of the commands to a friendly creature within 60 ft. of you that can see or hear you:

F It can use its reaction to move half of its speed.

F It can make one melee weapon attack.

F It can use an object.

@UUID[Item.xGvbOtjmZaerAhE0]{Gladius of the Legionary}

Weapon (shortsword), rare

This magic weapon grants you the ability to reroll one attack roll that you missed. You can use this ability a number of times equal to 3 times a day and restore all uses at dawn. If you drop a creature to 0 hit points, you can restore a use of this ability. It can’t be higher than 3.

In addition, attacks made by this shortsword are counted as magical to overcome resistance against piercing damage.

The exit leads to either Room of Hispania, Room of Roma, or Room of Germania.

Room of Hispania.name: Room of Hispania
Room of Hispania.text:
Instead of illusions, flowing waterfalls, and mystical atmospheres, this time, you are greeted by stone statues whose reality you do not doubt. The room contains nothing but these statues. They resemble Roman legionaries and stand in an awe-inspiring state of readiness. They look so lifelike that your eyes instinctively search for the gleam of serpentine eyes around you, and soon enough, you spot the eyes you seek within a crack in the wall, watching you in a sinister manner.

The room has no exit.

Three Roman legionaries made of stone stand in the middle of the room. They are not actually stone statues but petrified soldiers that appear to be trapped here. Behind them, a crack in the stone can be noticed immediately, and a gazing creature can be seen: a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.hqj2yXtgwt64v3Lj]{basilisk}j waiting to attack. Once the basilisk is destroyed, and the Roman legionaries are examined closely, three pieces of paper can be found among them. However, these papers are magical but fragile, and if they are exposed to damage from a source (vulnerability to fire) of at least 10, they are destroyed. Three pieces, when put together, describe an antidote to the &Reference[petrified] condition that could be salvaged from the remains of a basilisk. The papers can be noticed early by adventurers with a [[/skill perception 12 passive format=long]] or an active [[/skill Perception 12]] check.

However, only one dose of antidote can be produced to save the legionaries from their horrible fate. Each legionary offers different solutions, but only one dose can be produced unless the adventurers have a way of somehow disabling the legionaries' petrified condition.

The princess can give advantage on Intelligence checks if she’s in the room.

First legionary: He is taller and older than the other two soldiers and has a spear in his hands. A [[/skill history 13]] check reveals that he is a tribunus angusticlavius, an administrative officer in a Roman legion. If the adventurers free him, it means that they want a commander and an experienced warrior. The First legionary will hand them a magic item, the Ring of the Commander.

@UUID[Item.YhkuPOkxdb3lkhIa]{Ring of the Commander}

Wondrous item, uncommon

The ring, while worn, grants you the ability to cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.arzCrMRgcNiQuh43]{command}, compelled duel, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3Lo9boi7P2ro6QV4]{hold person} spells once a day (each), without expending spell slots. You can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

Second legionary: The soldier appears to be a classic example of a Roman legionary. He holds a gladius in his hands and carries a strong shield. A [[/skill arcana 10]] check reveals that the shield is actually covered in an illusion. Due to its magical nature, it wasn’t petrified, but is protected by illusion magic. If freed, the legionary will give the adventurers this magical item: @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.NgwrqNa6kkgoPW2Q]{shield +1}.

Third legionary: His right hand is empty and the other holds a shield. Inspecting closely with a [[/skill perception 10]] check reveals that his armor and helmet don’t fit and feel like they were made for someone else. His face also seems to belong to a northern man. If freed, he will give the adventurers a magic item called staff of the forest. If he notices the items taken by the Roman soldiers in the Room of Gaul, he will attack the party. You can use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.K15Yl8JmB5iPircc]{druid}j statblock for the attacker.

@UUID[Item.pqMvocY8ixlyKKAn]{Staff of the Forest}

Weapon (quarterstaff), uncommon

While holding this staff, you can cast the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.VzgFzcmocr1X1cp4]{shillelagh} spell at will. In addition, you can reroll one Wisdom saving throw you failed and use the new roll. Once you do so, you can’t do it again until you finish a long rest.

Room of Roma.name: Room of Roma
Room of Roma.text:
“Friends, Romans, countrymen! Lend me your ears!” A voice echoes throughout the halls of stone. You hear a charismatic and powerful voice, a man dressed in a senator's toga stands high up, and immediately in front of him, a body covered with a white cloth draws your attention. Dozens of Romans in togas, and dozens of legionaries in armor are gathered on the marble steps watching a man. “I’ve come to bury Caesar, not to praise him!” he shouts, and as his voice echoes in the hall, you witness an epic speech. When he shouts, “The killers of Caesar!” he points at you with his finger.

The room resembles the legendary Senate of Rome. Blood stains are everywhere, and people have worried faces. The man on the high ground seems proud and noble, sure of himself and his cause. Traces of anger, mourning, and sorrow can be discerned with a [[/skill Insight 10]] check. He is Marcus Antonius (famously known as Mark Antony), a prominent historical figure and one of the legendary politicians and generals during the transition of Rome from a republic to an empire.

The adventurers are expected to defend themselves to prove they are not the killers of Julius Caesar. However, Marcus Antonius will frequently blame them and point out the adventurers' sins, deep hidden desires, temptations, mistakes, and other things related to the characters. Each great argument will lead to a Charisma contest. Marcus Antonius has +10 to his Charisma (Persuasion, Performance, and Deception) checks and +7 to his Charisma (Intimidation) checks.

The princess may defend the party very well due to her high Charisma if asked to. Otherwise, she will wait and see. Marcus Antonius will not have anything on her, as the spirit can’t sense or know many bits of information like he does with the adventurers.

If the adventurers succeed on a DC 12 Intelligence (History) check, they may recall information that could benefit them against Marcus Antonius. This is a moment that transcends time, and this is not the actual spirit of Marcus Antonius, only created by the magic of this room, so the adventurers may use information happening after the demise of Caesar, such as Marcus Antonius’s love affair with Cleopatra, his losses against Augustus or many historical events which happen during his lifetime.

  • According to Cicero, the father of Marcus Antonius was corrupt and incompetent and was only given power because he was incapable of using or abusing it effectively.
  • According to the historian Plutarch, Marcus Antonius spent his teenage years wandering through Rome with his brothers and friends gambling, drinking, and becoming involved in scandalous love affairs.
  • He was an associate of Publius Clodius Pulcher and his underground crime organization.
  • He may also have been involved in a dark cult, as he was referred to as a priest of this cult at a later time.
  • By age twenty, Antony had amassed an enormous debt. Hoping to escape his creditors, Marcus Antonius fled to Greece in 58 BCE.
  • He lost the Battle of Actium against Octavian (who would be later known as Augustus, the first emperor).
  • He committed suicide to prevent being captured by Octavian.
  • He constantly cheated on his wife, Octavia, with Cleopatra.

If the adventurers win at least three contests against Antonius, they will be free to go. The exits lead to the Room of Germania or the Room of Carthage. If they fail, they will be thrown out of the room, and its doors can never be opened again.

If the adventurers helped Vorenus and Pullo, they may grant advantage by stating their honesty and other good deeds in the dungeon.

Room of Germania.name: Room of Germania
Room of Germania.text:
You enter a room so densely covered with trees that you can hardly guess how far it extends. As the smell of fresh air fills your lungs, you are certain that there are eyes on you. It feels as if, should you take a few more steps into the room, the trees would start to speak, and you might not hear pleasant words.

This is a room that resembles forests in Germania, especially Teutoburg Forest, where the Roman legions suffered a crushing defeat against the united forces of Germanic people. At the very entrance, a dead body of a legionary can be seen and far from it, a magical spear is stuck on the ground in the middle of the room. If the adventurers reach for the spear, six tribal warriorsj will attack them, using the tree cover to their advantage. Consider the adventurers with a passive Perception score of 14 or lower to be surprised. For every 10 ft. they move, another tribal warriorj will spawn and attack the adventurers.

Spear of Teutoburg

Weapon (spear), rare

While holding this spear, you can’t be surprised, and you have immunity to fear. Once a day, you can speak its command word when you hit a creature. The creature must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened of you for 1 minute. It can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns to end the effect early. If you drop a creature to 0 hit points, the ability recharges. Otherwise, you must finish a long rest before using it again.

The warriors can be persuaded (DC 10 Charisma - Persuasion or Intimidation check) not to attack if the adventurers do not wear or carry any Roman items on sight.

A DC 10 Intelligence (History) check reminds the adventurers of the phrase Clades Variana upon seeing the dead legionary. It means “Varian Disaster/Disaster of Varus” in Latin, and they can immediately remember the events of the Battle of Teutoburg Forest. This information will let the adventurers enter the combat without surprise as they will for an attack emerging from the trees.

Secret Passage

At the eastern wall of the room, there is a shortcut to the last room of the dungeon. However, it must be detected with a DC 20 Intelligence (Investigation) or Wisdom (Perception) check or can be directly seen with truesight. In order to use the secret passage, each item gained in the dungeon must be left behind. This will most likely make their battle with Theodore much harder due to the lack of the ability of Sword in the Stone, as Theodore has immunity to normal attacks.

Room of Carthage.name: Room of Carthage
Room of Carthage.text:
A Mediterranean man sits in the middle of the room amidst relics and ruins that look sorrowful even at a glance. It's as if a civilization has been completely buried under the ground, with some parts bursting forth. In front of the man, there are four cups, each containing different liquids. As you step forward, you notice a difference in the soil. It looks as if a large amount of salt has been scattered over the ground, as if the soil had been sowed with salt.

The man's skin is dark, and his eyes are bright but one can also discern his age in them. It's clear he has witnessed great wars, tragedies, and betrayals. He smiles at you like a man who has accepted his fate. “Which cup should I drink from?”

A DC 10 Intelligence (History) check reveals that salting the earth is done to destroy a land’s fertility, actually a curse regarding the city of Shechem. In the context of Roman history, it could mean two things: Roman Emperor Titus salting the earth in Jerusalem after taking it in 70 CE or Scipio Aemilianus salting the earth in Carthage after Rome’s victory in the Third Punic War.

The man is Hannibal Barca, the legendary commander of the forces of Carthage in the Second Punic War.

When asked, Hannibal will not state his name and will ask to be called “the Exile” by the adventurers.

There is a well on the ground in front of him and four taps, each pouring different liquids into the four cups before him. He asks once again which one he should drink. All of the drinks are poisonous, but the adventurers may have ways to neutralize the poisons, which would mean a fifth alternative. In that case, Hannibal will give them a magic item called the general’s mantle.

General’s Mantle

Wondrous item, uncommon

This magic cloak allows you to use the Help action as a bonus action. In addition, allies within 10 ft. of you are not affected by difficult terrain.

A DC 10 Wisdom or Intelligence (Medicine or Herbalism Kit) check for each poison reveals their nature. If the adventurers can’t discern the poisons, Hannibal can name one of them by its effect.

Magenta Liquid: It smells like lavender and fills your heart with the feeling of a morning breeze. If drunk, this liquid poisons the drinker immediately and kills at the end of their third turn after drinking.

Cyan Liquid: It smells like fresh waves at the beach and puts your mind at ease with the serenity of a vast ocean. If drunk, the liquid kills the drinker immediately.

Reddish Liquid: It smells like roses and reminds you of a beautiful sunset. It poisons the drinker immediately, and they die after 24 hours.

Golden Liquid: It smells like a grand bazaar filled with spice and cinnamon and fills your heart with excitement. If drunk, this liquid poisons the drinker immediately. It kills after one week.

The princess may immediately know who he is and inform the party. She then suggests the quickest death for Hannibal, as she thinks that this legend deserves respect.

Each choice offers a different spell scroll at the bottom of the fountain after Hannibal consumes one of them.

  • Magenta - gentle repose
  • Cyan - revivify
  • Reddish - warding bond
  • Golden - blight

If you decide that Hannibal takes a liking to the adventurers, he may share stories, legends, and similar tales with them while revealing who he was, and there is no wrong choice here, only consequences. Would they rather kill him in a merciful, swift way, or give him more time? It would entirely depend upon their ethics, beliefs, and similar things.

If this room happens before the Room of Roma, Marcus Antonius may use the events here against the adventurers, as well as the adventurers can use them for themselves.

Room of Mare Nostrum.name: Room of Mare Nostrum
Room of Mare Nostrum.text:
As you stand at the door of this room submerged in water, a deep echo washes over you, mournful and angry. Those among you who have spent time at sea or lived near the coasts recognize the sound as belonging to a whale, yet no whale can be seen. It’s as if you can feel the echo of its voice, its sorrow, and its anger. Beneath the water, you see sunken ships, skeletons of sailors, and hundreds of gold dinars scattered across the seabed.

In the room, an echo of a spirit ventures: The bane of the Bosphorus, Porphryios. It is a whale that attacked seafarers in Mediterranean and Marmara waters, especially near the strait of Bosphorus. It became a nightmare for the Byzantine merchants and warships. Emperor Justinian made great efforts for this whale to be hunted down and for seafaring to be safe once again. However, it proved useless. Porphyrios apparently beached near the Black Sea and was killed by the locals.

The only place the adventurers can stand is the five grounds that appear in the middle. All grounds have a Greek sign that symbolizes sacrifice. They should put five of the items they gained in order to venture forth.

The water is 60 ft. deep, and the grounds are actually pillars that reach 65 ft. from the water’s surface. The ceiling is 90 ft. high from the water’s surface.

A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals two items: A spear lies next to the middle pillar. It looks like a magic weapon: If the adventurers reach for it, the echo of the whale's voice becomes frantic. Even with the warning, if a creature touches the spear, each creature in the room must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 45 (10d8) thunder damage as the whale screams with all its might.

The other item is a seemingly magical glass bottle with a moving shape inside it: a shape that looks like a whale. The bottle has a magical lock on it. It can be opened with a knock spell or a DC 20 Dexterity (Thieves’ Tools) check. If freed, the whale is free, and its spirit vanishes slowly, seemingly in peace, and the angry echo will disappear. After that the adventurers are under the effects of the bless spell for 1 hour.

The exit to the Room of Constantinople is revealed after five items are offered. They immediately vanish after the door reveals itself.

Room of Alexandria.name: Room of Alexandria
Room of Alexandria.text:
You feel as though you have entered a calm and peaceful room. Before you stand only a table, and on the table, you see a book, an inkwell, and a quill pen. There is nothing else—no magic, no illusion, and even the door leading to the next room stands plainly in sight.

The book itself is magical. It contains the spirit of a sage from Alexandria. When something is written on it, she answers. Her name is Hypatia, once a sage in the famous library. After the first writing, she asks a question: “Why did Rome fall?” If the answer is far away from objectivity, she responds no more. Many answers that reflect a factual part of history and are open to debate are acceptable, such as:

  • It still lives in Constantinople (as the Byzantine Empire, Eastern Roman Empire)
  • Military overextension
  • Internal corruption
  • Economic decline
  • Changing world order
  • The migration period
  • The Huns - The Visigoths
  • The rise of Christianity
  • The end of virtues or similar philosophical answers are also accepted.

She can answer any question as long as it doesn’t involve violence, weapons, or similar topics; what she knows is at your discretion as the GM. It is recommended that she gives clues and small bits of information about the main events of the adventure, such as the First Crusade’s unnaturally bloody nature or ancient rumors about an evil that lurks beneath the city of Jerusalem. She can also be used as a device for personal backstories, prophetic warnings to players, or many other purposes.

The princess can suggest some interesting topics to help you out with the story you desire or some important things the adventurers may have forgotten.

In addition if used for a source on the main story,

Room of Constantinople.name: Room of Constantinople
Room of Constantinople.text:
The corridor between the Mare Nostrum and Constantinople is cut by a shadowy figure and with a question deeply echoing in the dark corridor: “The past or the future?” And the figure elaborates no further.

If they choose the past, read the following text box:

Standing beside the strait is a man who appears noble and wise; you can see the years of experiences etched on his face. He is clad in armor adorned with purple hues—an armor that trained eyes immediately recognize as Byzantine. The armor is of such quality that only a general or an emperor could wear it, and then you notice the diadem on his head. Across the flowing water that splits the room like a strait, you see a man chained to an ancient cross. The cross looks so old that it's hard to understand how time has not taken it away.

The man by the strait turns to you and smiles: “It seems we have at least a few minutes, don’t we?”

The man is Constantine the Great. He welcomes the adventurers and has a few words with them while explaining the danger ahead:

  • The bound man is the guardian of the cross. He has immunity against bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage types. He is very hard to hurt. However, before crossing, they have time to choose a relic from the strait.
  • If activated, the cross shrinks to a tiny cross that can be worn as a necklace or held safely in a pocket.
  • The bound man is the brother of Emperor Heraclius, Theodore. He was brutally wounded in Damascus while defending against the advancing Muslim forces and believed to be dead. However, Heraclius couldn't let his brother die, brought him here and bound his soul to defend this place. The bound nature of his situation made him brutal and angry. He will not show mercy.

If they choose the future, read:

First, your attention is drawn to an angry man chained to a large cross on the opposite side. Wrapped in numerous chains like a demon bound to the earth, his eyes are not even visible. Then, on this side of the strait, you see a man wearing a turban and Eastern garments that do not feel specific to this era or the past. The man has a prominent nose and black hair, a curved sword hanging at his waist, and he smiles upon seeing you.

"Welcome to Konstantiniyye!”

The word 'Konstantiniyye' catches you off guard. It means the city of Constantine, for sure, but he said it with a touch of the Levant.

This man, Sultan Mehmed II of the Ottomans, will be the conqueror of Constantinople in 1453 CE. The emperor of a yet unexisting empire. He’d love to hear about the adventurers’ lives, especially any stories of Saladin. Seemingly, Mehmed sees himself as an heir of Saladin’s deeds and wants to make sure that he will conquer Jerusalem, no matter what. However, he is reluctant to share some details about Baldwin and his time of death, stating that it is unclear. A DC 15 Wisdom (Insight) check reveals that Mehmed respects Baldwin, and is sad about the talks of his death, pointing out the possibility that he will not live that long.

The princess will be very interested and insist on learning the fate of the future, especially the kingdom and her brother. However, Mehmed’s vague answers will upset her dearly.

Mehmed will also express the dangers ahead and warn them of one final thing: “Your journey at the end, towards the unknown and unfamiliar, the Ruya (dream for Arabic) may need your sacrifices.”

The strait has four spell scrolls:

  • Scorching Ray
  • Shatter
  • Slow
  • Mass Healing Word

After one of the spell scrolls is taken, Theodore’s chains will shatter and free him, thus engaging in battle. The other spell scrolls will vanish right after.

After his defeat, the adventurers can take the Blood of Basileus, which Heraclius believed to be the True Cross itself.

Blood of Basileus

You can almost hear the sobs of a devout man upon finding the enormous cross. Its religious significance is right there, in front of your eyes; you can’t deny it. Even if you have never engaged with any religion, you can sense what the cross before you has influenced: fallen empires, rising kingdoms, crowned kings, and temples that were erected in its name flash before your eyes. Perhaps it stands as the symbol of a god, not exalted among dozens of other gods in a forest, but as a solitary name, the symbol of a single god: The God.

The bloodstains still mark it. The rust from the nails used to pierce hands and the holes they made remain as well. Whether this is truly the cross used by the Romans who sought to crucify Jesus of Nazareth, you cannot say, but you are certain that it has witnessed the tears of the Byzantine Emperor Heraclius and the bloodshed here.

Blood of Basileus, the True Cross

Wondrous item, uncommon

With a command word used as a bonus action, this magic cross can change its size from large to tiny (it can’t become small or medium, only large or tiny).

If a creature voluntarily gives its blood to the cross, the blood’s essence is protected and makes the target’s Constitution score 23 (+6) if it isn’t higher already. It can’t be turned to an undead and is immune to any spell that is 4th level or lower, except the ones that it accepts.

The cross can carry three people's blood and essence. It currently has all three fulfilled, and newer ones can’t be added without removing one. If one is to be removed, the body or soul of a random occupant is cursed with the worst kind of undeath.

Church of the Holy Sepulchre: The Second.name: Church of the Holy Sepulchre: The Second Rift
Church of the Holy Sepulchre: The Second.text:
After the Blood of Basileus is placed in the hole described in the Under the Surface section above, a new staircase reveals itself. While the adventurers follow it, they encounter a second rift like the one before. If they willingly leap, they will find themselves in the Second Balcony (Check out Act III: Little Death by the Paradise) and experience the events there.

The new seal appears before them to guard the last door: A harp with a stone tablet near it. It says in Old Persian: “I, Cyrus the Great, hereby bound the whore’s spirit, chained its offspring. The darkness yet grows, I know. Once the day of doom approaches, only the greatest song will guide the way. The song of my soul.”

All the legends you may have heard about Cyrus the Great come to your mind: The great warrior who brought the world to its knees. Now, his wish is to find him a song. You feel the histories may not paint the whole picture for you and Cyrus has a different story to be told.

The last seal can be opened by the Voice of Shahenshah, the Cylinder of Cyrus. It is hidden in the Pyramid of Khufu.

Other than the seal, the black veins and the cord that feeds the dragon is more visible through the wall. If the adventurers try to strike it down, cut it open or deal damage through magic, they must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain one level of exhaustion for each failed attempt. When that happens, they hear in their mind a scream of a child, so loud and so full of sorrow, it also deals 21 (6d6) psychic damage.

Phoenix Rising.name: Phoenix Rising
Phoenix Rising.text:
Story Moment: The Phoenix’s Voice

After the adventurers venture out from the dungeon, they will be summoned to the Temple Mount by the king. When they arrive, they stumble upon a council meeting on the news of Saracen movements in the border towns and cities. There is troubling news that Saladin is gathering his armies and the peace is threatened. The adventurers will be introduced as “bodyguards” if necessary but will not draw any attention as the nobles and commanders are very much worried about the developments.

A few moments later, Guy of Lusignan enters the courtyard:

The sound of footsteps echoes on the marble floor, cutting through conversations as dozens of men march. All eyes focus on one figure: a man as graceful as the moon and sun, whose confident steps seem to claim the land of Jerusalem itself, inviting the entire kingdom to submit to his power and elegance. His sky-blue eyes are as bright as a sunlit day, piercing through the nobles and commanders with his furrowed brows, as if his gaze alone could penetrate their armor.

Standing before you is Guy of Lusignan: exuding a refined power, a noble posture, and eyes as sharp as a hawk's. His armor bears traces of blood, clearly not his own.

What stands out most prominently is the three heads he holds in his hand. He lifts them high with pride and almost spitefully addresses all the nobles, starting to speak with a voice as smooth as the finest silk yet as scorching as a midsummer day: “Spies of Saladin! Right under our noses! Are we still going to discuss what is to be done here like worried old men, or are we going to act against the enemies that surround us?”

The three heads were recently cut from their bodies, and their expression is horrible. Most of the crowd reacts with uncomfortable faces and troubled voices. Some of the nobles openly state their discomfort by questioning Sir Guy about his intentions.

Before events lead to discourse among nobles, the king intervenes and silences both parties, declaring that Guy’s service means a lot and that he’d like to see the evidence of these men’s treachery.

One of the heads belonged to Sheref ad-Din (Scholar of Cairoa), and if adventurers missed him in the Act I, this information is important: he was actually a Satrap: In the world of Historica Arcanum, a satrap is a dedicated protector of the world who is dealing with otherworldly dangers and eldritch horrors with the ability to banish them from this world. Satraps are heavily detailed and examined in Empires of the Silk Road and Herald of Rain; for further information, the Characters section in HoR may be checked, as many satraps are introduced, and the main antagonist of the story actively hunts down satraps: prominent satraps from that from that book are Al-Istakhri, Yaqut al-Hamawi, Caliph Al-Zahir, Hayat-Jawhar Khatun and one of the mightiest satraps, Rumi.

If your story consists of Satraps, all have the following features:

Otherworldly Calling. The satrap is sensitive to otherworldly events and receives dreams as a warning and a call to action if a strong influence from other worlds exists nearby. The satrap also learns the location of otherworldly interference with the material world.

Ritual of the Thousand Nights. The satrap can spend 10 minutes to close a rift, portal, or a similar influence from other planes of existence by maintaining concentration for a full duration (as if concentrating on a spell). The satrap must be able to speak and see the otherworldly presences and must not be incapacitated. If the concentration is not broken for the whole period, the portal closes, and all magic, depending on its existence, ends. Additionally, the satrap may target a creature that does not belong in the material world and use an action in an attempt to banish it. The target must succeed on a DC 16 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, it is banished to its original plane of existence and won’t be able to return to the material world for one year and one day. On a success, it takes 27 (6d8) psychic damage that cannot be reduced in any way.

Wisdom of the Otherworlds. The satrap’s Wisdom score is 21 if it was lower before becoming a satrap.

If the adventurers didn’t meet him before these pieces of information may be important: Sheref ad-Din came to Jerusalem as he sensed the rise of the dragon and the ascension of Whore of Babylon. However, Guy of Lusignan and Sibylla of Jerusalem discovered his presence and acted before him. A satrap is powerful against otherworldly entities and events, but he was ambushed by Guy’s loyal soldiers, without any otherworldly interference. Guy rapidly killed him and his two aides and placed false evidence as if they were Saladin’s spies.

Before the matters can be handled with delicate care, a herald rushes in and declares an important event:

Saladin is on the move to Kerak Castle with a significant force, at least ten thousand strong.

The king assesses the situation and decides on war. With the excitement spreading in the courtyard, he signals Balian to give the adventurers this message: “Before our departure to Kerak, investigate the men killed. Guy is not honest about this. Go to The Archbishop tavern and see Oswald; he might have heard something from the street.”

Guy won’t let anyone touch or examine the heads, but a look from afar may be successful in detecting an important clue: With a DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check, one of the heads is revealed to bear a marking, a tattoo that seemingly exceeds the head and would continue towards the body from the neck. If the body is found, valuable information can be gained.

On the Trail

Adventurers visiting “The Archbishop” are greeted by one of the residents. For more info about the tavern, check out the Jerusalem - The City of God section in the Era of the Crusades. Residents state that Oswald (Local Priesta) just left for a stroll in the Byzantine Cardo, and the adventurers can find him or wait for him inside the tavern.

In a case where adventurers wait for his return, Oswald doesn’t take too long to come back. Hearing the adventurers coming along with regards from Balian, he tells them he was taking a walk to speak with his connections and heard about shady business happening around the butcher shop. If the adventurers want to learn more details about this butcher shop, Oswald tells them he usually avoids visiting there because he dislikes the taste of its meat, but advises visiting the beggar on the street, claiming he should know more about the situation.

The informant who gave this information to Oswald is a half-crazy beggar named Pierre (Commonerj). He usually sits around the Byzantine Cardo and is known by the locals. If adventurers go after Oswald while he is on the walk, they encounter him as he is paying Pierre a visit and chatting with him. When talked with, Pierre informs adventurers about a shady business occurring behind the butcher shop “The Cleaver” the night before. He says he saw two figures make some kind of agreement, one looking like a thin figure while the other looks bulkier. “After some talking, they shook hands and exchanged something like a body, dragging it between them.” If Sir Claude isn’t decapitated before this moment, a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Insight) check reveals that the description of the bulkier man closely resembles Sir Claude.

Adventurers visiting “The Cleaver” during the daytime are greeted by Willa (Acolytej) at the shop. While she is greeting them inside, Isabel (Handmaiden of Jahih) steps out from the door behind the counter to speak to Willa. For more info about “The Cleaver,” check out Jerusalem - The City of God section in the Era of the Crusades. On a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check or with a DC 13 Passive Perception, adventurers notice a glimpse of the room inside as Isabel leaves and see remains of humanoid body parts. Surprised by the company of the adventurers, instead of speaking, Isabel takes a cleaver hanging from the wall and returns to the room in the back. A successful DC 14 Wisdom (Insight) check reveals that she was disturbed by the unexpected company. If the adventurers consume any products from the place after seeing these body parts, they must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw, or they will gain 1 level of exhaustion due to vomiting. The residents of this shop secretly conduct various rituals inside the backroom using humanoid body parts and would fight those who might intervene.

During the nighttime, the store must be entered illicitly. The adventurers must make a DC 13 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check to unlock either the back or front door of the shop. The locks aren’t sturdy, but attempting to force them open in a brutal manner, such as by breaking them, would make enough noise to draw attention if they fail to succeed on a DC 16 Dexterity (Stealth) check. On a failed save, if he hasn’t been decapitated before, Sir Claude sneaks up on the adventurers when they start investigating the body inside, initiating combat.

Inside “The Cleaver” there are two rooms. The front door opens to the main entrance, where a counter stained with blood stands alongside knives and cleavers hanging from the wall. Behind this counter, there is a door that opens to the backroom and it isn’t locked. This backroom is also reachable from the rear entrance, and it is the place where the tattooed body lies naked on a table. On the other side of the room, a second table displays the diseased Satrap’s belongings and his severed hand. Upon investigation, a chess piece and an unfinished letter stand out on the table besides his daily wear. A successful DC 12 Intelligence (History) check reveals that carrying a chess piece indicates that this man was actually a Satrap.

The unfinished letter follows:

“Peace be unto you, Saladin. As I have sensed and investigated this evil, I have located that the evil roots deep beneath the Church of the Holy Sepulcher. As I was pursuing the source of this matter to end it, I noticed some knights inside the city may be upon me, not wanting me to dig into this unholy subject…”

The letter is signed as “Sheref ad-Din,” but most of the page still remains empty. This letter indicates that these Satraps weren’t against the Crusaders and was against the dark forces.

Kerak Castle: The Wolfsbane.name: Kerak Castle: The Wolfsbane
Kerak Castle: The Wolfsbane.text:
Section Summary: They will travel to Kerak Castle with King Baldwin, bearing the dire news about Raynald of Chatillon. They will witness Sultan Saladin and King Baldwin speak in private and will be commanded by the king that Raynald should be killed. They will be let into the castle by Saladin himself at nightfall, and they will attempt to kill Raynald of Chatillon, Lord of Kerak.

A great host is assembled to leave the city and launch the offensive against Saladin’s invading forces near Kerak Castle. The king personally asks adventurers to come with him, stay nearby, and observe. The rumor has it that Sir Raynald of Chatillon broke the truce and killed Saladin’s sister. That’s why Saladin hastily took offense against him, especially moving forward to Kerak Castle.

As dawn broke over the ancient walls of Jerusalem, the air hummed with a tension that could slice through steel. The gates groaned open, revealing the host of Baldwin IV's loyal soldiers, a sight that could stir the soul of any beholder. Clad in burnished armor that caught the first light of the sun, the soldiers moved as one strong and proud entity, their determination palpable in the air could be felt from afar, perhaps enough to unsettle Saladin’s heart once more.

When you set out to leave the city, the silver sea called the Crusader Army marches before your eyes toward the city’s exit. It resembles an endless silver sea with an unforgivable storm, shining under the scorching dawn with bravery and devotion. Each soldier leaving the city gates behind knows they may not be back and see their city again.

As the spearhead, Baldwin IV rode with the might of a king, Godfrey’s descendent and a pillar of courage. His presence ignited the knights' and foot soldiers' hearts and stirred their souls, turning their fears into a fierce resolve. Each step they took out of the sacred city was a defiant beat in the rhythm of an upcoming battle, the last breath taken before a destructive storm.

Flags bearing the golden cross upon a white surface fluttered like the wings of Michael, the commander of heaven’s angel forces, above them. Their fight against the strong wind proved their determination to everyone, ending the silent prayers that filled the hearts and mouths of soldiers and civilians watching them leave the city. This was not merely an army—it was the king’s fist, will, and devotion to a cause; a silver hammer waiting to defend the city and strike the enemies where needed, although you are not sure where the real adversaries reside.

As the army marched forth, the rising sun cast long shadows behind them as if skies themselves paused to watch, beholding a moment worthy of all the heavens above them.

The road to Kerak Castle is about a two-day march. Since it is a supplied and relatively close settlement, no problem is expected along the way. However, you can have the adventurers act as a reconnaissance group or a scouting party if you do not want the road to be that safe.

The tables below can also be used for the Road to Cairo section in the upcoming pages.

Random Event

Body parts sticking out of the sand point to a battle that happened not so long ago. Roll on the encounter table. The creature adventurers face is what caused this massacre and is hostile towards them.

A man-made water well stands in the drouthy land making an interesting sight to behold. A bedouin warriorh approaches from afar and states that it belongs to his tribe. He doesn’t let the adventurers drink from it and runs back to gather allies for combat (1d6 Bedouin Warriors).
