A group of traveling artistsa sit under a canopy playing their instruments. They welcome the adventurers under the shade and offer delicious drinks. The adventurers are given a Saharan Headband weaved by a bedouin fabrics spell, but in return the traveling artists ask for a story to be granted to them.

12

At a distance, a Chol-Shaha chases down a fennec fox as its prey. If adventurers take no action, the fennec fox is devoured by the Chol-Shah.

Kerak Castle is a heavily fortified keep held by Sir Raynald of Chatillon. However, it is closely surrounded by another army: the Saracens of Syria and Egypt under the command of Saladin.

This is probably the first time the player characters meet with Saladin unless they have a different background.

As the horns of the Saracen army echoed towards the Dead Sea under the eternal blue sky, all of heaven and hell held their breath. Was the impending battle a harbinger of the apocalypse? Would the birds now sing only of the dead and the blood spilled? Would thousands perish before reaching Noah's Ark? Would the evil lurking beneath the earth triumph because of a handful of warmongers? How would they describe this day in the future, looking back at the honorable confrontation of two men? Was this the unleashing of hell and the herald of doom?

The horns of Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub, the Sultan of Syria and Egypt, had not sounded so defiant and furious for a long time. Even the angels, demons, and gods turned their gaze upon Kerak Castle, while Baldwin never shifted his eyes from the enemies before him.

Before you stand an army made of gold, invincible and proud, with their red banners high in the sky, proudly declaring their bravery and decisiveness. They await, watch, and perhaps count down to the spark that will kindle the most destructive storm the Holy Lands have ever seen. You never had the chance to see the faces among the Saracen army, but you feel no trace of fear in them, not even a fragment, and then you grasp the unfortunate deed of the Lord of Kerak, who flies the wolf-covered banner. You see more clearly how he has brought unwilling kings to face each other and that every drop of blood spilled will be drowned into the earth and into oblivion.

Scene: Parley Before the Storm.name: Scene: Parley Before the Storm
Scene: Parley Before the Storm.text:
In this scene, King Baldwin does not expect the adventurers to listen to the conversation between the king and the sultan. The sultan will use telepathic bond spells to prevent this. However, if you wish for the characters to hear what they say, you can ignore this and let them hear. It was a narrative choice to keep the Sultan’s and King’s conversation more mysterious.

King Baldwin would like to meet with Saladin; thus, he sends envoys to declare this. He may choose one of the adventurers for this mission. Saladin will accept the meeting, and eventually, two great kings will slowly ride towards each other, alone and out of earshot. Baldwin himself will personally order or advise (depending on how they would react) the adventurers not to listen to the conversation between him and Saladin. If he must, he will phrase this as the last wish of a dying man.

Now, there, the two most powerful men of the Holy Lands converse with each other, deciding the fates of thousands… or tens of thousands. With two words coming out of their lips, they could change the known world forever.

Both of them are aware of this sorrowful reality. You sense the weight of their crowns. The gold must be cold and heavy on the head. Both kings know this better than anyone, and they have nothing else to do but accept their duty. The crown may have chosen them, or they may have taken the crown for themselves, but it won’t matter in the end: They will decide how the future generations will remember them. Which bards will sing about them? Which poets will make them immortal in their words? Or is there someone in the future making stories about them, crafting their legends for generations to come? You’ll never know, but you have a feeling that history will never forget these men.

King Baldwin and Sultan Saladin will speak about these subjects:

  • The unforgivable crime Raynald of Chatillon committed: Baldwin will personally apologize about that and ensure that if Saladin hadn’t come here, he would have himself and punished Raynald.
  • The war negotiation: Baldwin will ask Saladin to retreat and wants to secure the continuation of their truce. He suspects Raynald has darker intentions and Baldwin is intended to find out.
  • The remaining life: Baldwin admits that he is at his limits, coming to an end of his journeys. The excavation in the Church of Resurrection probably won’t yield a cure for leprosy. He will also thank Saladin for his guidance on the seals and the little hope he had for a cure.
  • The Cylinder of Cyrus: Saladin will inform Baldwin that Ismail Al-Jazari knows where the last seal is. He is about to obtain it.
  • The adventurers: Baldwin will describe the adventurers and their personalities. He will inform Saladin that they could be of use, and if they ever travel to Cairo, they should be accepted as guests. If the adventurers have a good relationship with the king and mostly act towards his desires and the general good of the realm; he would speak highly of them and assure Saladin that they can be trusted.
  • And any other topic you’d like included.

Saladin agrees to withdraw his armies, and Baldwin enters the castle with dozens of Crusaders at his side.

Raynald of Chatillon has already arranged a welcome party. However, you are not sure whether all this fuss is out of respect or includes heavy mockery. Raynald forces his hand, it seems. The colors are too much, almost all of the castle is there at the courtyard, ordered to be there. The king senses Raynald's intentions and recognizes how he's becoming too much for all of this.

Raynald bows all the way to the ground, his forehead almost touching it. He welcomes the king with all his titles and more, overdoing every step, showing too much respect and being everything he is not. The King dismounts from his horse and refuses all the help he was offered. He walks by himself. Your eyes are trained and experienced, you notice his fragility, his vanishing health and his diminishing flame within. He approaches the beast in front of him. He realizes the charade; perhaps all of Kerak and the Holy Lands know it. Everyone knows Raynald’s intentions, or at least they do not disturb the king’s walk with their doubts and opinions.

But you know.

Each step taken by the king is filled with agony. He hides it well, maybe too well. His grace is on the edge, about to vanquish. His temper is at the limits, even rivaling the scorching sun in the sky. His pain is unbearable, but it’s not just his leprosy. He feels the upcoming doom in his bones, but as the man who’s done everything to protect the kingdom, he is about to fail.

When Raynald’s words are over, the silence becomes so thick that when the king removes his glove, even the farthest soldier knows what is going on. The slap on Raynald’s face is so hard that one could think thunder had struck from the skies, as if God himself were angry at the lord of Kerak, the beast within the kingdom.

Raynald laughs. He enjoyed the pain and he is used to his blood spilling. You are now sure: He attacked the Mother’s Hand. He killed Yakup, and he is indeed the carrier of that sigil. You feel your sigil’s anticipation, eagerness. It wants to be the one that attacks Raynald.

When Raynald laughs, the king becomes angrier. He strikes and strikes. There is no magic, nothing arcane or mysterious about it. It is all on sight and real. The blood of Raynald sows the soil, and while he enjoys it, the King delves deep and finds the mark of the sigil himself.

After the events are over, Raynald stops all the laughter, and King Baldwin turns to head back to Jerusalem, without saying a word. All the men turn with him, and most of them are relieved: they can go back to Jerusalem safe and sound. While the host prepares to head out, the king will send this message:

“He carries a sigil. Kill him. This may be the last time we see each other. I bid you farewell and good fortune in your tomorrows to come. I’ve fulfilled my duty as best as I can. Now, it is time for you to bear the burden, I’m afraid. Wait until nightfall; wait outside the castle at the hill with the ancient bell; an old friend will show you the way in.”

The king then will leave with his army and return to Jerusalem. The castle will be locked down, and Raynald will be taken with six brute knights of the Wolf Sigila to the infirmary, to have his wounds checked. Raynald will be surveilled at all costs, with many men standing guard for him. It is advised to deter the adventurers from attacking Raynald without the Hill with the Ancient Bell section first.

Hill with the Ancient Bell.name: Hill with the Ancient Bell
Hill with the Ancient Bell.text:
When you reach the top, the sight of ruins welcomes you. The winds of the night salute your coming, and old memories of the ruins still mourn for what they have lost. You suddenly realize they are not mourning for themselves or their losses that belong to an ancient time; they keep company with a man in sorrow.

The bell is rusty, almost living its last moments. It is surprising that it survived this long against bitter times and cruel winds. A man in a white robe, dressed like a pilgrim, takes your attention right away. You can feel his sorrow. The ruins are his companion tonight, with all the ones that they lost, buried, only they could understand his pain.

When your eyes adjust to the approaching dusk, you realize this man is none other than the Sultan. Him. Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub. The one that inherited a holy dream from earlier sultans, earlier custodians of the two mosques. The man carries the legacy of Omar, Suleyman Abd al-Malik, Harun al-Rashid, Mahmud Ghaznavi, Toghrul of Seljuk, the great Sultan Malik-shah, Nizam al-Mulk, and Muhammad Tapar: The dream of the unity of all Muslims.

“Es salamu alaikuma.” He regards you with the iconic greeting of Muslims that offer their safety to others, meaning, “Peace be upon you.”

The proper response to this phrase is widely known as “Wa Alaikuma es-salam.” Saladin used the plural version of the phrase. He stands up and closely inspects the adventurers, as the adventurers may notice he wears the colors of sorrow while the sultan is making sure they fit the description given by the king. If you desire, you can apply proper questions to this moment related to the adventurers’ backgrounds, personalities, or special moments with the king. For example, one of the adventurers may have adopted a nickname, and Saladin could ask about that to be certain they are the adventurers sent by the king.

The king is open to conservation and could spare a good deal of time if the adventurers wish it. Other than that, he wishes to speak his mind:

  • Raynald stole an item of importance from Saladin’s sister after the murder. Saladin’s main goals are to retrieve the item from Raynald and have his head.
  • He knows an entrance to the castle; his engineers found it through some old plans of the building, and he intended to use it if Baldwin didn’t arrive.
  • He has a way to draw Raynald to the hidden entrance’s tunnels, alone. He can be considered invulnerable in that castle with so many sigil knights around him. He needs to be lured in.
  • Saladin has two conditions to show the adventurers the way and lure Raynald in: the item he stole and his head. The latter can be negotiable, but the first condition isn’t.
  • The item that belongs to Saladin’s sister is Scheherazade’s Mirror. It is a powerful magic item and has sentimental value to the Sultan. Raynald does not know its command word.
  • Saladin can offer the adventurers many rewards: coins beyond measure, making them emirs, beys, or nobles of the sultanate if they are of Turkish, Arabic, or a similar Muslim origin; a religious title if they are on a religious path or can harness divine powers; a position in his council of warlords; a place at his right hand; manors on beautiful soils; fertile lands to build their houses; and anything within his power, if he sees potential in them and you deem that they are on favorable terms. It’s important to remember that he is the wealthiest and one of the two strongest men in the Holy Lands. He can offer many things based on the adventurers’ backgrounds or personal desires and goals, such as if one of them wishes to open an orphanage in Damascus to honor their mentor, he can grant it. If they want to find a particular person related to their story, he can make sure it happens. If one wants to own a ship and sail to the Indian Ocean, he can buy one and find the men to sail it.
  • Maybe the most important topic: he knows where the last seal is. He is aware of the dangers that lay under Jerusalem. Do they really think he only wants to take the city to become a conqueror? He studied in Baghdad; he saw how an otherworldly threat was properly bound (check out Herald of Rain’s Act IV for more details in this subject). So in comparison, the seals are weak in Jerusalem, and whatever lies there is making them weaker by the day. So after Raynald dies, they are invited to Cairo, where his most trusted advisor, Ismail Al-Jazari, already has put the item needed to break the last seal, in its place.
  • If they accept, Saladin will give them a magical totem, which will lead them to the hidden entrance, guarded by magic.
  • If the adventurers mention the dead satrap in Jerusalem, he will admit it may be his fault, because he thought their power could prevent the coming of evil. However, he failed to protect them. He will explain what a satrap is and their place in the world. The closest satrap is probably far away.

The sultan guesses that the seal has been taken to the Pyramid of Khufu, the safest place it can be. This part is true. However, unbeknownst to him, Al-Jazari offered himself in exchange for the seal, and he is with Peter the Hermit at the Library Pageless. Peter the Hermit took the seal long ago, as it was the only one that wasn’t in Jerusalem already.

Scheherazade’s Mirror

Wondrous item, rare

This magic mirror’s back is made of jade and gold. While holding the mirror, you can speak the command word and cast the following spells by spending the necessary charge: comprehend languages (1), disguise self (1), alter self (2), suggestion (2), tongues (3), legend lore (5)

The mirror has 10 charges and regains 1d8+2 expended charges daily at dawn.

If they should accept, Saladin will leave and tell them to arrive at the tunnel he described at midnight.

The adventurers may actually skip going back to Jerusalem and advance directly to Cairo, after dealing with Raynald. This act, however, will result in Guy of Lusignan being alive, Balian of Ibelin dead, and Guy being present in the last encounter at the Dragon’s Womb, making all things harder for the adventurers. Saladin will probably advise them to turn first to Jerusalem.

The Tunnel That Reaches the Lightless Ro.name: The Tunnel That Reaches the Lightless Room
The Tunnel That Reaches the Lightless Ro.text:
Saladin will use his way to bring Raynald exactly where the adventurers want, alone in the dark. Saladin has a spy among Raynald’s ranks; the spy baits Raynald to the tunnels suggesting there is a man nearby, trying to enter the castle, who apparently dropped a chess piece. Raynald was warned about the people who carry chess pieces by Guy, and he knew he should take this matter personally. So he kills the spy to ensure there is no witness, and comes to the tunnels himself directly.

The hidden entrance begins from a rock protected by ancient magic. The adventurers’ magical totem can find it. If they did not make a deal with Saladin, they must try other ways, or you could introduce this totem to the players as loot during the road to Kerak Castle.

A damp and narrow tunnel, built long ago, possibly by the Romans, leads well into the underground and reaches a pagan shrine after a ten-minute walk. As it is abandoned, there are no traps or signs about the men of Raynald.

The pagan shrine is in total darkness and has two opposing entrances. It is built as a circle and has a 30-foot radius. In the middle, a large, 7-foot-high pillar has been erected, and four chests are put on each edge of the pillar.

Raynald of Chatillon arrives almost immediately as the adventurers arrive, assuming they went in at the time Saladin said. If they arrive earlier, Raynald may hear their voices while coming down (depending on their Stealth check), or if they arrive too late, Raynald will only spend 10 or so minutes here; they may miss him.

If the adventurers have the means to see him in total darkness, read:

There he stands; the Lord of Kerak, a beast in the night, breathes loudly. He has noticed his prey, or his senses are warning him. He stands there with total silence, a deadly shadow in the night, and the bane of the light.

He is ready to strike.

Raynald will fight to the death.

In each of the four chests, there is one magical item chosen from the following options or any items you desire: horsemaster’s bow, judge’s hammer, shroud of sihr-i azam, shroud of sihr-i nadir, rod of the seeker, crescent blade, +2 weapon, bracers of archery, +1 armor, +2 shield, bracers of defense. In addition, the item Saladin wants is on Raynald.

The adventurers advance to Level 5.

Jerusalem: The Broken Tree.name: Jerusalem: The Broken Tree
Jerusalem: The Broken Tree.text:
Section Summary: The king is dead. Adventurers will be ambushed at the courtyard in the Temple Mount by Guy of Lusignan and will be forced to leave the city.

As you approach Jerusalem, you see a tree split down the middle on a dominant hill stretching toward the city. You have encountered this tree before; it was strong and lush, daring to reach for the sky. Now, it stands broken, yet the Dead Sea quietly mourns it.

As you draw closer to the city, your steps seem to take you backward. The closed sky refuses to explain what has happened, and you approach the gates without seeing a single person on the road.

Your ears do not hear the ringing bells; your eyes do not want to see the flags draped in black cloth. Rain falls no longer from the sky but from the eyes of the people in the city. Grief and pain are now Jerusalem’s fate, and it is not just stepping but even breathing that has become too difficult for the city's residents.

For the king is dead.

Will the new king live long?

When the adventurers reach the city, they are immediately summoned to the Temple Mount, the heart of the royal court, to a very important meeting. They hear that Princess Sibylla will be crowned queen, and on a more sorrowful note: the boy, her child, Baldwin V, was also found dead in his bed this morning. The city is in a state of absolute devastation and almost everyone mourns deeply for the king and the very young prince.

The death of the young prince is a lie conducted by Sibylla to crown Guy of Lusignan and rule as the sole leaders of Jerusalem. Sibylla has other plans for her boy.

These events will occur:

  • At the Temple Mount, the adventurers will realize the intensity between the Knights of Lazarus and the guards under the command of Balian. The city is very tense and the tensions are rising between the parties.
  • Sibylla is crowned queen and is about to announce Guy as king. When the adventurers arrive at the courtyard, they may coincide with the coronation or the aftermath.
  • The queen knows and expects the adventurers’ arrival and has already convinced Guy that the adventurers should be killed.

The courtyard has more tension than the eve of a pitched battle. The fields of Kerak Castle didn’t have this enmity floating in the air between the two parties. This is not the Jerusalem you know. Brothers in arms, comrades that fought shoulder to shoulder, now standing against each other with hateful eyes. What happened here after the king died? Was he the only one who stood between them and the slaying of their kin and comrades?

Where was the queen? Right under the sky of Jerusalem, boldly spitting on his brother’s legacy. Rather than a mourning sister, you see a face without emotions, a mother without a child, a sister without a sibling, a queen without the bearings of the duty.

The phoenix spoke instead of her like she was never there. Away, distant.

“Here come the traitors,” Guy says without raising his voice. The courtyard is so silent that his whispered phrase reached all ears. There are no lies in it. He indeed thinks you are traitors. Traitors to the mother. You are in the way.

“You will pay.”

Without any warning, without any sign, you look to your queen. She only looks away. She remains indifferent.

While many of the sigil knights plan to escort Guy, Balian of Ibelin uses his loyal guards to stop the attacking mob. The adventurers are only confronted with Guy of Lusignan. This is their moment to face him. They may flee or try to change the situation. Balian will advise by shouting that they should flee as soon as possible.

After Guy initiates the attack, it is advised to retire the queen from the line of sight. She expects the adventurers to be taken out by Guy of Lusignan, and she will prepare for the ritual to happen in a fortnight and five days.

Guy will take the matter into his own hands to take down the adventurers while frequently asking, “Where is the White Book?” Unbeknownst to Guy, the book in the king's possession was given to Mother Queen Agnes of Courteney. Guy may even lose an opportunity to kill or wound an adventurer in order to get an answer.

If Guy falls quickly, Balian will explicitly urge the adventurers to flee. If the adventurers try to attack the queen, use any number of Crusaders as needed.

Possible Conclusions

  • Guy is dead, and the adventurers escape successfully.
  • Guy is dead, but the adventurers are captured. Balian escapes the scene and attempts to save the adventurers. However, with the powers of a Level 6 party, the adventurers are expected to easily break free from the city.
  • Balian risks his life in order to save the adventurers and make sure they escape.

Due to his interruption in catching the adventurers, Balian of Ibelin is thrown into jail and most of his force is scattered, killed, or sent into exile in one way or another. Most of the men are forced to escape.

While Saladin comes to conquer the city with a great army, the knights and most capable warriors in the city are sent to fight off Saladin by the orders of the queen in the historical climax of the Battle of Hattin. Sibylla is planning to delay the arrival of Saladin and wants the enemy to be met away from the city while the return of the Whore of Babylon is ensured. However, this proves futile as Saladin wins an epic victory in Hattin and lays siege to Jerusalem.

When the army is away from Jerusalem, the city is left defenseless while the princess is under the Church of the Holy Sepulchre; Balian is rescued from the prisons by civilians and takes control of the defenses of the city.

Road to Cairo.name: Road to Cairo
Road to Cairo.text:
Before their journey, Queen Agnes of Courtenay (Jerusalem Noble), mother of Baldwin and Sibylla, will intercept their journey to give them an important item: The White Book of Jerusalem. She would like it to be used for the good of the realm.

It is recommended that the Master of the Order of Saint Lazarus, Sir Lambertus, may be the one to help them get out of Jerusalem and escort them on their journey to Cairo. In addition, Balian could send some help for the adventurers while they leave the city.

The manner of the Queen Mother’s interception of the adventurers is up to which gate they will use and in the boundaries within your flow and gameplay choices. The Queen Mother will act cautiously and warn the adventurers that the book is important, and their duty still remains in Jerusalem; even after going to Cairo, they should come back.

E The book contains very important information about the past. With this book, much information regarding the Sigils of Jerusalem and the Seal of Kings can be reached. The book can be a useful exposition tool.

E The book was most recently used by Emperor Heraclius and was passed down to Caliph Omar in 636 CE; and then it was lost for a long time after the events of his reign. The last conqueror of Jerusalem, Godfrey of Bouillon (who refused to be known as king and took the title Advocatus Sancti Sepulchri), acquired the book. He never trusted Guy (disguised as Raymond of Saint-Gilles during the First Crusade) when the city was conquered and never shared this information. However, he took notice of the sigils and their marks. Later on, he carefully investigated the matter, but he died a year after. Until Baldwin IV acquired the book, earlier kings disregarded it, and most of them were focused on wars against the Muslim forces, especially Zengids.

White Book of Jerusalem

Wondrous item, legendary

This magic book is descended from ancient times and has been used by the Kings of Jerusalem. While holding the book, you can cast some spells; however, at a certain risk greater than spell rebound. Each time you cast a spell, you must succeed on a DC 10 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, your lifespan decreases by 1d4 years unless you are the rightful monarch of Jerusalem.

You can cast any divination spell of level 4 or lower, except hunter’s mark. In addition, you can cast legend lore, contact other plane, zone of truth, and dispel magic spells once a day (each). You can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

In their journey to Cairo, you can use the random encounter and events table above, in the beginning of the Kerak Castle: The Wolfsbane section. However, with a party of Level 5 adventurers and other potential allies, they are not likely to face too challenging encounters, as most of the main roads are secured by Saladin’s vanguards, spies, and light cavalry units of reconnaissance.

Cairo: The Golden Towers.name: Cairo: The Golden Towers
Cairo: The Golden Towers.text:
Section Summary: They will reach Cairo, reunite with the legendary Sultan Saladin, and learn the place of the last seal: The Cylinder of Cyrus at the heart of the Pyramids of Giza, hidden by Ismail Al-Jazari himself. They will explore Cairo for precious items, prepare to enter the Pyramids, and face their dangers.

Last time you saw the army of Saladin, his numbers were great and formidable, worthy of a sultan of the two jewels of the Holy Lands: Syria and Egypt. However, this time stood an army capable of waging war against the heavens and becoming successful against the god Neptune if it attacked the Mediterranean itself. You see only golden armor stretching from the city walls for an impossible amount. How many soldiers are there?

In Cairo, the adventurers are welcomed into the city and are greeted by Saladin’s men at the gates. They will be immediately summoned to talk about important things. If you want the adventurers to travel around the city, find out about its secrets, and do side quests, check out Cairo - Jewel of the Nile section in Era of the Crusades.

After Saladin summons them, he mentions these:

  • Al-Jazari has not returned; however, he sent Cylinder of Cyrus, also known as the Voice of Shahenshah. If at least one of the adventurers has proficiency with a musical instrument, they should be fine; if they are not, he can recommend a palace musician: a woman named Farah Layla (Traveling Artista) can be of assistance.
  • The automaton that carried the item here was placed in an unfortunate place: At the heart of the Pyramid Khufu. In order to reach it, they must take the key from the Great Sphinx. The pyramid is protected by Al-Jazari’s automatons and the pyramid’s already existing defenses.
  • Before entering the Pyramid of Khufu, they should consult with his brother and his advisor. They should help them around the city.
  • If you wish, you could enforce a time restraint on the characters: Saladin guesses that they have only five days that could be spent in the city. With the week they spend on the way, it could be too late to approach later than that. They will find a city in ruins, nevertheless. Either the evil lurks beneath will have won or Saladin. While phrasing this, Saladin’s face becomes very strict and dark, as he implies that his conquest will have many bloody consequences. If you choose to put a time limit, it is twelve days total, starting from now.

Farah Layla was born in Damascus. Her father was a skilled musician and spent his years trying to find “the lady of the olives,” a local legend in Syria. By the age of six, Farah was already a skillful musician and gifted at story-telling by instantly memorizing the stories told by others and especially her mother: Havva (meaning Eve). Havva was a tutor at the Zengid palace and a personal close friend of Nur ad-Din Zengi.

Her father left one day and never returned. Farah always felt responsible because she brought up a story from a foreigner about a lady who lived in the Nile. She thought that’s why her father left and never returned. When her mother died of a plague, Farah was already mesmerized by the stories that were told about Saladin and his rule. Nur ad-Din’s dream lived through him. On a day of destiny, while Saladin laid siege against the Hashashins in Syria, Farah caught a spy among them and reported this to Saladin. Even though the spy was a close advisor to the sultan, Farah used her powers to make him tell the truth, and she became a part of the court ever since.

With a spirit as free as her music, Farah is warm and charismatic, always eager to share her art or a good tale. Yet she harbors a longing for the deeper mysteries of the world, which fuels her travels and enriches her performances, giving each a unique glimpse into the heart of the lands she visits. She dreams of finding her father and the lady of the olives.

The legend of the Lady of the Olives can be concluded in the Pyramid of Khufu, as a celestial being captured in the Nile is a source of the tale.

Saladin mentions a bloody outcome due to the ritual of sealing. In his days as a talebe (the one who demands knowledge) in Baghdad, he came across a way to bind powerful creatures while they enter the world. However, it requires a heavy blood sacrifice, and Saladin is sure that if no one intervenes, the other way will cost the world something greater: darkness without end.

Historical Note: Saladin will meet with the army of Jerusalem in the Battle of Hattin. After his victory, he will besiege the city. The city will be defended by Balian of Ibelin and a handful of knights.

The Great Pyramids of Giza & The Great S.name: The Great Pyramids of Giza & The Great Sphinx
The Great Pyramids of Giza & The Great S.text:
The sun shines upon the oldest building in the world, as far as you know. How could humankind ever erect this mighty tomb? How did civilization come from the wonder before you to the cities you already know? How did pharaohs imagine this?

The wondrous pyramids reach the clouds as if declaring their divinity. Even though you came from Jerusalem, you realize this was here long before the divinity you’ve seen in Jerusalem. Before Moses split the Dead Sea in two, before Jesus of Nazareth ascended, before Prophet Muhammad united the Arabian Peninsula… Egypt stood with a thousand gods at its peak. Still, their monuments defy time and bitter winds.

Close to the pyramids lies the Great Sphinx, recently excavated by Al-Jazari’s engineers and students at the Al-Azhar University. For further information about Al-Azhar University and its teachers, students, and stories, check out Cairo - Jewel of the Nile section in Era of the Crusades.

The excavation site in the Great Sphinx is led by a man called Mustafa Hashim (Banu Musa Disciple), one of the chief officers of Layet-Efel-Ahen (Stainless Iron) and a former student of Al-Azhar University.

Mustafa Hashim is a young man with a knack for understanding how things work. Even as a child, he did not believe stories such as “the storks bring a child to a father and mother”, “the gods are angry, so the lightning strikes,” or similar folktales and myths. He was not a religious person due to this feature of his. It got him into trouble many times, and he almost faced execution due to “being a heretic,” but it was ordered by Saladin that he be freed. Since that day, Al-Jazari kept a keen eye on him while he worked his way through the Stainless Iron.

Known for his meticulous nature and profound analytical skills, Mustafa combines his academic knowledge with a deep-rooted passion for Egypt’s heritage. Since childhood, he was fascinated by the construction of the pyramids and always wondered how they were made originally. Rather than magic, he was more interested in the physical ways of solving problems and creating things. Although magic required hard work and understanding, he believed the human mind could surpass the need for magic. He still, of course, studied magic and put it to good use.

Personality-wise, Mustafa is reserved yet profoundly dedicated, often losing track of time amidst his projects. His former peers at university remember him as a brilliant yet humble student, always eager to share knowledge and learn from others. Despite his achievements, he maintains a quiet demeanor, preferring the company of ancient relics over large gatherings.

The Machine’s Heart. The disciple can take control of a construct by spending a spell slot as an action. The construct must succeed on a DC 13 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the construct is under the disciple’s control for 1 hour.

Mechanical Mind. The disciple has advantage on Wisdom and Intelligence checks that about automatons, machines, and robotics.

Actions

Arcane Push. Melee or Ranged Spell Attack: +6 to hit, one target, reach 5 ft., or range 60 ft. Hit: 12 (2d8 + 3) psychic damage.

Layet-Efel-Ahen - The Stainless Iron

Originally founded in Damascus, the Stainless Iron is a guild of dedicated blacksmiths, armorers, and weaponsmiths. Damascus Steel is already legendary in the Holy Lands, and the Stainless Iron guild has become legendary under the leadership of the Zengid Dynasty and now its successor, the Ayyubid Dynasty. After fully taking control of Damascus, Saladin invited many guildsmen to Cairo and wished for their work to flourish in the city.

The Stainless Iron is currently working closely with the Banu Musa Society at Al-Azhar University. They are producing quality metalwork for them and for Al-Jazari personally. Many of the robotics are built with the metals they specifically produce. Through Saladin's orders, if the adventurers are considered to have been on good terms with the sultan, the Stainless Iron can make each of the adventurers' armor or current clothes resistant to one type of elemental damage: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder for free or for 100 gold dinars each. They also produce +1 versions of all kinds of armor, shields, and weapons for a price suitable for the friends of the sultan (150 gold dinars + the original price of the item).

The Stainless Iron currently oversees the excavation on the Sphinx, believing they will find new sources and a way to improve their art of blacksmithing. Mustafa Hashim can help adventurers to get inside the sphinx.

Possible Stainless Iron Features

Stainless Work: A member of the Stainless Iron doubles its proficiency bonus on a tool of its choice.

Arcane Smith: A member of the Stainless Iron knows the mending and produce flame cantrips.

Armor Training: A member of the Stainless Iron has proficiency in light armor, medium armor, and shields.

Heat Resistance: A member of the Stainless Iron isn’t affected by extreme heat conditions and needs only half the total amount of water a normal person needs to survive.

Working Mind: A member of the Stainless Iron adds his Intelligence modifier to its Armor Class while wearing light or medium armor. Light armor has no maximum; however, a member can only add a maximum of +2 of their Intelligence modifier to their Armor Class.

Arcana of the Art: A member of the Stainless Iron immediately knows if a metal object is magical or not and has advantage on Intelligence checks that determine to reveal a magic item’s abilities.

The Royal Camp

The Stainless Iron are governed by an important figure: Al-Adil, also known in the West as Saphadin (Commander Emir, Noble of Levanta, 17 INT), and by his side, Imam ad-Din (Scholar of Cairoa, 18 INT, 16 WIS), the philosopher and historian of Saladin.

Saphadin is a great minister of war under his brother and the best choice of replacement for ruling Cairo in the absence of the sultan. He was one of the main actors who dethroned the Fatimids from power and put his brother Saladin on the throne of Egypt. He also has the nickname “Sayf ad-Din,” the “Sword of Faith,” where the name Saphadin comes from.

Saphadin is a serious and cautious man with great attention to detail and is very good with numbers. It is said that he knows almost exactly how many soldiers each province can produce during a bountiful harvest and how many men occupy the strategic points in Cairo at any given time. He carefully plans a line of logistics for his brother and works with provincial governors on supply lines. Most of the council of warlords recognize Saphadin as the invisible hero behind the curtains. It is also rumored that, with a glimpse of a second, he could guess how many men there are in an opposing army.

He is informed about the adventurers and knows they must enter the Pyramid of Khufu. He arranged a scouting party before their arrival. However, the party was unsuccessful in getting in. Al-Jazari had some robots build a steel door in the entrance, break its key to three pieces, and hide them in the Great Sphinx. Normally, he shouldn’t have shared this information with anyone, but because of his forced stay in the Library Pageless, the Muzahira that carried the Cylinder of Cyrus brought the news about it. There is, unfortunately, no way to enter without getting their hands on the keys. Thus, the excavation on the Sphinx was sped up and monitored by Saladin himself.

Imad ad-Din is an intelligent scholar and careful recorder of events and is one of the few friends of Saphadin and Saladin. He has a way of bringing bad news and is usually known as “Stormcrow” because he constantly shows up in hard times and delivers troubled news. He also has a way of analyzing history and predicting future events. It is said that he predicted Saladin’s defeat at Montgisard, and since that day, Saladin kept him close. If they wish, Imad ad-Din can accompany the adventurers on their journey to the Sphinx.

During their meeting with the adventurers they are free to discuss many topics mentioned above and the dangers that could be found in the Pyramid. Additionally, in this meeting, the information below can be shared:

  • The Pyramid is also a prison complex. No prisoner that has entered there ever came out, but Al-Jazari informs them that no one has died yet.
  • Al-Jazari performs many experiments, having changed the inside of the pyramids for years. He has been obsessed with it. In his own words, “A place of my undoing, although I’m not a pharaoh.”
  • Pyramid contains some intact floors, while others have been completely altered by Al-Jazari. His robots are mostly loyal to him and perceive anyone except him and Saladin as enemies. Only an engineer like Al-Jazari, a Disciple of Banu Musa, may help the adventurers immobilize certain threats.
  • Al-Jazari’s creations are very dangerous constructs, so the adventurers must be extra careful.

The Sphinxes of Egypt

The entrance is blocked by a gate that is actually a construct. The construct is ancient and has almost lost all mobility. Mustafa Hashim opens the way by using his abilities to control a construct and lead them through the door found under the excavation.

The inside is a giant building, bigger than expected, built to dine with the gods themselves. You notice the inside is highly illuminated, with strange orbs of light brightening virtually every corner. A closer inspection reveals they are some sort of fireflies, miraculously alive still.

But the thought of a miracle stops right away. Between giant pillars, praiseworthy wall engravings and magnificent tiles that shimmered of royalty and divinity, you notice three large figures, not very far from each other. A mighty sight to behold! Three sphinxes gazing at you with a smile on their faces.

One bears the markings of the god Anubis, the middle one resembles Bastet, and the last one is the aspect of Sekhmet.

The sphinxes in the Great Sphinx have been here for the longest time. Thousands of years ago, the Great Sphinx was built as a measure for speaking to gods, and the sphinx was the symbol of unity and harmony between humans and gods, sometimes referring to the pharaohs.

The Sphinx is a result of that devotion and belief in divinity. When they wanted to commune with gods, a godly creature appeared, but no one knew how. At the height of the Bronze Age, before the invasion of the Sea Peoples, divine magic and devotion infused the stones and statues of the priests of the Great Sphinx. The aspects within these statues revealed themselves as sphinxes, and many others around the world, imbuing them with life as celestial beings. They prayed so devoutly that the stones eventually came to life.

Al-Jazari, when he came to Cairo, discovered the existence of the sphinxes and appealed to their guardianship. He made three keys and gave them power over the Pyramids. He convinced the sphinxes by stating he works for the new pharaoh of Egypt: Salah ad-Din Yusuf bin Ayyub.

Adventurers don’t actually need any keys to enter; they only need their blessings. However, each Sphinx holds a certain power in the Pyramid. They needed to convince them to release those powers.

As long as they are truthful about being sent here by Saladin, they are allowed to go into the dungeon no matter which trial they fail or pass. If the adventurers act incredibly out of character or highly disrespect the sphinxes, Egyptian gods, Saladin, or any other aspect deemed worthy by the sphinxes, they may become hostile as a last resort.

Aspect of Anubis

Power: Judgment of the Afterlife

  • Mechanic: While the adventurers are inside the pyramid, they receive disadvantage to Constitution saving throws and are vulnerable to necrotic or poison damage (GM’s choice for each creature when they enter the dungeon). The undead are supposed to be considerably easier for the adventurers as the combat is not the main trial here.
  • Solution: The Aspect of Anubis has a cage behind it with four skeletons, ghouls, or a similar undead creature. The Aspect of Anubis says one phrase only: “Deal with the undead.” A DC 10 Intelligence (Religion or History) check reveals that Egyptians usually buried their dead. The adventurers are expected to destroy or immobilize the undead and make their bodies go back to the soil. If a believer of another religion conducts a ceremony suited to their beliefs, it is also acceptable. For example, a Zoroastrian character could burn the undead with proper prayers.
  • Reward: The adventurers have resistance against necrotic or poison damage while in the pyramid (Their choice at this moment).

Aspect of Bastet

Power: Enchanter’s Will

  • Mechanic: While in the pyramid, the creatures that have entered the pyramid can’t hit a construct unless they roll 15 or higher in attack rolls.
  • Solution: The Aspect of Bastet is a powerful enchanter, saying only one phrase: “Impress me.” She expects a visual or a solid presentation of talent, power, intelligence, devotion, or something similar. A DC 10 Intelligence (Religion or History) check reveals that Bastet is a gentle lioness goddess, representing fertility and motherhood, but also linked to music, dance, joy, and pleasure. If you desire, you could appoint a DC based on the characters’ performance preference. For example, singing a song for a bard should not be too hard (DC 10), while a character with a low Intelligence could have a hard time remembering a song dedicated to Bastet. However, Bastet may consider dedication and sincerity as good signs as long as the adventurer tries something for real. Magicians could put up a show with their illusionary abilities, while a barbarian with a Strength score could demonstrate their muscle power. Each adventurer must succeed in order for all of them to earn the reward.
  • Reward: The adventurers choose a damage type. If a construct has a resistance or immunity against it, that specific resistance or immunity is removed. If it doesn’t have a resistance or immunity against the chosen damage type already, the construct becomes vulnerable to that damage type. The damage type can’t be poison, necrotic, or psychic.

Aspect of Sekhmet

Power: Warrior’s Might

  • Mechanic: Known for her ferocity in battle, the Aspect of Sekhmet represents healing and destruction simultaneously. Due to her aura, each healing received in the pyramid has a 50% chance of instead damaging the creatures by the same amount. For example, a potion of healing could harm the creature by a total amount of 2d4+2. The damage is necrotic and can’t be prevented in any way.
  • Solution: The Aspect of Sekhmet will either want to duel with the adventurers individually or combat them collectively. If the adventurers choose to duel individually, only three hits or three effects are considered a victory. If collectively, the adventurers are expected to drop Sekhmet to 0 HP. Any damage done during the trial is reversed after the combat ends.
  • Reward: The adventurers can take 2 short rests rapidly. A 10-minute rest is counted as a short rest. This only works in the pyramid.

Dungeon: Pyramid of Khufu.name: Dungeon: Pyramid of Khufu
Dungeon: Pyramid of Khufu.text:
Here lies a wonder stretching before you, reaching up into the sky, blazing with the fire of the sun itself, defying all the orders that came after it, still standing proud and strong. A poem comes to mind:

Here lie the toppled gods
Whom the crescent did shun,
Thus they erected this wonder
When the skies had a brighter sun.

With each step you take, you shrink, even as you approach the tomb of an empire powerful enough to pierce the sky, you know you are entering the dominion of kings buried underground. The area you approach is their territory. In death, no one rules over them. Whether it be Saladin or Baldwin, here lie the fallen gods – their followers may have dwindled, but their power still firmly resides in their hearts.

As you enter their majestic shadows, you realize you underestimated their grandeur. From afar, it seemed merely a palette of beautiful colors on canvas, but now it appears larger than any building you’ve seen, and you marvel at how it stands. Once again, the intelligence and knowledge of its builders impress you deeply. Then, the voices of emperors lying deep below, the workers who died during construction, and the kings who dreamed of looking upon this place echo in your ears. You walk in as if bearing the legacy of all civilizations. Before you now stand not just a building or simply a pyramid.

You are stepping towards a graveyard of civilizations, a land of dead kingdoms, and a day of mourning for worlds.

Effects of the Sphinxes

If not disabled by the sphinxes, these mechanics are active in the pyramid:

  • Anubis’ Effect: While inside the pyramid, creatures receive disadvantage on Constitution saving throws and are vulnerable to necrotic or poison damage (GM’s choice for each creature when they enter the dungeon).
  • Bastet’s Effect: While in the pyramid, the creatures that have entered the pyramid can’t hit a construct unless they roll 15 or higher in attack rolls.
  • Sekhmet’s Effect: Due to her aura, each healing received in the pyramid has a 50% chance of damaging the creatures in the same amounts. For example, a potion of healing could harm the creature by a total amount of 2d4+2. The damage is necrotic and can’t be prevented in any way.

Permanent Effects

These effects are always active, unless you decide otherwise.

Resting Place of the Dead: If a creature knows or has prepared the speak with dead spell, it requires no material components and can be cast without a spell slot. It doesn’t trigger spell rebound effects due to its integrity with the natural magic of the dungeon.

Servants of the Pharaoh: All undead are under the control of Pharaoh Khufu. He can see through their eyes and use their senses. Even if the undead do not have proper organs, he can speak, see, hear, smell and feel through them.

Rise o’ servant!: If a creature dies from the effects of necrotic damage, it rises in 1d4 turns as an appropriate undead of your choice (maximum CR of 3).

Floor 0.name: Floor 0
Floor 0.text:
The dry air hits you very hard as if the very air is being stolen from your lungs. An interesting triangle-shaped room welcomes you and you feel all the ancient sightings, pharaohs and Egyptian gods that would wait for you here, gone, taken into some place away.

This is the entrance to the dungeon, and the largest room is located here. This was once a maze built by the ancients, but now it produces power for this complex. Ismail Al-Jazari made this place as a sundial working with sunlight and also sensitive to starlight. It absorbs light and creates energy, a work in progress by the master artificer.

For intruders, it creates a time trap to repel them. Each zone is hazardous in its own way. From the control panel in the room, the effects can be observed as if it is a sundial or a clock. The clock’s hour end determines the area that will possibly be more dangerous.

In order to reach the exit and upper floors, the adventurers must pass each room clockwise. Once the system is activated by stepping their feet onto Floor 0, each room has an area of effect designed to hurt or even kill the intruders. Once characters roll for initiative, roll for the room as well as if it’s a creature, and when its turn comes, the room’s effect is activated on that turn.

Lawha-i Idara: Control Panel

In the entrance, R1, a metallic table sparks the adventurers’ interest. It has Arabic letters as well as gibberish symbols on it. A DC 10 Intelligence check reveals that it says “Lawha-i Idara”, meaning the “plaque/sheet/table for management/control,” or, as the adventurers intuit, a control panel. It has a clock depicted on it, and the hour hand is made of gold to be easily distinguishable with the eyes.

In order to control the panel, a character must have proficiency with cartographer’s tools, smith’s tools, tinker’s tools, navigator’s tools, alchemist’s supplies, or a similar tool you deem appropriate, or a feature, a background, a class ability or something similar that could fit here. This panel lets the creatures mechanically attempt to control the sundial mechanism. Each attempt to change the hour hand requires a DC 10 Intelligence check to move the mechanic parts on it carefully.

In addition, A DC 15 Intelligence check reveals that the panel is actually sensitive to light. If the panel is opened sideways, mirrors in it can be observed. If the mirrors are aligned correctly, the hour hand can be fixed to a desired room.

Doors of the Clock

One of the challenges in Floor 0 is the countdown. In every room, the room rolls for initiative, and when its turn comes, it activates its ability. However, the doors are also reinforced. Each one has a lock that can be opened with a DC 15 Dexterity (Thieves’ Tools or Sleight of Hand may apply) check.

Each door has 14 AC, 10 HP and 4 Damage Threshold with immunity to poison, psychic, and necrotic; resistance to slashing and piercing from nonmagical forces; resistance to fire, cold, lightning, radiant and thunder; and vulnerability to acid and force.

Hour Hand

When the hour hand coincides with a room, that room has an initiative count of 20 with an available lair action. The action is a release of energy by means of an area of effect in the form of magical beams. Creatures in the area must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 4d6 force damage. This damage can be interrupted by a shield spell due to its similar nature to magic missiles.

If intruders are in a room on this floor, roll a d12 at the beginning of a round. It determines the hour hand’s current position.

The Walls

The walls are covered with a special material made by the Banu Musa Society and perfected by Al-Jazari himself. It is called sitara-reng, “star color” in Persian. It is made from the roots of a tree that undergoes heavy induction and alteration by magic. Normal trees are transformed into this particular tree called Rishe Sitara (Star Root) in Persian. The root is carefully crafted through an alchemical process infused with holy water to produce star color. Star color is always sensitive to light and catches whatever is in the sky at the moment. It is said that these trees can be found in underground regions and guide those that dwell there.

The Main Engine

In the center, a huge pillar made of metal takes your attention. All the walls seem to circle it. Its metal surface looks extremely hot, almost to the point of white metal. A touch would surely be incredibly painful. However, you hear a faint noise, resembling a windmill or a watermill, constantly turning. But this time, it is a metal.

A DC 18 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals (or characters with passive Perception of 18 or higher) that there is also a sound of water - a constant presence. It resembles when a white-hot sword in the state of candescence is plunged into water, creating a burst of steam pouring out. A DC 10 Intelligence check reveals that it is to cool the huge pillar, and if overheated, most of the mechanics may not work. The adventurers may choose to break the pillar, as it powers most of the mechanics in the dungeon.

The pillar must take 50 points of bludgeoning damage (magical) or fire damage to be broken. It has a threshold of 10 points and an Armor Class of 18.

If the pillar breaks, it will explode and force each creature within 40 ft. of it to make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it deals 14 (4d6) fire damage plus 14 (4d6) bludgeoning damage due to shrapnel from the metallic parts. The doors lose their magical quality, and Mechanics with an Ω symbol do not work anymore.

The Effects in Rooms

The rooms have nearly identical interiors, with nothing noteworthy to distinguish them. However, there's an unsettling feeling of entrapment, heightened by the eerie glow of the star color, reminiscent of impending doom. It feels as though time itself is trapped in an hourglass, with impending demise closing in.

If the adventurers manage to fix the Hour Hand to a place, it is unnecessary to play all the rooms. In such a case, we recommend that a door directly to R12 can be revealed with a guardian covering it: An Ajal’ayn, the Little Deatha.

Most of the construct stablocks are included in the Appendix section.

R1 Ω: Creatures inside must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw while the poisoned fumes fill the room from the floor. On a failed save, they are poisoned for 1 hour and take 5 (2d4) poison damage.

R2 Ω: The floors start to collapse from the furthest northern point. Each turn, a total of ten squares (5 ft^2 area) opens up, and any character on it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall 90 ft. below to a pit of spikes. The spikes deal 7 (2d6) piercing damage.

R3 Ω: Each turn a set of ice is fired from all walls. Characters must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or lose 10 ft. of movement and take 2 (1d4) piercing damage plus 2 (1d4) cold damage.

R4 Ω: Each turn characters must succeed on a DC 10 Charisma saving throw. On a failure, they are teleported back to the closest unoccupied space within the entrance door of R4.

R5 Ω: The point Փ forces each creature to succeed on a DC 10 Strength saving throw or will pulled towards it for 25 ft. Each turn after the first one DC increases by 1 and it also deals 3 (1d6) bludgeoning damage as its pull becomes very strong.

R6 Ω: Each turn the terrain is filled with mud from the ground. With each turn, 1 foot of movement costs 1 more foot of speed. So after 3 turns for example, 1 foot of movement costs 3 feet of speed.

R7 Ω: A flash of light erupts and all creatures in the room must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or become blinded for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each turn. Each turn after the first turn, the light also deals the failed ones 1d4 radiant damage and makes them blind. Any blind person is immune to this effect.

R8 Ω: The room is covered with magical darkness (4th level). Each turn after the first turn anyone in the darkness must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or take 1d4 psychic damage. If the darkness is dispelled with a daylight spell or a similar effect that destroys magical darkness, the darkness is cast again after 1d4+1 turns.

R9 Ω: Each turn, magical chains with hooks attached erupt from the ground where the creatures stand and attempt to grab them. Creatures must succeed on a DC 10 Strength saving throw or be restrained by the chains. Chains have 10 Hit Points and can be burst with a DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check. Each turn after the first one, the chains magically pour tiny spikes on them and deal 2 (1d4) piercing damage to restrained targets.

R10 Ω: A sleeping gas fills the room and forces each creature to succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. Those that fail fall asleep for 1 minute, until they take damage or are slapped awake by a creature as an action. After 1 minute, the floor disappears and all creatures fall 80 ft to the ground, and then the floor reappears, leaving only 1 hour of oxygen.

R11 Ω: The surface becomes magically reflective and each creature (that is able to see) must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or fall under the effects crown of madness spell.

R12 Ω: Only a Muzahira waits in the room, right at the beginning of the stairs. It has a recorded version of a speech by Al-Jazari:

Forgive my incompetence. I never thought this would happen to me. I’m guessing you are entering here to retrieve some important item. If you are here to retrieve – andI hope you do retrieve it – say its name out loud. This way, this Muzahir can deactivate some of the traps.

Unfortunately, even if I commanded the lord of this pyramid to stand down, he would not. My deal with him only included myself and the blood relatives of Salah ad-Din. Even if Salah ad-Din himself would be with you, he would attack you while sparing him. Do not attempt a negotiation with him.

May good fortune be upon you, my dear friends! Hope you’ll find me later, for I am trapped with a sigil holder. Yes, the sigil that I really hope you can destroy!

The stairs lead to Zero A. They connect to a narrow tunnel that can be used to access Zero B. The tunnel is not suitable for large creatures; only medium or smaller-sized creatures can fit into the tunnel and medium creatures must be prone to advance.

Floor Zero A.name: Floor Zero A
Floor Zero A.text:
The room’s feeling resembles a shiny firefly in a cruel underground cavern. The small garden has beautiful smells and the workbench clearly is a place of serenity, focus and dedication.

Workbench: The workbench consists of large, organized counters, tables, and tools dedicated to engineering, robotics, metalsmithing, and various other tasks.The workbench has some intriguing items on it, but due to being very crowded in detail, an adventurer with a passive Perception of 13 or higher, or with an active DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) or Intelligence (Investigation) check, recognizing the items if you deem so. If multiple characters realize there are some magic items, you can roll more than once.

D8

Encounter

1

6 potions of healing, two aid spell scrolls.

2

A fireball spell scroll, 2 potions of greater healing.

3

4 potions of resistance (your choice)

4

An elemental gem, emerald.

5

A pearl of power.

6

A shortsword of lifestealing.

7

A wand of paralysis. 4 potions of healing.

8

A stone of controlling earth elementals.

The Garden: It is guarded by a mummyj under Khufu’s control. The plants and flowers, all, have a fruit produced by them. A small basket has many of the said fruits. They resemble exotic fruits. They are magical, and if consumed, they have a 50% chance of giving advantage on ability checks for the next hour or it gives disadvantage on them. For each fruit eaten after the first 24 hours pass, the probability of advantage decreases by 10%.

Patient made of metal: The right side of the room has metal made from marsik and a really tall construct made of metal. It has human-like features like limbs, a head, and a face. It is motionless and almost lifeless. A close inspection (DC 10 Intelligence check, possible tool or skill proficiencies may apply) reveals that there is a layer of human skin and body parts underneath. There is a notebook written in Arabic letters that can be found near it. Even if it uses the Arabic letters, the text is in Turkish:

A loss of intelligence has always bugged me. Will I ever be able to retain the way I feel or act? My capability of analyzing? People keep saying that I’m young and I have nothing to worry about getting older. However, I was never young; I was always me, who I am right now. I gained experience and new perspectives on events and learned much new information but I didn’t grow up.

It was sad to see a brilliant mind die from a common disease. It was his desire for me to try to return him to life, not by just the touch of magic. No, that would be very dangerous and could cause unwanted spell rebound effects that could hurt so many people. So, I resorted to science. I used my knowledge of machines.

The creature awaits. In silence. Now I also think about the day that I will eventually grow up and become old. Will I still retain the abilities that make me who I am? Will my intelligence slowly rot away while I realize everything fades into the abyss before my eyes? I fear no death, I’m sure; I only fear losing my touch.

Floor Zero B.name: Floor Zero B
Floor Zero B.text:
You hear the faint crackling of the fire and let yourself think about the past days, far into the past that you think you have forgotten, your first days and maybe your first memories. Only glimpses are with you; there are no complete memories, but they are there. Perhaps the first laughter of a mother, the first drops of rain and the first time your hands got dirty in the soil.

B1: A long hall filled with whispers and faint images of a long-lost life. Creatures must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or will mistake illusions for reality for the next hour. You can use the illusions here to address their past mistakes, remorse, sorrows, or similar aspects of their background as a means of reflecting the past. There are two doors that open to B2 and B3. On the opposite side, there is a giant door with a magical seal on it and a note by Al-Jazari: “The way is shut. No one can go in there now.”

B2: A room with a metal plaque on the northern wall. Two other doors lead to B3 and B4. The metal plaque is magical and is sensitive to Al-Jazari’s spirit; it can be used to build parts of the robotics he works on. There is a parchment paper on it, with markings belonging to the Old Persian language. It is a remarkable document belonging to the past.

My beloved shah and husband,

We have arrived at a place spoken of in the legends passed down by your father, and found them to be true. This valley is enchanted as he said, resonating with the purest of melodies and the most beautiful songs. The winds here mimic the songs we sing, weep for the laments we recite –a marvel that feels both surreal and divine. I plan to conduct a ritual to seek the valley’s blessing to capture this miraculous echo in the stone you sculpt. Together, we shall create an instrument unparalleled in beauty and sound, my beloved Shah.

The splendor of the stars and the glow of the sun pale in comparison to what we share, my love.

Yours eternally,
Shah-banu Cassandane

Shah-banu is a Persian title that can be translated to queen. A DC 15 Intelligence (History) check reveals that Shah-banu Cassandane was the wife of Cyrus the Great.

B3: There’s a giant bonfire in the middle with many smith’s supplies and other tools scattered around it. An elemental creature is bound to the flame and thus, the flame is inextinguishable. The creature is called Odparvar (check out the Appendix for its statblock). In addition to its statblock, it has the ability to summon a construct with its action: Atash-parvaz, the Flame Wardena. It can’t do so again until it finishes a long rest. It rises from the bonfire with Odparvar’s command.

Odparvar has the ability to summon the dead spirits and communicate with them. Before letting the adventurers go, they will ask them to face their sins and summon a spirit which they are connected to in some way. They could apologize, ask for forgiveness, forgive the summoned spirit or fulfill a promise to them, up to you and the adventurers. Odparvar is not hostile unless the adventurers act in that manner towards it.

In exchange for facing their pasts, it will reward them with immunity to fire for 1 hour. Each day, they can activate this ability for 1 minute once a day with an action.

B4: This room is empty except when intruders enter Room Zero B. Once they set foot inside, a Kharim al-Ghalib, Custodian of the Sanda (Ω) appears in the room from a hole in the wall, covered by a metal door. The wall houses one such construct and immediately defends the room once the intruders enter. If the adventurers investigate the hole, they will find a hold monster spell scroll, and it can be taken as an action.

B5: This room has an ancient trap to repel the invaders. Once the creatures step into the middle of the room (it is marked with a ⊕ symbol on the map), spears from the wall emerge and adventurers must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5 (2d4) piercing damage or half as much on a successful one.

B6: This room has nothing, except the guardian at the door: a mummyj. The mummy is controlled by Pharaoh Khufu. The door leads to a staircase leading to Floor 1.

Floor 1.name: Floor 1
Floor 1.text:
The smell of an ancient tomb and dry air scorches your throat. This floor seems untouched by Al-Jazari and carries the scent and soul of the Ancient Egyptian ruins. You feel that eyes are on you. Every moment of you is being watched.

General Mechanic: Pharaoh Khufu is able to see this entire floor. This floor is designed to learn of the adventurers’ abilities and weaknesses and to generally observe intruders that are able to reach this far and also prevent any prisoners from running away. He may adapt his tactics based on the information he gains.

Use the table below to generate the rooms with hazards and treasures: Roll two times, one for Encounter and one for Treasure. Hazards may include traps or monsters. Reroll if the same number coincides with older rolls.

d20

Treasures

Bits of Lore & Information

Throughout the floor, there are many personal and ancient belongings of Pharaoh Khufu that could be implemented in the dungeon to tell his story slowly. There are three parts of information in the dungeon: Ones that are left by the builders of the Pyramid after Khufu’s death (Legacy of Khufu), the ones that Khufu depicted himself later (Engravings of a Pharaoh), and the ones that were left behind by Al-Jazari (Memories of a Scholar). Out of respect to Khufu’s legacy, Al-Jazari did not touch this floor, as he will explain below with a Muzahira.

Most of the information left behind by the Ancient Egyptians is in the form of hieroglyphs, hieratic and demotic scripts. If there are no adventurers that are proficient with reading the hieroglyphics and other forms of writing, consider giving this magical item:

Pearl of the Moontide: While holding this stone, you can call forth its magical ability to unveil your eyes against foreign scripts. As an action you can expend a charge and for 1 hour, you gain the ability to read all writings. This pearl has 5 charges and when the last charge is expended, the pearl turns to dust.

Legacy of Khufu

“In the time of great brightness under the sun, our Pharaoh Khufu reigned with a heart inflamed by love for his people. He strove like the mighty Nile, ever pushing forward, to uplift the land of the black soil. His decrees were wise, and his commands just. With strong hands, he forged a realm undiminished, a beacon of prosperity that might forever gleam like gold in the expansive desert.”

“Behold the horizon where sky clasps the earth, where our sovereign Khufu, the horizon’s own son, erected this eternal stone to merge heaven and earth. Through this sacred monument, he aimed not only to grace the skies but to elevate us, his devoted followers, so that together we might dwell amidst the stars. This pyramid, a ladder of stone, stands as his divine aspiration, a passage through which the soul ascends to the everlasting celestial realm.”

“In the days to come, long as the river and enduring as stone, let it be known that we, the caretakers of his legacy, will kindle the flames of remembrance. For Pharaoh Khufu, whose spirit guards us still, we consecrate these days of splendor. Each year, when the sun reaches its zenith, we shall celebrate his deeds, rejoicing in the shadows of the great pyramid, so his memory, like the sun, shall never dim nor his glory fade from the heart of the Nile.”

“As the sun rises steadfast each morning, so too does the spirit of our people glow with unwavering pride. It is in the shadow of the great pyramid, beneath the gaze of the all-seeing sun, that we stand as one, upholders of the glory wrought by Pharaoh Khufu’s hands. Our voices lift in unison, our hearts beat to the rhythm of the ancients, and our actions are guided by the legacy of his greatness. Proudly, we carry forward the mantle of his achievements, ensuring that the echo of his reign resounds through eternity.”

Engravings of a Pharaoh

“From the timeless depths of my divine contemplation, my vision was grander than the horizon itself. I sought to forge a beacon of ascendance, a domicile where the bonds of the earth may be severed to unite with the celestial. This structure, rising steadfast from the sands, was to be a confluence of the heavens and our mortal coil, a place of enlightenment and communion with the gods. Yet those who came after misunderstood the breadth of my decree, erecting what they saw as a monument to hubris rather than a portal for advancement and unity with the divine.”

“In the solitude of the gods’ embrace, it weighs heavily upon my heart that my true intent has drifted like sands lost to the winds among my people. This edifice, meant to elevate and unite, has been shadowed by misinterpretations. Yet a flicker of hope remains, kindled by the foresight of the learned ones who may yet traverse these stone halls. May the scholar, wise and discerning, come forth to preserve and herald the true essence of my legacy. Let him be the guardian of our heritage, the one who understands and perpetuates the enlightenment we sought.”

“Bound to the dust of my former empire by the immutable chains of undeath, I dwell among the remnants of a time long passed. My corporeal form has succumbed to the relentless march of decay, reduced to naught but desolation within these hallowed chambers. Yet in the stillness of this eternal vigil, here I remain—my spirit tethered to the very stones that were to be a bridge to the divine. From this silent throne, I watch over my legacy, enduring as both sentinel and sovereign, forever a part of the monument that was to transcend mortality.

“Behold, as dawn ushers in the age of a new horizon, a learned scholar from distant lands approaches, bearing the seal of his sultan, a ruler whose vision mirrors the grandeur of my own. This emissary of knowledge seeks to parley with my eternal essence, to uncover the secrets bound within these ancient stones. Together, we may forge an alliance that transcends time itself, blending the wisdom of the past with the innovations of the present. Here, amid the echoes of antiquity, a dialogue begins—a potent exchange that promises to rejuvenate the enduring legacy that I, Pharaoh Khufu, have bequeathed to the sands of time.”

Memories of a Scholar

“Standing at the threshold of this grand structure, my heart races with the thrill of discovery and the utmost respect for the ingenuity of Pharaoh Khufu. His vision was grand—constructs not just as tombs, but as beacons of progress, striving to advance humanity. Here I am, a humble servant of science, ready to converse with the guardian of this monumental legacy. My objective is clear: to learn, to adapt, and to implement the ancient wisdom housed within these walls, ensuring that it serves to foster advancements that would indeed make our world a better place.”

“Behold the might of this wonder! I’ve been mesmerized by it. However, my sense of beauty is interrupted by a sudden wish from Salah ad-Din. He wanted to turn this place into a prison. The moment I heard it, I rejected with all my power but in time I realized this could be a great opportunity: To observe and improve them!”

“In the streets of Jerusalem shadowed by dark stars, an ancient evil stirs, concealed but disturbing. My Sultan’s command is clear: seek out the relic, an object of immense power, believed to be safeguarded by a hermit, Peter, a leader of the First Crusade. I feel the weight of this quest, knowing well the sacrifices it may demand of me. I must obtain it and hide it here, where it will be most safe. Who better to guard this artifact than Pharaoh Khufu himself? A ruler, a protector of his realm, whose spirit still haunts these sacred halls.”

“Well, this may be a farewell. I don’t know who will read this, but I do not know a better place than the pyramid of mighty Khufu. My adversary, Peter the Hermit, has proven himself not merely a relic of the First Crusade but a harbinger of darker tides. He serves a dark purpose, a karabasan of nightmares. It is such a wicked being that even though you could see it with your naked eyes they would prove useless against it. He aligned himself with dark stars above, to a matriarch from Babylon, who aspired to the greatest heavens but only took the form of the lizard, whose grace is but a chthonic lullaby, a melody that lulls the living into a slumber unending, stripping away freedom and ensnaring souls in her chilling embrace, with our minds at peace, but our spirits enslaved. This battle, then, is not just for a relic, but for the very essence of liberty itself.”

The constructs called Muzahira can be found in most rooms at your discretion to share the memories of Al-Jazari.

Floor 2 - The Prison.name: Floor 2 - The Prison
Floor 2 - The Prison.text:
The metal cages and the eyes that turn to you immediately catch your attention. So many eyes are looking at you, restrained in the metal cages with dangerous-looking iron chains, all glowing with runes on them. You realize none of them can talk, only some rise to their feet and look at you menacingly or begging. A chill runs down your spine because you know these are the prisoners put here by Al-Jazari or on the orders of Saladin himself.

There is no innocence here.

The prison appears to be guarded by two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.IyIybE5t2adMEVUM]{ghasts}j. However, they are only put there to conceal the actual guard.

A Viran-dahl-Asude is the actual prison guard here, but it remains invisible and will not intervene with anything unless a prisoner is released. As soon as the magical chains lose their glow, a prisoner moves out of its cage or a similar escape attempt happens, it will strike and will have Initiative count 20 (losing ties). It has a special feature: it can summon and control two air elementalsj.

Viran-dahl-Asude,
the Voiceless One
