Invisible Existence. The voiceless one is a shapeless entity and therefore always has the invisible condition. When seen by a spell like see invisibility or a sensitive sight such as truesight, it appears as a pale and pure white cloud.

Lost Voices. The voiceless one remembers everything it's heard and can repeat it. In addition, if it hears the voice of a dead creature, it can copy the creature’s talking style and can use its voice, mannerisms and patterns for speech.

Memory Fragments. If the voiceless one is within 15 ft. of a dying creature, it can see the creature’s memories, ideals or other aspects decided by the GM. If the dying creature is willing, the voiceless one can see through their whole life. If the creature is unwilling, the voiceless one can force it to make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the voiceless one can see any memory it desires and memorize the visuals immediately.

Actions

Thunderous Strike. Ranged or Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, one target, ranged 120 ft. or reach 5 ft. Hit: 9 (2d8) thunder damage.

Sorrowful Scream (Recharge 4-6). The creatures within 300 ft. of the voiceless one must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save the creature is deafened indefinitely and takes 21 (6de6) thunder damage. On a successful save, the creature only takes half of the damage. The deafened condition can be dispelled by a greater restoration spell.

Speed of Sound. The voiceless one can use its action to teleport to a place it can see directly, no more than 1000 ft.

Cages

Cages and Chains

Magical chains and cages are connected to each other and creatures inside it are restrained, can’t cast spells and can’t attack, and their STR becomes 6 while bound. While bound to these chains, a creature only needs one meal for ten weeks.

The chains and cage doors have 25 AC, 15 damage threshold and 50 HP.

There are some potential prisoners in the cages. They are not mandatory for the story. You can also add your own NPCs or any other NPC that would fit here and enrich the story.

Raymond III of Tripoli (Jerusalem Noblea): Regent of the late King Baldwin. There were rumors that he joined Saladin, and that was true to an extent. Raymond bargained with Saladin to save his family. After his family was secured, he tried to reconcile with Guy of Lusignan, but he never came to the place they would meet, instead, Saladin’s men ambushed and captured him. Saladin gave his word: to release him after he completes the conquest of Jerusalem.

Morgan the Sorceress (Magej): A young and beautiful sorceress came to poison the mind of the sultan and prepare him against the “war with the upcoming king of Avalon.” She was arrested after her attempt to put an enchantment on the sultan's mind. Due to the rising conflict, Saladin did not have time to question her. She comes from the British Isles and was banished by the king of the round table due to dark magic and treachery.

Korkut Abbas (Hashashin Fedayeeh): A Hashashin loyal to Hasan Sabbah. After the news of Sabbah’s death, Korkut acted independently and went deep into the Saharan Desert to find relics. When Korkut returned, he learned about Saladin’s war against the remaining Hashashins, and he reported the names of ones in Cairo, thus betraying the order. He was arrested because he was also one. He hid many important and powerful relics in the desert and won’t share their locations.

Pierre Bartholomew (Vampirej): A prominent figure in the First Crusade and one of the first vampires. He is also known as Peter Bartholomew. He is a mystic and one of the soldiers that participated in the Siege of Antioch. He lost his vision due to famine and repeatedly had visions of St. Andrew. He excavated the castle to find the Holy Lance. However, he was experiencing the first symptoms of being an undead and a vampire after he committed cannibalism during the siege. After his ordeal by fire, he traveled south, away from the lords who did not believe him. He spent decades in Jerusalem and slowly regained power through feeding on mortals and slowly building an army. He believed himself to be a messiah, the king of the new generation of humans. His actions was revealed by Queen Melisende and he was banished from the city, only to be captured by a raiding party of Cairo origin and an imam called Hafiz Üsame, a monster hunter at that time.

Hall of the False King

A throne made of stone greets you, and it looks like it was made for a giant. And a giant sits on it, indeed – like the black skies among a fierce storm, a construct made of black steel sits right there. Eyes lifeless, its body is still, the eye of the storm. You can’t help yourself but wonder, where is the storm? Where will it awaken?

The Baraq-Hamil, the Thunder-bearera (check out the Appendix section for its statblock), the mightiest creation of Al-Jazari, sits on the throne. There are carvings and hieroglyphs on the wall, describing the fall of a false king. A DC 10 Intelligence (History) check reveals that this part of history has never reached outside this pyramid, depicting really old events, lost to history. There are two sarcophagi on both sides (A and B in the map) of the stone, they look like royal tombs. Inside them, there are two mummiesj. Right in front of both sarcophagi, a small insignia appears. It is the word نفس (nefs) in the Arabic alphabet, meaning ‘breath.’ It signifies caution, taking a break, stopping, and similar meanings. If no character knows how to speak Arabic, a DC 14 Intelligence (Religion or History) check applies to notice this. It is a warning left by Al-Jazari not to disturb the ones that rest there, giving them a chance to breathe.

If the adventurers succeed on a DC 10 Intelligence (Investigation) or if they are already proficient in reading the Egyptian hieroglyphs, they can decipher this: The walls tell the story of a false king, who uses his powers to rob the wealth of his kingdom and was cursed by the gods. The two priests prayed to the gods for his defeat and were honored, and their tombs were treated like royalty.

If the adventurers do not disturb or try to take any items from the sarcophagi and wait for 1 minute, a passage right below the throne will reveal itself. If they disturb, Baraq-Hamil awakens and attacks the adventurers.

Floor 3 - Water Trap.name: Floor 3 - Water Trap
Floor 3 - Water Trap.text:
A strong wave of force activates when a character moves 20 feet in the room, propelling them to succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw. On a failure, the character is pushed 25 feet into the middle of the room. Additionally, the stairs indicated on the map will disappear into the wall, creating a flat surface that makes climbing nearly impossible.

The stairs reach 40 ft. below, and the area between the other sides starts to be filled with water from the statue marked with a Ͼ symbol (Initiative count 21, losing ties). It fills the area with water each turn (5 ft. high) until the area is filled with water 20 ft. high.

A giant metal plaque (Ω) which is marked with the ㊋ symbol is activated when intruders set foot on the floor (Initiative count 20, losing ties). If a creature touches the plaque, it takes 14 (4d6) fire damage. The metal heats the water, and each turn its heat increases to deadly measures. The creatures inside the water must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take fire damage depending on how many rounds the plaque is active.

  • First round: 7 (2d6) fire damage.
  • Second round: 14 (4d6) fire damage.
  • Third round: 21 (6d6) fire damage.
  • Fourth round: 28 (8d6) fire damage.
  • Fifth round: 35 (10d6) fire damage.

Floor 4 - Time Trap (Ω).name: Floor 4 - Time Trap (Ω)
Floor 4 - Time Trap (Ω).text:
The adventurers must find the portals to reach the exit room. Only through portals (or a hidden lever, which is marked with an A on the map) can they access exit rooms in the north or the south.

Once the intruders are inside Floor 4, they hear a click sound, and it counts seconds. At the end of each of the adventurers’ turns, they magically return where they started their turn unless they coincide with the exit rooms. The exit room has two portals, each leading to an exit.

Portal X: If they exit through the door where they are led by Portal X, the small corridor that leads to Floor 5 has a tiny hidden compartment on the wall (hidden, can be found with a DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check or can be detected with a passive Perception score of 14 or higher). It contains four potions of greater healing.

The Portal X, if analyzed by detect magic, identify or an Intelligence (Arcana) check (DC 15), will leave a faint aura of abjuration behind.

Portal Y: If they exit through the door where they are led by Portal Y, the small corridor that leads to Floor 5 has two spell scrolls of scorching ray in a tiny chest put in the furthest corner. The tiny chest has a lock (DC 13).

Portal Y, if analyzed by detect magic, identify or an Intelligence (Arcana) check (DC 15), will leave a faint aura of evocation behind.

The Lever (A): It can be found by a DC 17 Wisdom (Perception) or an Intelligence (Investigation) check. The find traps or see invisibility spell also reveals its location. It is hidden behind an illusion of rock. The lever opens a magical door to the exit room where the Portal X can be found.

If you wish, the adventurers may encounter Muhafız Al Sihir, Mage Slayersa in the way to prevent them from casting spells as best as they can.

Floor 5 - Passage of the Cognizant.name: Floor 5 - Passage of the Cognizant
Floor 5 - Passage of the Cognizant.text:
Inside the room, a Madd-Jazira (Ω) stands perfectly still at the other end. The ground is jagged with ages of corrosion, making 1-foot movement cost 3 feet of speed. The floor is separated into 6 equal parts with 3 of them empty and the 3 other revealing ancient carvings of the old gods of Egypt. The room has no doors, but a lever is visible behind the frozen construct. Any living creature stepping within a 15-foot radius of it triggers Madd-Jazir to wake up and fight creatures inside the room. Madd-Jazir taking damage also triggers the same effect. A DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check about the construct reveals that as characters get closer to Madd-Jazir, they carry the warm air around them. This air wakes up the construct if it gets closer than 15 feet.

Carvings on the floor symbolize 3 ancient gods of Egypt: Sia, Shu, and Tefnut. The entrance part of the room is dedicated to Sia, the northwest to Shu, and the northeast to Tefnut. With a DC 12 Intelligence (History) Check, the characters can remember the names of the gods and what they symbolize. They roll with advantage if they have a background related to ancient Egyptian culture. Sia symbolizes perception, knowing, and cognizance. Shu is associated with dry, calm air; Tefnut is associated with moisture and rain.

As the characters step into the room, the walls on the east and west of the entrance start to make a shifting noise. The characters notice that the walls are about to start moving. Roll for initiative at that moment, and play the room in turns. Any character with a background related to stonework, such as masonry, realizes that the walls are made out of separate pieces.

At the first round of combat, the walls start to close at a speed of 5 ft per turn on initiative 20 (losing ties). The moving walls are 30-foot-long blocks, leaving no space behind them as they move, and are the same height as the room. There are 2 different wall sections on each side of the room, indicated as the A Walls and the B Walls. A Walls move until they meet but B Walls stop moving after 4 rounds of movement, leaving 5 feet of space between them. If A walls cut through a creature's space when they meet, the creature takes 15 (2d6 + 8) force damage and is pushed to one side of the wall (your choice of which side). The section marked with Sia remains empty when the walls complete their movement. On a successful DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check or DC 13 Passive Perception characters notice a trap door located right above the entrance. On a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check, the wear on the floor is noticed, this reveals that the B Walls stop moving before meeting each other. The lever on the other side of the room opens this trap door and returns the walls back to their starting position. When the trap door is opened, a wooden ladder drops down, allowing characters to continue to the Treasure room.

Floor 6 - Treasure Room.name: Floor 6 - Treasure Room
Floor 6 - Treasure Room.text:
The treasure room is what the pharaoh tried to keep secure from unwanted visitors. It is a frowsy room with a low ceiling, filled with precious jewelry and shiny gold piled on the corners. There is a small passage on the wall that a medium-sized creature can fit through when crawling. The floor of this place, unlike the room before, doesn’t seem to be worn out by the presence of guests. Characters with a Passive Perception 13 hear a mechanical sound as they step into the room. With a successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check they are aware that the sound belongs to a weighing scale. Their entrance to the room triggers the trap door behind them, with a loud shifting noise coming from the walls below. The trap door has no handles to open and it is not locked by a locking mechanism (knock spell doesn’t open it). This trap door is made out of stone and has 100 HP with AC 0.

If characters pick up any item or gold from the ground that was there before they entered, they trigger the golden rain trap. This trap moves the closest wall of the room downward, creating a small gap above. This gap starts pouring gold dinars into the room without stopping. Characters with a Passive Perception 11 realize that after 10 rounds the whole room will be filled with gold, blocking their exit point and crushing them.

After the 10-round timer has started, any action to pick up objects from the ground results in another gap forming on the walls and decreases the timer by 1 (1d4 - 1) rounds (minimum of 1). Characters can pick up 2d12 * Dexterity (Dexterity is considered to be a minimum of 1) amount of gold dinars using an action from the pile on the ground. If they think of a more creative way, such as opening a sack under the gap, they get this amount doubled. Any character trying to hold the gap sealed must succeed at a DC 20 Strength saving throw, this throw is repeated every turn.

When the 10-round timer reaches or passes the middle point (5), the rising gold level makes it difficult terrain. When the timer runs out and the room fills with gold, all creatures inside must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, on a failed throw the creature takes 4d12 force damage and half of it on a successful one. The treasure room contains 1,200 gold dinars worth of jewelry and gold, this amount gets an extra 4,800 gold dinars when the golden rain completely fills the room and then stops, making the total treasure 6,000 gold dinars.

Floor 7 - Khufu’s Room.name: Floor 7 - Khufu’s Room
Floor 7 - Khufu’s Room.text:
The small passage which must be crawled to get here opens into a smaller room than before. This room high up in the pyramid reveals the ultimate protector standing on the farthest corner right before the exit. Albeit the ceiling is high enough for a medium humanoid to stand upright, this room is not any more spacious than the one before. The walls on the opposite side of the room appear segmented unlike the walls next to the entrance, with a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check the characters are informed these walls are moving like the room before.

Other than the moving walls, you are met with the most royal sight: A king in yellow, mummified with elegance, stares at you. Welcoming you with menacing looks, threatening the very life of you. The undead eyes gaze at your very soul. It knows who you are, your vices, sins, and you feel he reads your thoughts. He guards his own tomb from intruders; he is a king, a pharaoh, that fights his own fights.

Roll for initiative when the first character sets foot in the chamber.

Pharaoh Khufu

Medium undead, neutral

Armor Class 16 (Natural Armor)

Hit Points 82 (11d8 + 33)

Speed 25 ft.

STR

18 (+4)

DEX

10 (+0)

CON

17 (+3)

INT

11 (+0)

WIS

18 (+4)

CHA

16 (+3)

Saving Throws Wis +, Cha +7

Damage Resistances bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks

Damage Vulnerabilities fire

Damage Immunities necrotic, poison

Condition Immunities charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, poisoned

Senses darkvision 60 Ft., passive Perception 14

Languages all

Challenge 9 (5,000 XP)

Wallpass. Khufu can pass through walls as a part of his movement but the walls are considered difficult terrains for him. If he ends his turn in a wall he will take 5 (1d10) force damage.

Magic Resistance. Khufu has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Rejuvenation. If it is destroyed, Khufu returns to life in 24 hours unless its heart is destroyed or it is subjected to a dispel evil and good spell.

Spellcasting. His spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 16, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It has the following spells prepared:

Cantrips (at will): sacred flame, poison spray

1st level (4 slots): command, shield

2nd level (3 slots): hold person, spiritual weapon

3rd level (3 slots): animate dead, dispel magic, counterspell

4th level (3 slots): divination, guardian of faith

5th level (2 slots): contagion, insect plague

Actions

Multiattack. Khufu can use his Rotting Bandages ability and make one attack with his Rotting Fist.

Rotting Fist. Melee Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (3d6 + 4) bludgeoning damage plus 10 (3d6) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or be cursed with mummy rot. The cursed target can't regain hit points, and its hit point maximum decreases by 7 (2d6) for every 24 hours that elapse; if the curse reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the target dies.

Rotting Bandages. Khufu hurls his bandages enchanted with magic at a creature within 15 ft. of him. The target must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone and restrained by the bandages. At the end of each turn, the target can repeat the saving throw to be free.

Combat Tactics: Khufu will try to utilize his information on the adventurers, possibly prioritizing attacking those who can hurt him the most or healers. He will also try to utilize his ability to pass through walls with the mechanics below, choosing to strike more isolated foes first.

Unwanted Visitor Repulsor

The West and South walls are separated into 4 blocks each. Every block can move individually through a piston connected to its back. When a block moves, it reaches the other end of the room with the piston fully extended behind and retracts after the round is over.

On initiative count 20 (losing ties) 1d4 is rolled to decide which piston moves for the West wall. At the end of the round, that piston retracts and another piston from the South wall (roll 1d4 to decide) moves on initiative count 20 (losing ties). This is repeated for only one wall (West or South) in a round. Any creature standing in the way while the piston is moving must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or it is pushed 5 feet towards the entrance and takes 20 (4d6 + 6) force damage, on a successful throw the creature can choose which side to be pushed and takes half the damage.

Any one of the wall blocks has 50 HP and the pistons behind them have 40 HP each. When one of the pistons gets broken, the whole system stops working. Pistons are solid and cannot be passed through physically. After the pistons have been activated, a DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check about the room unveils the different types of engineering between the moving walls of the Pyramid, and piston-powered blocks of Al-Jazari.

After Khufu is defeated, you realize the walls tell you a story. It is a story of a king who built this whole pyramid to be a source of inspiration, advancement, and research. You see his dreams, his desire, and his attempt to build the most magnificent building in the world for his country; to reach the gods and be better at everything they already do. However, his demise came too early, with treachery. After that, this great monument was built for the wrong purposes. Still, it carried the will of his people. He couldn’t stay angry at them.

He even forgave his assassin and included a note to her: “My beloved, your actions were clear to me; your motives, born of a heart both fierce and tender. I hold no malice, only forgiveness. Though your journey has taken you beyond my reach, my hope is for your peace, wherever you may rest. I forgive you. You may have taken my life, but you were the one who already gave it to me.”

Stairs open to the final floor.

Floor 8 - The Voice of Shahenshah.name: Floor 8 - The Voice of Shahenshah
Floor 8 - The Voice of Shahenshah.text:
As you step into the hushed expanse of the ancient chamber, your eyes are immediately drawn to the center where a soft, otherworldly light bathes a solitary object. There, on a time-worn sandstone pedestal, rests the Cylinder of Cyrus. This artifact, made of clay and intricately inscribed with cuneiform script, radiates a presence that is almost tangible.

You feel the air around you charged, the very stone beneath your feet thrumming with the cylinder’s hidden power. Shadows play along the walls, hinting at the presence of guardians long passed who might still watch over this sacred relic. As you move closer, the whispers of a struggle fill the chamber, echoing with tales of peace and governance from an empire long faded.

You are standing in a vault dedicated to the protection of this world. The last item you need to reach the further depths of the Church of Resurrection: The Cylinder of Cyrus before you is not just an ancient artifact, it carries the Voice of Shahenshah, the shah of shahs; only few truly carried this title. Only a few of them achieved becoming the king of kings.

A faint melody can be heard from it, as if it desires a note, a command or some voice in a similar note. It knows you are there, it feels the existence of your brand, your sigil.

The Cylinder of Cyrus can be obtained, but it is not the only item there. A DC 16 Wisdom (Perception) or Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals that the stone holds one more item: Khufu’s Heart. Unless destroyed, Khufu will be born again.

Once the cylinder is taken, a magical portal will appear and a Muzahira will recite Al-Jazari’s voice:

“Well, since the brutal curse I put on the cylinder did not obliterate you, I can assume you wish to be rid of this place without encountering any more dangers. I only have one small request from you: do not harm the pharaoh’s heart. It is already broken as it is, and I do not want it to be entirely gone from this world. With a universe full of cruel and evil kings and lords, I count myself lucky that I met three such figures in this narrow part of the world. It would honor me that the pharaoh may continue to guard his tomb, as it is the only thing that remains for him. Thanks in advance.”

The portal leads them right outside the pyramid, potentially without any eyewitnesses. If the adventurers do not destroy Khufu’s heart, he will rise again in a few days. If they wish to destroy it nonetheless, it can be done with a single attack that deals at least 3 damage. The heart is immune to necrotic and poison damage.

The Voice of Shahenshah, Cylinder of Cyrus

Musical instrument, legendary, requires attunement by a creature that has at least one musical instrument proficiency

It has twelve rings on it. The rings can be turned to produce some magical effects:

  • The Bard of Bards: While attuned to it, you can cast these spells: fly, invisibility, levitate, protection from evil and good, confusion, control weather, and fire storm spells. To cast them you must turn a number of rings equal to the spell’s level from the cylinder. Once turned, they won’t turn back until dawn. The DC for the spells is 18.
  • Chorus of Liberation: Once per day, by correctly aligning the rings and playing the harmonious tune prescribed in the ancient scrolls, you can cast the spell dispel magic at the 5th level without expending a spell slot.
  • Harmony of Binding: Twice per day, you may align the rings to emit a series of notes that replicate the effects of the hold person spell on up to two targets simultaneously (A DC 18 Wisdom saving throw to resist).
  • Symphony of the Shahenshah: Once per day, you can turn all the rings and choose a tune that is recorded by it or record a new song. Each “recording” must be at least 1 minute and can be up to 10 minutes.

The adventurers advance to Level 7.

Act III: Little Death by the Paradise.text:
“God sleeps in the rock, dreams in the plant, stirs in the animal, and awakens in man.”

-Ibn Arabi

Library Pageless - Sanctum of the New Man

Section Summary: The adventurers will infiltrate the deadly library of Peter the Hermit and will meet with Ismail Al-Jazari, the famous advisor and engineer of Sultan Saladin. They will venture deep into the Library Pageless and clash with Peter the Hermit.

The approach to the Library Pageless is unassuming at first - with the Sanctum, the Castle of Peter the Hermit looks to be but a bland construct of stone. Yet as you approach, the texture of the stone reveals a portion of its secrets to your eyes. The stone is almost infiltrated by a blue sinew-like substance, ever so slightly pulsing with energy.

There is no other possibility - this is the place you are looking for.

Basics of the Dungeon

  • The adventurers are Level 6; they will reach Level 7 at the end of this dungeon.
  • They will meet Al-Jazari in this dungeon as Al-Jazari exchanged himself so that Saladin would gain the last seal.

  • The monsters in the dungeon are bearing the Moth Sigil. There are 4 types of monsters, all connected to each other through the Sigil’s Hive Mind. Their combat style emphasizes assisting and empowering one another during combat. Check out their statblocks below.

The Sigil of Moth

Ignorance is bliss for those who carry the mortal shell of humanity. Only the ones that serve Peter the Hermit and his Library Pageless find the true meaning of knowing and learning, that is moving beyond the constraints of flesh. It is no simple task after all. Their life is in agony, yet their mind is stronger than ever. They carry the burden, and face the consequences while facing their fear. They share one mind and heed the voice of the hermit, and all see and think as one.

Shared Spellcasting: The bearers of Moth Sigils have access to these spells and can cast them innately when they are within 60 ft. of each other and at least three of them are together, due to their connection with Peter the Hermit, the bearer of the Moth Sigil. Their spell save DC is 15 and they have +8 to hit with spell attacks.

The Mechanics of the Dungeon

Peter the Hermit is a trans-human who has transcended the limits of humanity, and he resides at the brain of the dungeon. Within the Library, there are several chambers where paralyzed individuals are placed to have their brains, minds, experiences, memories, and information drained.

The main attraction of the dungeon is the Atrium - where an artificial heart is chained at the very center. Melded with the pulsing heart, Bernard of Clairvaux (an ancient preacher that ignited the Second Crusade and an old master of the Knights Templar) serves as the gatekeeper to the brain, at the Atrium. Flanking the Atrium, there are two enclosed botanical gardens that fulfill the role of the lungs - pumping compressed air for the artificial heart.

Below the main floor lies the spine and the ribcage of the New Man, which is still in construction. Battling through the cultist-infested debris, the players reach the laboratory and the prison - where new items, allies, and secrets can be gathered.

Dungeon Aesthetics

Half lost in a craggy expanse of the Sinai mountains, the Library Pageless is a stone church that marries the stark grandeur of medieval architecture with something wholly otherworldly. The building’s heavy stone walls, worn and chipped by time, are tinged with vivid blue sinews that beat in slow, rhythmic pulses: the motion of arcane life. At night, the sinews generate a faint spectral light, highlighting the intricate façade against the moonlit sky, creating a striking contrast between the bizarre sinew and the harsh stone. Their faint light creeps through the structure’s cracks and gaps, as though some terrible power were held captive deep in the church’s very bones.

The church’s defenders are not outside. The statues of knights and saints that guard the Library Pageless are carved from the same stone as its walls, but they remain untouched by the sinew’s livid blue light. They stand sentinel along the walkways and watch the shadowed alcoves, stony gazes that follow every movement. Executed with lifelike detail, the statues evoke an awful sense of movement – as though the Library Pageless’s defenders might hurl themselves into battle the instant they are summoned. The drowning of the church’s history in this creeping mysticism instills a sense of grim majesty in all those who visit: The Library Pageless’s beauty is a thing of shadowed power, brought to life by an omnipresent thrum.

Approach to the Library Pageless

As you traverse the windswept plains that lead to the Library Pageless, the silhouette of a grand stone church-castle emerges against the dusky sky. Its spires pierce the horizon like jagged teeth, and its walls, though seemingly impenetrable, are etched with the passage of time and secrets. The castle stands solitary, its imposing structure casting long shadows over the barren landscape.

As you draw nearer, a sense of unease begins to gnaw at your senses. The wind carries a whispering echo, as if the very air around the castle is laden with watchful eyes. The ground beneath your feet feels unnervingly firm, almost as though it compels you forward on a path from which there is no deviation.

The closer you get, the more palpable the sensation of being watched becomes. There are no guards visible, yet you can't shake the feeling that every step is being monitored and measured by unseen observers.

Observant adventurers may notice subtle movements in the castle's windows—a DC 14 Perception Check reveals a fleeting shadow here, a brief flicker there, suggesting the presence of patrolling entities within.

If the Perception check is a success, the adventurers begin to realize that they are being watched. Given the unnerving feeling of being observed, moving stealthily becomes crucial. A successful DC 15 Dexterity (Stealth) check allows the party to approach the castle without alerting its inhabitants. Failing this check might mean that the adventurers are expected, and perhaps, unwelcome surprises await at the entrance.

Possible Entrances

Main Entrance

The main entrance, although heavily guarded, proves to be the easiest access to the main floor of the Library Pageless. If the adventurers fail to scout the area properly, or decide that they do not have the time or the means to slip into the dungeon undetected, this is their entrance.

The Cracked Rib

The basement of the Library Pageless is a maze of stone and arcane sinew - as eldritch bonelike structures are being built by hand. This floor is still under heavy construction and a careful eye, with a DC 18 Wisdom (Perception) check, could spot a haphazardly covered cave allowing entry to the Sanctum, unhindered by the guards at the Main Gate.

Main Entrance.name: Main Entrance
Main Entrance.text:
Main Entrance

As you climb the few untainted stone stairs spiraling up to the main entrance of Library Pageless, the feeling that you are being watched is undeniable. The stones appear to be gently moving with your step in unison, a dusty trail is evidence
of this conclusion.

You gaze upon the imposing stone door, barely distinct from the walls of the Sanctum. With a bold challenge, it declares, ‘’ Only those who dare change for the faith may enter.’’ A flurry of footsteps is approaching.

This is the entrance to the Library Pageless - a small courtyard flanked by a rocky cliff, reached by a few flights of stairs. The main building is accessed through a massive stone door which is unlocked. Some Sigil Knights are present here as a direct challenge, and others lie in ambush if the party is careless in their approach to the Sanctum.

3 Hermit’s Followers of the Moth Sigil guards the entrance, and will fight to death against any intruders.

If the party approaches carelessly, 2 Hermit’s Acolytes of the Moth Sigil will wait on the other side of the stone door. They will burst through the door and rush into combat when the party attacks the main entrance.

The First Corridor.name: The First Corridor
The First Corridor.text:
The First Corridor

The first corridor of the Sanctum is eerily silent, with the fluttering of moths and breathing of your allies the only evidence of life.

The walls are, just as they were from the outside, tainted with blue sinewlike fibers. The stones are cracked and some parts of the walls appear to have collapsed inward. Some occasional inward bends are adorned with statues of knights, and displays of crude metal armor.

From within one of the cracks, you sense movement for a second, not to be repeated again.

The first corridor of the Sanctum connects the main entrance, the Atrium, the Prison, and the Laboratory.

The corridor is bereft of any sort of life for the naked eye. There are many holes within walls, appearing as if they are cracks in stone - though some are simply too large and uniform to be as such.

A DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check would reveal these cracks were actually intentionally manufactured - and some, now very narrow cracks have organic material within them. If the organic material is investigated a DC 18 Wisdom (Medicine) check would reveal that the material is awfully similar to human guts - and it pulses as if it is still alive.

All four gates are unlocked. The gates to the left and the right are significantly less imposing than the main entrance and the gate to the Atrium.

If the party goes to some other room and comes back to the First Corridor, 3 Hermit’s Followers, and 1 Hermit’s Prophet will attempt to ambush them. The Hermit’s Prophet will pose as the armor on display, and the Hermit’s Followers will try to pull the party tanks away from the Hermit’s Prophet so the prophet can target the mages and healers.

Prison - Main Level.name: Prison - Main Level
Prison - Main Level.text:
Prison - Main Level

As you open the door, you are greeted with a sea of locks, locks, keys, and torches, as if someone were preparing to construct a prison that would stretch the whole Sinai. The growls coming from below tend to agree.

This is the main level of the Prison Complex. This room appears to function like the guard’s gateway into the prison cells below - with a massive spiral staircase right in the center of the room. The room is filled with an impressive trove of locks, keys, and unburnt torches. The stairs have enough room to have two medium-sized creatures in one row.

When the party starts descending the stairs, 2 Hermit’s Acolytes from each end will assault them. These Acolytes’ will first attempt to throw party members down the center of the spiral stairs - resulting in a 60 foot drop.

The details on the stairs, the prison cells, and the dropzone can be found in the section below called Prison - Basement Level.

Barracks - Main Level.name: Barracks - Main Level
Barracks - Main Level.text:
Barracks - Main Level

The Barracks of the Library Pageless are stark and minimalistic, reflecting the utilitarian lifestyle. This long, narrow room is lined with rows of simple cots, each accompanied by a small wooden chest at its foot. The air is heavy with a mixture of dust and the faint, lingering scent of incense. Sparse torches mounted on the walls cast a dim, flickering light, shadowing the faces of stone statues of saints that watch silently over the sleeping arrangements.

The chests contain a peculiar mix of personal items and equipment, remnants of the cultists' former lives before their transformation into hive-minded servants. A faded painting peeks out from one chest, its edges worn and the colors muted, depicting a lively marketplace that seems worlds away from the cold stone confines of the barracks. Another chest holds a collection of carefully wrapped and preserved letters. The ink has faded, but the handwriting is still elegant and desperate, hinting at a past filled with love and loss. A third contains an assortment of old, rusting tools—a hammer, several chisels, and a worn leather apron—tools of a craftsman's trade long abandoned.

This is the main Barracks of the Library Pageless. It seems to have been abandoned, though the room is overflowing with assortments of personal items - discarded as the Sigil starts taking a deeper control of those afflicted by it. You can find some of the items in the table below.

At the far end of the room, a small, spiral staircase winds tightly downward, disappearing into the darkness below. This stairway, barely noticeable among the shadows, leads to the lower levels of the Library Pageless. The creak of the steps and the cool draft rising from below add a physical sense to the mysteries that lie below.

d4

Personal ıtems

1- Cracked Locket

A small silver locket, its surface scratched and the hinge cracked, containing a carved portrait of a woman with a gentle smile. The locket, when inspected closely, reveals an intricate engraving on the inside that reads "Always with you, M & J.’’

2- Child's Wooden Toy

A simple wooden horse, the paint chipped and faded, tucked away in the corner of a chest. This toy is a stark reminder of the humanity that once was.

3- Herbalist's Pouch

A small pouch containing dried herbs and a few crumbling pages from an old botanical book. The herbs still release a faint, earthy aroma when handled, indicating a past life devoted to healing and nature.

4- Map of Distant Lands

A rolled-up, tattered map showing lands and seas far from Sinai, marked with notes and routes in meticulous handwriting in Old Norse. It showcases two massive continents to the west of Europe. It must be some madman who drew this.

The Atrium.name: The Atrium
The Atrium.text:
The Atrium

The Atrium of the Library Pageless is a grand chamber that both captivates and horrifies. Dominating the space is the Artificial Heart, a grotesque and pulsating construct at the room's center. This abomination blends molten organic matter with the sinuous blue veins of the castle and intricate mechanical devices into a living engine. Chained to this heart is an ancient preacher now serving as a tortured power source for the heart's ceaseless throbbing.

The room is filled with the constant, eerie hum of energy pulsing through the blue sinews, intertwining with the clanks and hisses of the mechanical components.

The Atrium is quite literally and figuratively the heart of the Library Pageless. This is the room that unlocks the entry to the final room where Peter the Hermit, and his prisoner Al-Jazari, reside.

In the right center of the room is the Artificial Heart - an abomination created by combining molten organic matter, the blue sinews, and mechanical contraptions. Chained to it is Bernard of Clairvaux (Hermit’s Prophet of the Moth), an ancient preacher that ignited the Second Crusade and an old master of the Knights Templar (for further information on Knights Templar, check out Jerusalem - City of God section in Era of the Crusades). He turns immediately hostile to the adventurers, though he cannot move from his place in the center of the room.

Once Bernard of Clairvaux is defeated, the party can access the controls of the Artificial Heart. The party needs a DC 18 Arcana, Medicine or Investigation check to learn how the contraption works. The Artificial Heart pulls compressed air from Western and Eastern Hothouses, uses the arc generated by the blue sinew pulses to ignite it, and spins the massive engine in the Trachea, opening the gate to the Cranium, and distributing he waterthroughout the Sanctum.

There are five levers controlling the Artificial Heart. Only after passing the previous checks can the adventurers figure out which is which.

  • Lever One empties the water in the Trachea.
  • Lever Two fills the Trachea with water.
  • Lever Three ignites the Air in the igniting chamber.
  • Lever Four empties the Air in the igniting chamber.

  • Lever Five fills the chamber with air. This can be done three times, but upon the third pull, the chamber explodes - the effect is equal to a fireball spell. If the chamber explodes, the Trachea is also destroyed, breaking open the entry to the Cranium.

Western & Eastern Botanic Gardens.name: Western & Eastern Botanic Gardens
Western & Eastern Botanic Gardens.text:
Western & Eastern Botanic Gardens

The Botanic Gardens of the Library Pageless are different from the rest of the stone-clad Sanctum. These lush, verdant rooms are more akin to a botanical garden, albeit one twisted by eldritch infusions and dark purposes. Towering plants with vibrant, unnatural colors stretch towards the ceiling, their leaves tinged with an eerie luminescence. Interspersed among the flora are brass pipes that curve and twist like vines, drawing air into the room to fuel the arcane mechanisms of the Library.

Western Botanic is one of the lungs of the Library Pageless. The room is filled with a chaotic array of plant life, all corrupted by the Sigil and penetrated from root to the flower with the blue sinews. The room’s inward wall is porous, hosting a series of brass pipes. Stone windows embedded in the thick walls are equipped with an ingenious system connected to the pulsating blue sinews of the castle. These windows open automatically in response to rhythmic signals from the sinews, regulating the environment within the hothouse to perfect conditions for its strange occupants.

In this room, the Moth cultists have undergone horrific transformations, becoming one with carnivorous plants. These cultist-plant hybrids are camouflaged seamlessly among the foliage, waiting for unsuspecting prey. Their bodies are partially visible, melded into the stalks and roots of the plants, with their faces twisted in permanent grimaces of both agony and ecstasy. Success on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check allows adventurers to avoid a surprise attack, while failure means being ambushed by these gruesome guardians, 2 Hermit’s Acolytes.

The Trachea.name: The Trachea
The Trachea.text:
The Trachea

This room, located just before the entrance to the Cranium, is dominated by a colossal gear situated in the center. The gear, an intricate assembly of brass and steel, sits partially submerged in a pool of water that fills the chamber. The walls are lined with stone and brass conduits that channel the water, pulsating with the same eerie blue sinews that run throughout the castle.

The Trachea acts as both the literal and metaphorical throat of the Sanctum. As the Artificial Heart in the Atrium pumps and pulses, it drives the massive gear in the Trachea, which in turn activates the water distribution system of the entire building. This mechanism not only circulates water but also, when fully operational, unlocks the gate that leads to the Cranium, granting access to the most sacred and guarded area of the Sanctum.

The operation of the gear is deeply tied to the rhythmic life force of the Artificial Heart. The energy generated by the heart travels through the sinews, converting into mechanical power that turns the gear. This process is vital for maintaining the life-supporting systems within the Library, symbolizing a breathing process through which the Sanctum itself lives and operates.

If the explosion in the Atrium occurs, due to the room being filled with water, navigating through it requires swimming. A DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check is necessary to move effectively through the water without exhaustion or disorientation.

The Spine.name: The Spine
The Spine.text:
The Spine

Descending into the depths of the Library Pageless, you enter a vast hallway marred with construction material. This immense space stretches far beyond the reach of your torchlight, with brass pipes running along the ceiling and walls, intermittently emitting steam with a hiss that echoes through the corridor. The hall is dominated by large bulges of the pulsating blue sinews that are embedded into the structure of the castle itself, weaving in and out of the walls and floors as if forming a complex organic network.

The walls are lined with identical small doors, each leading to various ongoing construction sites within the Library. The sound of distant hammering and the clang of metal suggest that the construction is a continuous effort, with cultists laboring tirelessly to expand the Sanctum's eerie anatomy.

This is the main hallway of the Basement Level - where it is apparent that a massive construction effort is ongoing. Examining the layout of the pipes and the placement of the sinews, an astute adventurer might realize that the architecture mimics the human circulatory and nervous systems, hinting that the castle itself is being shaped into a vast, living organism - and that they are at the Spine of this New Man.

Recognizing the organic nature of the sinews, a character passing a DC 15 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Medicine) can discern here that the stone-piercing blue sinews and copper pipes function similarly to nerves and veins, pulsating with what could only be described as the castle’s lifeblood.

For those well-versed in arcane lore, on a successful DC 22 Intelligence (Arcana) check they will see that the pattern and flow of magical energy through the sinews reveals how the energy must be harnessed from something alive, possibly acting as a conduit for a larger, unseen power.

Within the construction site, there are several items useful for carrying heavy objects.

Worker's Harness: Found hanging on a hook next to one of the doors, this harness is designed to distribute weight evenly across the body, making it easier to carry heavy loads. It grants a temporary +1 bonus to Strength checks related to lifting and carrying.

Tonic of Vigor: A small, dusty bottle containing a thick, syrupy liquid. When consumed, it grants the drinker a +2 bonus to Constitution checks for one hour, useful for enduring the strenuous labor of construction.

There are several small, identical doors to the north of the hall - and two massive doors to the south.

The Ribs.name: The Ribs
The Ribs.text:
The Ribs

Branching off from the Spine are several corridor-shaped rooms. These areas are in varying stages of construction, filled with the sound of clanging metal and the glow of forge fires. Massive brass spires dominate the centers of these rooms, each meticulously crafted and awaiting installation. These spires are designed to extend upward through the floors of the Library Pageless, symbolically and structurally serving as the protective ribs of the castle.

The air in each Rib is thick with soot, and the heat from the forges is almost suffocating. Scattered around the forges are tools and half-finished brass components, reflecting the immense scale of the construction efforts.

There are 8 mostly identical rooms in total. The table below provides details for each - and a few skill checks to determine which is which for the players below.

d8

Description

Associated Skill Check

1

3 Hermit’s Followers are chiseling stone within this room, their senses dulled to nothing due to the sound and dust cloud within. If the adventurers enter the room, they immediately turn hostile.

DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) Check - Reveals the room as being inhabited.

2

This room appears to have been used for planning and logistics. Several blueprints of the Library Pageless lay on a table right in the middle of the room. There is a contraption by the entrance, a rope attached to some mechanism that goes into the stonework of the Library Pageless. If the rope is pulled, bells ring out, and 1 Hermit’s Acolyte and 1 Hermit’s Follower march to this room.

DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) Check - Reveals that the contraption summons cultists to this room.

3

The construction in this room is almost finished with the forge’s embers dying out. A brass spire is erected near the end of the room. A successful Arcana check reveals that these brass spires will pierce the ground and cover the main level like a ribcage.

DC 18 Intelligence (Arcana) Check - Reveals the purpose of the Spires.

4

A corpse decorates the floor of this room - freshly cut. The body belongs to a young boy, wearing what was supposed to be a shepherd’s cloth - now in tatters. A successful Wisdom (Medicine) check reveals that the body contains no taint of the Sigil.

DC 15 Wisdom (Medicine) check reveals the lack of Sigil on the corpse.

5

This room is used as a small warehouse to store all the heavy materials used for construction. A great place to hide to evade pursuers.

Advantage on Stealth checks in this room.

6

This room is empty, and the construction work has not started at all here. A good place to rest perhaps.

No discernible noise comes from this room.

7

The Cracked Rib. This is the room where a brass spire poised to break the ground broke down, leaving a medium-sized passage connecting outside to the inside. Adventurers may use this passage to move between the Basement level and outside of the dungeon.

DC 18 Wisdom (Perception) or Intelligence (Nature) check reveals the fresh air coming from this room.

8

This room is practically empty. Except for a tortoise, standing right in the middle of it. He seems to be wearing a Crusader helm.

‘’Hi!’’ the tortoise says, muffled under the helm. ‘’How’s it going? You wouldn’t happen to have any lettuce on you now, would you?’’ The tortoise seems to be distinctly uncaring of what is going on around him.

DC 30 Intelligence (Arcana) check reveals that this tortoise is more than what he seems.

Prison - Basement Level.name: Prison - Basement Level
Prison - Basement Level.text:
Prison - Basement Level

Located just beside the massive spiral staircase that leads to the depths of the dungeon, the prison cells line the walls of dimly lit stairs. The air is damp and heavy with despair, the stone walls cold and unyielding. Each cell is secured with thick iron bars, some showing signs of rust from the moisture that seeps through the stones.

The very bottom of the staircase is a grim scene, covered in dried bloodstains that tell tales of past tortures or executions.

The prison cells are mostly empty - though this brings no comfort as even the empty cells are covered in bloodstains, and the eldritch hue emanating from the blue sinews. The iron bars are all covered in the same pulsing nerves, disallowing any attempt at lockpicking. The adventurers may attempt to break open the prison bars - a heavy bludgeoning weapon or tool (like a maul), and a DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check is needed. If they undertake such a task, a guard force of 3 Hermit’s Acolytes will notice the noise and will attempt to stop the adventurers.

The Prison Complex contains the following cellmates:

Sir Geoffrey de Payens

Sir Geoffrey de Payens, one of the founding knights of the Templar Order, was captured during a secretive mission near Jerusalem. Known for his strategic mind and devout faith, Sir Geoffrey was exploring ancient relics that purportedly could sway the outcomes of battles when he was taken prisoner.

Zafar al-Bahr

Zafar al-Bahr, a celebrated navigator and tactician of Saladin's fleet, is renowned for his crucial role in securing the coastal cities against Crusader fleets. Captured during a clandestine mission to undermine the Crusaders' sea routes, Zafar is a wellspring of naval strategy and geographic knowledge.

Avempace

Once a renowned philosopher and polymath from the Iberian Peninsula, Avempace finds himself a prisoner within the cold, damp walls of the Library Pageless. His extensive knowledge of astronomy, medicine, and philosophy made him an invaluable but dangerous figure to those who feared the spread of knowledge. Avempace spends his days deep in thought, often engaging in profound discussions with his fellow prisoner, Ser Alistair, about the cultural and intellectual exchanges during the Reconquista.

Ser Alistair

Ser Alistair, a determined and battle-hardened crusader from Spain, was captured during his mission far from the familiar battlegrounds of the Reconquista. His quest led him to Persia, where he pursued a djinn-like figure rumored to possess ancient secrets and formidable powers. In the prison, he shares these stories with Avempace, finding common ground in their discussions about their homeland’s history, despite their differing perspectives on faith and warfare.

Laboratory.name: Laboratory
Laboratory.text:
Laboratory

This sterile, dimly lit room is lined with rows of intricate machinery and arcane instruments, each humming with a low, ominous energy. Whatever air is left in this forsaken room is thick with the scent of chemicals. At the center of the Laboratory stands an array of massive apparatus—a combination of alchemical distillers, mechanical restraints, and mystical sigils—designed for the extraction and manipulation of the human mind.

The walls are adorned with shelves filled with jars containing swirling, luminescent substances—essences and memories extracted from the minds of prisoners. These shelves also hold numerous implements used for the precise and often painful installation of the Moth Sigil, a mark that binds the will of its bearer to the collective consciousness of the cult.

Lesser inmates are strapped into mechanical chairs equipped with neural interface helmets. These devices are designed to siphon thoughts, memories, and knowledge, transferring them into containment vessels. The process is excruciating, as it not only extracts informational content but also drains the subject’s vitality, leaving them in a state of empty compliance.

Once the minds are extracted, other subjects—potential cult members—are brought in. These individuals undergo a forced indoctrination process where the extracted essences are either infused into them or used to manipulate their thoughts to align with the cult’s doctrines. The Sigil of the Moth is then surgically implanted into their bodies, marking them physically and spiritually as members of the cult. This area is fraught with surgical tools and arcane devices that glow with a menacing light.

There is one poor soul still attached to the contraption - though a DC 15 Wisdom (Medicine) check reveals his indoctrination process is incomplete. The man violently screams and flaps his arms around. The adventurers may choose to free him, put him out of his misery, or decide to leave him there in fear of guards catching them. If freed from his shackles, the poor man will keep saying between sobs, “Rosemary, little girl of mine. Where have you been for all this time?’’ He will also attempt to run away from the Sanctuary, with no regard for stealth.

The Final Room - The Cranium.name: The Final Room - The Cranium
The Final Room - The Cranium.text:
The Final Room - The Cranium

You approach the final room through a gate, now flooded with water. The room is brightly lit with natural light shining through two observatory openings in the domed roof. This would have been a marvelous vista had it not been thoroughly corrupted by the being that is nestled in the other side of the room. A twisted amalgamation of bodies, organic tissue, and stone appears to have descended from a singular figure on a stone throne - Peter the Hermit, or what remains of him that is. He is in a heated conversation with another human being, interestingly uncorrupted and locked in a cage-like contraption.

This is the final room of the Library Pageless, where the party has the chance to break the Seal of Peter the Hermit and save Al-Jazari.

By the time the adventurers enter the room, Peter the Hermit and Al-Jazari will be far into their discussions regarding combining organic matters with clockwork mechanisms. Peter was expecting the party to arrive since the moment they set foot into the Sanctum. A series of events occur as the encounter starts. Before initiatives are rolled, an organic leech-like apparatus strikes the back of Al-Jazari’s head, grasping the inventor’s head and not letting go. Secondly, the observatory openings close, cutting all the natural light from the room. Then, Peter attempts to parley with the adventurers with clear demands: leave the Sanctum and never return, or the world will never have a chance at ascending from the human form - otherwise he will kill them in a heartbeat, and suck intelligence from Al-Jazari, leaving him a husk of his former self.

Once the combat starts, each turn Al-Jazari’s intelligence will be drained by 1. The first 5 points drained can be brought back by casting a greater restoration spell, but any draining after that is permanent. Any healing spell cast on Al-Jazari stops the drain for that turn. Peter the Hermit will gain any Intelligence drained as a temporary bonus until the end of combat.

The players may attack the contraption to free Al-Jazari and get him to join the combat as an Ally. The apparatus has the following stats:

It has 10 Armor Class, and 110 Hit Points. It has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage. It is immune to poison, psychic and lightning and it's vulnerable against force damage.

Boss Room: Peter the Hermit has his own stat block and a special Lair action. At initiative count 20, he decides whether to cast magical darkness (4th level) or create a blinding bright light by controlling the observatory openings: the characters must make DC 15 Constitution saving throws or be blinded this turn, and they must repeat the roll every turn as long as the room still has the blinding bright light. He can also forgo this ability and instead focus the lenses on a single player character, making a free scorching ray spell attack (the spell attack stats are the same as Peter the Hermit’s own stats).

The adventurers advance to Level 7.

The War Camp of the Victorious Sultan.name: The War Camp of the Victorious Sultan
The War Camp of the Victorious Sultan.text:
Section Summary: The adventurers will have a chance to visit Sultan Saladin and learn of the ritual he is planning on the city. Saladin offers them several solutions for defeating the ancient evil lurking beneath the City of God.

The sight of the golden sun greets you. This time, the sun has a twin on the ground: The army of Saladin the Victorious. After his victory at the Battle of Hattin, the armies of Jerusalem were scattered and no great power could stand in his way! The city of Jerusalem is besieged and waiting for the darkening of days.

If the adventurers are on good terms with Saladin, they will be welcomed into the war camp. Saladin will see them personally in a private tent where no one is able to see them.

If the adventurers bring Ismail Al-Jazari with them, the sultan will be grateful and even if there is some enmity towards them, this could heal it.

There are some topics they may discuss:

  • Saladin is sure that the city must be taken tonight. However, the biggest challenge they face is Balian of Ibelin. The brave knight has taken control of the city’s defenses and even though most of the knights are dead and scattered in the Battle of Hattin, the civilians that took up arms in the city fight very well. The first assault on the gates failed.
  • There are three options in the eyes of Saladin: First option: The adventurers could convince Balian to parley (A Call for Truce). Second option: They could sneak into the city (City Sewers). Third option: Saladin is preparing a small strike force that will attempt to storm a small breach and open the gates (Storm the Gates). They could help these soldiers and lighten their tasks easily.

It is recommended that the adventurers have a few hours to prepare before embarking on their last quest, especially if you placed a time limit for the adventurers as mentioned earlier under the Cairo: Golden Towers section in Act II. However, if they are delayed in Cairo or between cities, time could be compressed to force them to act quickly.

If they arrive too late, check out the Conclusions section at the end of this Act.

If the adventurers are delayed or arrive late to the scene, they will find Saladin preparing for a bloody ritual, one that is close to what Cyrus the Great did once. He will briefly explain the situation and his lack of options:

  • Cyrus sacrificed many souls and blood to bind the Whore of Babylon. Saladin must do what it takes to do the same. One city is not important against the safety of the Holy Lands.
  • This ritual will require the deaths of thousands, and a victorious siege can present the sacrifice necessary.
  • Saladin prefers not to go down this route, but he is running out of options as Balian refuses to yield the city. He can only grant the adventurers very little time for them to slay Whore of Babylon.

A Call for Truce

The adventurers could try to convince Balian to parley for a truce that would let the adventurers enter the city and give them time to take the evil out. However, first, they will have to convince that the evil that they are trying to destroy truly exists as Balian does not know the full extent of what is transpiring behind the veil.

Balian of Ibelin can be convinced to participate in a parley with a DC 13 Charisma (Persuasion) check. However, he must be given assurances.

  • Adventurers could offer some valuable (both material and sentimental could be applied at your discretion) aspects of themselves, such as a really precious magic item, a token from their dead mentor, the White Book, or something similar..

  • If their actions were honorable during the time they spent with Balian, they could prove their sincerity by taking an oath,, or showing a similar way that is appropriate for their culture with a DC 15 Charisma check (proper proficiencies may apply).

City Sewers

The Jerusalem walls are sternly guarded by Knights and Balian himself, and all gates are also protected by Crusader garrisons. Balian already anticipates an attack through the sewers.

If they attempt to go through the sewers they can be put against a handpicked Crusader Veteran at the entrance to the city with a potential threat of the Crusader calling for help. You could enforce a time restraint (such as 3 rounds) for the Veteran to be taken down or there could be a bell for him to call for reinforcements, unless stopped earlier. If reinforcements are called, Balian and 5 Crusader Veterans show up to confront the adventurers.

Before they venture, Saladin offers them whatever their heart desires in exchange for opening the gates for him. However, he won’t hold a grudge or resent the adventurers if they refuse to do so and will understand their decision.

Storm the Gates

If the adventurers decide to Storm the Gates, they will be escorted by a Mamluk Ghazia and 5 Mamluk Cavalriesa. The names of the cavalries: Yaqub Qabar ad-Din Dibiyaza, Khalid Kashmiri, Khidir Kharawita, Ismail Ahmad Kanabawi, Usman Abd-al Jalal Shisha and Ghazi’s name is Muhammad Sumbul.

These men are counted as heroes in the army, the finest of the Mamluk warriors. During Saladin’s ascension to power, they played a pivotal role and took down the whole vanguard of the former Fatimid Sultan, consisting of at least fifty men in under a minute. Since that day, they have been known as “Qabdat al-Yusuf”, the Fist of Yusuf, the birth name of Saladin. If the adventurers choose this way, they must fight against at least twenty Knightsj, three Crusader Knightsa and Balian of Ibelin himself.

Whatever they choose, the effects of the Whore of Babylon start to shake the core of the Holy Lands as soon as they enter the Fallen Jerusalem.

A sudden rush of emotion rushes over your mind: A Mother's Embrace. You are sure that the evil that lies beneath the holy city is close to emerging from the ground. You are sure that this is her effect that puts this feeling in your hearts. It’s penetrating down to your guts, your spirit itself, and strangling it.

Your willpower and the the sigil lets you embrace the arcane pulse and perhaps even disregard it altogether, but the people around you start to fall asleep one by one. Only the strongest remain awake, fighting the terrible curse. Only those whose minds could fight back retain conciousness. The shock of the event is not only a bane for the defenders of Jerusalem - it terrorizes both sides. Saladin's warcamp took control back quickly, pulling their forces back from assigned assaults with cries of faith and resurgence.

Inside the walls, Balian remained with a handful of civilians, hardly able to fight - so Saladin's retreat was a boon as much as the curse a bane. With the power of Roland’s ring, those that rose as true Knights of Jerusalem manage to beat back the acute effects of the eldritch corruption surrounding them - for a brief moment that is. The city held her breath.

A dark hour is now the fate of the city.

Jerusalem: Under the Dark Star.name: Jerusalem: Under the Dark Star
Jerusalem: Under the Dark Star.text:
Section Summary: The adventurers are greeted by a sleeping Jerusalem as they venture deep in the Church and open the last seal. There, they reach the Womb of the Dragon and Sibylla, the Queen of Jerusalem.

Estimated Level: 7-8

The adventurers are drawn to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre like moths to a flame - their sigil whispering eldritch madness to their mind. The Church is abandoned and not guarded anymore. So, the adventurers can easily enter the Church and go deeper than Omar and Heraclius once did.

Church of the Holy Sepulchre:
The Last Seal

With the Cylinder of Cyrus, the adventurers can break open the last seal with words from a lament, any lament. If they know none, the remains of the room can be examined with a DC 10 Intelligence check. (Investigation, Religion or History) or Wisdom (Insight)) checks may also apply.

If they succeed on the check, they will realize that many of the mosaics and remnants, visible through the black veins and other broken tissues, resemble a tear taking shape. If they can read, the words are strictly about weeping, mourning, bidding farewell, leaving, heartbreak and similar emotions - with occasional fragments forming lyrics of ancient laments. Laments to Orpheus, Laments to Tammuz, to Enkidu, and to many myths of bygone times.

The Womb of the Dragon.name: The Womb of the Dragon
The Womb of the Dragon.text:
The pulse is getting stronger. You are getting closer. You notice the arcane tingling of a ritual conducted not too long ago, a dark art that is unspeakable beyond imagining: Blood sacrifice. Whose blood? That is the most disturbing question, yet you realize whoever entered here, entered without breaking the seal.

Once you open the last door after the long stairs and with the pulse getting stronger, you feel your heart in your throat and your very soul stirred. As if the pulse belongs to you and your life is at stake.

Princess Sibylla may have entered the Womb using different methods depending on different events. Check out the Characters section for further information. These include possible entrances:

  • Using the blood of the fallen Crusaders and including her husband’s. If Guy is still alive, he is the most likely candidate.
  • Sacrificing her own son. Believing that she can save him from the clutches of death, only if she ascends with the Mother: The Whore of Babylon.
  • Sacrificing the Saint Lazarus knights, including their leader if they did not accompany the adventurers out of Jerusalem.

Inside the entrance, a corridor greets them. Two gateways stand to the north and south. With a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check they notice the holes in the grounds of the gateways which appear to be markings of iron gates.

Iron Gate Trap (Tg):

These gates close if a creature steps on the tile, impaling from below. When the gate shuts, all creatures on the tile must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 14 (4d6) piercing damage and is restrained, or takes half as much damage on a successful save and is not impaled. Alternatively, creatures might choose to hold the gate above them with a successful DC 15 Strength saving throw. If they succeed, the gate doesn’t shut down until the creature drops it. The Strength check is repeated every turn. Creatures can not pass through the gate if it's shut.

At the end of the hallway, there is a hidden panel where traps in the chamber can be controlled. With a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) or Intelligence (Investigation) check, players notice where the panel is and how to open it by prying. Inside the panel there are two levers, and with a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check the players can enable or disable the traps from the panel. If the players fail the check they can still try their luck with the levers by rolling a d4 on the table.

d4

Trap Control Panel Table (p)

1

Trap triggers for Iron Gates are disabled or enabled.

2

Iron Gates are forced open.

3

Iron Gates are forced shut.

4

Fire Trap is disabled or enabled.

Room 2 North.name: Room 2 North
Room 2 North.text:
Inside the room to the north, there are alcoves in the eastern and western walls with stone graves inside them. A successful DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals this information to players. If the players try to read the writings in Old Persian, they either need to know the language or pass a DC 15 Intelligence (History) check to remember from before. This information hints that Skeletons may rise to defend the chamber from intruders.

Skeletons inside these tombs are ready to fight any intruder; if the players move any of the tombs’ lids, they need to succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or be grappled by the enemy inside. In that case, all the eight Skeletons rise and join the fight.

At the northernmost point in the room, an altar lies silent looking like a stone bed above the stairs. Anyone who touches it is forced to make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or fall asleep. If a creature falls asleep, it takes 10 minutes, rather than 1, to wake up or until they take damage or someone spends an action to wake them up. Touching the altar also awakens the undead inside the tombs.

Room 3 South.name: Room 3 South
Room 3 South.text:
The room to the south is where Sibylla attempts to complete the ritual, getting fed through the cord of the Womb. There are fire-shooting hoses in the ground running along the room from east to west (TF). A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals this information to the players. Hoses shoot fire for 1 round every 2 rounds unless disabled from the hidden panel in the corridor.

The Womb has trigger tiles surrounding it raising the undead in Room 2.

If the players enter the room, the Womb senses them and starts growling uneasily. Roll a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check for Sibylla in order for her to understand what is going on. If she succeeds, roll for initiative. If not, the players can ambush Sibylla, provided that they also succeed on a DC 18 Stealth check.

Flame Trap (Tf):

These traps shoot flames 10 feet high and create a flame pillar for the duration of 1 round every 2 rounds. When the flame pillar is active, each creature that starts its turn there or enters the area for the first time must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 23 (5d8) fire damage or half as much on a successful save.

Mechanics of the Womb of Dragon.name: Mechanics of the Womb of Dragon
Mechanics of the Womb of Dragon.text:
The essence of what’s left behind by the Whore, this abomination, is about to give birth to a dragon: A vessel that is able to cross and break the boundaries of the Lullaby Palace and shatter the bond that was left by Cyrus the Great and his beloved one.

The Womb has 100 HP and an Armor Class of 10. While taking damage, it will slowly form a portal that is linked to the Lullaby Palace. Its death will finalize the portal’s opening.

Womb Lair Actions:

  • Water Breaking: A sticky, goo-like substance pours out of the Womb. Making 30-foot cone terrain difficult.
  • Contractions: Flesh of the womb starts to cover the dragon. (duplicates the false life spell)
  • Flesh Crawl: The Womb starts to creep away to a safe position. Speed 20 ft. It can climb walls (Climbing Speed 10 ft.)
  • Grappling Veins: The Womb’s veins grapple anything that touches it. Any creature attacking the Womb must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw to escape its grapple. On a failed save creature takes 4 (1d6) acid damage and is grappled.

Will of the King of Kings.name: Will of the King of Kings
Will of the King of Kings.text:
If Sibylla is defeated and the Womb is destroyed, a rift resembling a portal filled with eldritch power will break loose from the cords of the Womb. The adventurers will be able to use it to cross to the Lullaby Palace and take the fight to the very heart of the enemy: the Whore of Babylon herself. The spirit of Shah-banu Cassandane will appear and warn the adventurers:

“If you cross this threshold, your lives are forfeit. She will claim you as if you are her own, you bear her Sigils after all. You can turn back now, rebuild the seals, form a new circle. You’ve stopped her ascension for this Era. The nightmares will not return, at least not during your lifetime. Yet she lives, and she will attempt to rise again. Where there is war, there is blood spilt, and her powers will awaken.'' The spirit of the Persian Queen gestures upwards. ''So many lives lost, so many tears, feeding the beast below. Yet, know this. She is not immune to death – she is not a true goddess, only an arrogant and equally powerful being, broken by ambition and reality’s vengeance.'' Her gaze turns to you - a face bold yet filled with what could be described as motherly compassion had you been in different circumstances. ''You may rid this world of her, but you will not return to see it.''

The adventurers advance to Level 8. If they are to travel to the Lullaby Palace, they are offered a special item by Cassandane: A potion of the divine kiss.

Potion of the Divine Kiss

Potion, legendary

The potion resembles the finest wine ever made with radiant beauty and a magical shimmer as if the moonlight were always on it. When you drink this potion, you immediately gain the benefits of a long rest. In addition your exhaustion level decreases by one more level.

Lullaby Palace.name: Lullaby Palace
Lullaby Palace.text:
Section Summary: This is the inter-dimensional space where the Whore of Babylon resides due to her banishment from the material world by Cyrus the Great. If the adventurers choose to advance here after the Womb of the Dragon, they will encounter the ancient evil lying there.

When the adventurers enter for the first time in Lullaby Palace, read:

You are suffocating. Your breath is bound and drawn away. You strain as if the whole world and universe have turned on their heads, and you are now being pulled back not by the earth but by the sky itself. You feel like a crooked, broken root is making its way right inside your soul, and you are forced to behold. Your lungs are now filled with water. The breath that has been taken from you makes its absence known from the very depths of your soul. You feel like you are not only losing your breath from your lungs, but your whole existence.

Weirdly enough, the sensation is both scary and peaceful. Terrifying and beautiful. You feel astonished by how these two emotions can be combined. The only thing you feel like you have is your consciousness as you float through the abyss. You feel as if you are grazing the collective consciousness of the whole of humanity; however, everyone here is blind to this place but you. The memories, fears, dreams, and happiness of everyone who has ever lived and will live preserve themselves in the abyss in which you float. Nothing that has happened is ever forgotten. No time that has ever been spent is in vain. The collective consciousness remembers it all. Even though your hands cannot reach it, the struggle of keeping your consciousness together keeps you going.

Your lungs are filled with air again as you approach a terrible destination, and your mind, which has been satiated with the collective consciousness in the infinite abyss, is now filled with soul and breath again.

Even though the sensation of suffocation continues, your attention is shifted to a garden, which has a type of beauty that you have never seen before, and a terrifying tower rising right in the middle of it. Even though this is the first time you see it, it feels like home. As the reality of the universe bewitches you with its beauty, it keeps on astonishing you with its truths and horrors.

The dance of colors and the beauty of the scents in the air prevail over every inch of this beautiful garden and terrifying tower, and they have become a wonderful part of this frightening realm. The wind is accompanied by a lullaby, it grieves the dreams of a mother, of a queen, who once fell from a tower that reached the heavens. This is her pedestal; long and wide. There is no taking a step forward or continuing with normal rules here. You are only as strong as your dreams and knowledge. This is the truth that has been engraved into your very roots.

You feel the root which penetrated into you while you were approaching here has always been with you, but you never realized it yourself. All beings that breathe have the same capacity: to achieve horror and beauty.

General Mechanics:

  • Spell rebound effects (from Magic in Historica Arcanum section in Era of the Crusades) are not present here.

  • This special and magical realm has its own optional movement rules: player characters must dream and desire that they move to a certain place and they are instantly there as long as it is within the boundaries of the Lullaby Palace. It costs them a bonus action, but they do not provoke opportunity attacks. In addition, by using an action (or with a reaction when a creature moves) they could also desire to change another character’s place. They can force them to make a Charisma saving throw. The DC is 8 + proficiency bonus + Charisma modifier, as Charisma reflects the sheer power of being. However, you could implement other ability scores if you deem appropriate.

  • The imagination and power of knowledge is the essential part of the Lullaby Palace. To respect both aspects, another set of optional rules can be found below: Power of Imagination & Knowledge. The rules are specially designed for characters to meddle with the integrity of the palace and include their creativity in potential combat.

Power of Imagination & Knowledge

Optional Rule

Characters can attempt to create objects or change their surroundings (bringing down a ceiling) by using their actions and sacrificing their vitality or other aspects in the process. It is similar to giving the adventurers access to the wish spell, channeling their imagination and will into reality.

If the adventurers attempt to create an object they have seen, they must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence check.
