However, as the GM, you have the final say on the matter of creation, and the DC could be higher for more powerful items or objects that have the size of large or larger. If it is a magical item that is rare or more powerful, the DC could increase by 2 for each rarity above rare. If it is consumable, this could increasethe DC by another 2.

If the adventurers attempt to change their surroundings in a way that they experienced beforehand (for example, creating an explosion, taking down ceilings, or rotting away a material they have witnessed before), they must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom check. However, as the GM, you have the final say on this matter as well and could change the DC depending on the act.

Each successful attempt reduces a creature's maximum hit points by an amount equal to 14 (4d6), while each failed attempt reduces it by an amount equal to 21 (6d6). This reduction cannot be prevented except by the Whore of Babylon.

If the adventurers attempt to use their imagination and alter reality or create a thing they have imagined, they must succeed on a DC 20 Charisma check. The ability score can be altered and the DC may be adjusted based on the imagination. For example, an adventurer may have never seen an anvil before, but it could be considered an easy item to imagine. As this rule is very open to interpretation, it is suggested to remind the adventurers that the Whore of Babylon can also use these powers for her own good and feel free to adjust the mechanics that would benefit your game better.

As a rule of thumb, it is suggested that the wish spell’s rules apply here: “The GM has great latitude in ruling what occurs in such an instance; the greater the wish, the greater the likelihood that something goes wrong. This effect might simply fail, the effect you desire might only be partly achieved, or you might suffer some unforeseen consequence as a result of how you worded your desire. For example, wishing that a villain were dead might propel you forward in time to a period when that villain is no longer alive, effectively removing you from the game. Similarly, wishing for a legendary magic item or artifact might instantly transport you to the presence of the item’s current owner.”

The Balconies.name: The Balconies
The Balconies.text:
When adventurers visit the Balconies in earlier acts through the Rifts, their bodies do not enter the Palace, thus they are unaffected by the Palace’s ultimate rule: There is no way out.

The balconies are fragments of the memories of the great struggle between the Whore of Babylon and Cyrus the Great.

The adventurers have a chance to influence reality. There are some choices that are represented here, while reliving some of the memories from the past If they succeed on both balconies, the Whore of Babylon loses one of the immunities in her statblock.

First Balcony.name: First Balcony
First Balcony.text:
The balcony is a wide and refreshing area with the fragrance of amber and the sensation of relaxing breeze. The adventurers are meant to relive some moments in the past regarding the story of the Whore of Babylon:

You are at the top of the world. The pyramids, buildings, towers, and cities you have seen so far seem simple and pitiful next to the tower you are in. You are in the only place daring enough to approach the clouds, reach the gods and conquer the heavens.

Power is in your hands. You feel the need to make a decision; one among you will be chosen, and powers will be bestowed upon that person. Who will it be?

The adventurers are on the top floor of a tower, one that reaches the clouds easily. They can’t leave the room. It all feels very real. Any Intelligence check made will make them realize they are indeed here and this is not some for of illusiom. It appears that there is no door and only an altar is in front of them. They are sitting by the altar forming a circle.

A voice from the altar will announce: “Choose among you!” and will not respond to any questions. They will not know what will happen to the chosen one.

When the party decides on the chosen adventurer, that character will receive the following benefit. Choose a damage type: acid, cold, fire, poison, or lightning. You can ignore resistance and immunities against it.

After an adventurer is chosen, the method is entirely up to them, the altar will transform into a portal and take them to an arena. A minute later, any remaining adventurer that didn’t use the portal will drawn into it as if sucked by a black hole.

In the arena, read:

Applause like the most powerful thunderclaps in the skies greets you. You find yourself in an arena amid thick mist. The arena is so vast that you cannot see those applauding; everyone appears tiny. You are certain you are amidst the ashes of a very ancient time, because you are met by a being you could not even imagine in your dreams: six dragons.

A voice booms: “Choose your bane!”

The adventurers must choose a dragon to be fought: a young red dragon, a young black dragon, a young white dragon, a young blue dragon or a young green dragon. The rest of the dragons will slowly be taken underground by the descending ground. The adventurers will be put in an infinite battleground with the dragon - with spirits forming a circle around the combat. The spirits appears to be slain warriors from different eras of Jerusalem, all chanting “Mother! Mother! Mother!” in their native tongue with all their power. If the adventurers are able to defeat the dragon, all participating adventurers will have a permanent resistance to the chosen dragon’s breath type. The remaining dragons will reappear. The adventurers can choose another dragon to fight or be teleported back to the Second Balcony from a portal recently opened.

The adventurers can roll a DC 10 Intelligence or Wisdom check to understand they are reliving the moments of a Whore of Babylon from the era where she walked the Earth as a mortal. This creature defeated all dragons and gained all kinds of resistances.

Second Balcony.name: Second Balcony
Second Balcony.text:
The adventurers are teleported to an underground place; they realize that they are not far away from the Second Rift. All adventurers experience this section alone - though it is recommended that the GM picks one player to focus.

The storm is beginning to ease. The smell of blood slowly fades. Blood has splattered everywhere. Almost everyone is dead. The great enemy is bound in a dark chasm. Only you could have sent her there. Now, you know she could return at any moment. You must imprison her somewhere.

You are beneath a city held sacred by a people who once followed Abraham and Moses, a cradle of civilization that has journeyed here. You know you are close enough to hell to stare into the eyes of Ahriman Mazda. Now, you search within yourself for the strength to imprison a soul so demonic that it deserves to go there. Defeating her isn't enough; she will grow stronger each passing hour and will return far worse than before.

Despair and helplessness engulf your heart. Ruling an empire that could bring every known civilization to its knees does not change how powerless you feel. Despite all your powers, you find no solution.

Your beloved is holding your hand tightly. "This is the only way," they whisper. Is this really the only way?

This memory lets the adventurers relive the moment when Cyrus the Great bound the Whore of Babylon by sacrificing his beloved queen, Shah-banu Cassadane. According to Herodotus, all nations greatly mourned her passing, and the whole empire accompanied their shah’s grief.

It is up to you to decide the essentials of this moment. Each adventurer is presented with the option of sacrificing someone close to them - including another party member (the party member they sacrifice will be an illusion that can only be decyphered with a DC22 Arcana Check).

Cyrus the Great sacrificed his wife, Shah-banu Cassadane, by binding the Whore of Babylon to her dream. Cassandane’s body was lost in a maelstorm of arcane might as she drew the defeated Avatar of Ishtar within a realm her death created. Cyrus ended her life weeping and cursing the fates.

Each partaking adventurer must be presented with such a scene:

  • The person the adventurer deems their most valuable companion (lover, friend, mentor, family member, etc.) lies in the altar as witnessed in the Womb of the Dragon.
  • There is a potion, and a rope on the altar.
  • The sacrifice starts to suffer, exhibiting observable pain, shaking or a similar symptom of your choice. It could be about reliving past traumas regarding their backstory (The Whore of Babylon is in their mind forcing them to relive those moments).

The potion poisons the drinker in a magical way and deals heavy force damage to the drinker and any creature that may have possessed it.

The rope is enchanted and when used to suffocate a breathing creature with it, it actually attacks the mind and deals psychic damage to the target.

The adventurer can also choose another way that is not covered by this or choose not to act at all. This scene will last for 1 minute, and if the adventurer chooses not to intervene with their death, the suffering grows, so does the screams. If the player decides to do the sacrifice, they are rewarded with an increase to their maximum hit points by three hit dice. Their sacrifice will turn to the corpse of Cassandane and they are all teleported back to where they entered the Rift.The ones that chose the potion receive resistance to force damage, and the ones that chose the rope gain resistance to psychic damage.

If they fail to go through with the sacrifice within 1 minute, their sacrifice will die from pain, and the corpse will reanimate as a silhouette of the Whore of Babylon. She will compliment them on what a great companion (lover, parent, friend, student, etc.) they are. These adventurers will be automatically frightened as soon as initiate combat with the Whore of Babylon.

A House of Dreams.name: A House of Dreams
A House of Dreams.text:
As you enter the massive room accompanied by lullabies, you are greeted by a striking sight: The being hailing from millenia beyond, the horror from a thousand sins and of unalligned stars, and the undeniable divine Mother stands right in front of you: the Whore of Babylon. With a smile that betrays no malice and nobility unmatched, she stands there as if carved from marble and colored by the finest artists’ paints. It should be impossible that she is real. You can see the dignity of a queen, the compassion of a mother, and the arrogance of a sorceress with the power of a goddess all at once.

While your mind is being filled with eldritch madness, you focus on one thing you know to be true. If you do not slay this creature, this Goddess now, generations after generations will have to face her vengeance. You knew this when you came here. Here, at the end of the World, spun by fates' web, the final battle between you and the Whore of Babylon thus begins.

This is where adventurers confront the Whore of Babylon, a giant room that seems to be without an end. The Whore of Babylon will not show mercy under any circumstances and utilize all of her power. Her statblock and combat tactics can be found in the Characters section.

If you use the optional rules mentioned above, the Whore of Babylon will also try to make the best use of those rules, as she is more than three thousand years old, more experienced in the nature of this realm, and has also observed the material plane through her sigil bearers and other methods.

After the fight is over, and if the Whore of Babylon is defeated, the realm will collapse, Cassandane’s spirit will be free to find peace, yet the adventurers will be stuck in the Lullaby Palace. If the adventurers are all defeated without a hope of survival, they will be raised as fallen spirits they witnessed in the First Balcony.

Conclusions.name: Conclusions
Conclusions.text:
I met a traveller from an antique land,

Who said—“Two vast and trunkless legs of stone

Stand in the desert. . . . Near them, on the sand,

Half sunk a shattered visage lies, whose frown,

And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,

Tell that its sculptor well those passions read

Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,

The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed;

And on the pedestal, these words appear:

My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings;

Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!

Nothing beside remains. Round the decay

Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare

The lone and level sands stretch far away.”

-Percy Shelley

The adventure ends here. Depending on the feats, achievements and failures of the adventurers, you can check out below to decide how to conclude your game.

Golden Ending

  • The Whore of Babylon is defeated.
  • Sibylla of Jerusalem is defeated.
  • The Womb is destroyed before the dragon is born.
  • Peter the Hermit is defeated.
  • Ismail Al-Jazari was saved without serious damage.
  • Balian of Ibelin is alive.
  • Guy of Lusignan is defeated.
  • Raynald of Chatillon is defeated.

If the adventurers were able to secure most of the feats above, this could be considered as the best possible scenario for the adventure.

After the death of Whore of Babylon - eldritch madness engulfing Jerusalem is also broken. Saladin takes the city without any further bloodshed as Balian witnesses firsthand what horror Saladin was trying to stop. If any of the adventurers did not enter the Lullaby Palace, they emerge from the Church of Holy Sepulchre unscathed. After this, they would be counted as one of the most prominent, respected warriors of the Holy Lands, with petitioners and allies all over the realm.

Saladin will expand his empire and will be revered as one of the most successful and greatest sultans in the Islamic world. His name is still remembered today and many books will write his name with golden letters. Al-Jazari will return to his studies and contribute to science and engineering depending on his remaining Intelligence.

The adventurers who gave their lives to slay Whore of Babylon will be remembered by only the few who saw what truly lies behind the veil.

Silver Ending

  • The adventurers did not enter the Lullaby Palace.
  • Sibylla of Jerusalem is defeated.
  • The Womb is destroyed before the dragon is born.
  • Peter the Hermit is defeated.
  • Ismail Al-Jazari was saved without serious damage or with minor mental damage.
  • Saladin took the city peacefully and without much bloodshed.
  • Balian of Ibelin is alive.
  • Guy of Lusignan is defeated.
  • Raynald of Chatillon is defeated.

This ending is not that different from the Golden Ending, however they decided not to enter the last area. They were still able to stop the great threat of their generation and saved the Holy Lands, for a time. Saladin, Al-Jazari, and the adventurers -if they are willing - join forces in creating a more complete seal - though with the knowledge that a perfect one is impossible. Most of the rewards below can be applied to both endings.

Possible Rewards for Golden & Silver Endings

  • Nobility titles and wealthy lands for them. Many soldiers to command and people to rule over.
  • A high rank in a war council, a position in a military that is equal to a marshall or similar.
  • Leading a faction related to their expertise, background, class and similar. For example, a rogue could be Saladin’s spymaster, a wizard could be a highly respected teacher at Al-Azhar University, a cleric could accompany Balian of Ibelin and survivors to remaining Crusader realms and be a Patriarchal figure, and similar.
  • They could build their own faction: A school, a society, a sect, an order, a guild, a pirate group, a mercenary band and similar.
  • Wealth: They could own unimaginable wealth, especially in terms of gold dinars and more precious gems.
  • Power: Now that the evil is defeated, they can decide the fate of the Holy Lands and beyond and they are probably the most powerful people in the Holy Lands.

If the adventurers are able to defeat the Whore of Babylon but die in the process, they will also become legendary figures in the Holy Lands, for those who are aware of the extent of their sacrifice. If they can’t defeat the Whore of Babylon, they will be mourned by these select few people.

Bronze Ending

This is the ending where the world is still safe, but many sacrifices were made.

  • Sibylla of Jerusalem is defeated.
  • The Womb is destroyed before the dragon is born.
  • Saladin had to take the city by force and within the last moments, much blood was spilled.
  • Some of the Sigil Bearers are still alive.
  • Al-Jazari did not survive or suffered heavy Intelligence loss, being unable to speak again.

The adventurers may receive moderate rewards based on their alliances and friends. One of the brightest arcane minds were lost in the war against the eldritch, and Saladin knows the seal he will craft will not hold for long. He prepares the realm for the eventual return of the Avatar of Ishtar. The surviving Sigil Bearers still carry the taint of Whore of Babylon across the land.

Iron Ending

  • Saladin had to do his ritual and cause great suffering to the population of Jerusalem.
  • The adventurers are dead/or have failed somewhat or allowed Saladin to go through with the ritual.
  • Some Sigil Bearers are alive.
  • Balian of Ibelin is dead.
  • Al-Jazari is dead.

This is a pyrrhic victory for the Holy Lands. Although Saladin was able to bind the Whore of Babylon again, much was sacrificed and the world will not be the same anymore. Too much blood is on the hands of the sultan and the hope is diminished upon the world.

Red Ending

  • The adventurers die at any point of the story, possibly in Act III.
  • Sibylla is able to conduct the ritual and Whore of Babylon emerges.
  • Some of the Sigil Bearers are alive.
  • Saladin is dead.
  • Balian of Ibelin is dead.
  • Al-Jazari is dead.

This is the worst ending possible. The Holy Lands will never recover from this and now the Whore of Babylon roams free - someone, or something will interfere for such power does not remain unchallenged for long. Though this intervention will not be for the good of the people of the Holy Lands.

Spells from Era of the Crusades.name: Spells from Era of the Crusades

Al-Biruni’s Fantastic Quıll.name: Al-Biruni’s Fantastic Quıll
Al-Biruni’s Fantastic Quıll.text:
@UUID[Item.5CJhcVq40x88SzkJ]{Al-Biruni’s Fantastic Quıll}

Transmutation Cantrip

Casting Time: 1 Action

Range: Touch

Components: V, S, M (an avian feather)

Duration: Special

You touch an object with an avian feather to give it properties of a magical quill. The object must have some sort of a sharp part to be used. A wooden stick, a sharp stone, a metal shard, or a similar object would do.

The Marvelous Quill: The object can be used to write and produce its own magical ink when you activate it as an action. It can be used for writing on any solid surface for 1 hour. When you reach 5th level, you can spend 4 hours and 15 gd to produce a cantrip scroll of your choice. When you reach 11th level, you can spend 8 hours and 50 gd to produce a 1st level spell scroll of your choice. When you reach 17th level, you can spend 12 hours and 200 gd to produce a 2nd level spell scroll of your choice. The spells that you scribe as a scroll must be known to you or you must have them prepared.

The Unexpected Eraser: The object can be used to erase writing that is put on a surface within 1 day. The writing disappears, and the surface resembles as though it were never written. An identify spell cast on the surface reveals that the writing was erased and a dispel magic spell brings back the writing. When you reach 5th level, the duration of 1 day becomes 1 week. When you reach 11th level, the duration of 1 week becomes 1 month. When you reach 17th level, the duration of 1 month becomes indefinite.

Class Lists: Bard, Cleric, Sorcerer, Wizard

Al-Farghani’s Alchemy.name: Al-Farghani’s Alchemy
Al-Farghani’s Alchemy.text:
@UUID[Item.0CFNptdASjz99m5c]{Al-Farghani’s Alchemy}

Transmutation Cantrip

Casting Time: 1 Action

Range: Touch

Components: V, S, M (a sprinkle of ginger)

Duration: Special

You touch a tiny object and grant a magical property from below that is useful for daily life and in matters of taste, aroma, and similar things.

Beverage Shifter: When put into a cup, jug or a similar object filled with water or another liquid, it can turn the liquid into a liquid that is drinkable and harmless, such as juice, coffee, tea, or something similar. Unless consumed, the liquid turns into its original state after 10 minutes. This object can’t change the magical or other potentially harmless properties in the liquid (such as poison). When you reach 5th level, it can eliminate poisons and similar dangerous and non-magical properties. When you reach 11th level, it can change magical liquids into non-magical and harmless ones. When you reach 17th level, it can change magical liquids or normal ones into common or uncommon magical substances, such as turning water into a healing potion or a potion of fire resistance.

Magical Aroma: When applied to a creature, clothing or to a specific place, such as the corner of the room, kitchen counter or the dining table, it gives off a certain smell designated by you. It lasts for 1 hour. When you reach 5th level, you can make the aroma poisonous. You designate a point, and the air in a 5 foot radius area around that point becomes poisonous for anyone who enters or anyone who starts its turn there. They must make a Constitution saving throw or be poisoned. When you reach 11th level, they also receive 1d8 poison damage on a failed save. When you reach 17th level, the damage becomes 2d8, and the radius extends to 15 feet. When you make the area poisonous, you must concentrate on this spell, and it lasts for 10 minutes.

Class Lists: Bard, Sorcerer, Wizard

Al-Jazari’s Metalsmith.name: Al-Jazari’s Metalsmith
Al-Jazari’s Metalsmith.text:
@UUID[Item.qUrOw3957MgINZ8t]{Al-Jazari’s Metalsmith}

Transmutation Cantrip

Casting Time: 1 Action

Range: Touch

Components: V, S, M (a small hammer)

Duration: Special

You touch a tiny object made from metal to assign one of the features below to it. The features last until you dismiss them (no action required), after 1 hour, or when the feature says so.

Flame Tender: The object can start or snuff out fires on candles, torches, campfires and similar objects, as an action. At 5th level, you can use it to make a melee spell attack using your spellcasting ability scores to deal 1d6 fire damage as the part of your action to lit it and it is extinguished at the end of your turn. At 6th level its damage increases to 2d6. At 11th level, 3d6. At 17th level, 4d6.

Acid Mouth: The object produces 0.1 ounces of acid. This acid can be used to melt and pierce through locks, handles and similar things and disappears after 3 uses. At 5th level, you can use it to make a melee spell attack using your ability scores to deal 1d6 acid damage. At 6th level its damage increases to 2d6. At 11th level, 3d6. At 17th level, 4d6.

Arcanasteel Shield: The object must be a circular or of a similar shape that is proper for a shield. It becomes a disk big enough for your hand. When a creature attacks you, you can use your reaction to activate it. It magically appears on your arm and does not take your ability to use your hand and grants you +1 to your Armor Class until the end of your next turn. When you reach 5th level, it grants +2 to your AC.

Class Lists: Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard

Bedouin Fabrics.name: Bedouin Fabrics
Bedouin Fabrics.text:
@UUID[Item.oHuPNO2BjBcl6Vjd]{Bedouin Fabrics}

Transmutation Cantrip

Casting Time: 1 Action

Range: Touch

Components: V, S, M (a piece of silk)

Duration: 1 Hour

You magically weave a tiny fabric to have magical aspects and choose one of the following options.

Saharan Haeadband: The object can be used as an action and grants advantage on saving throws related to extreme heat for the next hour to the creature using it. At 5th level, the creature wearing it is immune to the effects of extreme heat. At 11th level, the creature wearing it has advantage on death saving throws in extreme heat conditions.

Desertnight Scarf: The object can be used as an action and grants advantage on saving throws related to extreme cold for the next hour to the creature using it. At 5th level, the creature wearing the scarf is immune to the effects of extreme cold. At 11th level, the creature wearing the scarf has advantage on death saving throws in extreme cold conditions.

Surgeon’s Bandages: When you receive healing from a source, or roll a Hit Dice to recover hit points, the bandage helps you magically. You can reroll a 1 or 2 once, but you must use the new roll. The bandage then disappears. When you reach 5th level, it can be used twice without disappearing. At 11th level, it can be used 3 times.

You can only have up to 3 of the objects at the same time.

Class Lists: Bard, Druid, Sorcerer, Wizard

Al-Jazari’s Woodwork.name: Al-Jazari’s Woodwork
Al-Jazari’s Woodwork.text:
@UUID[Item.K5ur1r0EHHqJjkON]{Al-Jazari’s Woodwork}

Transmutation Cantrip

Casting Time: 1 Minute

Range: Touch

Components: V, S, M (a small carving blade)

Duration: 1 Hour

You touch a piece of wood that was carved into a shape by human hands and assign some features to it.

Water Diviner: The object can be used for 1 hour to guide you toward the nearest water source within 5 miles. You can use it to clean contaminated water of 5 gallons. It doesn’t remove poisons. When you reach 5th level, it can be used to duplicate the purify food and drink spell and it can’t be used again, until you finish a long rest. At 11th level, it can duplicate the create or destroy water spell and you can’t use the Water Diviner again until you finish a long rest. At 17th level, it can be used to cast create food or water and you can’t use the Water Diviner again until you finish a long rest.

Totemic Ward: This totem wards you from otherworldly threats. You designate a type of creature: Aberration, celestial, elemental, fey, fiend, or undead. The object can be on a person, under a bed, or hanging above a door or a window to be active. While under the bed, whenever a chosen type of creature enters within 10 feet of the ward, it gives a designated sound, visual or scent and forces the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature can’t come close to the ward until the end of its next turn and takes 1d6 psychic damage. The damage

increases to 2d6 when you reach 5th level, 3d6 when you reach 11th level, and 4d6 when you reach 17th level.

Sturdy Weapons: You touch five pieces of ammunition, a wooden club, a wooden quarterstaff or a similar wooden weapon and grant them magical properties for overcoming resistances against non-magical attacks. For the duration, they can’t be broken by normal means. For example, if you imbue 5 arrows, all can be collected after firing as normal ammunition. At 5th level, you double the number of ammunition or wooden weapons you can imbue. At 11th level, you triple the number.

Class Lists: Cleric, Druid, Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard

Al-Jazari’s Practical Summons.name: Al-Jazari’s Practical Summons
Al-Jazari’s Practical Summons.text:

1st Level Conjuration (Ritual)

Casting Time: 1 Minute

Range: 15 feet

Components: V, S, M (an owl’s feather)

Duration: 10 minutes

You conjure a solid and non-magical object that you have seen before within 15 ft. of you. The object must be Large or smaller, and its price must not exceed 150 gd. The object must not go further than 15 ft. from you or it disappears immediately. The object disappears 10 minutes later.

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can conjure one more item equal to the slot’s level.

Class Lists: Bard, Sorcerer, Wizard

Al-Jazari’s Flexible Casting.text:

2nd Level Conjuration

Casting Time: 1 Action

Range: Self

Components: V, S, M (a spellbook worth at least 50 gd)

Duration: Instantaneous

When you cast this spell, you can choose a 1st-level spell (its duration must be 1 action) from your spellbook and cast that spell instead. If the spell asks for a material component, you must have it on you.

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher (maximum is 5th level to benefit this) you can duplicate a spell that is one level below from your spellbook.

Al-Jazari’s Greater Summons.name: Al-Jazari’s Greater Summons
Al-Jazari’s Greater Summons.text:
@UUID[Item.p1lbyXZnztwLqZ1O]{Al-Jazari’s Greater Summons}

2nd Level Conjuration (Ritual)

Casting Time: 10 Minutes

Lies We Told.name: Lies We Told
Lies We Told.text:
Lies We Told

  • Al-Jazari was not this young during the sultanate of Saladin.
  • Raynald and Guy actually lead the assault at the Battle of Hattin against Saladin and are captured. In the story, they most likely die earlier.
  • Balian of Ibelin is presented more as a “captain of the guards of the city” but this is not actually correct. He was a noble lord and had his own lands.
  • Baldwin V was actually made co-king two years prior to the king’s death but the time-line is condensed to fit the story.
  • The actual political scenery of the 12th century Holy Lands is much more complex than presented here. It has been simplified a lot for the sake of the story and the setting we wished to build. Due to this, many important figures such as Raymond of Tripoli and the frictions/factions that crippled the kingdom before the death of Baldwin were cut from the story and many events about the ascension of Sibylla and Guy to the throne have been simplified.
  • Peter the Hermit normally returns to Europe after the First Crusade.

  • Raymond III of Tripoli is actually a prominent figure in the conflict between Baldwin IV and Saladin. While he made a pact with Saladin during his rift with Guy, they reconciled later. Raymond fought against Saladin in the
    Battle of Hattin.

  • Although known as a university, Al Azhar Mosque in the Era of the Crusades: Cairo - Jewel of the Nile section is actually a place of Islamic learning during that era, it became an actual university much later. We wanted the city of Cairo to have a similar place based on Al-Jazari’s achievements and improvements.
  • Normally, the salting of Carthage with its literal meaning is considered legendary and entered the literature in the early 20th century. In the dungeon, the legend is addressed with its literal meaning for dramatic effect. For further reading: Ridley, R. T. (1986). "To Be Taken with a Pinch of Salt: The Destruction of Carthage")
  • The Great Sphinx has actually been submerged in sand for a long time. In history, it was excavated in later centuries and its body was revealed much later originally rather than in Saladin's era.

Raynald of Châtillon.name: Raynald of Châtillon
Raynald of Châtillon.text:
Raynald of Châtillon

Dreadknight of the Kingdom of God

Introduction

War shaped my flesh. War shaped my mind. War shaped my past and future. I am Raynald de Châtillon and I swear to flood the Sinai with the blood of my enemies.

I ride each twilight with a hundred knights carrying the Crimson banner of Al-Karak, and the sigil of my Martyred Mother, like hounds of the Wilde Hunt, to cull the meek, to call men to their destined demise, in the honored field of war.

Let the weak Kings and queens, bureaucrats in undented armors, ink spitters and quill gulpers engage in their frivolous and unending bickering to delay the inevitable war. Their inability to decide only gives me more time to play with my prey. A hundred villages and caravans I have burned, and before the pompous crowns decide enough is enough, I will burn a thousand more. In this delicate balancing act of peace and coexistence, danced by the Leper and the venomous Saracen, I alone sit at the other end of the scale, and each soul I reap is a stone for my side of the scale, the side of blood and glory.

Bestowed with the powers of my Martyred Mother who branded my skin, I rise; and knighted under a blood moon a hundred butchers rise with me. Our ride is a call to the truth of this world - war is eternal. And if this accursed land is to be the Kingdom of Peace, first they will have to kill the God of War.

Character’s Past

Raynald’s childhood, set against a backdrop of strength and weakness, profoundly shaped his worldview. As the heir to a minor lord, he was born into a position of authority for all those around him, yet his early physical frailness and small stature led to mockery in the sparring grounds. His weak demeanor, and the whispers of his inability to fight, led Raynald to lose his father’s approval - and his father even went so far as to allow these mockeries to continue, to reinforce his own worldview on his son: power is the true measure of worth. This cursed upbringing forged in Raynald a deep-seated belief in the supremacy of strength and dominion.

With a sudden growth spurt, without a doubt shaped by eldritch powers, for a price none except Raynald knows about, the young heir’s physical capabilities aligned with his and his father’s ambitions. The young Raynald started hunting down all those who hurt him, either by challenging them to single combat - where they were demolished under his newfound brutality - or by plotting horrific hunting accidents.

Seeing what a menace Raynald was becoming to his court and possibly even to his own life, his father sent Raynald to join the Crusades - so that the young hellhound could use his appetite for bloodshed for Godly ends. For Raynald, however, his fathers decision was nothing more than a dishonorable exile.

His journey to Jerusalem itself was a tale of bloodshed. Raynald, with an entourage that he handpicked from bandits and highwaymen, carved a bloody path to the Kingdom of God, plundering caravans, pillaging villages, and assaulting pilgrims - regardless of their creed. Once the butcher knight found his way to Jerusalem, he was promptly given a minor fief, Al-Karak, and was sent on missions to distant parts of the world - to keep his warmongering away from the delicate peace.

It was in between his missions in Cilicia and Armenia that Guy de Lusignan entered Raynald’s life as more than a mentor; he filled the void of a father figure, offering the recognition and validation Raynald sought in the battlefield. Guy used his force in the court to reestablish Raynald as one of the Knight Commanders situated near Jerusalem. This was not just for his protection, however, as Raynald was given a secret mission by Guy: disrupt the peace and force Saladin’s hand to attack Jerusalem.

Roleplaying As Raynald

Raynald exudes the demeanor of a classic bully, marked by an overbearing sense of entitlement and a lack of restraint. His behavior suggests a life unaccustomed to the word ‘no’, where his wishes and whims have seldom been challenged. Yet deep down, he is still the small child that was mocked for his small stature and was lacking parental validation. A horrible combination, recognizable by any who have a sliver of understanding of human behavior.

He revels in provocation, deriving a twisted pleasure from irritating others purely for his own amusement. His communication is often laced with vulgarity, reflecting an egocentric worldview where his desires and opinions overshadow all else. Raynald’s respect, or lack thereof, hinges solely on the perceived power of those around him - this is also why he respects Guy, who bested him a few times in sparring matches. He adjusts his behavior dramatically in the presence of those he considers physically powerful, displaying a level of respect that is directly proportional to his assessment of their strength and influence.

However, this respect is fluid and can shift rapidly as Raynald reassesses the power dynamics at play. His recognition of an opponent’s strength can lead to a swift change in his attitude, from disdain to grudging respect. Despite him being easily provoked, Raynald exercises a unique measure of self-control in situations involving Guy. His fear of inciting Guy’s wrath and disapproval acts as a check on his otherwise impulsive nature, compelling him to act out only when explicitly directed.

Motives

Domination: Raynald is primarily driven by a desire to assert his dominance and showcase his power, both on the battlefield and off. This stems from his childhood experiences of being seen as weak and his subsequent transformation into a fearsome warrior.

Let the World Burn: He harbors a deep-seated need to avenge the slights and mockeries of his past. This motive extends to a broader scale as he seeks to disrupt and provoke major political powers, such as through his mission to force Saladin’s hand.

A Lost Validation: Raynald’s actions are also motivated by a craving for recognition and validation, particularly from figures of authority like Guy de Lusignan, who has filled a paternal role in his life.

Interests

Rivers of Blood: Raynald is deeply interested in demonstrating his martial prowess. He constantly seeks out challenges that allow him to display his strength and combat skills.

Cull the Weak: Raynald can’t stand weakness - especially in his ranks. He actively seeks out weakness amidst his Knights and in the population he interacts with - just to exploit any and all weak spots he can find.

Flaws

Like a Rabid Dog: His tendency to provoke and challenge others often leads to unnecessary conflicts and can destabilize larger strategic goals. His impulsiveness can make him predictable to his enemies who might exploit this trait.

No Sense of Empathy: Raynald’s ruthless nature and focus on domination often come at the expense of empathy and regard for others’ suffering, which can alienate potential allies and earn him numerous enemies.

Fear of Inadequacy: Despite his outward bravado, Raynald harbors an internal fear of being seen as weak or inadequate. This fear can drive him to take excessive risks to prove himself, potentially putting him and his forces in danger

Combat Tactics

Raynald’s approach to combat mirrors his personal nature, characterized by a relentless focus on challenge and exploiting weaknesses. His strategy in battle is straightforward yet effective: identify the most vulnerable aspect of his opponent or the weakest link in a group, and then ruthlessly target that vulnerability to the highest level of brutality possible at present.

This method reflects a pragmatic, if unscrupulous, mindset. For Raynald, the concepts of honor and fairness hold little sway; his primary objective is the swift and decisive defeat of his adversary. He eschews complex tactics in favor of overwhelming force, applying relentless pressure to prevent his opponents from regaining their footing or mounting a counterattack.

In gameplay terms, this means that if Raynald’s forces render any party members unconscious, Raynald will either personally strike the unconscious target to kill them off, or order his men to do the same if he is unable.

Character Progression

Raynald of Chatillon is one of the most static characters in the adventure, he has one goal: To cause chaos and feed his inner beast. Due to sigil and relevant powers, he is directly under the control of Guy of Lusignan and by extension, Sibylla of Jerusalem.

The Remains of Peter the Hermit.name: The Remains of Peter the Hermit
The Remains of Peter the Hermit
The Remains of Peter the Hermit.text:
The Remains of
Peter the Hermit

Patriarch of the People’s Crusade & the Maker of the New Faithful

Introduction

Flesh is not adequate to worship God. This is the only lesson I learned from a bygone era of faith and devotion.

A lifetime ago I was a man of god, an orator, commanding immense authority over the souls of thousands. I led my flock like any good shepherd would, through a journey of redemption, cleansing the Earth and our bodies from sin. Arms and armor we did not have, nor did we need any. For our weapon was holy fire, and wield it we did. Tens of thousands of men marched in unison, judged and executed in unison, under a divine choir led by me. A lifetime ago, my flock was taken from me, for it was revealed to me that my mortal flesh was not enough.

A lifetime ago, I found myself in the clutches of starvation in Antioch. It was then I realized this mortal self was not enough - not enough for a life of true worship. Whispers agreed, and I found myself a tutor, who promised me another form, one who would breathe in the soul, but would not breathe it out. A pact I signed with the Whispers, and I was turned into a being made of a fallen star in the eyes of my broken, starved brothers of the Crusade. My voice became a beacon of hope and faith, my hands brands of God and the Mother within Whispers, promising bodily transformation to a greater devotee. Seventy eights knights accepted the gifts, and sallied forth from the gates of Antioch, for a pilgrimage of our own, breaking the siege of the Saracen as we departed.

In the mountains of Sinai, we built our sanctum. A sanctum of stone and flesh, working in unison to understand the secrets that God Almighty laid out for the faithful to discover, to worship forever. It is in this sanctum I will construct the new man, who suffers no weakness of mortality in his devotion to Lord, guided by my Mother within Whispers.

Character’s Past

Before losing his mortal form into amalgamation with his eldritch sanctum, Peter the Hermit was a man of god who played a critical role at the onset of the Era of the Crusades.

Heeding the call to war to reclaim the Holy Lands, Peter the Hermit used his skills as an expert orator and his popularity as a member of the clergy to rally the support of the thousands. People’s Crusade, as this army of unarmed pilgrims and peasants were called, and their legacy became of bloodshed and tragedy.

As the People’s Crusade started its march from France towards the Holy Lands, Peter the Hermit became the leader of tens of thousands of men - who entrusted their lives and consciences to him. This trust, however, was misplaced within Peter, as under his leadership, these crusaders burnt and pillaged towns and communities within Europe itself to find supplies and funds, and even went so far as to massacre the Jewish population of major cities and towns as they marched by.

The bloody People’s Crusade reached the gates of Constantinople by August 1096. Alexios I Komnenos, the Byzantine Emperor, had already heard the reputation of these men, and was more than happy to ferry this 40,000 strong army and its leader Peter to the other shores of the Bosphorus, away from his capital - and into the hands of the Seljuk Turks.

Peter and his 40,000 motley crusaders pillaged and burned the Anatolian countryside as they marched from town to town towards the Holy Lands. However, their lack of discipline and arms were all too noticeable for the Seljuk horse lords. The crusaders were goaded into a trap near Civetot, modern day Yalova, and were thoroughly destroyed.

It was this battle that broke Peter’s beliefs and began shaping him into the eldritch creature he ended up as. The crusader forces right before the battle were bolstered by a combination of Peter’s proclamation of divine protection, and actual, albeit minor, arcane power of holy origin. Victory was ensured for Peter and his close circle of followers, and the Seljuk Turks were only delaying the inevitable plan of God.

What ended up happening was a true massacre, a fitting end for the bloody People’s Crusade. Arched, whistling arrows pierced the torsos of men of beastly statures, cavalry charges threw unarmored crusaders meters apart, splattering the remains of torn carcasses. Crusader arms, even when blazing with holy fire, failed to pierce heavily armored Sejuk Sipahis. These all were carved to the mind of Peter the Hermit, who, at that moment, decided that the flesh is too weak for God’s work.

The means of his survival of the ambush is a mystery to all but Peter - yet months later he emerged back in Constantinople. During this time, Peter had also searched for hidden, arcane wisdom, while he waited to link up with the survivors of the People’s Crusade and newly arriving - well equipped - crusaders. He departed as soon as a force sizable enough to cross the Anatolian highlands were assembled.

His final appearance in his mortal form was in the Siege of Antioch, accompanying the crusaders who were caught in the city that they themselves sieged but a few months past. Burning with the secrets he uncovered in Constantinople, Peter was haunted by the prophetic images in his mind, resurfacing the memories of torn human bodies and screams of faith in Civetot, a sun rising from below Jerusalem, and whispers promising a new man, with flesh and mind fit for divine service. The hunger, disease, and death encountered by the besieged Crusaders within Antioch finally caved in his mind and opened it up to what he called Mother within Whispers, and a pact was sealed.

Peter rallied men who dared follow him in his final pilgrimage, blessing their arms and armor with an eldritch sigil that none had seen before. He and the seventy eight knights that accepted the Mother’s blessing sallied forth, breaking the siege, before being lost to the eyes of all who did not join this madness.

Decades later, knights and peasants began emerging within Jerusalem - all marked with the sigil and s strange affliction of the skin. These men who offered services to the Kingdom of Jerusalem, once interrogated, have spoken of one Peter the Hermit, who wishes to extend his invitation to whoever wishes to learn about the new man whose faith is like mountains impenetrable.

Motives

Transcendence of Mortality: Driven by his experiences during the People’s Crusade and the perceived limitations of the human body, Peter seeks to transcend the frailties of flesh through eldritch transformation and create beings more suited to divine service.

Spread of His New Doctrine: Peter is motivated by a desire to propagate his newfound beliefs and transformations, aiming to convert others to his vision of a more perfect, enduring form of worship.

Protection and Expansion of His Sanctum: Peter aims to protect and expand his sanctum in the mountains of Sinai, which serve as both fortress and holy site for his followers and their transformative practices.

Interests

Forbidden Knowledge: Fascinated by arcane wisdom and divine secrets, Peter actively seeks out mystical texts and relics that could enhance his understanding and powers.

Transformation of Others: Peter is deeply interested in converting others to his cause, using both persuasion and eldritch magic to transform them into followers who share his transcended form.

Control Over Followers: He invests significant effort into maintaining control over his minions, ensuring they are completely loyal and integrated into the collective consciousness he is building.

Flaws

Fanaticism beyond Comprehension: Peter’s unwavering belief in his divine mission can blind him to the moral and ethical consequences of his actions, leading to fanaticism that disregards the well-being of others.

Isolated in a Mountain: His extreme transformation and radical views isolate him from broader society and even from other Sigil Knights who do not share his vision, limiting his ability to influence outside his direct followers.

Roleplaying As Peter

Peter the Hermit exists within the world with the confidence of a man who has seen all. He senses motion with an anatomical eye, he senses faith and disbelief like sensing light. He sees the mortal form of humanity as inferior, referring to them as a sort of nutrition, food for the brain. He interrogates those who are deemed worthy to extract from them delicious treats of knowledge. So it is possible to see him distracted by the prospect of what he might uncover if he got a hold of your thoughts. Almost like a starved man, staring at a feast.

His mind is crowded with the minds of many, as his followers are being amalgamated with him within the Sanctum, a constant distraction throughout his day. In the middle of his speech, he tends to stop, tilt his head and listen to emerging thoughts from his minions. He has a constant wonder and knowing smile plastered on his face. An unsettling expression for many. One can sense that he peers through your soul without even trying to.

Combat Tactics

Peter uses his sanctum strategically in combat scenarios, utilizing its arcane-imbued architecture to create barriers, traps, and illusions that disorient and weaken his enemies. His followers, deeply loyal and transformed, serve as his first line of defense, engaging enemies directly and sacrificing themselves if necessary.

As a transformed being, Peter wields potent spells that can manipulate minds, invoke fear, or directly harm opponents. His spells often focus on weakening the resolve of his enemies or controlling their actions, making them easier to defeat or convert.

Character Progression

Peter the Hermit was a prominent figure in the First Crusades but over time, he changed so much and dedicated himself to ascending the best possible version of himself in the dream granted by Whore of Babylon. He may be the only sigil bearer with the actual means to prepare for that world, even standing against Guy and others. He plans to one that dominates there. Peter can realize the adventurers’ power and may try to convince them of the beauty and the potential of that world, emphasizing on being able to do and dream anything they want there, becoming the ultimate gods.

Salah ad-Din Yusuf Ibn Ayyub.name: Salah ad-Din Yusuf Ibn Ayyub
Salah ad-Din Yusuf Ibn Ayyub.text:
Salah ad-Din Yusuf Ibn Ayyub

Khadim al-Haramayn aš-Šarifayn, The Avenging General, The Unchallenged Master of Cavalry Warfare, King of Kings of Syria and Egypt

Introduction

We have been the custodians of the Holy Lands for five centuries. Until they called on not an army but a horde of butchers in our hour of weakness. Bloodied and divided, my ancestors were subdued and slaughtered.

I, Saladin, am born with a destiny of vengeance. For years I have fought to unite the fragmented forces of the Crescent, forging a new army to take on the invaders. In courts, halls and libraries of my lands, I outplayed many frail men, persuaded, bribed, and threatened any who dared challenge my guiding hands, the coffers of my legions, my revenge. And on horseback I cornered the Crusader states, castle by castle, hill by hill. The blood I spill is holy, for Jerusalem cannot be left to those who do not know her deepest secrets, who do not respect her traditions and rituals, who refuse her hand in peace.

Yet I know that revenge breeds revenge, and true strength lies in building an equilibrium, with the world restored under the protection of my armies. Conquering a city, a region, even a continent is easier than ensuring your hold on it. My mission is not just to take the battlements of Jerusalem, but it is to ensure those walls will not change hands again. For this, I vow and pray not for eternal warfare, but for an enduring peace.

My tutors were wise. For centuries they gathered knowledge of thousands of wise men, whom even in their deaths had much to say. I know what awaits me in Jerusalem - spirits of the past have been forthcoming with information. A taint, a rift, the Mother of Abominations - to whom I will deal only death, something my predecessors were too weak to consider.

For the moment, I entrust the King of Jerusalem, a kindred spirit with a cursed fate, with the protection of the city. After all, the City of God must be intact, if I am to conquer it - so I dare not raise another enemy against Baldwin, tipping the scales towards his destruction. In fact, I already put my finger on his side of the scale - secretly supplying the King with information and wisdom. However, I have no illusions about the fate of the Leper King. His strength will wane, and he will become feeble, and the wolves in his den will eat each other for the Crown and the secrets of the City of God. When that happens, my army and I will be ready to retake what we have lost.

These eyes have seen many weak men, failing to unite the land, failing to realize where their true enemies lie, failing to act when the time is right, failing to seize victory when steel meets steel; and when the blood dried, failing to understand the power of mercy.

Know this, I am not those men. I am Salah ad-Din.

It is I who shall restore the Holy Lands to Dar al-Islam, to the House of Peace; and it is I who shall unearth and obliterate the horrors hidden beneath Jerusalem. It is I who shall deliver salvation to our world and faith.

Character’s Past

Saladin, born in Tikrit as Yusuf ibn Ayyub, was marked for greatness early in his life. His title “Salah ad-Din,” which translates to “Righteousness of the Faith,” mirrored the lofty expectations set for him. Raised among the lower nobility, he had the opportunity to receive an extensive education in both warfare and politics. His royal lineage allowed him to study under the guidance of the caliphate in Baghdad with full access to the renowned House of Wisdom. The Caliph who noted young Yusuf’s aptitude was a high ranking member of the Secret Order of Satraps, carrying the millenia old duty of sealing any rifts from this realm to Al-Ghaib. Under the Caliph’s tutorship, Yusuf dedicated his years to studying mundane and arcane texts, learning of warfare, history, politics as well as arcane lore of the world hidden from unsuspecting eyes.

Most importantly, during his studies Saladin discovered ancient parchments in a secluded part of the library, texts long untouched, revealing aspects of Cyrus the Great’s life. Fascinated, he delved into these parchments, drawing parallels and inspiration from his wisdom and achievements. Among these records, Saladin found references to a seal created by Cyrus beneath Jerusalem, intended to contain a significant, arcane threat. Comparing this with the seal of King Solomon which subdued a Djinn of immense power below Baghdad, he deemed Cyrus’s seal weaker and incomplete. Convinced that this frail seal could not indefinitely contain the danger below Jerusalem, Saladin set a personal mission to eliminate this lurking threat, driven by a deep sense of duty and strategic foresight. The loss of Jerusalem to the Crusaders made Saladin grow anxious about the potential arcane danger - which led him to secretly communicate with the nobility and clergy of Jerusalem which he deemed to be trustworthy. It was these communications that established the future alliance between Baldwin and him against the threat of the Sigil Knights.

In his early life beyond the hallowed halls of House of Wisdom, Saladin served as a cavalry commander, where he gained first hand experience in warfare. However, his ambitions extended beyond military prowess; he understood that to rectify the situation in Jerusalem, he needed greater authority. He built his own roads to political power for years, gathering support among the nobility and the people with his military victories. When the time was right, Saladin orchestrated a political coup d’état, seizing control of Egypt and establishing himself as its ruler, thus marking the start of the Ayyubid Dynasty. This strategic move significantly elevated his power, positioning him to pursue his broader goals.

Saladin distinguished himself as a commander of exceptional intelligence and skill. He overcame numerous threats and engaged the Crusaders on many occasions, emerging victorious in nearly all encounters, with a single exception. His sole defeat came at the hands of the young Baldwin, whose remarkable courage and unwavering faith not only earned Saladin’s great respect but also left a lasting impression on the Sultan. With dignitaries and whispers to the right ears, Saladin warned Baldwin of the danger lurking below Jerusalem - a warning that Baldwin managed to corroborate with the information from his Whitebook.

In another lifetime, the two men could have easily united their forces against the eldritch conspiracy that threatened the lives of everyone in the Holy Lands. Yet the inexorable currents of fate and the looming shadow of the end times cast them as adversaries. Both courts were filled with warmongers, and potential usurpers; both men were filled with the dread emanating from their time running out. Destiny placed both Crowns on the path to war - and they could only hope to delay the bloodshed until whatever threat lurked below Jerusalem was ended.

In anticipation of a decisive and large-scale conflict, Saladin now prepares for a campaign that might signal the end of the Kingdom of Jerusalem. His mamluks and beys, eager for triumph, exert pressure. Torn between his obligations to his kingdom and his resolve to vanquish all supernatural menaces, Saladin finds himself at a crossroads, balancing the weight of duty against the fervor of his aspirations.

Motives

Reconquest: Saladin is determined to reclaim Jerusalem from the Crusaders. However, he is well aware of the danger lurking beneath Jerusalem. At the moment of the campaign’s start, he places Jerusalem’s safety over his plans of conquest - which lead him to help Baldwin uproot the Sigil Knights and uncover the conspiracy.

An Enduring Peace: He understands that unless permanent arrangements are made, the fate of Holy Lands will be of perpetual warfare where no side will have an enduring foothold on Jerusalem. Therefore, he is trying to win over people’s hearts, while at the same time, forging a massive army.

Internal Affairs: Saladin is fighting hard to keep his court in order. With layers upon layers of plans to avoid unnecessary blood and his wishes to see Jerusalem free of the eldritch threat before he takes it - he is taking his time to unleash his war machine on the Crusader States. This has made several warmongers in his court very anxious - and the Sultan is looking to discipline or eradicate them.

Eradication of Arcane Threats: Motivated by his discoveries and the teachings from the House of Wisdom, Saladin aims to confront and eliminate the arcane dangers lurking beneath Jerusalem, which he perceives as a significant threat to the entire region.

Interests

The Waning Seal below Jerusalem: Aware of the failing seal below Jerusalem, Saladin is interested in finding out more about what horror it was crafted to contain and how to safely dispose of whatever is trying to break free from it.

Brewing Discontent in Court: Saladin is besieged, not by an army, but a cadre of nobles and warlords he united, who all want him to stop delaying the march on Crusader states. The sultan is looking for ways to stabilize his court and win Baldwin the time he needs to eradicate the Sigil Knights. This effort, however, is doomed, as the Leper King is not long for this world.

An Edge in Warfare: The Avenging General is a true military leader, who understands the intricacies of warfare much better than almost all of his contemporaries. He is looking for any edge in combat that he can muster - whether it is a new weapon, a new stratagem, or a new spell.

Flaws

A Mind for Results: Saladin is exceptionally focused on outcomes he desires, unconcerned with the measures he must take to achieve his ultimate goal. He would have been a butcher had he not understood the role of mercy when it came to solidifying his rule over land. This means that if he is not convinced that a possible solution is worth investigating in his grand calculations, he will disregard any humane reasons to pursue that solution.

Results, regardless of the Cost: In direct contrast with his previous flaw, if he deems that the cooperation of certain people is necessary for his plans moving forward, he will go out of his way to not use force against them - to the dismay of his generals and advisors.

Internal Conflict Over Arcane Matters: His awareness of the arcane threats beneath Jerusalem places him in a precarious position, torn between his role as a ruler and his duty as a guardian against supernatural dangers. This dual responsibility can lead to internal conflicts and decisions that might not align with the expectations or norms of his culture or his allies.

Roleplaying As Saladin

Saladin is a man of direct communication. His approach to dialogue is unreserved, never shying away from expressing his thoughts and desires - a luxury his immense political and military power affords him. Yet his political acumen also ensures that his directness is always tempered with his charisma and wit to persuade or even manipulate if he needs to. In every interaction, Saladin is calm, collected, and meticulously planned. However, his confidence is such that this meticulous planning never becomes apparent to others, bar from those who are also masters of rhetoric. Instead, they see a leader who speaks with natural ease and assuredness.

His education, befitting a person of royal stature, is of the highest caliber, whether the topic is politics, science, warfare, or arcane.

Combat Tactics

Saladin is a master of both strategy and combat. From his youth, he was shaped by the teachings of the finest warriors and tacticians, an education that honed his innate abilities to their zenith. Throughout his life, he has continually refined these skills, emerging not just as a warrior, but as a strategist of the highest order.

His intelligence in battle is marked by an acute awareness of his surroundings. Saladin never isolates himself; he is perpetually surrounded by his loyal men, a tactical decision that ensures he is seldom caught vulnerable or alone. This not only fortifies his physical defense, but also serves as a psychological deterrent to his enemies. He leads his entourage of warriors and mamluks deep in the battlefield, shouting orders, and exposing enemy weaknesses for his men to exploit.

A true master of tactic and strategy, Saladin would pull the enemy heavily armed fighters into quagmires, and allow precise attacks against targets that have little melee protection.

Saladin also has access to some spellcraft to bolster the abilities of his men at arms - and banish any summoned creature who does not originate in this realm of existence.

Character Progression

Saladin is determined in his cause to capture Jerusalem and put an end to evil that lies beneath it. He is desperate in that regard and is ready to do even the harshest of things for it. He is strict and definitive and is determined to raze Jerusalem to the ground if it means to stop the evil. Through adventurers’ actions, he may gain a new perspective in that regard and be convinced to let the matter into their hands, realizing their value, depending on the acts of the adventurers. If not intervened he does not fear to be written down in history as the leader who destroyed the holiest city.

The Sword of Saladin

It is said that this sword was a gift to Saladin from Nur ad-Din Zengi himself. At the time of its gifting, this was a masterfully crafted blade, but it held no magical properties. Yet the current state of the blade is much more powerful, hinting at Saladin’s skills in enchanting artifacts.

The Sword of Saladin is a yatagan with a classic curved blade; its hilt is decorated with black gems, the insides of which are adorned with purple silken script telling the legend of the Caliph Umar, who took Jerusalem in the 7th century CE. On it, the following is written:

تعلموا العلم، وتعلموا السكينة والوقار

These words are written on the blade. It is a quote by the Caliph Omar: “Acquire knowledge, and learn tranquility and dignity.”

Baldwin IV, the Leper King.name: Baldwin IV, the Leper King
Baldwin IV, the Leper King.text:
Baldwin IV, the Leper King

Advocatus Sancti Sepulchri

Introduction

I, Baldwin IV, the anointed King of Divine Jerusalem, the City of God, the stalwart defender of this sacred realm, and the architect behind an epoch of enduring peace. Enduring, it could have been, had my mortal body not betrayed its master.

Here I am, confined within the tormenting prison that is my own flesh. The pain is burdensome, yet what is truly tormenting is the time of my reign being stolen from me, being stolen from the men and women of the Holy Lands.

Within this decay, I learned a stern lesson. There are truths of the universe man can’t change. My fleeting life is one such truth. I will die soon. But before I die, I will ensure a legacy that will echo in eternity, I will carve out the dark souls and foul beasts corrupting The City of God from within.

As the melting skin upon my back languishes with each fleeting breath, my intellect remains unyielding, sharpening like a finely honed blade. While my enemies discount me as a dead man, I perceive the shadows of treachery, conspirators eager to dismantle the foundation I have meticulously laid with blade and quill. Even a dead man walking, no move of theirs I can’t predict, no conspiracy I can’t foil, no treachery I can’t respond in a force tenfold.

This fragile equilibrium of power that I have nurtured, the legacy entrusted to me, now weighs upon my shoulders like a mountainous burden, and I intend to ensure its stay. As my physical form succumbs to decay, I witness my enemies eyes’ alight with sinister anticipation - against whom no alliance is unholy. I shall stand resolute; I refuse to allow them to tarnish the legacy I have cultivated, nor will I permit the desecration of the City of God.

Character’s Past

Baldwin IV’s life story is marked by early challenges and remarkable resilience. At the age of nine, he was placed under the guidance of William of Tyre, a well-educated and worldly man of belief. It was here that the first signs of Baldwin’s affliction appeared; the young heir did not react to pain in his right arm, a condition that initially baffled his tutor. Physicians from all across the world were brought in to treat him and teach him horse riding, a vital skill for a nobleman of his status. Despite only having sensation in one hand, Baldwin became adept at controlling a horse with his knees, showing early signs of determination and adaptability.

The stigma associated with leprosy delayed a formal diagnosis, sparing Baldwin from being sent to the Order of St. Lazarus, a fate that would have isolated him due to his condition. As he grew into adolescence, he displayed a striking resemblance to his father, not only in appearance but also in his mannerisms and speech, although he struggled with a stutter. Baldwin was noted for his sharp memory and keen interest in history and stories, a testament to his intellectual curiosity.

The reality of his leprosy became undeniable during his reign, with his condition worsening over time, particularly affecting his limbs and face. Despite this, he broke with tradition by remaining among his people, a decision that surprised many, including observers from the Muslim world. His illness also meant that he could not marry or have children, making the marriage and succession of his sister Sibylla a matter of urgency.

Baldwin was apprehensive about Sibylla marrying someone like Guy de Lusignan, fearing that Guy might succeed him after his death. Prior to her marriage, Baldwin had not been particularly attentive to Sibylla, leaving her feeling neglected. Aware that her association with Guy would capture her brother’s attention, Sibylla initially got involved with him. By the time Baldwin realized the gravity of the situation, it was too late to intervene, leading him to blame himself for inadvertently driving his sister towards his adversaries.

Once in power, Baldwin displayed strategic acumen by planning a major offensive against Egypt, capitalizing on Saladin’s engagement in Aleppo. This marked his first experience in warfare, where he actively participated despite his physical limitations, demonstrating a commitment to his role as a leader and a warrior. Despite his young age of 16, Baldwin achieved victory, elevating his status as Jerusalem’s last hope. He was perceived as the one capable of halting the longstanding retreat against Egypt. Baldwin shared this belief until his illness weakened him. During this period, Baldwin and Saladin developed a respectful rivalry. Saladin recognized Baldwin as a formidable commander, leading to a mutual and immense respect. While Saladin was anticipated to be the ruler who would reclaim Jerusalem, Baldwin was seen as the one who would preserve the Christian presence in the Holy Lands.

With his ascension to kingship, Baldwin received the White Book of Jerusalem, a tome detailing the true history of the city, including its arcane aspects. Unlike most kings who typically overlook such mystical matters until they become unavoidable, Baldwin was captivated. He dedicated himself to thoroughly reading and comprehending the entire book, making it his mission to rid his city of the arcane terrors it faced.

He discovered the secrets of the seals beneath Jerusalem and the mysteries lurking behind the doors from the White Book. To locate and fortify these seals, and find a cure for his affliction, he commenced an excavation beneath the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, where the first seal is rumored to be hidden.

Motives

Unite the Bloodline: Baldwin seeks to draw Sibylla back to his side in this conflict. He is worried about her marriage and her involvement in the future of Jerusalem. His aim is to repair their relationship and ensure her allegiance to him.

A Matter of Succession: He is troubled by the decision of whom to bequeath his kingdom to. Aware of the many eyes coveting his throne, he fears that none of the contenders could maintain the fragile equilibrium he has painstakingly established.

Approaching War & Peace: He worries that without his presence to uphold peace, Saladin and his army might decimate Jerusalem and demolish the kingdom he has laboriously built. He aims to devise a plan so comprehensive and enduring that it will resonate through generations, safeguarding Jerusalem from those who seek its destruction, even long after his death.

Enemies Within: He seeks to gain a more profound understanding of the Sigil Knights - who were referred to numerous times in the White Book as a cursed force that allowed the conquest of Jerusalem.

A Dying Body: Desperate for a remedy to his ailment, he delves deeply into the pages of the White Book. He is in search of a cure, hoping that the ancient tome holds the key to healing his sickness. He thinks whatever is below the Church of the Holy Sepulchre can help him. Operating under the pretext of renovation, he orchestrates an excavation, carefully concealing his true purpose.

Interests

Deciphering the White Book: Baldwin has been nearly obsessed with the White Book ever since it was handed down to him. He is fascinated by the arcane events in Jerusalem and surprised by how much they have been overlooked.

Keeping the Peace, for Now: Baldwin is attempting to do things differently - even better - than what his predecessors had done. Rather than being overly action-oriented, he is striving to win the war politically. With his political talents, he has managed to maintain a gentle peace between Egypt and Jerusalem.

Uncovering the Secrets of Jerusalem: Baldwin is highly intrigued by the history of Jerusalem, focusing on both its political and arcane aspects. He aims to learn from the past while improving upon areas where others failed to succeed.

Flaws

Overburdened: Baldwin is weighed down by the realization that, despite possessing significant power, he is unable to halt the corruption ravaging his city - and his despair is hindering his rationale.

His Final Hours: Baldwin’s health deteriorates, casting a shadow over his ambitious plans. The fear of succumbing to his illness before fulfilling his goals haunts him, adding a layer of urgency and vulnerability to his endeavors.

Sibling Rivalry: His deep-seated remorse regarding his treatment of his sister is a personal regret that threatens to cloud his judgment at critical moments.

Obsessed with the Whitebook: His fixation on the enigmatic White Book occupies his thoughts. This obsession, while driven by a quest for knowledge and power, risks becoming a distraction, potentially diverting his focus from the immediate and pressing challenges at hand.

Roleplaying As Baldwin

Baldwin possesses a radiant presence, with his low voice and well-considered speech commanding respect. That being said, Baldwin does have a mild stutter - which he occasionally covers with simple spellcraft. Although he is constantly in pain, a condition he has endured all his life, he has learned to manage it effectively. This pain might occasionally be evident in his movements but seldom affects his speech. Known for his respectfulness and calm demeanor, his composure often instills a sense of unease in others. He is observant, often scrutinizing people under his mask, analyzing their mannerisms as if he could see into their souls. Baldwin is thoughtful, typically pausing to think before speaking, and is known for his non-erratic demeanor. His rare displays of anger contribute to his image as a cool and collected ruler.

Combat Tactics

Baldwin IV, marked by a fragile frame and marred by open wounds, is a figure seemingly unsuited for the brutal demands of combat. Yet beneath this delicate exterior lies a reservoir of formidable strength, a power he can summon in brief, intense bursts. This unexpected prowess makes him a formidable opponent, one whose frailty belies a deadly capability in battle.

However, this physical engagement comes with a perilous edge. Baldwin’s illness, ever-present and insidious, poses a risk not just to himself but to those he comes into contact with. His very touch carries the threat of contagion, adding a layer of danger to any confrontation. This aspect of his condition renders him a unique combatant, one whom many would find daunting to face.

His presence in battle, therefore, is a rarity, a moment of dire necessity when the king must call upon his hidden strength. In these fleeting instances, Baldwin IV transforms from a ruler constrained by his physical ailments to a warrior of surprising vigor and resilience. Yet, the shadow of his illness looms over these moments, a constant reminder of the cost of his involvement in physical strife and the risk it poses to those around him.

Character Progression

Baldwin, starts of the game believing it is paramount that he must find a cure to his condition as he believes he is the only person that can save Jerusalem. In order to find a cure, he cared not what ancient evil he would awaken. However, in time, Baldwin realizes the benefit of people of the realm is more important and whatever lies in wait below Jerusalem is a far greater threat than his life a safeguard. He forgoes his search for the cure and aids the adventurers in the best way he can, in defeating Whore of Babylon.

The Mask of The Leper King

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This marble mask is carved to resemble a kingly visage and adorned with fine lines and astonishing details. It is the mask that was worn by Baldwin IV, the Leper King to hide his leprosy-afflicted face. An arcanist could easily tell that The Mask contains a sliver of Baldwin’s immense arcane power and consciousness, an eldritch accident undoubtedly related to the Leper King’s disease.

The mask fixes a creature’s Charisma, Wisdom and Intelligence scores to 19, if it isn’t higher already and gives advantage to all saving throws while wearing it.

The Robe of The Leper King

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This white robe made of silk has many adornments made with ultramarine lines. The robe produces an aura of 60 feet and can affect as many creatures as the wielder wants within it. Within the aura, chosen characters add your Charisma modifier to their attack rolls and saving throws. You can’t use this if you are incapacitated or unconscious.

Leprosy

One of the deadliest diseases ever, leprosy is feared by all those who call themselves wise. No expert has ever found a way to cure it: simply manage it and accept it as it rots you from the inside out. Your skin sloughs off your body, your lungs betray you, and limbs become paralyzed. There’s usually no remedy for leprosy; it is only a question of time how much you can endure. It makes no distinction between kings and commoners. People with the disease are usually exiled from society, for fear that they will inflict others with their curse.

Infection: Touching the infected requires a Constitution saving throw.

Incubation: 2d6 weeks

Symptoms: Pox (Strong), Rash (Strong), Pain (Average), Air Hunger (Mild)

Diagnosis: Wisdom (Medicine) check for 3 symptoms. Its diagnosis DC becomes 8 after the rashes are visible.

Cure & Treatment: Indefinite. Only a healing spell of 7th level or higher cures it.

Disease DC: 13

Note: These effects are reduced on the king due to superior medicine he receives each day and his magical powers.

Symptom Name

Effects

Treatment

Air Hunger

You have trouble breathing. You can’t recover hit points except through magical means or some remedy worth 25 gp (which restores 1 HP). Each level of air hunger triggers a Constitution saving throw every week and on a failed save, decreases your Constitution score by 1 each hour.

Some remedies or potions (30 gp) make the trigger happen every 2 weeks.

Pain

Each level of pain deals 1 damage to the patient each day and grants disadvantage on ability checks. You can only recover half HP through resting.

Painkillers and other remedies worth

5 gp works.

Pox

Mild pox is only local and causes Mild Itch. Average pox can be found everywhere in the body and grants disadvantage on all Charisma checks.

Strong pox causes a Constitution saving throw at the end of each long rest. On a failed save, depending on the area, can cause blindness, deafness or paralyze.

Only magic works.

Rash

Each level of rash grants -2 bonus to Charisma checks.

Some ointments (15 gp) reduce it by 1 level but can’t get rid of it completely.

Note: If a symptom is cured while the disease is present, a Constitution saving throw is required at the end of a long rest for each symptom that is gone. On a failed save, the symptom returns.

For further information on diseases and similar situations check out the Historica Arcanum: Empires of the Silk Road - Plague & Disease Module section.
