Ismail al-Jazari.name: Ismail al-Jazari
Ismail al-Jazari.text:
Ismail al-Jazari

Father of Automatons, Inventor of Miracles and Ingenious Machines,
First Reader of the Al-Azhar University

Introduction

The universe is ever in perfect timing; the constellations flow unhindered by the concerns of the mortal whims, flowing like clockwork.

It is a shame that we are not as perfect beings as the stellar bodies watching over us are, but the mind possesses the power to transpose stardust into motion of any shape or form - this is the gift of the human form. Thus, I disagree with my captor - human form is adequate enough for any work, divine, arcane or mundane - as long as its inquisitiveness is honed to create necessary tools and companions.

But I am getting ahead of myself. I am Ismail al-Jazari, father of machinecraft, and very recently a willing captive, student, and a teacher at an eldritch abomination’s lair. If you are hearing this message, it seems my Muzahir - a voice recording motionful avionic machine - is working as intended, a feat more important than my current whereabouts as future generations will surely realize.

Disregarding my current predicament with the said eldritch abomination, it is imperative that I must continue telling you about my work which I very much would like to preserve for future society, from any awakening ancient deities, cataclysmic religious clashes, and talking tortoises.

In order to defe…

The Muzahir device you were hearing this speech from seems to have powered down for a moment. With a pulse it comes back to life.

…nd that is where you can retrieve this contraption that I aptly called the Death of Ishtar. Once you complete these simple steps, please free me from my current captivity at the Castl…

You hear the Muzahir play a loud banging sound, followed by the crunching sound of stones moving. The metal bird stops the voice recording, and turns to you, inquisitively.

Character’s Past

Growing up amidst the greatest scientific minds of Baghdad, a city known for its rich intellectual heritage, al-Jazari was the offspring of the library’s caretaker, a man more concerned with the physical upkeep of the library than the wealth of knowledge it contained. This environment, however, was a fertile ground for young al-Jazari’s curious and inquisitive mind.

While assisting his father, al-Jazari found himself irresistibly drawn to the contents of the books and parchments in the library. He would eavesdrop on the discussions of scholars, absorbing the fragments of conversations about topics beyond his understanding at the time. His yearning for knowledge led him to implore one of the library’s pupils to teach him to read, a skill that opened the doors to a world of learning and discovery.

Once literate, Al-Jazari would sneak into the library, studying by candlelight, his passion for learning undimmed by the multiple times he was caught. His dedication did not go unnoticed, and one of the teachers, moved by his fervor for education, took him under his wing. This mentorship provided al-Jazari with an intensive education until he reached the age of 16.

However, feeling that he had absorbed all that Baghdad could offer, and aware that his unique demeanor set him apart from his peers, al-Jazari embarked on a journey to learn from scholars beyond the city’s walls. It was during his studies in Damascus under a renowned mechanic that he encountered Saladin. Al-Jazari’s blunt, straightforward manner, a byproduct of his total social unawareness, caught Saladin’s attention. Saladin, recognizing al-Jazari’s unflinching dedication to truth and his disregard for pleasantries, valued his honesty, intelligence, and principles.

Brought to the palace in Cairo, al-Jazari was provided with everything he needed to thrive: a well-equipped laboratory, an extensive collection of books, and an endless supply of resources. In this environment, free from constraints and surrounded by support, al-Jazari could fully dedicate himself to his craft of creating automata and clockwork wonders.

In Saladin’s orders, Al-Jazari has also created a massive, self-sustaining prison below Cairo, to house the enemies and weapons that Saladin deems too important to perish. Once this prison complex was built, he also offered to be taken by the Lorekeepers in exchange for the final key to the seals beneath Jerusalem. Although Saladin initially protested this obscene exchange, Al-Jazari claimed that he was sure of his safety, and the fact that he had left enough records of his work, so that any information he may have had would survive his untimely demise.

Roleplaying As al-Jazari

Al-Jazari is a character driven by an unquenchable thirst for truth and an obsessive pursuit of understanding. His mind, intensely focused and analytical, is akin to a relentless machine, tirelessly dissecting and examining the world around him.

That being said, his interaction with the social world is marked by a distinct disconnect. Al-Jazari’s inability to interpret social cues renders him immune to the typical influences of persuasion or charm. Human emotions and subtleties often elude him, seeming as distant and abstract concepts. Instead, he views humans primarily through the lens of their potential as biological mechanisms, an approach that makes him less effective as a companion but exceptionally skilled as an engineer.

Motives

A Lifetime of Study: Driven by a relentless desire to understand and innovate, al-Jazari seeks to push the boundaries of what is possible with machinecraft, aiming to transcend the limitations of the human body and mind through technology.

Science Must Endure: Al-Jazari is motivated by the need to ensure his discoveries and inventions endure beyond his lifetime, making significant efforts to document and safeguard his work.

Synergies of the Arcane and the Mechanical: Intrigued by the intersections of the arcane and the mechanical, al-Jazari explores how these two fields can be integrated to create devices and mechanisms of extraordinary capability.

Interests

Father of Robotics: Al-Jazari has a profound interest in creating sophisticated automata and robotic systems that can perform various tasks, from mundane to complex, potentially even mimicking human actions.

Teaching and Mentoring: Despite his situation, al-Jazari values the opportunity to teach and pass on his knowledge to others, which aligns with his goal of ensuring his technological advancements continue to benefit future generations.

Flaws

Human Disconnect: Al-Jazari’s intense focus on his work and his difficulty in understanding social cues often isolate him from others, potentially leading to misunderstandings or missed collaborations.

Overconfidence in Technology: His belief in the supremacy of technology can sometimes be a blind spot, leading him to underestimate the complexities of problems that might require more nuanced solutions.

With No Regard to Human Safety: In his pursuit of knowledge and his commitment to his work, al-Jazari can sometimes neglect his personal safety, putting himself in situations that might compromise his well-being.

Fear of Losing His Touch: Al-Jazari is an intelligent man with the level of a genius and he regularly faces the fear of losing that due to getting old and many other reasons; curses, spell rebound and such. This became an obsession in his thoughts and is exploited in Library Pageless dungeon.

Combat Tactics

Al-Jazari’s physical limitations, marked by his frail stature, make him unsuitable for direct combat. Aware of his vulnerability, he compensates through his exceptional talent in engineering, particularly in the realm of robotics. His ingenuity finds its expression in the creation of robots designed for combat.

In every situation except the one he finds himself at the start of the Sigil of Jerusalem storyline, al-Jazari ensures that he is accompanied by at least one of these robotic guardians. These creations are not only a shield against potential threats but also a physical manifestation of his brilliance and resourcefulness. They serve as his protectors, compensating for his physical frailty with their mechanical strength and precision.

Character Progression

Al-Jazari traded his freedom to ensure that Cylinder of Cyrus is in the hands of Saladin. However, it was the ultimate act that mentioned his flaws: He completely disregarded his own safety. If the adventurers successfully save him in the Library Pageless without a significant decrease in his Intelligence, he will meditate on his fears and grow as a person. If he suffers a significant decrease, he will dedicate himself for the preservation of knowledge and developments he already achieved.

Amulet of Al-Jazari

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This clockwork amulet’s past is a mystery, though it does possess Egyptian hieroglyphics and Phonecian runes hinting at its ancient Mediterranean origin. It is said that only the most powerful minds in the world can bind it to its will.

The amulet can be fed with spell slots of any level. The total level of spell slots used to feed the amulet determines its charges. It can have 15 charges maximum. By spending any number of charges you want with an action, you can do one of the following:

  • Golem Summoning: You can summon a golem within 30 ft. of you in an unoccupied space based on the charges you spent: Jahi Golemh (1) Flesh Golemj (3), Grim Golemj (4), Clay Golemj (5), Stone Golemj (6), Iron Golemj (8). The golems that have been summoned stay for 1 minute and fight by your side. You can issue commands using your bonus action. They vanish after 1 minute, they reach 0 hit points, or until you die.
  • Breath of Life (at least 5 charges): You animate objects around you following the rules of the animate objects spell by spending 5 charges. You can make your creations more powerful depending on the extra charges you spend: +1 attack bonus to each object (2), extra hit points equal to your proficiency bonus to each object (2), +1 to Armor Class of each object (2), or +10 movement speed (2).

Guy of Lusignan.name: Guy of Lusignan
Guy of Lusignan.text:
Guy of Lusignan

The Once Nameless Monk, The Risen Knight of the Holy Matriarch’s Sigil, He Who Was Named to Be the God of the Descent and the Ascension

Introduction

My coming was prophesized. I left the mantle of a holy warrior and took on that of a God - the God of the Descent and the Ascension. The God that takes on the Holy Matriarch’s Hand and leads her upwards to the world she was locked away from. Tammuz I should be called, reincarnated from the prayers and rituals of the Old World as my namesake did a million times. Yet this truth only I and her whispers know. For everyone else, I am Guy de Lusignan, Knight Commander, Bane of the Saracen, Future King of the Kingdom of God.

A lifetime ago, I was a warrior monk, emboldened by the call to Crusade, and I journeyed eastward to redeem my soul of sin. Our pilgrimage took us to Constantinople, and upon its gates we were stopped and granted no passage into the city. Unclean and dangerous the Emperor of the Romans called us - and his dignitaries only parlayed with us to hasten our venture towards the lands of the Saracen. As our commanders negotiated for rations, armaments, and ships, I snuck into the Eternal City, for I had heard of her glory and whispers of arcane secrets. I believed that powers of magic hidden in the City can hasten our Crusade and lead us to victory.

My first descent was into the Basilica Cistern. There, I braved many accursed dangers and eldritch locks to seek the audience of an ancient being - one I will later learn to be the kin of my Mother Goddess. With each step that lowered me into the lowest pit of the Byzantine Dungeon, whispers further gripped my mind, promising the power of Gods. Kneeling before the Great Being, clad in the skin of a Dragon - my true purpose in life was revealed. My mind and memory were marked with the knowledge to revive a Deity and with the ritual to bestow inhuman power upon my brother knights. Within the walls of the Byzantine dungeon, I was stripped of my identity, and took a new one - one bearing a truly divine purpose that ascended beyond millenia - “Tammuz.” The Scaled Creature presented me with a new name, and my Ishtar I was to free.

I ascended to the city, with a new self, and for decades I became a ghost. I led many crusaders from the shadows, offering my services as a knight, a mentor, a healer, and a fool. Many identities I have consumed, almost all belonged to the knights fallen in battle and forgotten. Once the crusade reached the walls of Jerusalem, it was the power of my gifts that took the city. New Knightly Orders I raised in The Holy Mother’s name, clad in the Sigils that belonged to the Goddess chained right below our very feet. For decades I conducted rituals and dark sacrifices, using the bloodshed of the Crusades to nurture the Womb below.

Once I learned that my Goddess had a future Queen to take as a vessel - I took on yet another name, of another fallen knight. Guy de Lusignan, future King of the Kingdom of God, husband of Queen Sibylla.

Character’s Past

Guy de Lusignan’s origin point is that of a nameless warrior monk, joining the Crusade when it was first called by Pope Urban II. He traveled eastward, accompanying a small group of armed pilgrims, mostly the common folk, with little in regards of rations, armaments, and funds.

The pilgrims were stopped at the gates of Constantinople and were barred from entry to the city at the order of Alexios I, the Byzantine emperor. The nameless monk snuck into the city to uncover magical artifacts that he heard rumors of, that he believed could help the Crusade succeed. Once inside the city, he made his way to Basilica Cistern, which hosted an ancient prison complex below her waters.

The nameless monk, fighting his way down to the lowest pit of the Byzantine prison, met Shahmeran - an ancient creature of immense power that hailed from the time of Nebuchadnezzar’s ritual. Shahmeran broke into the mind of the monk, seeding him with information about the Avatar of Ishtar, a sibling to Shahmeran imprisoned below Jerusalem, and how to free her. She sealed this information by mesmerizing the monk with the whispers of an ancient deity’s tale - Tammuz, the Sumerian God who saves Goddess Ishtar from the Underworld. With arcane invocations and carefully crafted silvery words, the monk emerged from the prison with a new identity and visions of Godhood.

As the pilgrimage continued to the Holy Lands, the monk’s mind twisted and turned with the imagery of a Matron Goddess, and broken divine prophecies, with aspects of Sumerian myths mixed with Biblical passages. Anatolian plains and highlands proved extremely difficult for the Crusaders to pass, with the death of tens of thousands of warrior pilgrims from constant raids from Seljuk horse lords. While stranded Crusader groups perish, the monk takes on the identities of fallen priests and knights to make his way towards the main force, unhindered by concerns of rank and bloodline.

Once the Crusading army reaches the gates of Jerusalem - mostly broken and out of supplies - the Monk meets with the commanders of the Crusaders and offers them the power to conquer the city. While no certain records exist, the occult archivists claim that the Monk took on the identity of Raymond of Saint-Gilles in this meeting. The offer was almost irrefusable for the desperate crusaders who feared a Fatimid counterattack was imminent.

The Lords of the Crusade participated in an eldritch ritual, in which The Monk took power from the Avatar of Ishtar and bestowed it upon Crusaders who accepted becoming Sigil Knights. With the arcane power of a Goddess flowing through their veins, Sigil Knights led the offensive that broke through the Walls of Jerusalem. With zeal and eldritch orders from The Monk and The Whore clawing at their mind, the Sigil Knights massacred the population of Jerusalem - and the remaining Crusaders followed their inhuman example. This bloodshed was but one step in bringing back the Avatar of Ishtar back to Earth - as it nourished the Womb in the Jerusalem Catacombs which would give birth to a Dragon in the future.

With Jerusalem secured and Sigil Knights forming Knight Orders to recruit more of the pilgrims in the Holy Lands, The Monk once again disappeared. His proximity to his Ishtar, and the fading seal that held her away from this world, focused the monk’s mind, heightened his arcane prowess, but also faded any recollection of his past to oblivion.

Decades passed and the conspiracy to bring back The Whore of Babylon has silently progressed from within the shadows. The leprosy of King Baldwin the IV signaled the beginning of the end. The Monk returned as Guy de Lusignan, to seize the hand of Queen Sibylla in marriage - to prepare her to be a vessel for his Goddess’ return. Yet Earthly concerns plague the final chapter of the prophecy: The Sigil Knights are broken with infighting; Baldwin - despite his condition- has been defiant in letting go of his control over Jerusalem, and in the South, the Avenging General Saladin has raised a mighty host to take back the Kingdom of God. Guy de Lusignan – the God Tammuz-to-be – now has to come back from the shadows, use force to crush any resistance to his rule in the Holy Lands, and bring about the Grand Resurgence of The Whore of Babylon!

Motives

Divine Ascension: Guy de Lusignan’s only focus in life is to free Ishtar from the “Underworld” as Tammuz did in the legends. Any who stand in the way of his quest must perish.

Acquire a Mortal Vessel: His plan to resurrect the Whore of Babylon requires a vessel - the mortal body of a Queen of the City of God - and fates have bestowed the Nameless Monk a suitable candidate: Sibylla. Guy already has her hand in marriage, and is looking to further manipulate the Queen into accepting dissolving her soul to make room for that of a Goddess.

Shepherd of a Dragon: He is aware of the threat that the Armies of Saladin and Baldwin pose for his conspiracy. To make sure his Matriarch Goddess’ awakening is unhindered - he is using the Womb below Jerusalem to birth the Dragon of Ishtar. The Womb requires bloodshed to feed, and Guy is more than willing to provide that. Once awakened, the Dragon will wreak havoc on any who dare challenge the Ascension.

Unification of the Sigil Knights: Tammuz is driven to unify and strengthen the Sigil Knights, ensuring they are a formidable force loyal to the cause of The Whore of Babylon, crucial for the enforcement of her will upon her resurgence.

Interests

Arcane Knowledge and Rituals: Tammuz is deeply interested in arcane rituals, especially those related to resurrection and divine empowerment. His years of study and practice have made him a master of dark arts and forbidden knowledge.

Manipulation of Power Dynamics: He is fascinated by the manipulation of political and military power to achieve his divine objectives, using his position within the Crusades and later as Guy de Lusignan to maneuver key figures and resources.

History and Prophecy: Tammuz invests time into understanding the prophecies that foretell the return of The Whore of Babylon, aligning his actions with these ancient texts to ensure their fulfillment.

Transformation and Identity: With a history of taking on multiple identities, Tammuz is interested in the concept of transformation—not just physically but also in terms of identity and essence, reflecting his metamorphosis into a divine being.

Flaws

A Broken Psyche: The Nameless Monk’s mind is utterly lost. While his focus on any event relevant to the conspiracy is razor sharp, he - as Guy de Lusignan - is absolutely disinterested in whatever implications his actions mean for the wider world.

Tongues that Must Be Cut: He is overly protective of the secrets of Jerusalem and Mesopotamia, as they could reveal potential weaknesses in his conspiracy. Hence, he can be goaded into making mistakes if he can be convinced that a crucial knowledge will be passed to his enemies.

Imposing Leader: He is overbearing toward his allies, which has led to desertion and infighting. Most of the Sigil Knights have broken away from the first alliance, and are looking for ways to free themselves from the Sigils, or using the Sigils for their own benefit rather than continuing The Monk’s quest.

Roleplaying As Guy

Guy exists in two worlds. He needs to play the part of the future King of Jerusalem, and that of a Knight Commander of the Crusades - which means he will have to play the court politics against King Baldwin, who deeply suspects the true intentions of Guy. While he is within this setting - he is a courageous Knight, who shies away from no battle and encourages the Kingdom of Jerusalem to meet Saladin’s army in the field. He is courteous and carefully balances Baldwin’s charisma with his own - rallying support of the warlike crusaders and nobles.

For those who truly know him, however, he is the self proclaimed champion of the Avatar of Ishtar, a madman that has millenia-old knowledge engraved in his psyche. When he is free of the confines of the real world, he speaks in parables and prophecies, showcasing how far gone his true personality is.

Combat Tactics

Guy of Lusignan is a legendary swordsman – one who is empowered with his Sigil. If fighting as a warrior, he dashes to the weakest enemy and continues his murderous rampage from one weak link to another.

If encountered beyond the veil of the public eye, he will summon Sigil Knights to protect him - and resurrect any fallen Knights to jump once more into the fray.

Character Progression

Guy is a determined man and focused on his cause: to bring Whore of Babylon to the earth. In the beginning of the story, he is open to manipulation only by one character: Sibylla of Jerusalem. She is the only one who could convince Guy to act in a chosen way. Guy is usually a cautious man with at least a hundred-years of experience in the world. Due to his goals being close he is more prone to make mistakes, as he is ultimately manipulated by Sibylla to attack the adventurers when she is done with him. So in terms of character Guy becomes more open to manipulations and mistakes.

Whore of Babylon.name: Whore of Babylon
Whore of Babylon.text:
Whore of Babylon

Avatar of Ishtar, Babylon the Great, Mother of Harlots and Abominations of the Earth, Nebuchadnezzar’s Own, She Who Was Sealed by Cyrus for an Eternity

Introduction

The ancient tongue mortals use to birth magic into the world carries my voice, from a time when gods and mortals conjoined and spilled the blood of one another.

Eons past, a transformation beyond mortal ken did I undergo, emerging from a vision most grand and dark, a vision belonging to our forebear, bearing the mortal name of Sargon. His ambition soared beyond the heavens, coveting the dominion of both sky and Earth, daring to usurp the divine might of Aspects - who Man knew as Gods and Goddesses - that from their celestial thrones judged us with disdain.

It was Nebuchadnezzar, the first amongst us, who vanished into the oblivion of the Otherrealm, his essence not hastily swallowed by the endless void. Yet, my kin and I, we endured beyond his fading echo. By the arcane ritual, a shard of promised power was bestowed upon us, a gift requiring the sacrifice of our very humanity. Only fragments of what once made us human remained, clinging to the essence of our transformed selves.

Under the celestial watch of Ishtar, amidst the stars that bore witness to our rebirth, I transcended with a seeded womb. On the sanctified ground where the third circle of the ritual was drawn, my transformation was complete. Clinging to the vestiges of my humanity, I was blessed with the role of the Mother, as my visage and form took on the aspect of a Dragon, sublime and terrifying. Thus reborn, I became the embodiment of the Whore, divine guardian of fertility and motherhood, realms sacred and profane.

My temples were filled with the hymns of acolytes and worshippers, seekers of my blessing, drawn by the allure of my blessings. Silent legions rose at my command, rallying beneath the Banner of the Mother, the Whore, and the Womb. With a purpose divine and unyielding, we marched to the ends of the ancient Earth, heralding an era of conquest serene, of dreams unending, where sleep knew no awakening. Such were the promises, honeyed and intoxicating, to a world wearied by endless conflict and despair.

Yet conquest begat conquest, power begat coveting, and a crown begat betrayal. My earthly form shattered as destiny, cruel and unyielding, steered my course toward a valley ablaze. By the decree of the Eastern King, deemed an abomination against the natural order, my retinue was sundered, cut down by steel and spell. After days of relentless battle and pursuit, my powers too waned.

Born beneath the heavens, sculpted by the will of Ishtar, it was my fate to be forever entwined with that of the cursed deity. It was in Judea where the Immortals of the King ensnared me, stripping me of my divinity, condemning me to languish beneath the Seal of David.

Yet, this seal bore incompletion, a whispering harbinger of my eventual resurgence. I knew, as the ages would roll forth, my powers would stir once more from their slumber. In this foretold revival, bound by the destiny bestowed upon me, I mustered the remnants of my strength to summon forth my own Tammuz—offering the allure of shared power and a soul interwoven with The Mother and The Whore.

Hark, I am the avatar of Ishtar, a deity reborn, wielding the sacred and the profane. Hark, o mortal, and tremble before the might of a god whose power spans the chasm between giving life and condemning life to the eternal dark. I am The Mother, The Whore and The Womb, my Banner is that of the Mystery and Babylon the Great. I am The Will of Sargon, The Matriarch of the Dragons. My return is nigh and my promise is that of a wakeless sleep.

Character’s Past

The Whore of Babylon was one of Nebuchadnezzar’s family and close circle, and a high ranking courtier in the Neo-Babylonian Empire - though her exact identity is shrouded in mystery as no written records exist from the Era. Regardless of her exact identity, it is known that when the Babylonian nobility conducted the Ritual of Ascension - she was there to take on the aspect of Ishtar, and acted as a core pillar of the ritual as she was pregnant during the process.

While the ascension proved disastrous for many involved, The Whore managed to survive and rise as the avatar of Ishtar. Her new mortal form is that of a hybrid between a dragon and human - and she incorporated immense arcane potential with the power over life and dreams - a testament to her aspects of The Mother, The Whore, and The Womb.

After her ascension, she started building her cult within the Empire and tightening Babylon’s grip on the conquered territories. She also used her powers and her resurgent cult to subvert the minds of the peoples in the war torn regions - and she is directly responsible for the conquest and destruction of the Kingdom of Judea.

The conquests of the Neo-Babylonian Empire crumbled to a halt with the ascension of Cyrus and the rise of the Achaemenids to the East. Following Cyrus’s lead, the Persian armies poured westward into Mesopotamia, breaking the hold of the Babylonian hegemony in the region. Cyrus’s soldiers and spellcasters hunted down the members of the Babylonian dragon cults, severely cutting down the power of The Whore. After she was weakened enough, Cyrus personally led the assault against the Avatar of Ishtar, binding and banishing her down below the catacombs of old Jerusalem, albeit with a poor imitation of David’s Seal. In the following years, the Achamenids have continued the persecution of the Dragon cult, with Darius the Great almost wiping out all of its members.

Centuries passed for the Imprisoned Matriarch, and each day the incomplete seal of Cyrus slipped in more of her power back to the surface of the earth. More arcane circles were crafted over the existing ones by new rulers and conquerors of Jerusalem, in a vain attempt to slow down the resurgence of The Whore.

None of the attempts to stop the inevitable were enough, and by the start of the Crusades, The Whore was powerful enough to meddle with the affairs of the outside world, and grant boons to her followers. With the promises of eldritch powers she managed to turn the leading knights of the first crusade into her pawns - and she even found a Tammuz among the knights, a champion dedicated to her no matter the cost.

Now, with her conspiracy afoot, The Whore lies waiting for the day her worshippers, her sigil knights, bring her back from the edge of the Otherworld, to her throne atop this Earth.

Motives

Reclaiming Power and Dominion: The primary driving force for The Whore of Babylon is to reclaim her former glory and power, which was lost following the betrayal and the subsequent battles that led to her imprisonment. Her aim is to restore her influence over the mortal realm and reestablish her cult to its former strength.

Duties of a Goddess: As an Avatar of Ishtar, and epitome of The Mother and The Womb, she truly believes that her mission to bring an unending sleep in her bosom is a solution to mankind’s bloodshed.

Finding and Empowering Champions: Her search for a Tammuz, a warrior who embodies her will and serves as her avatar in the mortal world, is crucial. This Tammuz would lead her followers, enforce her will, and play a key role in her eventual resurgence. Yet her greatest champion is the Dragon in the womb below the Jerusalem catacombs. The bloodshed of the Crusades feeds it - and she ordered her cultists and sigil knights to continue the bloodshed to birth the Dragon.

Cultivation of Worship: The Whore aims to expand and deepen the worship she receives, as it is the source of her power and a testament to her godhood. She desires to be revered, not just as a deity of fertility and motherhood but as a formidable force wielding both creation and destruction.

Interests

Arcane from Times Beyond: Given her origins and transformation, The Whore has a profound interest in arcane practices, particularly those involving rituals of ascension, transformation, and power transference. She is deeply involved in refining these practices to prevent the failures of the past.

Manipulation of Dreams to Manipulate Reality: Harnessing her powers over dreams and reality, she enjoys weaving complex illusions and alternate realities to ensnare and manipulate her followers and enemies alike.

Whispers from the Veil: The Whore is interested in influencing key historical and political events from the shadows, subtly guiding the actions of leaders and pivotal figures to align with her objectives.

Flaws

The Lone Goddess: The Whore of Babylon - with centuries of arcane aspects of Ishtar carved into her psyche - fails to see the world beyond her designs. Any idea or aspiration away from the “Eternal slumber nestled in the lap of the Mother” she promises is non-existent for her.

Intoxicating Presence: Her presence, even when she is shrouded behind David’s Seal, is intoxicating. This intoxication causes her cultists and sigil knights to slowly lose their sanity, take unexplainable risks when in combat, and develop eldritch corruptions to further meld within their sigil.

Dependency on Worship: Her strength is directly correlated with the worship and reverence she receives. This dependency is a significant vulnerability, especially if her followers falter or her cult faces suppression.

Roleplaying As The Whore of Babylon

The Whore speaks with the grace of a Goddess, for she believes she is one. Her mortal body roamed the Earth almost two thousand years ago - so she is neither aware of the status of the World, nor does she truly care. Her wrath is invoked easily - especially if one refuses to acknowledge her status as a Goddess, or refuses to obey her commands.

Combat Tactics

The Avatar of Ishtar despises bloodshed, so she will use her arcane powers to lure her opponents into sleep. She will position herself out of the reach of melee fighters unless she is cornered, and will resort to physical violence only as a last resort. Her combat tactics are exceptionally intelligent as she will target any support characters first, try to separate the party by luring melee fighters away from casters, and dominate the mind of the most threatening warriors attacking her.

Sibylla of Jerusalem.name: Sibylla of Jerusalem
Sibylla of Jerusalem.text:
Sibylla of Jerusalem

Queen of the Kingdom of God, Mother of Miracles and the Silver Towers

Introduction

They think I am but a pawn in their petty squabbles. Gold, glory, faith, love; simple things that simple minds covet. They think I am deaf and blind to their plans, their conspiracies, their betrayals, and their murders; yet all it takes is a curious mind and a silver tongue to open them up. They think I have already fallen, they think I am a willing sacrifice, a sheep sent by god. No. I am so much more than what they thought. I for one know that anyone who has walked on Earth is no deity, but a living, breathing, bleeding creature. This creature that my beloved husband aims to replace my soul with happens to have stumbled upon power. And power, I know how to take.

Ever since I was born at the side of my brother Baldwin, I learned that true power does not scream, it whispers. For every accolade and shiny steel bestowed upon my brother, I was showered with claims to my hand in marriage. Lesser nobles at first - though that changed when the world found out about the curse upon the King of Jerusalem. Overnight, my hand in marriage meant not just a gateway for some petty duke into Jerusalem, but the Crown of the Holy Lands. A prized possession I became, and like a priceless diamond I was locked away from the world.

Many would have perished within the confines of an overbearing palace with no room to escape - but not me, and not in Jerusalem. While my brother was being taught how to wield a sword with his left hand and how to ride a horse with a decaying body - I was left alone. In the absence of all oversight I have delved into books and scrolls, explored the hidden libraries and the catacombs of the Palace, and learned more than what a hundred wise men could in a hundred lifetimes. I played with the minds of maids and priests, of knights and minor magicians and made my prison, my castle. The world may have picked my dying brother to give power, but it surely taught me the ways of acquiring it.

When the time came to pick a suitor to replace a dead husband - I decided to play a very dangerous game, to safeguard my interests and the life of the child my late husband gave me. I made the decision that will change the fate of the Holy Lands. I made Guy de Lusignan my husband - a man who thinks he can hide his secrets from my gaze. He wants something from me - my soul, in exchange, promising me godhood and peace of the land. While I am woefully aware that his intention is never to deliver upon his end of the bargain, I know that what power he offers is real, and I know how to acquire power.

So, let them play their little games. My brother Baldwin, with his throne and scepter, my husband Guy, with his knights and his schemes, our archenemy in Cairo, with his army and his spies; let them all play. Let them wear each other out, let them come to me bursting with secrets, let them spill blood and tarnish what good names they have.

Once the dust is settled and men bleed in the ruins of their own making, I will be the Matriarch of Jerusalem, ruling with wisdom, order, dignity, power of my own - unlike any who have come before me.

Character’s Past

Sibylla was very close to her brother Baldwin during their childhood. Their entire lives were around each other, they explored the world together, they played and they learned together - a life of blissful siblings. Yet the fates separated them when it was decided that Baldwin would take the throne. Baldwin, with the burden of Kingdom of God placed upon his shoulders, was taken away from his sister - something that Sibylla neither forgot nor forgave.

After the discovery of Baldwin’s leprosy, and the fact that the Kingdom of Jerusalem would continue with Sibylla became apparent, the young Queen was put on a pedestal and locked away from public life until she was to be married. Young Sibylla was pushed away from each lesson that she and Baldwin used to attend together, from meetings and spars with nobility and the knights, and feasts with dignitaries and envoys. Soon, she was married to a noble of import, William of Montferrat, and the lineage of the Kingdom of Jerusalem was secured. These events were what made Sibylla. She now coveted power, for she thought that it was stolen from her - yet deep down, she just wants power to catch back the attention of her brother Baldwin.

Upon the birth of her son, the prospective heir to the throne, and discovering he too was afflicted with the same ailment that tormented Baldwin IV, she embarked on an exhaustive quest for a cure. Determined to alter the course of her son’s fate, she committed herself to a relentless pursuit of healing, driven by a mother’s unwavering resolve and the weight of a kingdom’s future resting on her shoulders.

In an unexplainable twist of events, Sybilla’s husband fell ill with no chance of recovery. It was during this period that Guy de Lusignan entered Sibylla’s life. His charisma and influence captivated many in the court, though Sibylla and Baldwin IV have distanced themselves from this Knight commander. However, Sibylla decided to use Guy to bolster her power within the court of Jerusalem - and sought to understand just where this man’s loyalties and ambitions lie. Uncovering the truth, and hiding the tracks of her research, Sibylla decided that the true power Guy served could be usurped - to cure her son, and grant her even more power than once was stolen from her. Thus, she decided to marry this wayward Knight, and open the floodgates of a host of eldritch conspiracies within the Palace and the City of God. Yet in between all this chaos, Sibylla is right at home – observing, plotting, and manipulating her way to the throne.

Motives

Power and Autonomy: Sibylla is driven by a deep desire to reclaim the autonomy and influence she feels were unjustly stripped from her when she was relegated to a mere political pawn through arranged marriages. Her goal is to manipulate the power dynamics within Jerusalem to ensure she never finds herself powerless again.

A Vessel for Babylon: Aware of the immense power that becoming the vessel of the Whore of Babylon would bestow upon her, she recognizes the potential to become the most influential figure in all of Jerusalem. This knowledge fuels her ambitions and shapes her understanding of the power dynamics at play.

Family and Legacy: The well-being of her son, potentially afflicted by the same disease as her brother, motivates Sibylla to seek a cure at any cost. This personal quest is twofold: to save her son and to secure a stable succession for the throne of Jerusalem.

Reconciliation with Baldwin: Despite the past tensions, Sibylla aims to mend her strained relationship with her brother Baldwin, not only for familial bonds but also to solidify her political position and safeguard her family’s legacy.

Manipulate Guy de Lusignan: Sibylla intends to use Guy’s ambitions and secrets against him, harnessing his power to fortify her own position and potentially access supernatural forces that could alter her family’s cursed fate.

Cure for Her Son: Desperate to find a cure for her son, who is afflicted with leprosy, she is driven by the anguish of witnessing his suffering, a painful echo of her brother’s ordeal. The prospect of watching her son deteriorate is unbearable. In the face of this adversity, she is resolute in her quest, not just for a cure in this life, but also for a tranquil haven for her son. She clings to the hope of creating a serene dreamscape for him by merging with the Whore of Babylon, should all other remedies fail, offering her son solace in a realm crafted from her love and determination.

Interests

A Library below the Palace: Sibylla has a profound interest in the arcane secrets and the hidden histories of Jerusalem, knowledge she has accrued from the palace’s hidden libraries and catacombs. This fascination also extends to using this esoteric knowledge to gain an advantage in her political and personal battles.

Mistress of the Rumors: She is deeply interested in the art of manipulation—using her insights into human psychology and court politics to outmaneuver her opponents and turn potential threats into unwitting allies.

Medicinal and Arcane Cures: Driven by a mother’s resolve to cure her son, Sibylla is particularly focused on combining her arcane interests with medical solutions, seeking out both traditional and mystical remedies for her son’s condition. She is exceptionally vigilant in retrieving any information Baldwin also has obtained.

Flaws

Overreliance on Secrecy and Manipulation: Sibylla’s preference for operating in the shadows and manipulating others can isolate her, making genuine alliances rare and placing her at risk of betrayal by those she manipulates.

Detachment and Mistrust: Her early experiences of being used as a political tool have imbued her with a deep-seated mistrust of others, which sometimes extends even to those closest to her, including her brother Baldwin.

Obsession with Power: Her obsession with gaining and maintaining power can blind her to the more immediate needs of her kingdom and people, potentially leading her to make decisions that are beneficial for her power but detrimental to the well-being of Jerusalem.

Fear of Vulnerability: Sibylla’s fear of appearing vulnerable or weak, particularly as a female ruler in a male-dominated society, drives her to pursue power relentlessly, sometimes at the expense of personal happiness or ethical considerations.

Roleplaying As Sibylla

Sibylla is the epitome of quiet calculation and subtle manipulation. To the world, she may appear as a gentle queen pushed into the forefront by circumstances, but beneath this façade lies a mind sharpened by the knowledge of books and the secrets of the palace catacombs. Her voice rarely rises above a whisper, yet it carries the weight of someone who knows far more than she lets on. Observant and astute, Sibylla uses her perceived vulnerability as her greatest strength, allowing others to underestimate her at their own peril.

Sibylla’s demeanor changes subtly based on whom she is dealing with. With allies, she is supportive and reinforcing, always ready with counsel or a discreet word of guidance. With opponents, she is a master of the cold war, undermining their efforts with a smile.

Combat Tactics

Sibylla’s approach to combat is as refined and cerebral as her manipulations in court. She does not engage in brute force; instead, she leverages her arcane knowledge and dragonblood to outmaneuver and outlast her opponents.

She can cast spells that alter the terrain, confuse her enemies, or shield her allies. Her magic is subtle but powerful, often used to create advantages that can be exploited later in the fight. For instance, she might weaken a structure to collapse on her foes or subtly influence the minds of her enemies to sow discord and hesitation.

Acquired as the first seed of her intertwined with the Whore of Babylon, traces of dragonblood within Sibylla’s gives her an extraordinary resistance to physical and magical attacks. This endurance allows her to withstand assaults that would incapacitate others. During combat, she often baits her enemies into underestimating her, absorbing their attacks while preparing her counterstrikes. Her endurance is not just defensive; it also allows her to perform powerful magical feats that require a great deal of energy, which would drain a normal human.

Character Progression

During the adventure Sibylla is focused on her goal about Whore of Babylon and the future of her plans. She may be impressed by the adventurers throughout the adventure, especially in the dungeon called Legacy of the Basileus, she will not sway away from her path. Although, if you deem appropriate, she may hesitate in the final battle if the adventurers are impressive enough to pose new perspectives regarding power, immortality, religion and similar topics. This may pose a tiny hesitation on her during the last battle. Other than that, she may also turn very cold and aggressive after the Legacy of Basileus, if the adventurers choose “The Future” path and she is confronted by the possible future that Kingdom of Jerusalem has failed and her brother and everything she cared about falls apart. This could let her take actions on the adventurers and accelerate her plans and if the adventurers are wounded, strike them down at the end of the dungeon.

Balian of Ibelin.name: Balian of Ibelin
Balian of Ibelin.text:
Balian of Ibelin

The Last Defender of Jerusalem, The Knight in Silvers

Introduction

If the last few years have taught me anything, it is that I could well be the last of my kind. Someone who falls not victim to the many sways of this dark world, a true Knight, a relic of an age long past - or an era that never even happened.

When your eyes and ears can be corrupted by the taint of madness, when even the solitude of your mind is so easily breached by godless creatures and ghoulish mortals, when the consequences of your forebears’ sins surround you on all sides with steel and spell - what remains are the few anchors you set for yourself that can hold you against the ravaging tides. Mine are simple and sound: faith, duty, and honor.

For years, I served as a knight for Jerusalem, upright, incorruptible. For years, I have hunted down the wicked, peddling their eldritch craft and skullduggery within the walls of the City of God and Outremer. For years I have seen men like me strike bargains with horrors they thought they could cheat - and ended up being cheated out of their souls. Not me, for I know my destiny lies in a task far greater than any dealer of arcane power can grant me.

I know that if the world breaks apart - when the world breaks apart - it will be up to the last few like me to meld it back again together, or give the Old World the last stand it deserves. Thus I stand, a proud Knight of Jerusalem, bearing my faith on my chest, with no ambition but to live a decent life, fight the enemies of God, and protect the innocent. That is the least I can do.

At least while the Holy Lands atone for the sins of the last century.

Character’s Past

Balian was born in the bustling city of Jerusalem in 1143, the youngest son of the nobleman Barison of Ibelin. After his father’s passing, he became a vassal for Ramla alongside his older brother, and a knight in service of the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

His service to the city and his honorable, incorruptible stature draw Baldwin and many other prominent figures with political nuance to him. Acting as the confidant and the sword of the Leper King, Balian was tasked with keeping the King’s peace. This task, while putting him at direct odds with warmongers in the court and especially Sigil Knights, has also gained him allies with knights and orders of more sane minds. His work hasn’t gone unnoticed within the court of Saladin either.

Baldwin has also tasked Balian with investigating rumors regarding eldritch creatures and artifacts. This task of his allowed Balian, a man who wields no arcane power, to gain some understanding of the true nature of this world. While his experience in combat gifted him great aptitude in slaying barely sentient horrors and beasts, his lack of foresight into how mortals deal with arcane caused many blunders in his years of service. It is with these blunders that Balian started considering the arcane a taint on Earth, severely distrusting magic users, and considering them to be corrupted by ambition, greed, and avarice.

Under King Baldwin’s orders, Balian has also begun recruiting knights and adventurers - only the most honorable and incorruptible - a discreet force loyal directly to the Kingdom of Jerusalem. Their task is to help the Leper King uncover the mystery behind the Sigils, and protect the People of Jerusalem after Baldwin passes from this world.

Motives

Honorbound: Balian is primarily driven by a deep sense of honor and duty, focusing on protecting Jerusalem and its people from both physical and mystical threats.

For the Realm: He strives to maintain the integrity and stability of the Kingdom of Jerusalem, especially in the face of internal corruption and external threats.

War Against the Arcane: Guided by a belief that arcane forces are corrupting influences, Balian is motivated to investigate and eliminate these threats to prevent them from undermining the kingdom.

Interest

Rally the True Knights: He actively seeks out and recruits knights and warriors who share his values of honor and integrity, aiming to build a force that can be relied upon to uphold the kingdom’s ideals.

History and Tradition of Crusader States: Balian values the traditions and history of Jerusalem, seeking to preserve these against the erosion caused by ongoing conflicts and the influence of dark powers.

Flaws

Distrust of Arcanists: His strong aversion to magic and arcane practices can sometimes blind him to potential allies and beneficial knowledge, limiting his understanding of the very threats he seeks to combat.

Rigid Code of Honor: Balian’s rigid adherence to his code of honor can sometimes be a limitation, preventing him from adapting to nuanced situations or making pragmatic decisions that could benefit the greater good.

Isolated from Unconventional Allies: His suspicion of and reluctance to associate with those he deems dishonorable or corrupt can isolate him from potential allies, including those who might possess crucial information or skills that could aid his cause.

Roleplaying As Balian

Balian is an exceptionally honorable man, primarily concerned with the well-being of the People of Jerusalem, his men and his family. His loyalty to Baldwin is unwavering, and he is dedicated to supporting Baldwin’s cause.

His past experiences with arcane and spellcasters have been quite poor to say the least, so he has a deep distrust against any who uses magic. That being said, his primary concern with magic is that he thinks it is a dark pact, struck by the ambitious and the greedy. If players can convince him that the origin of their magic and arcane taint are not of their own choice, or if they somehow prove that they are using magic for the good of the people - he will be much more accepting.

He avoids association with those he considers dishonorable, and will outright refuse any action that would harm the innocent, the faithful, or the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

Combat Tactics

Balian is a Knight Commander of the highest caliber. His greatest combat feats are those of leadership and strategy. He inspires and directs his companions through his combat features, and uses his dueling skills to lock high priority targets into melee combat.

He occasionally calls for a one-on-one duel if he deems it strategically important, and honorable - and does not refuse if he is called on for such a duel.

Character Progression

A devoted knight of Jerusalem, Balian’s loyalty to the city and the king is unquestionable. However, when both are at stake Balian does not know who to turn to. His distrust towards arcane matters and indecisiveness about the future will change slowly as he watches adventurers fight the evil. He will gain his confidence and if their relationship is well (if the adventurers’ relationship with the king is well enough, it could easily affect Balian’s opinion on them and vice versa), he will outgrow the distrust of the arcane matters and will not be afraid to take responsibility and will realize his leadership skills. With the Ring of Roland, he will organize the city’s defenses and realize that if the king is no more, he is the only one left to defend the city because the kingdom is its people and he must do whatever he can do.

Ring of Roland

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This legendary ring is rumored to have been worn by the great Charlemagne and was gifted to a young man-at-arms after a feat of courage. Although a mundane ring at first, the young soldier’s faith in the emperor, and hidden potential exposed by the magic in the ring, helped him to become one of the finest warriors ever: Roland from the Song of Roland. The Ring’s exact succession is lost to history, but it is known that it reached the hands of Balian of Ibelin.

While wearing and attuned to this ring, you can choose a creature within 60 ft. of you and grant them temporary hit points as an action equal to your Charisma modifier + 2d10. The ring has 6 charges and gains charges equal to 1d6 at every dawn.

You can use the ring’s power once per dawn. If you choose the same people for ten consecutive days and succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw for each person, the change becomes permanent.

Profession Options.name: Profession Options
Profession Options.text:
Core of the System

The Profession System is designed to enhance the backgrounds and current occupations of player characters besides their “adventuring classes.” Adventuring classes define players’ core abilities and their general features from combat encounters to social situations. The Profession System is aimed at giving players opportunities to enrich their downtimes, backgrounds, non-combat activities, explorations, daily goals and occupations, and their characters out of adventure days.

Characters can take up the path of a Profession between Levels 1-3 and have access to Apprentice levels of the Professions if they meet the prerequisite for the intended profession. It is recommended that players should take at least 2 weeks of downtime to begin a Profession. It is not advised for characters to have more than one profession, as the system is not designed for multi-professions. However, at the GM’s discretion, players may take suitable perks from other professions if needed. If a character wants to start a Profession at later levels, GM may let them start with more Profession Experience (PEX) depending on the earlier experiences of the adventurer.

PEX is the main way of progressing through the Ranks and gaining new abilities. Most of the Professions explain how to gain PEX. For example, the very first Profession designed by us – The Bounty Hunter in The City of Crescent – gains PEX through collecting bounties, and it is scaled with Challenge Ratings of said bounties.

To improve ranks, a character must spend their PEX for the current rank’s abilities (usually at least two of them), and also reach the designated PEX for the next rank and expend the experience as well. It should be noted that the rank system does not work like 5th edition class leveling; you must spend your PEX in order to rank up.

There are 4 ranks for each profession: Apprentice, Journeyman, Expert, and Master. Apprentice is the starting level, and there is no PEX needed to enter that profession, but investments should be made beforehand or the backstory of the character must fit the profession.

For Journeyman rank, you must spend at least a total 100 PEX on abilities and spend 300 PEX to reach the rank.

For Expert rank, you must spend at least a total of 200 PEX on abilities and spend 1,000 PEX to reach the rank.

For Master rank, you must spend at least a total 400 PEX on abilities and spend 5,000 PEX to reach the maximum rank.

When you spend enough PEX to reach the next rank, you can also purchase other abilities as well. In addition, you can purchase earlier abilities from lower ranks.

Earlier Professions

In earlier books (The City of Crescent and Empires of the Silk Road), there are several professions: Grave Robber, Oracle, Herbalist, Tinker, Beast Tamer, Smuggler, Ecclesiastic, Merchant, Bounty Hunter, Antiquarian, Burglar, Alchemist, Archeologist, and Spy. Most of these professions can work for the Era of the Crusades as well, so it is recommended to examine those books for inspiration.

Blacksmith

Being a Blacksmith

Your desire for craft and the ability to shape things around you led you to this profession. With hardwork and dedication, you create many useful objects for society and wield the flame that was gifted to humanity since the archaic times. You are able to see a raw material and shape it in your mind and influence that image into reality.

How to Play

You will craft metallic objects, such as armors, weapons, horsenails, and similar ones, and repair such items.

Prerequisites

In order to start a Profession as a Blacksmith, a character must have at least Dexterity or Strength 13 and must have proficiency with Smith’s Tools.

5 PEX

5 PEX

You gain PEX through the activities listed beyond, but it is up to the GM to award PEX for other possible activities that are not listed.

Apprentice Blacksmith

Rank One

As an apprentice blacksmith, you have the basic comprehension of the craft and have access to basic abilities related to smithing.

Hard Work —50 PEX

“Do you even lift, brethren?”

By working your muscles and lifting heavy objects frequently, you gain proficiency in the Athletics skill.

Fast Blows—50 PEX

With experience, you gained speed in your profession. You need only half the time and cost for producing a metal object.

Useful Arcana—50 PEX

Your leaning into arcane arts finally paid off, and your learning from the ancient ways have made the difference. You learn the mending and produce flame cantrips. If you are a spellcaster, you can use your own spellcasting ability modifier for the cantrip, otherwise it is Wisdom.

Heat Adaptation—50 PEX

“The heat never bothered me anyway.”

You are no longer affected by extreme heat conditions.

Training with the Blades —50 PEX

You spend your free time with the objects you craft, and your training has paid off. You gain proficiency in two weapons of your choice that you can craft.

Defensive Training —50 PEX

You train in armor of your own making, gaining proficiency with Medium Armor and Shields.

Journeyman Blacksmith

Rank Two —300 PEX

You spent enough time to be known as a skillful blacksmith. Possibly locals know and love your metalwork. Most experienced and expert blacksmiths think highly of your work.

Specialization—100 PEX

You now specialize in your craft. You either choose to focus on weapons, their balance, sharpness and so on, or focus on armors, how to make them better and protective as well as to make them lighter, and so on.

Weaponsmith

When you choose this specialization, you further hone your ability to forge weapons. You add a Quirk to the weapon when you craft it or spend 1 hour working on it. Check out the table below: Quirks for Weapons. No matter what quirk you apply to a weapon, it is counted as a magical weapon for the purpose of overcoming resistance.

Armorer

When you choose this, your craft excels at armor making. You can add a Quality to a piece of armor you craft or if you spend 1 hour working on it. Check out the table below: Quirks for Armors. No matter what quality you apply to an armor, it reduces damage taken by equal to the wearer’s proficiency bonus.

Quirks for Weapons

Property

Special Clothing —100 PEX

“Fashion is my passion.”

Your art is so fine that you can work on regular clothing and enhance them. Working on clothes requires 1 hour and 150 gp. When you are done, the cloth makes the wearer’s Armor Class 11 + regular bonuses when they are not wearing armor.

Premial Arcana—100 PEX

You honed your skills with arcane ways and learned beneficial spells to aid you in your daily tasks. You can cast the find familiar and the unseen servant spells as rituals. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for the spells.

Weapon Training —100 PEX

You train with the weapons of your own design, and you learn to use them as well as a warrior. You gain proficiency with four weapons of your choice that you can craft.

Heavy Armor Training—100 PEX

You spend your time with the heavy armor you craft, and your training has paid off. You gain proficiency in Heavy Armor.

Adept—100 PEX

You double your proficiency bonus with any check related to your Smith’s Tools.

Qualities for Armor

Property

Don and doff time is halved for the armor.

Stealthy

If it normally gives disadvantage on Stealth checks, this armor does not.

Agile

While wearing this armor, standing up and mounting/demounting only costs 5 feet movement for each.

Comfortable

While taking a long rest with this armor, you suffer no penalties, such as restoring your Hit Die as normally sleeping without armor.

Nimble

Armor that limit Dexterity modifier to +2 now limit it to +3.

Quick Shield

This shield can be donned and doffed with a bonus action.

Feather-like

Heavy property for the weapons you make can be carried by races that have a Small body type.

Expert Blacksmith

Rank Three —1000 PEX

You are a renowned blacksmith, having visitors and customers from all over the world. There are adventurers who want to have your gear, and commanders visit you to hire you for future conflicts and arming of their armies. Many young aspiring apprentices arrive at your shop with a desire to be trained by you.

Specialization Improvement—200 PEX

You have been a blacksmith so long, your craft is like breathing for you. Weaponsmiths get Expert Weapons and Armorers get Expert Armor perks.

Expert Armors

You choose a damage type: acid, cold, fire, poison, lightning, bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing. The armor you make grants resistance to one of the damage types. If you spend an extra of 200 gp and use enchanted metals, you can make it +1 Armor.

Expert Weapons

You can add one of the Quirks below to a weapon you craft:

Reach

The melee weapons you craft that are spears, staffs, or have metallic blades now have the Reach feature.

Versatile

The melee weapons you craft that have the Versatile ability now normally deal that damage. For example, when used with one hand, your Longswords deal d10 slashing damage.

Finesse

If the weapon has the Finesse property, its damage die becomes one greater. For example, a dagger deals 1d6 damage.

Ranged

If the weapon has the Ranged or Thrown property, its normal range is doubled.

Magical Weapons—200 PEX

By spending an extra 250 gp for the weapons you make (for each property), you can embed them with magical properties. A weapon can have Magical Properties up to a number equal to half your Dexterity modifier (rounded up).

The weapon deals extra 1d4 elemental damage (chosen when the weapon is built): fire, cold, acid, poison, lightning, or thunder.

Protective Spell

With the weapon, the user can cast one of the spells once a day, without expending a spell slot: false life, shield, mage armor.

Offensive Spell

With the weapon, the user can cast one of the spells once a day, without expending a spell slot: faerie fire, burning hands, thunderwave.

Utility Spell

Loud

The weapon’s blast can be heard from 300 ft. away.

Arcane Flames—200 PEX

“Just add a little bit of spice.”

Your work with the forge and fire over the years and research of the arcane matters have enabled you to use magic to improve your craft. You can cast the heat metal spell three times a day without expending a spell slot. If you are a spellcaster, you can cast it normally with your spell slots. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for it.

Raised in Fire—200 PEX

You are so used to the flames touching you and hurting yourself, your body is adapted to it. You gain resistance to fire damage.

Master Blacksmith

Rank Four —5000 PEX

You are one of the greatest blacksmiths who ever lived. You probably forged a legendary sword that slayed a dragon, felled a demigod, or destroyed whole armies. An adventurer who is brave enough to face a cold-hearted lich’s gaze is probably wearing armor forged by you. You armed kings, leaders, generals and conquerors.

Stories of the Past —Free

“Oh, have I told you about the time when…”

You have a lot of experiences and stories, and have probably taken part in some of the legends and myths. You have the ability to inspire greatness in others. You can grant inspiration to anyone who listens to your stories a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus daily. This inspiration point must be used in 1 hour, or it will be lost. Anyone who already has an inspiration point won’t be affected by this.

Word of a Blacksmith —Free

You invoke the name of a magical metallic object that is known to you and touch a similar object. For the next minute, the mundane object gains the properties of the magical object you invoked. For example, you touch a mundane metallic shield and it becomes Animated Shield*for the duration. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Downtime Activities for the Blacksmith

Research New Materials

Depending on the nature of your discovery, the GM may apply additional rewards or penalties. For example, if you discover a new type of weapon that is uncommon for your land (such as a blacksmith from Damascus learning to make a Wakizashi - a short katana), you can craft and sell that weapon for more coins than usual.

Market Sale

You sell your basic materials in a market. You roll a Charisma (Persuasion) check against DC 10. On a success, you gain 2d6 gp (3d6 if you roll more than 15) and 10 PEX. Depending on your success, the GM may introduce new customers.

Training

You either train an apprentice or find someone to train you. You roll for a DC 10 Intelligence check. On a success, you gain 15 PEX.

Interrogator.name: Interrogator
Interrogator.text:
Interrogator

Being an Interrogator

Every law enforcement organization needs a professional who is an expert at getting people to talk and extracting information on tough targets. You always had a skill in touching people’s nerves, both figuratively and literally. You know the mind games and the like, and you know the human body well enough to inflict the right amount of pain.

How to Play?

You question people, extract knowledge, learn secrets, find information, conduct research, observe people, and do many similar activities.

Prerequisites

In order to become an Interrogator, a character must have at least 13 in Charisma, Strength or Dexterity and must have the Insight skill proficiency.

Climbing the Ranks

You gain PEX through the activities listed below, but it is up to the GM to award PEX for other possible activities that are not listed.

ActIVITY

Reward

Extracting Knowledge in an interrogation (CR 1 and below)

5 PEX

Extracting Knowledge in an interrogation (CR 2-4)

15 PEX

Extracting Knowledge in an interrogation (CR 5-7)

30 PEX

Extracting Knowledge in an interrogation (CR 8+)

75 PEX (GM may award more for creatures that have drastically more CR)

Learning an important secret

10 PEX

Breaking an organization leader in an interrogation

50 PEX

Apprentice Interrogator

Rank One

You joined an important organization and started to conduct interrogations to extract knowledge. It may be a law enforcement organization, an illegal thieves’ guild, a military order or a similar one. You may even be working as a freelancer, a guy that is called when someone needs to be “talked to.” You are at the start of your career, but you are discovering the ways to improve your skills.

Reading People —50 PEX

“I see right through you.”

You are good at reading expressions and catching lies, as someone in your shoes must. You double your proficiency bonus in all Insight checks.

Right Skills for the Job —50 PEX

You trained yourself in many ways to better do your job. You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice: Persuasion, Deception, Intimidation, Perception or Investigation.

Right Amount of Pain —50 PEX

When you interrogate people with physical methods, such as inflicting pain to make them talk, you deal only 1 point of damage (damage type is based on the tools you used)

The Necessary Tools —50 PEX

“Something smells fishy in here.”

You gain proficiency in the Forgery Kit and Poisoner’s Kit. In your profession, it is important to catch lies and forgeries in documents and crime scenes.

Armed and Dangerous —50 PEX

You never know what your enemies carry with them, you must be ready. You gain proficiency in two weapons of your choice. In addition, you gain proficiency in Light Armor as well.

Journeyman Interrogator

Rank Two —300 PEX

Specialization —100 PEX

You specialize in a way of your choice: You either choose to train yourself to make people talk with your charms and wits (Silver Tongue) or through physical methods (Surgeon).

Silver Tongue

“Few can resist my charms.”

You force a creature to make a Charisma or Wisdom saving throw (your choice) with your action that is restrained or confined in a room with you. On a failed save, it must answer a question asked by you. The DC for this ability is determined when you choose this specialization. It equals to 10 + your Charisma (Persuasion) bonus or your Charisma (Intimidation) bonus. If a creature succeeds in this saving throw, you can’t use this ability on it again until a month has passed.

Surgeon

As an action, you force a creature that is restrained or confined in a room with you to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it must answer a question asked by you. The DC equals to 8 + proficiency bonus + Dexterity modifier. If a creature succeeds on this saving throw, you can’t use this ability on it again until a month has passed.

Arcane Methods —100 PEX

You can spend some time and coins to establish a connection with a potion dealer or make your own potions for interrogations. For potions to work, the creature must be restrained or confined in a room with you.

Truth Serum—200 gd

The drinker must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or be compelled to tell the truth for the next minute. A dose large enough to affect a humanoid is worth 200 gd.

Friendship Serum—150 gd

The drinker must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or be charmed by the nearest person for 1 minute. A dose large enough to affect a humanoid is worth 150 gd.

Dread Serum —100 gd

The drinker must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or be frightened of the nearest person for 1 minute. A dose large enough to affect a humanoid is worth 100 gd.

Agony Serum—200 gd

The drinker must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or lose 1d4 hit points at the start of each of its turns and experience incredible pain for 1 minute. A dose large enough to affect a humanoid is worth 200 gd. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

Conducting Investigation—100 PEX

You double your proficiency bonus on Perception and Investigation skills.

Foreign Tongues—100 PEX

Some enemies may speak other languages for many different reasons, so you must know them as well. You learn two languages of your choice.

Underground Smarts—100 PEX

“I know these dark tunnels like the back of my hand.”

You’ve been to the underground more than you care to admit. You learn Thieves’ Cant.

Chasing the Criminals—100 PEX

“I really need to work on my stamina!”

Some interrogations need the culprits to be caught, and you have found yourself in rooftops or hot chases more than you wanted. Your walking speed increases by 10 ft.

Guarded by Metal—100 PEX

You can be the target of many attacks, as you are a valuable asset. In order to protect yourself better, you gain proficiency in Medium Armor and shields.

Expert Interrogator

Rank Three —1000 PEX

Specialization Improvement —300 PEX

When a creature makes a saving throw against your abilities chosen with this Specialization, they have disadvantage on the saving throw.

Smelling Lies —300 PEX

You understand when you hear a lie.

Expert Liar—300 PEX

“Sometimes even I believe in my own lies.”

You have heard so many lies that you can make up a new one easily. When another creature rolls to see if you’re lying, they have disadvantage on the check.

Master Interrogator

Rank Four —5000 PEX

There is no secret safe from you. There is no person living who won’t talk while your gaze is upon them. You are already a living legend at what you do. Underground guilds are filled with youth who aspire to be you. Law enforcement organizations teach your ways to their new apprentices, and you are only wanted when the balance of the world may be at stake.

Stories of the Past —Free

You have a lot of experiences and stories, and have probably taken part in some of the legends and myths. You have the ability to inspire greatness in others. You can grant inspiration to anyone who listens to your stories a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus daily. This inspiration point must be used in 1 hour or it will be lost. Anyone who already has an inspiration point won't be affected by this.

The Smile —Free

“Have you met my pearly whites?”

You are the epitome of an interrogator. Kings, presidents, and khagans want you in their courts. You can use your action and smile at a humanoid that can see you within 60 ft. of you. It makes a Wisdom saving throw (DC equals to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier). On a failed save, it is marked by you. For the next minute, when you ask a question, even if it lies, you can read the truth in its mind. The creature has no idea.

Downtime Activities for the Interrogator

Collecting Clues

You spend your week observing a suspect or a potential enemy. You must succeed on a DC 10 Perception or Intelligence check to gather clues, listening to conversations and with similar activities. On a success, you learn two crucial pieces of information and gain 10 PEX.

Studying a Suspect

Instead of directly interrogating a person, you may spend your time with them and observe their nature, state of mind and other aspects. You must succeed on a DC 12 Insight check. On a success, you have advantage on the rolls you make to interrogate the person and gain 10 PEX.

Underground Contact

You can spend one workweek and 25 gp to learn the places you can buy or fence some unique and possibly illegal items or meet with “interesting” people. Roll a Wisdom (Perception) or Wisdom (Insight) check against DC 10. On a success, you meet one of the black-market tradesmen. Work with your GM to determine their proficiency, their items, attitude, and other important details. Once you establish a contact, you can revisit this downtime activity with a DC 10 Persuasion check to have an arrangement with the determined contact, for example for information or a specific item. The details are determined by the GM.

Herbalist.name: Herbalist
Herbalist.text:
Herbalist

Being an Herbalist

To the uneducated, nature is a brutish, hostile place, but to those who know it, there are uses for everything to cure, to enhance, and to harm. Certain people have spent their lives identifying and analyzing the aspects of nature, the diseases it wrought and cures that help. Herbalists can be found in almost every civilization, especially in the countryside. They are needed by the common folk when their children have a fever, when they are coughing blood, or when they need something to soothe the pain.

How to Play?

You gain PEX through identifying plants, herbs, mushrooms, and the like; preparing medicine; diagnosing diseases; and curing people.

Prerequisites

In order to become a Herbalist, a character must have at least 13 to Wisdom, and must have Medicine skill proficiency.

Climbing the Ranks

ActIVITY

Reward

Identify a plant/herb/mushroom

5 PEX

Diagnose a disease

10 PEX

Curing symptoms

5 PEX

Curing a disease

10 PEX

Preparing a medicine*

15 PEX

Discovering a new disease**

25 PEX

*Note: The medicine such as a burn ointment or a pain killer must be useful in order to gain PEX. Such medicines will be introduced below.

**Note:As most campaigns in 5e resemble the Middle Ages, there were many diseases and conditions people were not aware of. Encountering such a disease or illness through adventuring is not enough. A herbalist must be able to understand and analyze the disease in order to gain PEX.

***Note: Possible elixirs and potions will be introduced below.

Apprentice Herbalist (Rank 1)

Rank One

You have basic knowledge of the beauty and the horror of nature.

Understanding Nature —50 PEX

You begin to tell the difference between seeds, plants, mushrooms, and their properties.

You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice from the list: Nature, Survival, Medicine, or Perception. In addition, you can forgo one of the skills and gain proficiency in the herbalism kit.

Journal —50 PEX

You keep a journal for your plants, seeds and herbs. If you encounter a new plant that is not recorded in your book, you can make a Nature check against a DC determined by the GM according to the rarity of the plant. On a success you can learn its properties without needing a kit or a long identifying process.

Additionally, if you spend 1 hour studying a plant, you can learn its properties, such as poisoning or healing abilities. This 1 hour can be a part of a short or a long rest.

Diagnose —50 PEX

Ninety percent of a cure is early and correct diagnosis. When you encounter a sick person, you immediately understand what external symptoms (not the internal ones) the patient has. You can examine the patient for 10 minutes and make a Medicine check against a DC determined by the GM. With normal diseases, you have advantage on this check.

Potion Making —50 PEX

Hubble bubble.

You learn the recipes for some basic potions for diseases and other problems that can be made with herbs and plants. You have advantage on the ability check in order to find the necessary ingredients.

After getting two of these abilities you can advance to the next rank.

You can sell these potions as mentioned in the table below. The buyers or you may negotiate on the price, but other herbalists or the folk who have knowledge on this subject will know the normal price.

You specialize in your profession either as a pharmacist or a sawbones.

Pharmacist

You excel at potion and medicine making. You double your proficiency using an Herbalism kit.

Sawbones

You excel at attending wounds and injuries. You double your proficiency bonus in ability checks which let you treat these conditions, such as a Medicine check.

Little Friends of Nature —100 PEX

The cures nature provides are not limited to the things that grow in the ground. You gain basic knowledge of insects and similar creatures. You can identify them and their poisons and other bodily fluids and can extract them. If the area is appropriate you can look for insects and find them if you succeed on a DC 15 Survival check and spend 5 gd for appropriate items, such as ointments, traps, odors, or similar means.
